description: I had a sudden craving for bahn mi sandwiches so I checked around work and I found this place on Uber Eats! I got their pork combo sandwich and it was so good that I killed it before I could even take a picture lol. I also got their spring rolls; they were also very good but I didn't like the mango in it. I can't believe I found a bahn mi spot near work! Will definitely be ordering from this place again!
author: Denise Rose B.

description:
There's nothing really special about this store, everything is as average as it gets. The meat (I ordered a Grilled Pork Sandwich) was a bit dry and their bread a bit tough. The shredded carrots and white radish weren't as pickled as I'd like them to be. They charge extra for pate, which was an interesting decision. The place is OK if you're craving, but if you have the time, find a better restaurant for your Bahn Mi. 

I would give them three stars instead of two, but when I went in I discovered their card system was down. I couldn't order sweet potato fries since I couldn't pay with card. Food came out slower, but I predict it's their volume of orders during the lunch rush.
author: Christine Z.

description:
I knew this place sounded familiar. I went to the same restaurant in Downtown San Francisco a few years ago. It was delicious, and I even ordered the same thing... a Hawker Food Bowl.

Mine this time had brown rice, tofu, cucumbers, shredded carrots, kimchi, jalapenos, and an egg. I had to douse it with Sriracha. Of course it wasn't anywhere near the freshness of the Downtown location, but it was okay.

Food came out super quickly, and service was friendly. Not bad for airport food. Solid 3 stars. But it does make me want to check out the quality of food at the other locations!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
On top of the complete lack of customer service provided by the clerk who could not have been more disinterested in helping me at the counter, the food I got from my takeout order is a pretty far off version of what was described on the menu. 

According to the GrubHub description (order placed through Yelp), the Saigon Rice Bowl includes: Brown or garlic rice, cubed mango, pickled carrots and daikon, jalapenos, bean sprouts, lime wedge and house peanut sauce, topped with roasted peanuts, cilantro and your choice of protein. 

I'm currently eating white rice (no chance there's garlic in here). There are shredded carrots, but they are definitely not pickled. There's no mango or daikon. The lime wedges and cucumbers are dried out and look/taste like they were cut several days ago.

Not worth the $11 for a rice bowl; go elsewhere. How is there food THIS bad on Fillmore??
author: Chanda G.

description: I should have known to order a bahn mi sandwich rather than a bowl at a place like Bun Mee! Based on all the pictures of sandwiches, those look delicious. Instead, I ordered the Bun Noodle Bowl which was very average. Despite saying it included an egg roll online, much to my sadness it was noticeably absent from my order.
author: Kirsten H.

description: Tried this place out since it was down the street from where I worked. They have a nice selection of non traditional banh mi's & rice bowls to choose from. Other than that, it's pretty non-authentic to Vietnamese food. The spring rolls are pre made so I wasn't able to order them since they had meat in it. They also give you a frequent banh mi rewards card (10 stamps = 1 free sandwich). However, you get a stamp per visit and not banh mi. At the cost, it'd be nice if it were per sandwich and not per visit.
author: Ruby V.

description:
I got the Bun Noodle Bowl with Pork Belly and it was not good. The flavors were way too salty, I didn't like the flavor of the fish sauce and it didn't taste fresh like vermicelli bowls usually do. 

Not recommended and will not be back.
author: Christina L.

description: Overpriced Vietnamese food, but they always get their food out quickly, so I can't complain if I'm looking for a quick lunch. I'd recommend getting the Hawker Bowl, sweet potato fries, or the Five Spice Chicken salad. Other than that, save your money to buy banh mi at a Vietnamese sandwich spot in the Tenderloin.
author: Monica M.

description: The catfish sandwich is delicious with the garlic fries. Their spring roll is pretty good too. Definitely will come back for the veitnamese iced coffee for a pick me up. Seating is limited but people move through it fast. Friendly and fast service!
author: Jacqui C.

description:
2 Words. Vietnamese Fusion.
If you are looking for authentic viet sandwiches or food, this spot  is not the place for you. We came knowing it was viet fusion and it was pretty good, but nothing spectacular to keep me coming back. 

FOOD: 
They offer, rice bowl, salad bowls, sandwiches and small dishes and drinks. The only thing on the menu that scream Vietnamese are the sandwiches, but other than a few viet oriented ingredients I would not know is was a viet food shop. We ordered: 
+ 5 specie chicken sandwich $8: sandwich was pretty small, had little chicken. Mostly packed with lots of veggies, specifically carrots. 
+ Caramel Citrus Chicken Rice Bowl $11: I appreciate that they have an option for brown rice :) The bowl also came with 3 slices of orange, grapefruit, some mango, avocado, carrots and your choice to meat. I thought the fruits would be a good touch to the bowl, but the strong acidity of the citrus and the saltiness of the sauce was not a good mix. Chicken tasted okay, but looked like pork. 

SERVICE: 
This is a order, grab the number and sit kind of restaurant. Servers are friendly and the food comes out relatively fast. 

AMBIANCE:     
Looks pretty small on the outside, but there are about 5 tables insides and plenty of bar seats in the back. There are also some outside seating as well. 

Verdict: Overall, decent food and I like how it's on the healthier side with simple ingredients. But I wouldn't probably come out here just for their food.
author: Samantha F.

description:
Had Bun Mee delivered via Caviar.

I ordered the combo sandwich and their fries. Both were extremely disappointing.

I've ordered delivery before via multiple delivery apps, but have never had such a poor experience with the quality of food.

The sandwich was so dry and the bread was hard. The flavor of the pork wasn't very flavorful or tasty. 

The fries were sooo cold and stale. It's as if they were sitting around all day and they scooped the remainder for takeout orders. The only plus is that their fries had a good flavor and I liked the addition of jalapeños.

Overall, I would highly suggest going elsewhere for banh mi.
author: Shirley H.

description: The sandwich was good I really enjoyed it but I had an upset stomach a half hour later which lasted the whole night.
author: Adam L.

description:
After hearing mixed things about Bun Mee I finally got around to trying one of their bánh mi sandwiches and unfortunately I'm left with mixed feelings too. The space is nice and service was quick and friendly with typical fast casual flair. 

Bánh mi's are one of my favorites, and while this sando had all the right components - wonderfully sweet and acidic picked veggies, hot Jalapeño, cooling cucumber, and fantastic bread - the flavor of the meat was pretty lacking. While I appreciated that it was leaner and of a higher quality than you'll find on most $5 mi's, the seasoning was pretty flat and left a lot to be desired. For the $8 price point I expected quality but I also expected a decent balance of sweet and salty that was entirely absent. 

The bread tho, was stellar, with a distinct sourdough tang and big hearty crunchy outside that was good enough that I would come back and try another protein. It's uncommon to see sourdough on this type of sandwich and it was a welcome and successful change.
author: Sean S.

description:
Simple, fresh, and your typical healthy food options. Bun Mee a restaurant that serves a Vietnamese fusion cuisine. The restaurant is similar to Panera Bread in that you order and pay first and then you can sit anywhere. Everything is the "do it yourself" afterwards. 

FOOD: 
They have Banh mi, noodle/rice bowls, sides, and various drinks.  The restaurant is small and with limited seating. I went with a group and we got the pork belly, lemon grass, combo, and 5 spice chicken banh mi. Then we also got a noodle bowl. The sandwiches are just okay but nothing that impressive. It was fresh but its very different from banh mi from other Vietnamese food places. Food comes pretty quickly (~5-10 mins from the time you order). 

SERVICE: 
They are a very small restaurant so many times one person basically works the cash register, wipes the tables, makes the drinks, and etc. So it may seem like they are inattentive to you the customer. 

OVERALL: 
A pretty good addition to the neighborhood. Food is prepared quickly and it is fresh. Would definitely recommend if you want a quick lunch. Recommended for smaller groups if you want to eat at the place since there is limited seating available.
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
Simple, fresh, healthy food in a comfortable setting on Fillmore is the home to this Bun Mee Vietnamese restaurant. 

First time dinning here and had the chicken kale mango salad with the strawberry lychee drink. The drink was very refreshing and not too sweet. My friends tried the Vietnamese iced coffee and must admit it was the best I have ever tried. A must try if you are a coffee lover.

The salad was generous portion with a great mix of the veggies and chicken. My friends tried the sandwich and the rice bowl, they both loved it.

The service was great and super fast, staff is super friendly and helpful. It was a nice and relaxing dining experience. 

Will be back to try other entrees.
author: Mehrnaz H.

description: This place seemed like an interesting addition to the collection of Fillmore restaurants. I ordered the fish sandwich and was disappointed. The whole sandwich didn't have much flavor except for the spiciness from the jalapeno. The pickled veggies in the sandwich were the biggest disappointment: they were not pickled long enough. And the meat was very sparse. I wanted to like this place, but I can get a much better sandwich from Cafe Bunn Mi on Clement.
author: Alli C.

description:
Banh mi that's been dressed up with good ingredients, served in a venue that's sanitized for gringo tastes, right down to the name.

The Bun Mee combo was tasty and flavorful enough, featuring grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, paté de campagne, mortadella, garlic mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro. It was a bit spendy at $8 for what felt like a somewhat petite sandwich, but I can understand that ingredients that are higher-quality than, say, your typical mom-and-pop shop do come with higher prices.

While the venue is a bit compact, the sandwiches can easily be enjoyed elsewhere. Overall, it's a decent experience that adds diversity to this otherwise vanilla neighborhood.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Love this location although smaller than the  Market St location.  Lines can be out the door at lunch time on weekends. Total seating for about 20 people

My go to sandwiches are the Lemongrass Pork, the 5-Spice Chicken and the Catfish.  The sweet potato fries are awesome as well.  If you aren't sweating after eating lunch, you didnt spice it up enough.

There are vegetarian options with egg rolls as well as eggplant or tofu sandwich options.

To go is big here and my sandwich took just 8 minutes.  Parking is fairly easy and if you live along the 1 California bus line this place makes for an easy take home dinner or lunch.

Current Health Code rating is an 86 for those who care.

They also serve limited beer and wine as well .
author: Erik H.

description: I work nearby and have ordered here often.  I have had the Grilled Lemongrass Pork and the Grilled Five Spice Chicken Bun Mee sandwiches along with the Salt n Pepper Garlic Fries and I have never been disappointed. My order is always ready on time and tastes like it was just finished.  I come here because its delicious and convenient, but I would also say its worth going out of your way for.  Plus the neighborhood is pretty dope.
author: Steve K.

description: Had the combo sandwich last night.  It was just ok.  Sandwich on the bland side and had more veggies than meat.  I like the sandwiches on clement way better.  It's like her a burger from Mickey Ds.
author: Pam P.

description: Food is good but the place is FILTHY. Tables are wood and sticky...the owner needs to clean the place up.....we won't be returning! There are too many other places with similar food...!
author: Cherlyn S.

description: I got upset stomach after eating here last night. The portion is good but on the pricier side. Id check out other vietnamese places.
author: Carol K.

description:
Prelim review:

Significantly more expensive than Lee's Sandwiches, without significantly better ingredients. Great location in Pacific Heights and great servers but in my opinion it's too overpriced for me to justify coming back.
author: Andrew H.

description: The most fresh and tasty quick bun mee sandwiches around. This is my go to place and I can almost never order anything besides the crispy tofu sandwich. The cauliflower relish is what makes this sandwich so tasty! A good quick pick up - eat in joint when you are in a hurry!
author: Ruchi M.

description:
Parking: can be tough during commute hours or prime times. Came to this one around 11:30am and found easy non-metered parking a block away. 

Pricing: a little more expensive than your usual bahn mi BUT it's pretty filling so I assumed I was paying for the quantity. Quality I'll get to in a bit. 

Ambience:
Pretty decent seating area, but I'm sure it gets packed during prime times so if you're in a rush just order to go. 

Food: 
SWEET PO' fries. Not oily. Not dry. Not soggy. JUST CRISPY YET SOFT GOODNESS. With a dash of salt. 

I ordered the crispy tofu bun-mee. It was delicious with a spicy kick. I would recommend chewing some gum after or brushing your teeth as the fried shallots does a number on your breath - MINTS PEOPLE. That's the only downfall of this entree. 

My friend ordered the Hawker Bowl. It looked like 2 meals (depending on your stomach size) and was pretty flavorful and filling. 

If you're really in a hurry, there's other places nearby but the food here was made pretty quickly so plan ahead if you want some good buns.
author: Cheri C.

description: Not a fan.  The chicken five spice chicken was overly sweet and had an odd taste.  The egg rolls were very greasy and fishy tasting.  Won't return.  Dragon Eats in The Haight rocks the banh mi - far superior, fresher tasting.
author: Chris B.

description:
I ordered a lemongrass pork sandwich with sweet potato fries and strawberry lychee drink:

1. Price: paid about $23. The sandwich was regular sized and the portions for the yam fries were large.

2. Sandwich: I'm guessing this sandwich is a Banh Mi, as implied by the name of the restaurant. It was okay at best, but for sure not authentic. The bread was an ordinary bun you can buy at Safeway, not the baguettes used for banh mi sandwiches. The bread this restaurant used was stale and dry. It was overwhelming and took away from the meat's flavor. As for the meat, it was greasy and not warm. Terribly disappointed for what some reviews on here say. 

3. Service: Friendly. People served with a smile. Was the only reason I didn't give this place 1 star.
author: Sean S.

description: Good, well priced Vietnamese food! I've gotten the sandwiches and vermicelli noodle bowls here. Definitely good, but there's a lot of more interesting food nearby! Stop here if you need something quick, otherwise check out some other places.
author: Caley Z.

description:
Came in here to try out their banh mi, and went with the lemongrass pork option. I was a bit unimpressed, the pork itself was alright, but the sandwich seemed to be a bit lacking - the supposed garlic mayo tasted of just regular mayo. Also my bun seemed a bit more like a ciabatta than a crisp baguette. I will say some of their other menu items seem interesting, but it worries me when a  banh mi place can't deliver on some of the main aspects of the traditional grilled pork type sandwich.

Also, at $8 a sandwich, I can't say that they have very great value, when a cluster of great quality and value sandwiches are fairly close by in the tenderloin area (although, maybe you are paying to eat in a nice sit-down environment and not in the tenderloin).
author: Neal B.

description: I love their 5 spice chicken sandwich and their bun bowl.... good service and quick...
author: Lynn A.

description: Wish their food was better as they are so convenient to my house. It's been about a year, and since my preferred Bunn Mi on Clement has gone downhill I gave Bun Mee another try. The pork belly was too salty to eat, even with the hard boiled egg addition which should have cut it.
author: Robin W.

description:
I was craving a banh mi, but was tired and lazy. Ended up ordering delivery through DoorDash last Friday, June 17th for dinner. I placed my order at 6:18pm and it arrived at 7:03pm. I live in Outer Richmond.

*Pork and Shrimp Roll (2): Sliced kurobuta pork, prawns, vermicelli noodles, bean sprouts, shredded carrots, pineapple, and fresh herbs served with a side of peanut sauce ($6)
*Five Spice Chicken: Grilled 5 spice chicken with caramel mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro ($6.95), add Pate (+$1)

I requested the rolls without pineapple, but since they are premade, they couldn't take out that ingredient. It ended not being too bad. The pineapple wasn't overly sweet, so it just added a slight fruity element. I still would have preferred it more traditional sans pineapple. The sandwich was pretty good except for the bread. The texture was a little hard, so it felt slightly old and stale. I liked the filling though. Good amount of chicken and the veggies had a nice pickle. I would have preferred more pate though. I wanted more of that creaminess.

Overall, everything was okay. Not the best vietnamese sandwich or spring rolls I've had, but convenient since I can get delivery.
author: Elena N.

description: After having a heavy lunch, we walked around the area to check out the shops. We passed by this Vietnamese place and it looked and sounded refreshing to take to go for dinner. The different bowls caught my eye. I wanted to just get the standard bun bowl because it had the rice noodles, but thought I should try something more unique. I ended up ordering the Hawker bowl, because how could you look past anything with a fried egg? I ordered it with chicken, which might be my first mistake since I usually opt for pork with Vietnamese dishes. When I ate it for dinner, it tasted really bland. I ate what I could of the fried egg and the pickled daikon because those were the best parts, and some chicken so it didn't completely go to waste. Perhaps I just got unlucky and maybe they are more well-known for the banh mi rather than their rice bowls.
author: Ashley C.

description: I love Bun Mee. I love the menu and the food. I've been to the other location downtown. I had the crispy tofu bun mee. I also really wanted the lemongrass pork or crispy catfish sandwich. I decided to get something a little healthier, so I got tofu. The veggies and bread are good. The menu is so fun and has an original take on a traditional concept-banh mis. I like the restaurant concept and design.
author: Denise C.

description: ​What a craphole this place is, I mean come on! First I walk in, and the cashier gives me a hard once-over and then cold "hello". Then she looks over at her coworkers and snickers about something as I dig for my cash. She sang loud as if one of the customer​s was going to get her a singing contract. When I got my sandwich, I was blown away by the huge carrot pile that was stuffed in the " baguette ". Like really, do we need a whole hand full of shredded carrots ( that weren't even picked by the way!). To top it off it tasted like those carrots needed to be in the trash. The meat was the worst, cold, bland, oldish, and I was so mad. After I went shopping, I went home and immediately took a charcoal pill to prevent food poisoning ​. I will never eat here again, never.
author: Tashi G.

description:
Love this place. It's simple yet tasty and the staff is always really friendly.  For a place that has a fast dining turnover, the tables are always clean. 

Def a great to place to grab a quick bite.
author: Juliette H.

description: The sloppy Joe is great as are the sweet potato fries, the eggplant leaves some flavor to be desired. We Lao got the garlic fries which were good but not really garlic flavored. The limeade is my favorite! The delivery was earlier than expected and much appreciated as the sloppy Joe can get soggy.
author: Tara K.

description:
Think classic bahn mi with a hipster twist.

As someone who's been eating traditional bahn mi's for his entire life, I was really intrigued at Bun Mee. Some of my favorites include the grilled chicken, catfish, and the pork belly. The pork belly especially is greasy (as some others noted), salty, extremely delicious, and my absolute favorite. The fries were also really good. Definitely coming back here when I come back to San Francisco.
author: Wilson L.

description: Did not agree with my stomach. Will not go into undue vivid details. Suffice to say I got the 5-spice chicken sandwich yesterday (2/19/18) and got ill. Had eaten here a few times before without this kind of problem. Now scared to go back. Just wondering if anyone else got ill around the same time. Wondering if it's some change in storage or food handling. Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. :(
author: J K.

description: I meant to update this sooner--the General Manager ended up contacting me a short time after my initial review. I very much appreciated him following up and offering complimentary lunch to make up for the mishap. I've only ordered a couple more times since, but the food has been on point.
author: Jess T.

description:
The bun bowl was made with a thigh piece of chicken and was basically just grease and gristle. It was roughly $12.50 for some noodles, a thigh, romaine lettuce, a few carrot shreds and some garlic. The dressing just pooled at the bottom of the bowl and made the end of the meal pretty oily and greasy. I wouldn't recommend getting the bowl, or if you do get a different sauce.

Didn't offer water and it just seems like for the cost it's hardly competitive with other choices. There's way too many amazing places to ever come back here.
author: Matt K.

description:
I've been eyeing this place for quite a while, we finally managed to come.  When you walk in you'll notice that this place is really hipster, which is not a bad thing.  The menu is really clear and easy to understand.

We ordered a combo banh mi, which had mortadella, pork and pate.  The quality of meat is definitely superior than a average banh mi, however your definitely paying more than your average banh mi (almost double). The banh mi was good, I wouldn't say I was blown away though, the bread was too toasted, but all in all it was good.

I'd come back here since the food was pretty decent and the employees are super nice.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: Absolutely love this place for lunch! They are quick and so good! Great for groups with dietary restrictions as well. It's my go to for catering work lunches and never disappoints my clients. Parking on the street can be a little tough but there is a public lot around the corner. Highly recommend!
author: Sally S.

description: First off this is a really great way to get your Vietnamese fix. I came in and couldn't decided so I went with a bowl that, while I waited regretted not getting the namesake Bahn Mi! LOL so take that into consideration. The people here were so nice and everything was packed to go with all the side tools and sauces I might need. My kids got egg rolls, a hit! a side of chicken-which they thought was plain and preferred my pork. The delicious Thai Iced tea with Chia Seeds was delicious and made me realize it's so much like Boba but with a healthy purpose! Def. order that drink!! Oh and the Garlic Fries were amazing! Def. will return to try the rest of the Menu!
author: Lisa H.

description: Sandwiches didn't taste remotely authentic, spices were a mess, and the ratio of filling to bread left a lot to be desired. Not worth your money or time.
author: Phillip O.

description:
Review for lunch:
- Pork belly sandwich, ate it there
- meh, had better elsewhere
- paid for my friend and she had the same; ordered extra jalepenos. It didn't look extra.
- Total around $17. A bit expensive with no drinks.
- too much carrots, and as other Yelpers said, little to no cilantro.
- pork belly meat was good though, tender and not dry. It was enough meat without being overwhelming. 
- would rather walk over 2 blocks and grab a sandwich to go at Cafe Dolce, or walk further into Chinatown to get a really good Vietnamese sandwich at Latte Express on Kearny.
author: Mary H.

description: Great place for Vietnamese sandwich, quality of food is perfect. Service is quick and efficient. Parking is easy to find
author: Ilya Y.

description: Food is tasty. Not sure why but my tummy is usually upset after eating here. Three out of four times. So despite the tastiness of the food, unless someone else wants to go here it's not top of my list.
author: Tim P.

description:
You know how a small shack-looking hole-in-the-wall taqueria ends up having the best tacos? I feel as though the same general sentiment applies to banh mis. The best I've had are on street carts in Vietnam for under a dollar a pop, or in the States, in a small shop nestled next to a gas station. I was hesitant when I walked into a hipster, modern, and spacious interior of Bun Mee, but I gave it a chance. I kind of wish I hadn't. And my initial hypothesis still stands. 

I got the crispy tofu "bun mee," which contained tofu, soy mayo, shaved onion, julienned carrots, daikon, cauliflower relish, jalapenos, cilantro, and shallots. The vegetables were plentiful, which was good, but didn't taste... vinegary enough? They didn't have the characteristic sweetness cut with a tinge of acidity from the vinegar and fish sauce that one would typically expect from a banh mi. The tofu was rather bland and the texture was rather rubbery. The bread was the biggest sin - it was too thick and not at all soft. 

There are better banh mi spots in the Bay that are literally half the price of what you can get here. I'm gonna call it a pass.
author: Crystal J.

description: Definitely a good place to eat. Pretty filling. Some good options. If you want something authentic and cheaper you could definitely find it in SF but this place is still pretty good, just a little bit more pricey than your average banh mi
author: Meg B.

description: BRETT is awesome. I ordered a sandwich I believe they accidentally cross contaminated my food with nuts and I am allergic. I went back with a friend and let them know how dangerous it was and I wasn't expecting anything - he made sure I got another sandwich on the house. Such good customer service. Thank you sooo much Brett
author: Tahirah L.

description:
This review is based soley on this incident... which has unfortunately made me never want to eat here again...

I got the salad which I normally get when I come here. I frequently came here as I work around the corner. But today, I got a very gross surprise. A beetle. The size of a pinky nail. I get that this happens.... but I expect more out of a place in Pacific heights... especially for the price. IMO, this should not happen. Wash your produce. Keep up with your sanitation. 

When I went back to show them what I found they just shrugged their shoulders and said sorry. Whilst a bird flies into the shop and they proceeded to make a joke that it's not just beetles in my food, but birds in the restaurant... ummm what? Why not offer me something to rectify the situation. 

Be warned. You might get extra protein in your meal... and it's gross.
author: Carla R.

description: Sad to be reporting that one of my favorites has let me down big time.  Went to get about 10 sandwiches for the extended family.  Raving about it ahead of time.  Then got sandwiches that were stale French bread "baguettes."  The rest of the sandwich (chicken, pork, tofu) was lukewarm.  No one expressed pleasure.  They get one star for being on-time in having the order ready on a busy afternoon.  Not SF caliber anymore, unfortunately.
author: W G.

description:
Cute spot, but there is definitely better banh mi out there, my friends. 

I stopped by with some friends on our way to Pug Sunday at Alta Plaza Park, and we ordered the Grilled Lemongrass Pork, Grilled Five Spice Chicken, and Belly Bun sandwiches to go. We ate at the park, and unfortunately, the resounding response was literally, 'Meh..' My sandwich was more saucy and greasy if anything, lacking the BBQ grilled flavor I'm used to.

I'm glad I stopped by, but would prefer the more legit, hole in the wall Vietnamese spots over Bun Mee. A pro is that they serve beer!
author: Camille B.

description:
Solid Vietnamese sandwiches if you don't mind paying $7-8 for one. The place itself is trendy and has nice service.

Tried the lemongrass pork ($8) since the server said it was one of their most popular. I added pate for $1 and that was a really good decision since it made the sandwich creamier. The pork was well cooked not the best I've ever had but overall good sandwich and nice location.
author: Linda X.

description: Nothing but positive things to say. Crispy catfish is our favorite. The salt, pepper and jalapeño fries are so addicting. Love the Thai tea with chia seeds. All reasonably priced. Perfect spot for lunch or for takeout dinner.
author: Jacqueline T.

description: This is just 5 min walk from home and Bun Mee offers refreshing & tasty bowl of vegetables and also great bahn mi. Something easy and convenient to go every time we crave for something refreshing and it's close by. Wouldn't go extra mile to get this, but this makes a good option for lunch / take away.
author: Hester D.

description:
Well, don't expect a $2.50 Viet sandwich like your high school days. Sandwiches are a 7 to 8 dolla holla (translation- $7-8). 

I got their five spice chicken salad which was a good portion and had good flavoring. We shared sweet potato fries which were crispy and delicious. 

Limited and cramped seating at this place- as with most restaurants in Fillmore. Makes it uncomfortable for the servers and customers to walk around, as there's always a line through the center of the restaurant. Tis city life at times.
author: Joanna L.

description:
I don't feel like i wasted my money but it wasn't great. Stay away from
The egg rolls- they are not good. The bun mee itself was decent. All in all, I don't feel like I wasted my money but I wouldn't really be dying to go back.
author: Tina L.

description:
I'm a big fan of this cute little local chain.  The ordering process and food delivery are quite quick and the waiting here is very minimal.  

The Vietnamese sandwiches are a bit pricier than other mom and pop shops around the city, but the ingredients are top quality and the bread is perfectly chewy and crusty.  I recommend the Grilled Five Spice Chicken sandwich.  

The salads and entrees are excellent.  The Bun Noodle Bowl is the closest thing to a true "bun", but has a unique Bun Mee take on it.  

When I'm craving a light lunch, a side salad and light bite do to the trick.  For example, I enjoy the Mango Sesame Salad with the Pork and Shrimp Rolls.  (the spring rolls are not deep fried like the egg rolls)

My only complain:  The takeout containers are excessive, creating more waste than they should
author: Andrea H.

description: walked in for lunch and ordered the banh mi with roasted eggplant and really enjoyed it! the jalapeño added a good kick and while there are a lot of carrots, I really like carrots so I didn't mind! Definitely recommend the eggplant and will be back to try the crispy tofu
author: Rachel N.

description: This was my second trip here. It's in one the the most fabulous, easy on the eyes, super safe neighborhoods in The City. I was actually looking for things to be wrong when I walked in...I only went in because there wasn't a line! I took that as a sign. The young man that sort of took my order was going to be my target. He was saved by the most amazing interception I have ever seen. There was another guy in ear shot of this looming outburst of mine and zoomed in, in mid-sentence took over. It was like a scripted movie scene...polite, efficient, eye contact, smile...DONE. Now the food was just amazing. 5 spice chicken sandwich with everything. (HOT) The house made sweet potato fries...unreal! I ate at one of the tables by the window.  A sunny day, good food, best service! Now, this could be a deal breaker...the table was so sticky, when I lifted my arm up, it sounded like pealing tape off the table. Back to the food...very, very fresh. Everything was cold that was suppose to be and hot as they should. The House made lemonade was fantastic. The price...I thought $21.00 (with $5. tip) for lunch there...deal! You have to eat there for best results...
author: Rodney M.

description:
Bun Mee was super disappointing. While I appreciated the vegan options (including soy mayo), the flavors were lackluster. First and foremost, I am obsessed with vegetarian spring/summer rolls and invariably like, and on some occasions...love, spring/summer rolls from every vietnamese place at which I dine. However, the summer rolls at Bun Mee were inedible; they were filled with too many carrots and had a strange taste overall. In addition, the peanut sauce that accompanied the summer rolls was thick and tasted very bad, almost like vomit. Second, the crispy tofu sandwich was not as described. The tofu was not even close to crispy and the sandwich was loaded with those ill-flavored carrots. The one aspect I did like about the sandwich was the soy mayo and the cauliflower; therefore, I took the carrots and tofu off and ate the sandwich as so. My partner felt disappointed with his meat sandwich, the Combo. Overall, for $30 total (two banh mi sandwiches, summer rolls, and a beer), Bun Mee is not worth the cost for uninspiring vietnamese sandwiches.

**PS- Be careful here too. They accidentally brought shrimp summer rolls to my table first when I clearly ordered vegan tofu summer rolls. Highly recommend you look at your food here first!**
author: Christina M.

description: Love love love and then some. My goodness, this place is everything I could want in a fast, explosively tasty, healthy Vietnamese option--they have literally anything you'd want to eat: Salads? Check. Sandwiches? Check. Rice bowls? Check. Noodles? Check. We got the steak banh mi with pate, specified "mild," and also got the garlic rice bowl with egg and shrimp. The sandwich comes fully loaded with pickled carrots, mild creamy pate spread, little sprigs of cilantro, bits of shredded cabbage, slices of tender steak, and likely some fish sauce piled atop a fresh crusty baguette, everything nestled here. And the bowl--on a generous mound of mildly spiced garlic rice, not overpowering, a perfectly yolked egg and grilled shrimp, large enough to deserve the "prawn" designation. Everything came out super fast, and the flavors were insanely explosively flavor-packed and tasty, to the point where my husband and I entered some soert of hypnotic zone, not talking, simply inhaling the food. We also got their coconut chocolate cooke and shared it. Big mistake: I should've gotten my own :-) It's a crunchy dark chocolate thin cookie sandwich and between two layers is a moist creamy coconut cream. It's not artificial sweetness or gunky; instead, like all their stuff, it's fresh and in a few bites, disappears. Yes, the prices here are more than you'd pay at a local Vietnamese joint in the tenderloin, but it's more than worth the prices because the ingredients and preparations are more refined, have a degree of sophistication and freshness that you'd be hard pressed to find elsewhere. If I had one of these near my house, I'd likely sleep there :-) Did I mention--the staff is always friendly and on the ball? They're hard-working and super busy, but never at the cost of a ready smile.
author: Ranjan P.

description: It wasn't bad, but it just didn't taste like a bahn mi. And I guess for the location $8 is ok, but I'll just stick to Saigon sandwich
author: Kaizer D.

description: Wonderful! Great service and timely delivery. Easy online ordering system and catering set up. I ordered the night before I needed lunch delivered and selected the 20-sandwich box, cookies, and three of the side kale salads. Everyone in my meeting loved their sandwiches and the variety. It made for a more "upscale" lunch; not just your average sandwich order. The delivery came right ON TIME and was CORRECT! Overall, a very satisfied customer and I would definitely order from Bun Mee again.
author: Loretta R.

description: The food is quick but that's about it. The bread is dry. The meat is not very flavorful and the fries have a strange taste. It's really overpriced for what it is.
author: Rachel D.

description: Order the bun with chicken,  lots of fresh veggies however the sauce for this is a bit flat. I guess after eating bowls like this in Hawaii I am a bit more spoiled with the flavor.  Need more fish sauce to give it a salty flavor.  Glad I tried this place as I always see a line at their Market Street location.  A 5 star for the ingredients in the bun and a 4 for their sauce.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I dropped by here for lunch on a Saturday around 12pm. It wasn't too busy so my order was ready in less than 10 minutes. I got the fried catfish sandwich. The first think I noticed was the amount of fish which was not as much as I would hope for. The flavor was there but it was mild because each bite wasn't packed with a ton of fillings. The bread texture and aioli were great however! I wish I tried the rice or vermicelli bowl instead of the sandwich or even the five spice meat sandwich. This place for me doesn't compare to the more authentic Bahn Mis I've had at smaller family owned Viet restaurants. 

Overall an OK place for a quick bite. For the Fillmore area, this is also very affordable option.
author: Manisha S.

description: The Bun Bowl is amazing. If I were in SF more often I would try every single item on menu.
author: Brian W.

description: Not bad, but not extraordinary. The portions are very small so one sandwich is definitely not enough. They have great sweet potato fries though, I highly recommend ordering a side of those.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
The most non-traditional and expensive banh mi I've ever had. I ordered it from Postmates on Christmas Eve. 

The carrots and daikon are usually soaked in vinegar and sugar before going onto the sandwich. There were no daikon. The carrots were just carrots. I ordered the combo and it was missing pate, usually the most important part of a combo banh mi. I know that different places makes it differently but if you're going to advertise it, at least put it in. 

Banh mi usually cost $6 at most but this cost a whopping $8. Save your money. Not worth it.
author: Serena F.

description:
Do Not Order from Bun Mee if you are vegan. I ordered the Bun Mee Noodle Bowl with Tofu (specifically marked Vegan) at their Market St location and it was served with a spring roll with ground pork.

With that kind of oversight, they clearly do not care about vegan/vegetarian diets.
author: Jon T.

description:
This is definitely NOT your traditional banh mi, so puh-lease don't come in expecting it.

I should have ordered what my friend ordered: the Belly Bun. Gawd, I love pork belly. Why would I NOT order the Belly Bun? *angst*

The BELLY BUN, $6.75, is a roll stuffed with braised Kurobuta pork belly, salted radish relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro. Fork over an extra $1 to get it with a hard boiled egg--totally worth it, I promise you. This entire combination of finger-lickin' pork&egg&veggies is totally worth it, actually. Can you really deny well-flavored pork belly and fresh veggies AND a fried egg!? CAN YOU!?

I ended up getting the HANOI-STYLE CRISPY CATFISH BUN, $6.50, a roll stuffed with crispy fried turmeric catfish, red curry mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bun-mee-san-francisco?select=-cMvBYwkXKot3x28py8Quw#-cMvBYwkXKot3x28py8Quw). I too added the fried egg for a dollah. I enjoyed the juicy fish filet, which made for a great sandwich. But, still. I'd recommend the Belly Bun. Hands down. 

We also got an order of SWEET POTATO FRIES, $2.75, served with red curry mayo. Crispy and perfectly paired with the bombdotcom mayo.

Need to get that Belly Bun in mah BELLY D:
author: Adele F.

description:
2.5 Stars
To put it plainly, I think Bun Mee is Americanized. At least with their banh mi's. That doesn't necessarily mean that it's bad though.
I tasted their 5 spice chicken and their combo sandwich, and I just wasn't that impressed. I love me some fresh, baked bread. With theirs,  it was chewy/hard and my jaws hurt from chewing/eating my meal. I was looking for that crunchy and soft roll. I did like the creamy sauce and there was ample veggies. The ingredients were good quality. That definitely set them apart from other places.
author: Mimie L.

description: Tasty Vietnamese sandwiches and  good selection of salads available. Great to go location during the weekday. Really recommend the kale salad!
author: Daisy L.

description:
Soggy rolls and all food. Hipster take on Vietnamese food gone wrong. Especially for the price.

Find other spots for better Vietnamese..
author: Wesley W.

description: Just a quick note about the Bun Noodle Bowl. It was a decent size with vermicelli rice noodle, one crispy egg roll, sliced lettuce, picked carrots, cucumbers, and your choice of meat. I opted for the grilled pork. The menu read well, but I felt that the balance of ingredients made the dining experience a little less fulfilling. More carrots and cucumbers were needed to balance out the vermicelli, especially since the lettuce took up so little volume and added little texture to the dish. The pork was very fatty and left me wanting more dense protein to fill up. The dipping sauce likely was fish sauce based and was fine on its own, but didn't make up for the aforementioned things.
author: Cici T.

description: This place used to be GREAT.  Not just good, but great.  They had three different types of salads (one specially for steak, one with shrimp and one with chicken).  The chicken was fresh and well seasoned.  The fruit and vegetables were great.  It was six stars.  But here's the thing: every time we eat here the food gets worse and since we have now eaten here 100+ times, we just lost a start down to one. Now the chicken is often gristly.  The fruit tastes two days old.  The greens are often limp.  I'd say they were the McDonald's of Vietnamese food but at least McDonalds is consistent.  Bun Men is all over the map.  Sometimes the rice bowl is stone cold.  Sometimes the salad is hot.  Ask for no jalapeños and get EXTRA jalapeños.  We ordered our last meal from here today.  Good riddance.  Glad the owner is a former lawyer -- no doubt there are some food poisoning lawsuits in her future.
author: G H.

description: Very unprofessional --slow, and the staff pretty much has zero interest in bothering to serve their customers. There are plenty of other good places right near them. Skip it.
author: Mercury S.

description: Ordered delivery from Caviar app. You guys should be ashamed of yourselves! I ordered the imperial rolls. And they had the double whammy of being completely cold AND burned at the same time! Do u guys just put the burned ones to the side to give to customers that order delivery and you don't have to interact with personally? Clearly these should have been thrown away, not given to a customer who pays $6! I had to throw these away. Bad form, guys, I'm pissed!
author: Amy W.

description: WAY too much vinegar in the fish sauce.  Made the vermicelli borderline inedible.  Mango salad was refreshing but no dressing?  Was that how it was supposed to be?  Way below average Vietnamese food
author: D D.

description:
I love all of the different options here. They're not as authentic as some of the other banh mi shops but they pack so much flavor in each sandwich. The five spice chicken is a classic but go for the sloppy bun mee, catfish, and pork belly is goood too. Ooh and the salt and pepper garlic fries rock too! 

The shop is pretty small and can get crowded really quickly. Since they only have 6 tables most people grab take out. Bon apetite!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
For Lunch a nice place to go, but only for that! 
I'm not a big fan of the sandwiches, but the rice bowls are a good and healthy option.
author: Nadine B.

description:
I was in town visiting a girlfriend and we were both hungry and looking for a quick bite. We stumbled upon this place and since she hasn't ever been here I knew this was our spot.
Upon entering we were greeted by a friendly and helpful staff member who helped my girlfriend who isn't a meat eater in the right direction. She ended up getting Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish, Crispy fried turmeric catfish, red curry aioli, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro, that she LOVED! 

The guy behind the counter recommended the sloppy bun with egg for me. I was a little hesitant since I am not a fan of sloppy joes but he swore up and down it was one of the best items on the menu! I am so happy that I listened to him! The sloppy bun was so flavorful and the egg took it over the top. We also shared the garlic salt and pepper fries. They were amazing, they are tossed with sautéed onions and jalapeños and their salt and pepper seasoning blend. They were addicting and something I still crave to this day. If your in the area and looking for something different head over to bun mee
author: Roxy H.

description:
Still pretty good and still pretty pricey. Also, you will be dinged the phony "SF Health Fee" which should just be part of their price to begin with. (What's next- water fees and electricity fees?).

It's Vietnamese-ish dishes for yuppies, and the mostly Latin staff does alright with the menu. Tables are a little claustrophobic and meat portions are slim for the price. It's nothing like you'll get in San Jose, but if you're stuck in the Fillmore it's not too bad.
author: T J.

description:
not your typical Vietnamese sandwich shop.  It has a hipster feel to it.
The pricing of the sandwiches are what I expected for location, but I'm still shocked that they charge extra for pate.  Usually isn't that a main ingredient in the sandwich?!
I ordered the combo sandwich, super filing, tasted okay.  Some of meat was a little chewier than what I'd like.  This isn't bad, but it's not great.  It's fairly close to where I work so it's nice to get a walk in during my lunch break.  Like to also note the lady took my order was really nice to me, she greeted me when I came in.

Overall, not bad.  I would probably come back whenever I'm craving Viet sandwiches or to try some of the other things.
author: Angelica Y.

description: I was surprised to find that my Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl with tofu did not have any peanut sauce flavour. The three thin slices of tofu had peanuts on them but the rice was very dry. There was a good amount of brown rice and overall the dish wasn't very flavourful or tasty. For $10, it was a bit disappointing.
author: June S.

description: Very cute spot with delicious sounding banh mi choices. I ended up getting a classic banh mi for comparison reasons, but think I probably would have been better off with something very different. It was not a good banh mi compared to traditional Vietnamese shops!
author: Jen B.

description:
I am really disappointed to have to leave this review.  I have been to this location and ordered food from them many times.  However, a few nights ago I order through eat24 and got a confirmed delivery time of 45-60min.  At an hour an 10 min I messaged Eat24 to see where my food was, they said it would be there in about 10 min, that the restaurant got busy and the delivery time went up.  Thats fine, but I feel like they could have easily called, texted, messaged through the app to let me know.  They didn't.  Whatever, so my food was supposed to now take an hour and twenty min to show up, which is kind of silly when it is some sandwiches.  But, my food doesn't show up for an hour and forty min.  I understand things get busy, but you can communicate with your customers. An hour and forty min is absurd.  

That alone would have left me a bit annoyed but there's more.  The delivery guy dropped my food.  Sweet potato fries spilling out on the floor leaving a trail to my door, he sheepishly handed my a torn bag and it contents piling them up in my arms reassuring me, "its all there"  No it wasn't.  And its kind of gross that my clearly just hit the floor fries are now what I'm supposed to eat. I get it, accidents happen, not blaming him personally, but I think everyone would be displeased with this situation.  Missing from my order were most of my fries, the dipping sauce for them, and the sriacha I had asked for.  Also the sandwiches were pretty messed up from whatever they fell on to.  

Now with my beaten and late food I sat down to devour what had moments earlier been on the floor, only to find that everything that was supposed to be hot was cold, and everything that was supposed to be cold was warm.  Fantastic! 

Great food, terrible experience.  Pretty annoyed with it especially since there is a $5 delivery fee...
author: Hillary K.

description:
I been here uuhm lets say 5 times in the past 3months, and i have tried the Lemon Grass pork sandwich with jalapeños. Omg sooo goood!!! 

And than i tried the Hawker Bowl with pork and i usually do not eat my eggs sunrise up but this combination was really delicious . 

I have also tried the garlic fries and they're good too.
author: Valentina P.

description:
I had the STRONGEST craving for a vermicelli bowl. Now, I love mom and pop Vietnamese places, so I know what legit Vietnamese food tastes like. This place, seemed like a great spot to try a v bowl, but I am sad to report that I experienced the exact opposite.

I called in to order a "bun bowl" which is, "vermicelli noodles, shredded romaine lettuce, mama tran's crispy egg roll, pickled carrots and daikon, cucumbers, jalapenos, bean sprouts, vietnamese herbs, peanuts, crispy shallots, nuoc cham sauce (vegetarian available) and your choice of pork, chicken, or organic tofu." [as stated on their menu on Yelp]. I went with the pork option.They told me my order would be ready in 10 and I went in, picked it up and that was my experience in store. Their customer service was good, welcoming and cool. The restaurant itself is small, located next to the MAC store on Fillmore x Pine. Very hipster yet has an industrial feel to it.

On to the food. I noticed right away the noodles were very slippery/wet when I  peeked from under the transparent to-go container. That was different. Usually when I order this same dish elsewhere, the noodles are drier, and cold. (Strike 1). Next I noticed the pork is a weird brown with hues of gray- I was expecting a nice colored BBQ pork of some sort. (Strike 2). Last but not least, anyone that's had a v bowl from a legit place knows the sauce you pour over the dish is arguably the "icing on the cake". But for Bun Mee, their sauce which, in my opinion and experience, should have been more "fish saucey" and not so malt vinegar-y. (Strike 3 - You're out!). (One of the) Saddest$13 I've spent.

I gave it a try, but it definitely did not live up to the expectations I had about this place - especially given the amount of foot traffic they get during the day.
author: Kathleene E.

description: The fresh coconut is a *must* have. We also had the lemongrass pork sandwich (tasty but I like more cilantro and this was light on it), and the salt 'n' pepper garlic fries with jalapeños (delicious!)! Great place to stop for lunch. Saw the bun bowl and they also looked like "no leftovers".
author: John W.

description:
Bun Mee: A place that shallow people would enjoy. 

--
So a good friend of mine recommended this joint to me knowing that I love Vietnamese food. He sent me a link to the restaurant one day, in attempt to lure me into SF. I have to admit... I was definitely interested. It seemed like such a hip new Vietnamese sandwich shop that I might truly enjoy. 

Although I never made my way out to the city solely to visit the restaurant, I was pleasantly surprised one day when I found myself in the area. My boyfriend and I were deciding on what we wanted to eat when suddenly, he said, "I want banh mi." I'm just like, "sure", as I let him take me up the street and to the entrance of an unfamiliar venue. I looked at the storefront sign and immediately perked up when I read "Bun Mee". I was thinking, "Hey! It's this place I've been wanting to try for a while now!" You know that feeling. 

I walk in with my sweetheart, admiring the decor. Everything is as hip in person as it is in all of the website photos. We were impressed. 

We take a few moments to look at the pretty menu board posted on the wall. I end up ordering the Bun Mee Combo; my guy orders the Grilled Five Spice Chicken bun mee. 

Everything is going swell. There's a cool bus boy moving about the restaurant to clean up the tables. He's friendly as he excuses himself around us. Limited space, thus he was unavoidable. It's SF, so the place is super small, of course. That's all good, though. I didn't mind that. So long as the establishment is kept clean, which it was. 

The sandwiches I see other customers eating look pretty good. 

We grab a table in the window nook and await our food. The sandwiches came and ours were just as pretty as all of the other sandwiches I was onlooking before. We begin to eat.

That was when... the fancy mirror started to crack. It was as if looks are all that matters to these people. Yeah, you've got a nice place. Yeahh, your sandwiches are good looking. But what about the taste, people?? At best, the sandwiches were mediocre :/. That is at best, but in my honest opinion, they were lame. 

The bread did not taste fresh. It was stale and dry compared to authentic banh mi's I've had the pleasure of eating in the past. That is the biggest tragedy, as we all know... a good banh mi needs good banh mi! 

The meat? Seasoned poorly! My boyfriend thought his chicken sandwich was subpar, and when I took a bite, I had to agree. My combo bun mee filling was all over the place. The pork was a weird sponge food with a flavor that didn't really compliment anything. As for the pâté, I could barely find any, let alone taste it. 

(Side personal story: When I first received my sandwich, I opened up the bread, only to take my order back to the register. All that I saw was Kurobuta pork in-between the buns.

It prompted me to say to the cashier girl, "I'm sorry. We ordered the combo, but received the pork." 

She looked at me, shifted her eyes, looked to her monitor to read something, looked back at me, and then said, "No. You ordered the pork. I'm sure." 

I'm a bit passive, so I took the sandwich back to my table feeling bad that I made a fuss. I talked about it for a minute with my guy, and we basically agreed with confidence that we did order the combo. 

It just didn't feel right, so I took the sandwich to register again. Being mindfully polite, I said, "I'm really sorry, but we're sure we ordered the combo." 

She then took the sandwich to the back, as I'm now firm on receiving my correct order. A minute later, she brought the same sandwich back to me, saying, "Oh, the chef says it is the combo." 

She pointed to a small sliver of pâté that anyone would miss. I mean, I missed it. My boyfriend missed it. She even missed it herself, as she previously believed it had to be pork. 

That specific part left me most confused! When the chef confirmed that the sandwich was the Bun Mee Combo all along, I couldn't understand why the cashier girl insisted earlier that we ordered pork. She made it seem like she was positive we ordered pork, and that she proved it by checking the monitor history. Was that all just an act? I think my guy said it best when she walked away. "It's like her first instinct was just to lie."

Anyway...)

With the stale bread and poorly tasting meat, the best part of the "bun mee" is the vegetables, which can only be described as plain and ordinary. Not really great adjectives to describe the best component of a meal, now is it? 

No. Not great.

Thus, overall, these sandwiches were very lame. They were like a pretty face that draws you in, only to reveal a character that lacks depth and substance. Well, I'm not about that. Thus, in conclusion: Bun Mee? Ehh. Tap it once then pass. 2 stars just for that.
author: Mimi N.

description:
(ubereats)

This place is decent and cheap, but frankly the banh mi sandwiches just aren't that great. Bread isn't good, I think is what the issue is. On the bright side, can a sandwich and a cookie for like 10 bucks, so, I'll probably be ordering from here a lot.
author: B H.

description: Shrimp Bun Bowl is a must-have. Lychee strawberry lemonade is phenomenal. However, if you do not want jalapeños, you must emphasize this to the waitress.
author: Arianna N.

description: First timer...horrible experience. First off, they got our order wrong and forgot our spring rolls. Second, their garlic rice is mushy white rice with NO GARLIC whatsoever. And third, just don't go here. If anything just get the BanMhi sandwhichs they are decent
author: Chico B.

description: Did not know vietnamese burgers were so good! Loved the ground meat, liked the mayo they put on top as well.
author: Siddhartha G.

description:
3.5 stars 

Bun Mee is the perfect place for you if:

-- You like a consistently good baguette.  I've been here couple of times (against my will!) And their buns are crusty and have a nice heft to it.
-- You're looking for something different in your banh mi: pork belly? sardines? sloppy joe style with a fried egg?  only at Bun Mee!
-- You like friendly staff who are super fast at getting your food ready 
-- You don't mind getting ripped off by Pac Heights prices.  Prepare to pay more than $5 for a banh mi that you can get in the Tenderloin for only $3. Additional $3-$4 for sweet potato fries (good), salt and pepper fries (skip) and mango sesame salad (great!) 
-- You don't want to go to the Tenderloin because you actually want to stay alive and see your grandchildren.  

I'm handing out the 3.5 stars because if you're in this area and you want a banh mi sooo bad, your only other choice is overpriced Out the Door which sells theirs for $13!!
author: Janice C.

description: Five spice chicken. The caramel mayo was interesting, but it didn't seem to add anything special. The chicken had fatty skin on it which I prefer removed. It was tender and a generous portion of meat. The bread was super hard and dense. The best thing about this sandwich was the crunch of the pickled carrots. They nailed the seasoning and texture. I'm a huge bahn mi fan and this is an ok choice for a place so far from all the good sandwich shops in the tenderloin. On the plus side, this isn't in the 'loin so you feel clean and safe while eating.
author: Sarah O.

description:
I'm so in love with this place. It's small, so come for an early lunch or a late lunch to grab a table. I had the peanut bowl and a Thai iced tea. 

I thought the portion size was perfect for a good meal. Filled me up! I highly recommend trying this eatery. Yum :)
author: Sara P.

description: Found this little Bun Shop on a walk through Lower Pacific Heights. For an unassuming little counter-service restaurant, it's quite fantastic. I enjoyed the Belly Bun with a fried egg topping and a side salad to balance it out. It was one of the messiest banh mis I've ever had, but it was so tasty I found myself licking my hands over reaching for more napkins. I left full and satisfied for under $15. Keep your eyes peeled for this place on your next stroll down Fillmore.
author: Anthony K.

description: Ordered the vermicelli with shrimp. A little over priced and very mediocre. Ordered through yelp and made a request which was completely ignored. They were not friendly or welcoming at the register when I went to pick it up. The food was incredibly underwhelming. Would never try it again. Just a bunch of ingredients thrown together. Bland and nothing noteworthy or yummy. Really disappointing all around!
author: Sophia M.

description: came because the name was cute, but won't make that mistake again. Service was slow and food wasn't authentic
author: Cynthia P.

description:
My biggest issue when traveling to SF is choosing among all the delish lunch spots surrounding my office. And now I can add Bun Mee to the list of deliciousness!

I had time for one last meal before hopping on a looong flight back home and Bun Mee did a nice job of filling me up for the afternoon and evening. I ordered the Bun Noodle Bowl, which came with all my favorites: rice noodles, peanuts, chicken and even a crispy egg roll in there. Oh, and lots of veggies too. Tasty! Also tasty..their house-made lemonade. 

A bit pricey for an order at the counter restaurant. The total for 2 of us (2 bowls, 2 lemonades) came to $32, but then again that's the case with most restaurants in the area.
author: Andrea R.

description:
This place is a solid 3.5 half stars (wish I could've given them four).  I had their grilled five spice chicken vietnamese sandwich along with their House-Made Strawberry Lychee Agua Fresca and mooched off of my friends' Salt n Pepper Garlic Fries.  

The sandwich was good.  It was missing the je ne sais quoi that comes along with an authentic vietnamese sandwich.  Perhaps it was too neat?  The pickled carrot and daikon a little too seasoned (I like my pickled goods just plain ole pickled)?  It definitely had all of the essential fixings of cilantro (could've used a bit more), jalapeno, and pickled carrot and daikon.  Maybe next time, it'd be worth it to throw in the pate.  The Strawberry Lychee agua fresca was a bit watered down for me.  The high note were the Salt n Pepper Garlic Fries.  Those were delicious.  A must get in my fry book.  

This is a great place to go when the line isn't too long....I'm not sure it's quite worth a long wait.  Very friendly staff and I enjoyed their simplistic menu.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Customer Service: The customer service is good. The food came out quickly. The cashier and I didn't really have much of an interaction. Which is good because I don't like chatty cashiers. 

Ambiance: it's a very casual spot.  A lot of good restaurants on the block.   I just wish they had more seating.  It's really hard to get a seat for a group of three or more.   

Food: I honestly enjoyed my food.  I got one of their bowls and it was good.   The brown rice was great, the meat was flavorful.  

Parking: good luck.  It's hard to find parking.  

I would have given this place 4 stars but I did not like cramped up the inside is.
author: M R.

description: This place is decent but Cafe Bunn Mi is way better on clement street. It's nice to have a Vietnamese place nearby though. I'm grateful about that. Wish it was cheaper but it's on Fillmore so can't expect much cheaper. I like their vermicelli bowls. Haven't tried their sandwiches yet. But that's what I'll ur next time.
author: Julia W.

description:
My girlfriend & I were visiting SF, we're originally from LA (FYI our first trip to the bay area,  the people there in general are FUCKING RUDE), so we were just cruising around downtown SF and seen this pot & looked interesting. I ordered the hawk bowl with chicken & it was on point! I loved it!  My girl ordered the bun bowl w shrimp & yeah I wouldn't recommend it at all. She's typically not into Asian food, other than Chinese fast food 
It lowkey bothered me how we didn't have to pay for a for a fountain drink, due to the reason the same cup we were given, they were right next to us where we sat RIGHT IN THE OPEN. smh. I also ordered the French fries and damnnnnn I would of never imagined sautéed jalapeños & onions with fries were an amazing combination 

Overall it's good & if, if, IF we were ever to consider to visit the bay area again I'd definitely would want to return to bun mee.
author: ed r.

description:
I've eaten here in person and ordered delivery--this review is mainly for the delivery experience. My order arrived about 45 minutes after I placed it, which isn't too bad, except for the fact that I was told it would only be about 20 minutes. When it did arrive, everything was askew and the food was cold. Even my drink order was wrong :(

Overall this is an overpriced Vietnamese corner store. The food is pretty good, but just go a little further west to the Richmond and you'll find much better, cheaper Vietnamese food. I guess I'm a sucker for their painted sign too.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Wow, I'm a vegetarian and pretty much hate tofu but I ordered the crispy tofu sandwich and was surprised at how delicious it was!  I feel that this sandwich is going to be one that I will crave and will have to drive across town to get on a whim.  The bread is delish, shredded veggies fresh and crunchy, and that cauliflower relish!? So good!  Throw in some jalapenos and cilantro and I'm hooked for life.  I'm glad I stumbled on this place while on Fillmore yesterday and opted to try something new rather than the boring old Grove across the street.
I'll definitely be back!! Oh yeah, free refills on Iced tea!? Bonus!
author: lucy w.

description: I really like to go to this place for lunch. The crispy tofu sandwich is really good. I just wish it were better value for the price.
author: Madeleine M.

description:
I work in the area and for awhile co-workers would bring me food from this sandwich joint. Until recently, and quite obligatory, I've gone vegetarian; although, their options still allow for me to continue at this eatery. In fact, their crispy tofu makes being newly veggie easier to bear. 
& the staff is AMAZING! Super down to earth, I've realized now having gotten my own sandwiches. Great service and front seats.
author: Lavina T.

description: This is definitely not traditional. The food is great, the chicken sandwich and the salad were both healthy options. Low key, stop in a grab a lunch type place. No alcohol.
author: Amos Y.

description:
Lunch here recently was exactly what I wanted.

The menu is simple, and when you just want a basic banh mi, simple is perfect. I got the lemongrass pork (with jalapenos and everything) and was really impressed with the flavor. To be fair, I've only recently branched out from lemongrass chicken and have tried other lemongrass meats--Bun Mee's pork does not disappoint!

The service was friendly and the shop was clean and comfortable, but I took my sandwich to go so that I could eat it at Alta Plaza and sailboat/dog-watch like a creep. In other words, great location!
author: Nina B.

description: Really?  Three stars?  The spring rolls were pre-made, so a roll without pork was out of the question.  The fried egg rolls were luke warm, suggesting they too were not as fresh as they should have been.  The pork in the sandwich didn't seem "barbecued" in the same manner as other Vietnamese restaurants. No flavor and quite dry.  Maybe we caught this place on a down day, but for us, we won't return.
author: Brian K.

description: Very mediocre sandwiches. I was hoping for a steamed bun, as the name hinted, but I just got a regular bun with very boring meat in eat.
author: Tal C.

description:
I am such a sucker for Banh Mi and Bun that as my friends and I were strolling down the trendy Fillmore area and saw Bun Mee we knew instantly that we had to stop by!

This modernized Vietnamese spot  instantly caught my attention with its cute decor.  A great spot to go for lunch with their sandwich and salad options.  I saw that there were quite a few Asian American fusion dishes such as the sloppy bun and meatball grinder sandwiches.   They also had a variety of vegetarian options which is always great.  Seating is quite a challenge since this place is pretty small so definitely not the place to go if you are in a big group.

I was craving just your basic bun so I ordered the bun noodle bowl with grilled pork.  It took quite a while for my order to come out and although the flavor and portion size was good they did not drain my noodles thoroughly and my Bun ended up in the end looking as if I were eating Pho.  Yuck.  I also thought that it was quite overpriced for what I was eating at 11.75 and if you wanted to choose the shrimp option add an additional 2 to that.  My friend ordered a side of sweet potato fries and I was shocked at the portion size.  I could practically count the small handful of fries in that basket.  

All in all I think that my first time experience here was okay but don't know if I'd venture back here during my next trip to SF.
author: Christine D.

description: Great veggie options, including organic tofu. Love the summer rolls, banh mi, side salad, and fries!
author: Mirabella Y.

description: Amazing new take on the traditional banh mi. Miss it now that I don't live in SF. Definitely try the sloppy bun with egg. Mouth watering.
author: Cat N.

description:
No idea why this place gets anything less than a five star rating. I had the tofu sandwich with a friend egg on top and it was INCREDIBLE. Super delicious, spectacular flavor. The veggies were crisp and added nice texture. I'm not a huge sandwich fan, but wowza, I'd do back to this place every day. 

The servers were helpful, friendly and attentive. Everything in SF is expensive, so $9 for a sandwich seems pretty normal to me.

There isn't a lot of seating, but it didn't seem to be a problem during dinner. People came and went with enough frequency for there to be seats available when people wanted them. The table I had outside was quite pleasant, even though it was little wobbly. 

I would highly recommend this place!
author: A C.

description:
Cheap and comfortable good bar. In Pacific Heights. No frills included just honest to goodness sandwiches and noodles  that provide a quick n easy lunch for people on the move. The food is filling, crispy with a little space and a breath of fresh foodie air.

It's great to have options from Starbucks to Subway and something this. Unique had the potential for real market growth.

Also, it's YUM!
author: Zara S.

description:
Bun Mee (Non-Viet friendly phonetic way to pronounce Banh Mi, or Vietnamese sandwiches) is a popular place on the upscale upper Fillmore corridor in lower Pacific Heights. 

Here is the magic formula: 
!. Take popular Vietnamese diner food dishes, 
2. make them seem healthy to the average White American 30s something 
3. dressed in LuluLemon Athletica yoga gear, 
4. charge double what you would find in Little Saigon for the same thing 
5. but don't use as much authentic Viet greens and ingredients,  
6. hire Latino help to prepare your casual Americanized Viet Diner food. 
7. keep the place small and crowded to seem even more popular
8. make a lot of money! 

Bun Mee is Viet food meets white yuppies. 

To be fair, Banh Mi is actually a derivative from the French, when they occupied and tried to colonize Indochine in the previous century. The sandwich uses a small French baguette like roll, baked perfectly for a sandwich. These became legendary at places like Lee's Sandwich shops and other similar Vietnamese establishments in Little Saigons in Westminster, San Jose, and other west coast cities. 

And also to be fair, it is Vietnamese owned. A mother-daughter team of Ms. Tran and her Mom, Ms. Truong, own and run the place. Mom is originally from Hue, the ancient capital, in central Vietnam. I asked her if the old Vietnamese saying was true:

1. A girl from the North is good in your living room parlor
2. A girl from the South is good in your kitchen
3. A girl from the Central is good in your bedroom

She smiled and laughed! I asked her if she is from Hue, why doesn't Bun Mee offer the classic signature dish from central Vietnam, Bun Bo Hue? 
She said that they would have to hire a Vietnamese cook to make it, and there are too many ingredients. 

So if you want simple, tasty, and fairly healthy Viet diner food, come here because there aren't any authentic Vietnamese Diner restaurants near here, because the rent is too expensive. 

Use the magic formula, and then replicate it downtown. Yes, they will be opening another Bun Mee on the 600 block of Market soon.
author: Wanugee N.

description: So we are very disappointed in you Bun Mee , or as I like to call them 'SCREW ME' so my initial review was one star years back.. then we have you guys another shot and thought you had improved greatly. However today my wife ordered a bowl meal and I ordered what used to be a nice fried catfish bun mee sandwich. My wife found three hairs in her rice bowl within seconds of eating! My catfish sandwich was almost purely over salted and cooked greasy scraps of old batter! What tiny amount of fish that was there was like rubber and a salt lick!!!! We had ordered from an app and had home delivery. Lucking we received a full refund through the app. We will now NEVER order from you guys again!!! What happens when you drop the ball. I and my wife are still feeling nauseous from even the thought of our 'meals' thanks a lot Bun Mee.
author: Kirk M.

description:
Tried the combo sandwich and the belly bun...I have to say I wasn't impressed by either of them.  

The bread just wasn't that soft, crunchy on the outside roll that you salivate for when you walk into an authentic place.  The filling just wasn't tasty and what I'd expect from a great banh mi.  It just seemed all to commercialized and not sticking to the Vietnamese roots.  

The price tag is also hefty considering you could get amazing sandwiches for half the price elsewhere.  Were the sandwiches decent?  Of course!  I think I'm just more accustomed to the real deal.  3 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
My workplace loves to order delivery from Bun Mee. My boss always goes for the Bun Noodle Bowl with Tofu (Vegan/Gluten Free) with extra Tofu. That itself is $11.75. They also love the Coconut Cookie Sandwich. My other boss goes for the Grilled 5 Spice Chicken Salad. I've never eating it myself until now, because my mom makes this stuff at home. I get it for free, mommy/home-made. I was skeptical every time I ordered the meals for my team after seeing the price and what you get. Although, I have to always remind myself Vietnamese food is way more expensive in SF, because people here are willing to pay a lot for something that's really cheap and easy to make. I'm pretty sure Bun Mee knows this and good for them. They will charge an extra $1 for extra fried tofu...good for them. I don't think they give that much more extra tofu, but I wish they would.  

Anyways, besides me ranting about how I think the food is overpriced. I got to try Bun Mee for free, which is the only reason why I even tried it. I was debating to try a normal bun mi with chicken or pork, but then I saw they had a Sloppy Bun which was one of their recommended items from Yelp. I ordered that with a side of Mango Salad. The bread was soggy, but that's normal for a sloppy joe. I enjoyed the red curry flavored ground beef. There's a good amount of lemon grass flavor that I really liked about the sandwich. I had 3 sprigs of cilantro, 1 jalapeno, and 2-3 shredded pieces of pickled radish/carrot. I had to transfer this sandwich onto a plate because it was messy...something I appreciated...brings me back. The side salad was meh. For some reason, I was thinking it was going to be with spicy fish sauce...but I was tripping. There wasn't much flavor except for the mango. The cookies are different. I've never had anything like it before. My team swears they're really addicting. They're good, but I didn't care for it. It's a sweet cookie with coconut in the middle...maybe it's something where you either like or are ok with it. 

Overall, I think Bun Mee is overpriced for what you get. You can get bigger bun bowls and more protein elsewhere. Please note, I'm super biased when it comes to Vietnamese food. If you want to find something really good that's worth your money, go to San Jose or even Oakland. The Sloppy Bun was good, but it was lacking in the garnishes.
author: Christina L.

description:
I got the sloppy bun with an egg - it was just meh for me...not enough filling and still too sloppy. too much fish sauce taste, the onions were sliced too think, and too expensive.

But the lady at the counter was very nice.

Bathroom needs a good cleaning.

Café bun me on Clement is FAR superior.
author: Amy W.

description:
I've ordered lunch delivery for our business lunches from Bun Mee 4 times now. Each time (literally), there has been a problem with the ordering process, the quality of the food, the invoicing AND the pre- and post-order communications. Each time, it was a different set of issues and snafus, so I'm not going to list them. But basically, I've spent more time managing each order with their manager than I should have. My impression is that they're just not well-organized for deliveries: from placing an order, to executing, delivering, and invoicing for it. 

When I've eaten at their Market location (also about 4 times), I was satisfied with the food, order process, timing, etc. That all went well. (That's why 3 stars, vs 2 stars). I don't think their food is spectacular, but it's solid, and easy to eat on the go. In the restaurant.
author: Stefani C.

description:
Was excited to try Bun Mee and had a difficuly time trying to decide what to order as so many things looked so appealing only to have my whole experience ruined when I approached the order counter and their Board of Health Score Card was brought to my attention. Their score is a 79!  I did not order and left.

Sorry Bun Mee but I am not interested at putting my health at risk because you do not want to maintain an adequate level of cleanliness. I am sorry but if you are not concerned about the health safety of your clientele that provides your income then you do not get my business. "Contaminated food sickens 48 million Americans, resulting in more than 3,000 deaths and more than 100,000 hospitalizations each year." 

Clean up your act and I might be back.
author: Steven B.

description:
I love here! So far I've tried 5 spice chicken one, sloppy bun and egg plant one. All of them are so so good! Plus, house made strawberry lychee lemonade is a must order! 
Now they have a store in downtown, I haven't tried but such a convenience location! Yay!!
author: Mii L.

description:
Bun Mee? BUN MEE?... BUN YOU!... and twice on Sundays!... Is anglicizing the term, banh mi, really necessary in a city as ethnically diverse as San Francisco?
