Oh yes, it is... especially in an upwardly mobile neighborhood like Pac Heights where the Tenderloin might as well be Timbuktu for a lot of the residents here. Somebody had a brilliant idea in taking the same sammies you can find in Little Saigon for $2.50, prettying them up a bit, and selling them in a hipster setting for almost three times more. The difference is that you don't have to trip over drug addicts to enjoy them. 

They're pretty good. Jamie W. had the $6.50 Bun Mee Combo, which combines roast pork, mortadella and a more upscale pate with the standard Vietnamese ingredients of onions cucumbers, and pickled carrots and daikon - all perfectly julienned - as well as jalapeno, garlic aioli and cilantro (see photo). Mine was a tad fancier and more satisfying, the $7.95 Juicy Steak, which you guessed it - contains grilled steak with the same Vietnamese ingredients plus crispy shallots, lotus root relish and lime pepper in the aioli (see photo). 

But I have to admit one thing as a non-Pac Heights glutton - they seemed a mite small to me to be completely filling for dinner. Good thing we ordered the Sweet Potato Fries which came in a little aluminum bucket with a red curry aioli (see photo). Jamie was a bit miffed that we were forced to have the upscale Boylan sodas, a sure sign of elitism since they do not dare offer the dregs that represent Diet Coke. I had less issue with my Diet Cane Cola since I just needed to wet my whistle. We ended our mini-meal with a $1.50 House-made Coconut Cookie Sandwich, a sliver of a chocolate cookie dessert with an Almond Joy-type filling in between (see photo). 

FOOD - 3 stars...good sammies with top ingredients but really overpriced compared to the likes of Lee's or Saigon Sandwiches 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...hipster rural and quite compact 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nice guy at the counter 
TOTAL - 3 stars...Bun You!
author: Ed U.

description:
The best peanut butter sauce in the world! We really enjoyed sandwiches and salads lunch today. My favorite dish called Bun Noodle Bowl with chilled noodles, veggies and tofu. The noodles were perfectly cooked and the thinly sliced vegetables were delicious. I loved the cucumbers and jalapeños.  With sweet spicy peanut butter sauce, it was amazing!!

I tried the catfish sandwich and it tasted very fresh. It had a very nice crispy coating and lovely soft roll, veggies and condiments. 

We loved everything and highly recommend.
author: Diane W.

description:
Was craving banh-mi and went for the Grilled Five Spice Chicken. Bread was crispy, sauce (caramel mayo) on the bread was amazingly delicious, and chicken was warm, juicy, and tender. 

At $6.25, its pricey for what it is but given its S.F and my craving at the time, it was exactly what I was looking for.
author: Amir A.

description:
There are many ways to pronounce the popular Vietnamese sandwich. But the newest Vietnamese deli in Pacific Heights has got that all figured out for the crowds in that area.

Looking at the posted menu on the left side, beware you're going to expect pay Pacific Height's prices here. If arriving during the midday, you may also expect a long wait for your food and a table, because of the limited seating which isn't much. 

I was here twice already and both times, I ordered the 5-Spice grilled chicken sandwich for $5.95. For an additional $3.00, I get a side of sweet potato fries with my meal and Iced Vietnamese coffee for $3.50. The sandwich had grilled chicken, an aioli sauce, slices of onions, daikons, shredded cucumber, a cilantro leaf and slices jalapeno peppers in a warm baguette bread. 

The sandwich was very good with the chicken spiced and grilled nicely. The side was good with the tangy aioli dipping sauce. I love my iced Vietnamese coffee made the proper long-established way. But the coffee is made beforehand and served in high volumes in a large bucket. I'm not sure how much sugar was inserted in that bucket, but the iced coffee was way too sweet.  I may skip the coffee here next time. 

My Visa was accepted here. 

The staff and owner were very friendly to me. Surprisingly, the food is just as good as any other Vietnamese deli. I feel the love at this hip restaurant.
author: Matt G.

description:
We tried the five spice chicken and the lemongrass pork sandwiches. The chicken was bland so I was happy I split and only had to eat half! The lemongrass pork sandwich was more flavorful. Both sandwiches were piled high with veggies.

Eat at the bar and watch them throw these concoctions together. Meal and a show!
author: Schelly Y.

description:
I just wasted $7 on the WORST Banh Mi ever!

Let me preface by saving that I have absolutely no qualms about spending $7, $10, or even $15 on a sandwich; a good sandwich is a good sandwich period. And given that Bun Mee is a hipster, fusion type establishment located in Pac Heights, one of the most exclusive areas in San Francisco, the higher prices are to be expected. However, what I have a problem is wasting money on a poorly made and flavorless sandwich.

For those who have read my reviews, I often note that not very keen on fusion cuisine because the flavors tend to be dumb-downed in order to appeal to the general public. But lately I have been having a good streak with fusion cuisine: Curry Up Now, Bushi-Tei, Betelnut, etc, so when I saw Bun Mee on the "Hot on Yelp" list today, I wanted to give it a shot.

Today, 4.4.11, I came to Bun Mee at around 6:05 PM. As soon as I walked in, an employee said, they were "closed" but then I could still order. I asked what time they normally close and he said, "Today at 6 PM, tomorrow at 7 PM, the next day at 8 PM and eventually at 9 or 10 PM" because they've been running out of things. Err, ok...not to sound harsh, but as a business owner, if you know you've been running out of things shouldn't you plan accordingly? It's plain commonsense, but anyhow...

I wanted to order the Belly Bun (Pork Belly Sandwich) but they were out of that, go figure; so I opted for the Bun Mee Combo - Roasted Pork, Pate de Campagne, Mortadella, Garlic Aioli, Onions, Pickled Carrots & Daikon, Cucumber, Jalapenos and Cilantro ($7.12 including tax).

When I was handed my order, juices started to soak through the paper wrapping and onto my hands which was already not a good sign. As I unwrapped the sandwich, the sandwich looked very unappetizing and sad as the only meat I saw was a slice of deli ham which was suppose to be the mortadella. Here's a pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_KtkAiwyxHbkn9O6yEMvjA?select=-jKCGO0uryFv3PBnbYUSzA

One of the essential components of a good, authentic Banh Mi is the bread; the french baguette should be light, crusty and chewy with a fluffy center. The combo of meats along with the accoutrements of the pickled veggies, cilantro, jalepenos and mayo (often egg yolk based) should pop with layers of salty, savory, tangy, sweet and sour flavors.

Keeping in mind that the Bun Mee Combo was fusion based, this banh mi was poorly excuted and lacked most, if not all, of the flavor profiles that a authentic banh mi has. Within minutes, the baguette was soggy and wet in the middle. The fillings were very scant; the little roast pork and one slice of "mortadella" in the banh mi got completely lost in the bread. There didn't seem to be any pate or at least I couldn't taste any as there was no hint of that rich, slightly gamey taste. The very few slivers of pickled daikon and carrots there were was bland and lacked the pungent sweet and sour flavor that I'm accustomed to. Sadly, it was a bahn mi FAIL.

If you're a loyal fan and/or have tried Saigon Sandwiches in the TL (http://www.yelp.com/biz/saigon-sandwich-san-francisco) which is the BEST bahn mi in SF in my opinion, you will probably be very disappointed in Bun Mee's version especially for twice the cost. 

If you're a Saigon Sandwich virgin and/or looking for an authentic banh mi jam packed with fillings and bold flavors, you MUST try it! For ~$3, this hole-in-the-wall will tantalize every one of your taste buds and leave you wanting more. 

2 stars is being extra generous; 1 star for the friendly service and 1 star for filling my belly with empty carbs. 

Sorry, Bun Mee but I wouldn't want to "Bun" you again...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Date & Time:  Thursday March 31, 2011 @ 6pm
Location:  Former Ciao Gelato Spot
Dining Companions:  Mommy & Michael
Scene:  Pac Height Couples:  Lululemon Blondes in Chanel Shades Accompanied by Athleta-Clad Guys in Ray Ban Aviators
Vibe:  Chill
Music:  Hip Hop
Decor:  Modern Retro.  Recycled Wood Benches & Tables.
Service:  Attractive Asian Women
Imbibe:  Limeade & Vietnamese Iced Coffee
Devour:  Belly Bun, 5-Spiced Chicken, Pork Belly Bahn Mi's w/ Egg & Side Order of Sweet Potato Fries & Chocolate Coconut Cookie
Total:  $30.45
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
3.5 stars.

Definitely overpriced but the sandwiches are yummy (I highly recommend getting a fried egg because it will make anything you order at least twenty times better)!  If I'm in the area, I'll definitely stop by here for a bite to eat.

The one thing that is majorly disappointing is the lack of vegetarian options.  I love eggplant, but their eggplant banh mi just did not sound appetizing to me.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
IMHO, the most important part of a good banh mi is the bread, and Bun Mee has that part down perfectly.  The baguettes here are just the perfect texture: crunchy crust with a soft and light center.  Most other banh mi places I've tried in the area use much harder bread which takes away from the whole experience of a good banh mi sandwich. 

What's also cool here is that while you will find the traditional Vietnamese combination banh mi here, you will also find some less than traditional interpretations here.  Sloppy Joe banh mi with a fried egg?  Pork belly banh mi? Check and check!  They call them "gourmet banh mi-inspired sandwiches".

Now, don't let the "gourmet" part scare you.  Sure, they are on Fillmore where rent is high.  Sure, if you compare them to the super dingy, hole-in-the-wall, traditional banh mi shops, you may think of them as expensive.  But the sandwiches here are still priced extremely reasonably, and with the quality of the ingredients, I'm happy to pay the few extra dollars.

Did I mention this place is adorable?  The owners really put a lot of care and time into every part of the design and decor, and it really shows!
author: Cindy C.

description:
One of, if not THE best banh mi sandwiches I've ever had.  And the Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl is pretty amazing as well...especially their white garlic rice.

Just be prepared to swoop up on a table as soon as one becomes available...
author: Rose A.

description: Simple flavor filled food created with great produce. We headed there with our 8 month old and they were very accommodating. The atmosphere was relaxed the service was great. We come from the other side of the world, however would venture to this spot again when in San Fran. Highly recommended!
author: Jacob B.

description:
HIPSTER BANH MI SHOP!!!
(3.75 / 4 stars)

This place brings something new to the area!!!! Hip place for vietnamese sandwiches. Just glad I didnt have to worry if it was mistery meat or liver spread in my sandwich. Sandwichs are prepared to target the locals of this neighborhood (if you know what i mean). It definately is not the most authentic vietnamese sandwhich i've had in my life. Nor was it the worst or best. But i've rated it 3.75 / 4 stars because the meal left me satisfied and I left saying "i'd come back again". AND the most important, its such a clean spot and i'm all about sanitary places to get my banh mi fix.

CUTE NAME!! Bun mee = banh mi

* Food, good
* Prices, pricy-ish for banh mi but affordable for the area (lower pac heights)
* Service, great friendly staff
* Ambiance, clean, simple, cozy, small spot

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

***See pictures***

GRILLED 5 SPICE CHICKEN ($5.95) - that was the most tender chicken i've ever had in a banh mi / vietnamese sandwich. It made the sandwich much more tastier then it looked. Spice? My palate is sensative to spice and I felt like I only recieved 0.005 spice instead of 5 spice. I had wish my sandwich had more cilantro as it only had 1 stem of cilantro. The french bread was fresh, easy to eat - unlike other places the bread is too toasted (or old) where the texture is hard. I'd definately order this again.

GREEN PAPAYA SALAD ($3.50) - enjoyed the papaya salad. it was very fresh and had that great kick to it that really complimented the sandwich. people may complain the blandness of the sandwich, well next time they should order this salad because its pretty flavorful and will balance the blandness out.

HOUSE-MADE STRAWBERRY LYCHEE AGUA FRESA ($2.50) - oh WOW now that was a refreshing drink. I'd probably have to order 2 of these in my next sitting. I cannot explain how yummy this drink was.

If I had brought friends who grew up eating authentic Vietnamese food to this establishment, they'd probably punch me in the face. Everyone else would probably appreciate the introduction and thank me.  


Will I be back? I can definately do this place again.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
God. I hate myself for enjoying this sandwich. For enjoying this chipotle-tizing of my beloved Vietnamese food. 

I ordered the lemongrass pork as this was the closest thing on the menu to something that would actually be on a Vietnamese sandwich.  (where's the thit nguoi btw?). I was so ready to hate it.  How dare they try to improve the perfect sandwich?

And damn it. I liked it. It was actually good.  

I think my problem is that they're calling it a Banh Mi and are charging 8 bucks for it.  I remember when Banh Mi's were $1 each!!  And yet, I have no qualms with paying $11 for sandwich from ike's which is equally as filling. I guess if they just called it a sandwich on a french baguette I wouldn't be so mad.

This really makes me think. My roommate hates Mission Chinese. He feels like it's a bastardization of his beloved Chinese home cooking. And here I am waiting in line just like everyone else for their thrice cooked bacon and pastrami.  Now I know how he feels, it's this fusion of Western and Easter tastes, clashing with my strong Vietnamese sensibilities.  I considered him too conservative, too... Old World when it came to this topic.  I said to myself, things change, things evolve.  They pick up new bits and pieces of every culture it passes through.  I'm sure even the Banh Mi from a legit Vietnamese place doesn't taste like the sandwiches in Vietnam.

Bah, get off my lawn.
author: Tu T.

description:
I have to hand it to Bun Mee - after at least a year of being open, they have stayed pretty consistently good and reliable. I love Vietnamese food, so there's very little on their menu that I don't like. If I had to pick a favorite, it would probably be the banh mi (sandwiches), but I've had the bun (noodle bowls) and rice bowls, too.

If you're ordering takeaway, you can order online without paying, and then drop in to pay and pick up your order. The online ordering system always gives you an estimated time way too far in the future (like 30-45 minutes), but apparently they receive orders immediately and fill them as quickly as they can, so don't think you can't go by earlier and pick up your grub.

Recommended for a cheap, casual bite to eat, either eat-in or takeaway. On a sunny day, you can sit outside on the sidewalk and tempt passersby.
author: Andrew M.

description: The wife wanted to know why I keep adding Sriracha sauce, "isn't hot enough with the jalapeños?", then we walked over to Smitten...
author: James G.

description:
I am a sucker for sandwiches! What do you get when you mix French baguettes with Vietnamese meets and vegetables? Bánh Mì!

Church Street, Hayes Valley, and the Fillmore districts have become a haven for trendy food and for those that want something "gourmet". 

Nestled in the Fillmore, Bun Mee is a great example for modernized Vietnamese flair, notably their Bánh Mì. When ever I am in the Fillmore, I can't but help myself for a Bun Mee sandwich.

Delicious, fresh, and uniquely theirs; I cannot find a reason to not recommend this establishment. 

You must try their Combination Pork (like the classic, but with two additional pork additions - which, to me, makes it even better than the original). The other stellar option is their Belly Bun (pork belly and classic vegetable inners, which is by far my favorite - slow cooked pork belly that melts in your mouth paired with crisp greens and a crunchy yet soft baguette). MMMMMMM. 

Little Paris of Chinatown (another of my favorite Bánh Mì establishments), watch out, because you have an equally good competitor in town!

One word, "YUM!".
author: Alex C.

description: My friends and I had an enjoyable time here last week. Service was at a great pace, and didn't feel like we were rushed to make an order. It was really good, and we are already making plans to come back again.
author: Jadrian G.

description:
Let's put the cultural authenticity standards aside for a sec.  

Damn, the Belly Bun is scrumptious!  That kurobuta pork belly was major tasty, gooey goodness.  And the Sloppy Bun was not too shabby with its well-seasoned sloppy joeness...not sure where the curry came in...and not sure how it's on the 7x7 list.

The pickled veggies were crunchy, fresh counterpoints in both sandwiches.  The bread was a revelation - toasty, flaky on the outside; tender and porous enough to be soppable (yeah, soak up all that juice) on the inside.  Thank you, Bun Mee, for not going the traditional banh mi route with dense, hard bread that tastes like foam.  

After all, there are some disadvantages to being a slave to the authentic.

PS: This is the perfect, casual spot for refueling during a long, hard day of shopping along Fillmore.
author: Sandy C.

description:
I've decided to not trust the 7x7 list anymore with Asian food.
The Sloppy Bun is listed on the 2013 list as one of the "big eats".
I really disliked it.  The ground beef is supposed to be "red curry" flavor according to the menu, but to me, this tasted just like a sloppy joe.  Like one from grade school. ::shudder::  I didn't like them in grade school, and I don't like them now.

The basil and pickled vegetables (that come with all Vietnamese sandwiches) were on the mild side, and couldn't save this sandwich.  I've tried some of their other sandwiches, and yes, they're good, but they're not great.  They can satisfy a craving.
Obviously the sandwiches are priced higher here (because it's on Fillmore street) than they should be otherwise.  If I have the time, I definitely head to Saigon Sandwich in the Tenderloin for my banh mi fix.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
My friend had never had banh mi before so I decided to take him here as a new experience for the both of us. 

The place itself is really nice. The atmosphere is cute and relaxing. I like that it's clean and has enough space for people to sit and enjoy their food. 

We ordered the Hanoi catfish banh mi, grilled pork banh mi, a basket of sweet potato fries, chocolate coconut cookies, and a limeade for myself.

The limeade was good, but very sweet. A little too sweet for me. The sweet potato fries were good too! I liked the curry aioli sauce a lot. 

The grilled pork banh mi was average. I liked it enough but have had better. The catfish banh mi, however, was the best! I don't normally like fish sandwiches but it was great! I love that it was crispy but not oily and it really did taste very good on it's own.

The cookies were saved for last. A simple concept, but tasty outcome. I don't even typically like coconut but it was good. The coconut creme inside was very sweet. It says that the cookie made it onto a list of top cookies in SF, but I think they're okay. 

Overall, I like Bun Mee. It's not a favorite on my banh mi list mainly because I don't like the bread that much compared to Dinosaurs or Saigon Sandwich but I would go back for the catfish banh mi. I would like to try their other items too.
author: Sofia R.

description:
My review is for their Vietnamese Iced Coffee.  It's pretty bad. For $4.20 I expected it to be authentic.

Nope.

It tasted like that bottled Starbucks frappacino beverage.  I see from previous reviews that they make it every two days or so in a big batch and scoop it out of a vat......

....Just.no.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Busy little place; 5-6 tables inside and a couple outside. Absolutely delicious, my smokey eggplant sandwich, slathered with red curry mayo, a dollop of cauliflower relish and topped with super fresh veggies. Staff efficient and very friendly. I'm coming back to try everything else on the menu beginning with the Handi-style crispy catfish sandwich!!  Just DO it!!!
author: Joan M.

description:
Stumbled upon this place during my last S.F. visit and was hungry so I thought I'd give it a try. It is cute and charming like nearly every neighborhood establishment in this city. That is, really, to be expected. It's small, not very many seats, so depending on your luck there's a good chance you won't find one. 

My friend and I ordered and sat at a four top but when it got a little busy, decided to move to a recently vacated two top so someone else could sit at our table. It really miffed the guy working because he had to clean our table and set it unexpectedly. He made it clear that he didn't like what we had done. To be fair, he was the only one working and was doing several jobs. He later warmed up to us in an effort to override his earlier rudeness.

We ordered two sandwiches with no sides. Sandwiches are $6-7 but sides are an extra $2-3 and we didn't want to spend that much without knowing if it was good. My crispy catfish was delicious. I loved the sourdough bread and everything on it. But it isn't a lot of food. This is a perfect snack for one of those "grazing" days when you just want to wander the city and try things without getting full.
author: Angelique L.

description: Thank you Bun Me. I ordered take out and when I got home, I found a hair in my sandwich. I called them and they said they would give me a free one next time I came in. I asked if they could deliver me a new one since my baby was sleeping and I couldn't leave the house...a total long shot. But they said they would and even came to my front door. Thank you so much for keeping a hungry mom fed without having to wake the baby!
author: Karen H.

description:
This is my first review as San Francisco's newest transplant. Yes, I took the crazy (and wildly expensive) dive to live in the Bay. Luckily, I'm enjoying this move thanks to the delicious food this city has to offer. Bun Mee has the distinct honor of being my first SF Yelp review mainly because it's one of my favorite neighborhood discoveries so far. 

I've known about this spot for some time, but each instance I've visited SF over the last year, I didn't have a minute to drop in. I live in the neighborhood so now I have to chance to. I went in the other night and was quite pleased with the food, the pricing, and the variety of items... oh, and I personally found the setting (and surrounding area) quite charming! 

I ordered the lemongrass pork banh mi, the pork belly bowl with brown rice, sweet potato fries, and the strawberry lychee drink. Now, I am well aware this is not the most "authentic" (this word is problematic -- sorry, it's the academic in me) Vietnamese food (as my mom reminded me repeatedly when she came in with me: "Umm... this isn't traditional Vietnamese!" "HAHA I know, Mom. That's part of the point." "Hmm... okay..." "Let's just give it a try... please!"). Nevertheless, I liked the banh mi very much. The pork was deliciously seasoned and the fried egg (for $1 extra) added some moistness to an otherwise semi-dry sandwich. Of course, the pickled daikon, cucumber, and carrots are essential for this and they were awesome. The pork belly bowl was quite massive and a "steal" (at least for SF) in price. The pork belly was braised beautifully and the accompanying sides were sorta sweet and spicy. The spicy cauliflower added a fantastic "oomph!" in flavors. The brown rice made this bowl quite substantial and could easily be eaten over two meals or between two people. The sweet potato fries are fantastic and the red curry mayo dipping sauce completed this cheap side of fried pleasure!! The strawberry lychee drink was lovely --- though I have to admit a bit on the sweet side. It could've used a couple tablespoons less sugar or simple syrup. 

I liked the setting. We sat in the sorta-awkward booth facing the doorway, but I liked that we were able to watch sidewalk traffic. That's always a simple pleasure -- and free entertainment of course! In case you wanted to know the clientele: Well, what do you expect? Bougie "hipster aesthetic" Yuppies! (It's fine. I too enjoy my plaid shirts, corduroy, and brown suede shoes. How stereotypical of me!) The service was alright. They bring the food out to you and while they don't "wait" on you, I'd like a little enthusiasm or at least a smile with the delivery. I'll pass on that side of passive aggressive smile with my Vietnamese sandwich please, thanks! Eh... I'm over it. Oh, and in case you were wondering, the opinion of this place from my mother (who is critical of non-hole-in-the-wall spots) --- she approved of Bun Mee. I guess that says something! Enjoy.
author: James Z.

description:
Solid bet for quick and healthy Vietnamese basics at a workable price. They also have great takeout you can order with the Eat24 app if you live in the neighborhood. 

I run in often for a summer rolls or a five-spice chicken salad. 

Decor is also great, and staff is friendly.
author: Laura J.

description:
I had the Bun Noodle Bowl with Grilled Chicken which was very good and hit the spot. It is 
vermicelli noodles, lettuce, pickled carrots, cucumbers, roasted peanuts, shallots, mint, cilantro, nuoc cham sauce, pork eggroll, and grilled chicken. Watch out for the chills, they pack a punch. I liked that it was the right portion size and not too big.
author: Sunil R.

description: How does this place have such low reviews? The Belly bun is one of the most stupid good things I've eaten in a long time. Go here. Get the belly bun. Enjoy the succulence.
author: Autumn B.

description:
Only had the sandwiches. The bread always hurts my mouth, too dry-too sharp.

I may go back and try something else, but for now its not my first choice.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Inspired by the delicious sandwich I just bought, I want to review this place NOW! Now mind you, I just ate lunch and walked down to the  place to see the menu. I ended up buying a roast pork sandwich and ate half of it on the way back to work.

Four stars because it's pricey for Vietnamese sandwiches; it's on Fillmore Street, so I'm not surprised. The wait for my sandwich to-go was less than 10 minutes, but also there weren't a lot of people.

The sandwich roll was nice and crispy, soft on the inside. My pork was tender and nicely seasoned, paired up with refreshing pickled carrots, daikons, heated up by the crunchy jalepenos, I was enamored with my first bite. It was refreshingly delicious.

I must have said, "wow," a few times on the way back to work. I NEVER say "wow" and "work" in the same sentence! 

Must be that good!

They have more than just sandwiches, they've got salads and desserts, but I didn't have time to peruse the whole menu, I wanted to try the meat of the place~ sandwiches!
author: Sharon B.

description:
We were in the area and debating lunch. Should we try a place something new or go for something we know? I'd heard about Bun Mee down in the FiDi and when we saw it, we figured why not go for something different and try it!

Despite it being lunch time on a Saturday, this location isn't busy at all. There were a few people seated in the restaurant, a few at the outside seating, and only one person ahead of us. We ordered the Crunchy Tofu sandwich, the Lemongrass Pork sandwich, and a side of Salt & Pepper Garlic fries to share. We got our number, grabbed a seat and waited for the food to come out.

Service was quick and polite, and our food arrived in under five minutes. First off, the sandwiches were made to order (one without jalapenos, the other without mayo). The pickled vegetables were crisp and sour, the cilantro fresh and tasty! I loved every bit of my crunchy tofu and ate almost the entire sandwich. The only reason I couldn't finish it was due to the fries that came topped with salt and pepper and bits of jalapenos and fresh garlic. There's not a lot of garlic on them, so if you're looking for true "garlic fries", this isn't it, but between the various seasonings and toppings, plus the insane crispness of these fries, you're not going to care!

The price was incredibly reasonable, although definitely more than the more authentic hole-in-the-wall bahn mi places, but it's the Fillmore and Lower Pac Heights, so what else do you expect.

I'm looking forward to putting this place on my list of "places to regularly get a sandwich at".
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Tasty sandwiches and refreshing drinks in a great neighborhood.

You can get cheaper Vietnamese fare elsewhere, but not with this ambience & location!  Good for a nice, casual bite or some take out.

Staff was friendly, but it can get pretty busy so the usual harriedness sets in during busy spurts.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
I had the Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish Sandwich and Vietnamese Coffee. The catfish and toppings were fresh and it was quite tasty. The Vietnamese Coffee was ok. I still like Thai Ice Teas better, but Vietnamese Coffee may eventually grow on me.

The place was clean and the service was fast. Very refreshing lunch on those beautiful warm sunny days in San Francisco.
author: Christian E.

description:
This place is great for a work lunch to-go or if you want something fast and convenient. 

Combo Sandwich - nice flavor, bread is just ok.

Catfish Sandwich - a lot more plain and bland compared to the combo. Stick with the Combo.

Venue is clean and modern with plenty of seating.
author: Katrina L.

description:
Bun Mee epitomizes the kind of banh mi that bourgeois white people dream of:

1. A heftier price tag marked almost twice as high as a standard sandwich from a Vietnamese deli to delude you into thinking that quality and farm-raised/sustainable whatevers won't be compromised. 
2. Admittedly more quality meats, because anything from an unidentifiable animal part would make them balk.
3. Really mild, unoffending, and bland flavors -- with all the wonderful pungent notes and spices of an actual banh mi being squelched for the opportunity to douse one's sandwich in Sriracha (which, by the way, I love as much as anyone else but I'm not a big fan of needing to sauce up my sandwich after I've already paid the premium price tag for you to hopefully flavor it properly for me to eat as is).
4. To top it off, everything is served to you by a bearded hipster man or a female in plaid and Warby Parker glasses. The slightly cleaned up versions compared to Mission folks for the Pac Heights crowd, but still trendy enough so that it still feels like a cool and modern place to frequent.

I'm totally not above a bastardized version of any ethnic food item if it's tasty and warranted. This exception absolutely did not apply here. 

Pass.
author: Betty W.

description:
I'll admit it, I'm the last person that should be reviewing a Vietnamese shop. I've had my fair share of bahn mi, but by no means didn't grow up on the deliciousness.

Popped in for an early dinner to-go. Staff was friendly and the space was cute. I'd happily dine if if looking for something quick and casual. Good variety of beer and a few wines on tap. 

We tried the saigon peanut bowl with pork, and the fried catfish sandwich. The bowl was good but the sauce to rice ratio was off, so once you got past the top layer of food, there wasn't much sauce left. Good portion size though. The sandwich was also tasty, but same issue with the ratio. Two tiny pieces of catfish + too much bread and not enough veg...boo. 

A solid three stars.
author: Brianna M.

description:
For something that's featured on the 7x7 list and suppose to be finger licking good... I am not impressed. 

We ordered the sloppy bun, the pork belly bowl and each got a strawberry Lychee drink. 

We proceeded to sit by the bar since there was not a lot of seating. The bar stools were really close together so I was trying to space out my stool so that I could get in. Without saying anything the waitress takes the chair I was going to sit on and pulls it in the back. Um okay. 1) I was going to sit on it and 2) if you were just going to take it you could have said "oh let me help you with that" Rude much? Very much so. 

Sloppy bun: like I said early. Not impressed. I could have made it at home. Just an egg, some ground meat. Nothing mind blowing. Will never order it again. 

Pork belly bowl: not bad. The meat was succulent. Garlic rice was flavorful. Topped with a over easy egg. Worth ordering again if I had to come back. (The only reason there are 2 stars and not 1)

Strawberry lychee: overly sweet. Would have been better if I added more water to it. Wasn't to crazy about it. The lychee included in it was good but then again they didn't have to make that.





Pork belly bowl

Service/ Vw
author: Victoria L.

description: Convenient, tasty, and fairly priced (for SF standards).  I usually get the catfish or the steak.  Eating in usually gives you the best experience as I find the bread and meats can get soggy by the time you get your to-go back to where you wanna eat it.  Fast service and a well rounded menu mean you can find something that suits your fancy.   I think their Vietnamese coffee is tasty, but on the sweet side.
author: Bobby L.

description:
$7 is a bit steep for a Banh Mi, but if you're in Pacific Heights, I suppose that's the price. 

I tried out the Fried Catfish Sandwich; and after reading a couple reviews, I agree that the carrots they provide in the sandwich is a bit excessive. My sandwich had more carrots than anything else in the sandwich. The food was great and I definitely could have eaten a lot more after that one sandwich. 

Will be back if I'm too lazy to go to Chinatown for a Banh Mi.
author: Sam K.

description:
It isn't too often that I'll eat a sandwich for dinner, but I made an exception when I came here. It's a small place with only one bathroom, so I would advise against coming during their busiest times.

I ordered the Bun Mee Combo: grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, pate de campagne, mortadella, garlic mayo, onions, pickled carrot and daikon, jalapenos, cucumber, and cilantro for $6.75. Juicy meat, good portion, friendly staff, and plenty of filling. The only complaint I have is that I would have liked the bread to be softer. In particular, the ends were too hard (not crispy) for my liking. It was like eating toasted bread that had gone cold after sitting out for a day or two.
author: Christina L.

description: Delivery; Preparation time was fast, price was reasonable, presentation was on point and accessories/containers were good. Will e calling for delivery again.
author: Daniel D.

description:
Came here around 6 on a Saturday night - seemed like every place on Fillmore was slammed, so we ended up here. Maybe we should have considered that a sign...

- Hawker Bowl with steak: Very bland and the meat was chewy and didn't seem fresh, so I opted not to finish it (and I was hungry!).
- Sweet potato fries: Soggy and oily, though the red curry mayo was delicious.
- Grilled Lemongrass Pork sandwich: Pretty tasteless.

The worst part? As I walked to the back of the restaurant to use the bathroom, I saw three of the line cooks eating out of the food storage containers with their bare hands. Yikes! 

Sorry Bun Mee - I'll wait to eat someplace else next time I'm on Fillmore.
author: Michelle V.

description: I love this place. Really good customer service skills by the staff. Nice friendly greetings, always. Suggestions and explanations from the order-takers. The place is so clean. A busser is constantly making the rounds. Last but not least, the bun- mee sandwiches are delicious and served on the crispest baguettes.
author: Paula H.

description:
I'm a sucker for beautiful sign-painting, I admit it. And New Bohemian Signs did this whole place up, which is really the only reason you should stop by to see this place.

We sat at the counter for a quick dinner and tried to get something old-style and new-style - Pork vermicelli bowl, and their Sloppy Joe-style banh mi sandwich. Both were pretty bland and unmemorable. The  former was especially unforgivable in its lack of fish sauce, or really any distinctive flavor...we found ourselves having to force ourselves to finish (which usually never happens when we're confronted with a Vietnamese vermicelli bowl). The latter was okay, just ground, saucy meat that just felt messy and pretty hardcore American (no Asian or Vietnamese twist that would explain its presence here).

Really, I know sometimes it's scary to go to a hole-in-wall Vietnamese place that seems way more unclean than this very chic-looking spot, but I guarantee that your taste buds will be happier.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Bun Mee is one of my favorite lunch spots to go to during the week. Though their spot is a bit small in space, it is very cozy inside. They also deliver to certain locations (either free or for a small charge, $3-$5 depending on location) which is very convenient for the days you want to stay in the office for lunch.  I called for delivery one afternoon at around 11:30, and although it says delivery may take up to an hour, my food arrived in 30 minutes despite it being a busy time for lunch. 

My hands-down favorite item here is the sloppy bun, which is packed with flavor and a slight kick of jalapeños. I also ordered the chocolate coconut cream cookie which was featured in 7x7 magazine's best cookie list, but I wasn't too happy with it. For $1.50, I had expected it to be a standard sized cookie, but instead it was more like the size of an Oreo. Pretty small for the price in my opinion. Also, the one I received didn't seem fresh and was slightly stale. 

But nevertheless, I remain a satisfied customer with this establishment.
author: Marilyn H.

description: Got the Lemongrass Pork sandwich. DELICIOUS. The sweet potato fries are happenin' as well.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Bun Mee is actually a really delicious place. I've been here once before to get sandwiches to go and it was really good. No doubt I had a great sandwich. I came by a few months ago again and had the pork sandwich - yum! I love their take on a great Vietnamese sandwich - although more expensive and a little smaller than what you can get a hole-in-the-wall place. 

Overall - great food!
author: Nina Y.

description:
When I want a tasty variation on the lunch-time sandwich, I come here.

Bun Mee specializes in Vietnamese sandwiches - which is a whole other level of sandwiches.

I usually order the Grilled Pork sando (Grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, garlic mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro) or the Sloppy Bun (Red curry ground beef, house garlic mayo, shaved onion, thai basil, jalapenos). Wow - talk about a delicious sandwich! These sandwiches are oozing with protein, spice/heat, and a bunch of other goodness served on fresh baked bread for under $7.

Now I know that a lot of Vietnamese sandwich purists are going to balk at Bun Mee's price (you can essentially get the same meal for $4 or less in the Tenderloin). But you know what - $7 for a great sandwich in a safe, sunny neighborhood is worth the price.

If you're not in a sandwich mood, the restaurant also serves tasty noodle bowls, salads, and appetizers (eg pork and shrimp rolls).

The place can be a bit crowded during peak hours, and it's not the most comfortable place for sit-down dining (I would recommend getting your food to-go).
author: Kevin B.

description:
I think this is overpriced Vietnamese food.  Anyone from San Jose will smack you sideways if you told them you paid $8 for a Vietnamese sandwich.  The sandwiches I thought were just OK, but I've grown to like other things on their menu besides the traditional sandwich.

I have to say their "chicken" salad is the best salad on Filmore, especially for the price.  I say "chicken" because I always replace the chicken with grilled pork.  So I normally get  a (almost always) warm grilled pork salad with an awesome lemon vinaigrette salad dressing  for $9.75 (w/ out tax).  I've tried their steak salad with actual steak and was not impressed.  The steak was over cooked and the salad dressing was super potent w/ garlic.  I would advise against the dressing if you're eating with someone besides yourself.

Pros: They deliver within the area for a minimum order/ "chicken" salad/ sloppy bun
Cons:  Delivery takes forever/ garlic dressing/ traditional Viet sandwiches that should only cost $3.50
author: Mrs. N.

description: Although more expensive than place in the 'Loin or in the Inner/Outer Richmond, this place offers a scaled-up, gourmet experience.  All of their sandwiches are great. Their bread-- arguably one the most important components-- is toasted well. You can't always get the bread 100%, but this place has been solid in the dozen or so times I have eaten here. In particular, I love the combo sandwich (with pate), the 5-spice chicken and the catfish, although the latter is fried. I still would like to try the sardine. Their Shredded Napa Salad is a perfect compliment as are their salad rolls (both veg and non-veg.) I am happy this place opened and has stayed that way.
author: Brian J.

description:
Yum bun mee!

I had the fried catfish sandwich and the lady had the crispy tofu sandwich...both super tasty fillings in that great french roll. Quality stuff. Got a seat at the bar had some lunch and watched them cook up all the other delicious items on the menu...had been meaning to come here for some time so will definitely be back to try something else!
author: Derek S.

description: Fatty flavourless pork. Dry bread. I had visited here before and I remember it being much better, maybe it was an off day for them. I will be reluctant to return though as there is so many other places where I can get a similar product.
author: Hannah H.

description: After having gone to Out the Door for lunch today and ordering the EXACT same dish (Lemongrass Pork Noodle Bowl), I'm convinced that for the price, Bun Mee's is significantly better.  Their pork is much more flavorful (Out the Door was WAY overcooked), the nuoc cham is significantly better here, and there was a larger bowl of noodles and vegetables.  I can't stress enough how much I've developed a serious appreciation for Bun Mee.  It may be that I've moved out of the  neighborhood so I'm suffering from separation anxiety, but after today, it confirmed that I really do love here.
author: Lisa I.

description: Generally, a banh mi is usually inexpensive. At Bun Mee they charge a bit more but the quality merits the price. For me, it's a toss between the 5 spice chicken and the combination. Also, you can't go wrong with either the sweet potatoe fries or the spicy fries. One order can easily be shared by two without feeling guilty about the added calories. A perfect light lunch if you are strolling Fillmore Street.
author: Thomas B.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and I approve of this place. I've had their combo sandwich and the turmeric catfish. All good. The only problem is that I'm use to paying less for my Vietnamese sandwiches, but you do get your money's worth here. The meat is lean and everything tastes fresh! 

If you're on the run and need to grab a quick lunch, try this place.
author: Logan N.

description: Shrimp/pork spring rolls were ok. Nothing special. They should throw in more pork and shrimp. Had the pork belly Bahn mi. It was very tasty but a small sandwich for a hungry appetite. You can get a similar sandwich elsewhere for $5.
author: Marat Y.

description:
While service was friendly, and food served fairly quick, this was really disappointing in the flavor arena.
We tried the combo and the pork belly. It wasn't that anything was wrong with the food, it just had no distinct flavors. Certainly not traditional Bahn Mi here. Bland meat on a French roll with jalapeños, carrot, a slice of cucumber here and there, and a few sprigs of cilantro. 
Don't see a return to this place in the future.
author: Robert M.

description:
I was so disappointed with Bun Mee! 

I ordered online through GrubHub. I asked for the Saigon peanut bowl with garlic rice and tofu. They sent brown rice, not garlic, and left out the papaya and daikon! All they gave me was a TON of *cold* brown rice, a few flimsy slices of tofu, shredded carrots and cucumber. Not to mention the $5 delivery fee!!! Absolutely ridiculous. It cost me almost $40 for two rice bowls and one cookie.  Won't be ordering from here again.
author: Madeline W.

description: I love and crave Bun Mee all the time.  Today I had their grilled lemongrass pork sandwich with a friend egg, and I was in heaven.  I love that is serves excellent food with no frills.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Being a poor college student in Davis, I used to always bike to downtown and get the $2.50 vietnamese sandwiches.  The crunchy bread, the cilantro, meat and perfectly acidic pickles was the perfect cheap lunch.  

Being all 'grown up', married, and living in the city now, i was super excited to have found a vietnamese sandwich spot on fillmore. You can imagine my disappointment when a $6.50 sandwich that I've looked forward a couple weeks for was less than subpar.  

The crunchy bread was great. But aside from that, the meats were either dry or one dimensional in flavor (even the 5 spice chicken).  The pickles were the most disappointing part.  With the thick bread, hint of sweet meat, the pickles really needed to deliver in the acid.. but felt completely flat.  It was way too sweet and wasn't crunchy. nononono. Oh and don't even get me started on their soggy anorexic sweet potato fries. (I put the pic up) 

Aside from that, I liked that they had a good nonalcoholic drink selection (although their beer selection is terrible).  Their service was nice and friendly.  But that doesn't make up for the fact that there is no where to sit after you buy your food.  


Yay:

Thick, crunchy bread
Non alcoholic drinks (though I can't vouch if they're not good or not)
Sweet service


Nay:

Soggy, incredibly thin fries
Too sweet and not acidic enough pickles in sandwich
lack of flavor in meats
Tiny area, hard to get seats
Bad beer (selection of 2)
author: Hannah W.

description:
Bun Mee's game is banh mi, fushionista style. decor is similar to a cafe/sandwich shop. there's seating and the menus on the left wall. (i always look ahead or to the right). didn't go bahn mi, thought meters were being enforced and i parked in a yellow zone. (they weren't, found out free parking today)
 
drink: 
-strawberry lychee drink(2.5)
very sweet talking with a lump of lychee on the bottom. drink didn't taste strawberry nor lychee

eats:
-mango lettuce salad(about 4oz, scoutmob freebie)
diced lettuce with minimango cubes,  flavored with fish sauce, some spiciness.
flavoring not even. much of salad had no seasoning.   3 stars.

leftovers:
-parking hard to find
-didn't bring scoutmob voucher, brought code. offer honored anyways . cool!
-service impeccable, very friendly  4.5 stars.
author: Victor G.

description:
Overall: ultra Americanized sandwiches x 10

Pros
- sweet potato fries

Cons
- expensive non-Vietnamese tasting sandwiches
- pickled veggies are no where near pickled
- no special mayo
- the bread is beyond gross
- sloppy "bun mee" with egg
- catfish "bun mee"

Sidenote: If you ever had a real "banh mi" and liked it, then this is not for you.
author: Michelle D.

description: Best 5 Spice Banh Mi I have ever had. It had a delicious caramel mayo served on a light baguette with scrumptious pickled cukes, daikon & carrot...Can i open a franchise here?
author: Bryn R.

description: Bun Mee is not bad, but not amazing. I'd put it like this. If I am in the neighborhood already and craving a banh mi sandwich, then I wouldn't mind stopping by this place because it's decent. This is a great place for the location but if I had more time I would definitely venture farther and visit Cafe Bun Mi, Saigon Sandwich or Woolly Pig. I did appreciate the service and felt that they definitely go out of their way to provide customers with a positive experience. They are really friendly.
author: Alice H.

description:
When you go to Japan, you will get the death stare if you ask for soy sauce with your sushi. In Italy, you will be forever spurned if you dare ask for parmesan cheese to splatter over your perfect Italian pasta. In America, these things are expected and accepted. This is because most traditional food from other countries becomes Americanized along its journey to the states. General American consumerism seems to require ethnically diverse foods to cater to its palate.

What the hell does this have to do with Bun Mee you ask? Bun Mee is Americanized Vietnamese food. It is absolutely tasty, well made and a pleasure to eat, but not authentic. When you have tracked down authentic Banh Mi in the past, you know this right away. It's not necessarily a knock on Bun Mee, but something to note and something to consider in the larger picture of how ethnic food gets adjusted in America (see the long list of rolls on sushi menus with ridiculous names like Love Roll).

Bun Mee is an engaging restaurant to dip into off of FIllmore with very smart three-on-one-side seating with two benches in the window. You order at the counter, get a number and get your food quickly. The menu is diverse and intriguing if not authentic, but overpriced. 

The Bun Noodle Bowl (Vermicelli rice noodle, Mamma Tran's crispy egg roll, lettuce, pickled carrots and daikon, spicy cucumbers, Vietnamese herbs, cilantro, roasted peanuts, and crispy shallots served with a nuoc cham dipping sauce) was excellent once you mixed all the parts together - a flavorful bowl of goodness that is unfortunately overpriced at $13.75 once you add chicken. There's just not enough in the bowl to warrant almost 14 bucks.

The Belly Bun (Braised Kurobuta pork belly, salted radish relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro) is a better deal at $6.75, but the construction of the sandwich is more assembly line than assembly for the eater. All the delicious pork belly is at the bottom, then all the dressings are on the top so unless you have a mouth the size of Andre the Giant you will be taking one bite of all pork and the next of all veggies. To make this sandwich perfect, it needs to be mixed together before and not made Subway style just following the flow chart of ingredients.

With all that said, if you are not looking to eat truly authentic Vietnamese food and are looking for a hip, quick, stomach full of some tasty food, you won't be disappointed at Bun Mee.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Food still excellent (citrus rice bowl).

Agua fresca too sweet.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description: Arrived at 8:45 pm, ordered immediately. Sandwiches still not ready at 9:10pm. The place was empty! They just forgot about me!!! What? This place is horrible and totally unprofessional. Stay away from nasty tasting sandwiches that are totally overpriced and take 25 minutes to cook!
author: Ryan R.

description:
Stopped by Bun Mee for dinner some time last week and decided to order the special. 

Which was a fried chicken bahn mi with Asian napa slaw, jalapeno, Vietnamese mint, and coriander.

I was expecting the chicken to be super crispy, but it was actually kind of slimy. I don't really know how else to describe it, it was just weird. The slaw also made the sandwich really soggy. 

I general Bun Mee is great, I have never had a problem with anything I've ordered here before, but I do not think I would order this particular sandwich again.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Came by for lunch today to find strikers out front but that really didn't deter us since were here for the food and not the politics!

To our surprise the food was NOT what we remembered.  If MaMa Tran really
Made these crispy egg rolls she would certainly be disappointed.  They were cold and soggy served with 2 leaves of tired mint, then came our Carmel Bowl with Chicken & Hawker Bowl w Shrimp which were both packed with tons of cold rice and flavorless topping! 

We haven't been here for a while but my sister who lives down south mentioned it this morning so we decided to swing by for something quick & simple, too bad it ended up being so disappointing!
author: Gary W.

description: Soggy imperial rolls. Ugh. Not a single Asian person behind the counter or in the kitchen. Pre-made iced coffee. About as far away from genuine Vietnamese food as you could possibly get.
author: Adam S.

description:
There are few better ways to discourage repeat business than not delivering food. This place is empty and I've managed to outwait three other take out orders and a delivery guy (all after me).  I've read my whole Zite front page and now have time to dash off this review.

Oh and there goes the fourth take out order placed after mine.  

And a fifth.

Won't be back.
author: Scottie B.

description: Ordered papaya salad which was described as having shredded papaya.  When it was served I asked the server why there was no papaya.  She said it was crossed off the menu.  I showed her the clalk menu on wall with description of salad, but it was not crossed off .  Nor was I told when I ordered it that it no longer had papaya.
author: blaine s.

description: $5 delivery fee "based on SF bag ordinance"? So instead of the $.10 that is actually required by the ordinance, you decide to gouge for $5 and blame it on the city? Scam.
author: Preston B.

description:
This place is meh. I had a lemongrass pork bahn mi and it was so-so. Quality of ingredients seemed alright, but for some reason it didn't have the right flavor of a real Vietnamese sandwich.

If you're in the mood for bahn mi, I'd suggest you look elsewhere. Saigon Sandwich in the TL or Little Vietnam Cafe in the Richmond District are WAY better. Not to mention cheaper.
author: Cameron W.

description:
I've been getting my banh mi fix here regularly since they opened.  I suppose it's impressive that they've barely raised their prices in this neighborhood for the  ~1.25 years they've been open, as most sandwiches are only 25c more than the early prices (and dropped a little for some other items?).  That said, lately it seems to have some consistency issues compared to the earlier days of its existence.

Bought a sandwich one night recently, and now I have to worry a little more about eating bread that will scrape up my mouth.  At first I thought it was stale (toasting stale bread does not magically turn it fresh; it just trades a bad chewiness for something hard that is more likely to scrape up the roof and bottom of your mouth as you eat!), but Denise the owner informed me that they get bread baked fresh every day, and that they even changed to a higher quality more expensive bread recently.  To be fair, it was around 7pm or later, so maybe the bread just gets a little drier faster than expected?  

Also, I could've sworn the sandwiches have gotten thinner over time, but I was assured that they've never changed the amount of meat in them.  If it's not that, then the workers are inconsistent.  At any rate I was fooled last week during lunch.  At first glance at the cross-section cut down the middle, a nice portion of meat is visible, ready for nomming.  But that's because it was all piled in the middle!  It was pretty much devoid of any pork for 25% of it, the lump of meat in the middle, and the remaining 25% had maybe a very thin slice of it.  I don't recall ordering a half veggie/half meat - of course, spreading out the meat would make it look skimpy for that first bite, heh.

The flavor is still good when the bread is fresh and you have meat in your bites, but now I worry that their $7.05 pork sandwich may not be any more consistent than the cheaper yet very tasty ~$4 buns you can find elsewhere around town (e.g. Fresh Brew Coffee, Sweet Aroma, Saigon Sandwiches).  As they have the monopoly on the lower priced banh mi in this part of town (Out the Door has tasty meat with a different flavor, but is way over priced at ~$13), I will still visit them on occasion, although I'm a little more wary about the evening.  The owner did also apologize for my more recent experiences, so I do want to give them the benefit of the doubt!  Curse this addiction...
author: Linus W.

description: This is a higher end banh mi sandwich place that ranges from $6-9. When I feel like a sandwich, I usually order the sloppy bun, chicken or combo paired with a Vietnamese iced coffee. Bun Mee also has rice bowls, salads, fries and other sweet drinks (their lychee strawberry drink is awesome!). I also do love their sweet potato fries! I'd also suggest that you come by, grab a sandwich and walk over to Alta Plaza park and enjoy another great view of SF!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
A lot of people like this place so they are doing something right, even if seemingly trendy - two stars is a biased opinion.

If you don't eat VNese food often then the items they carry are okay. But, props to them for creatively fused and updated VNese entrees in a sandwich form. Now if you are familiar with VNese dishes, then this is just meeh. There are just too many flavors involved so none stood out.

The ambience is hipster, touristy and casual which I liked.

Note, the closest item to the typical combination VNese sandwich is the Belly Bun, that includes everything as expected. The difference is it comes with slices of pork belly. That and a limeade comes out to $9.49 after tax.
author: Peter L.

description: wowee.  great food.  really surprised they dont have a higher yelp rating.  great fries, sandwiches salads.  something for everyone
author: Evan S.

description:
I've only gotten to-go from Bun Mee once, but have been wanting to return even though they are a bit overpriced for banh mi and are not authentic, but I like their fusion version of the Vietnamese sandwich. I got the Belly Bun (Braised Kurobuta Pork Belly, Salted Radish Relish, Shaved Onion, Pickled Carrot and Daikon, Cucumber, Jalapenos, Cilantro $6.50) which was delicious! The Juicy Steak that I tried was just ok, and it was really expensive (Grilled Flank Steak w/ Lime Pepper Aioli, Lotus Root Relish, Shaved Onion, Pickled Carrot & Daikon, Cucumber, Jalapenos, Cilantro, and Crispy Shallots $7.95)! 

Parking is a nightmare around this area, but it's worth it to stop by and check out this place once if you love banh mi!
author: Amy D.

description: Simple yet delicious. Love the fish and chicken sandwich, and the noodle bowls. Try the extra fried egg!
author: Stefan S.

description:
A couple months ago this would've been a 4-star review. I have a gluten allergy, and in past months, when ordering from this place I've been told the Hawker Bowl was gluten free when ordered with Shrimp, and it was great. 
Today I called to place a delivery order for my company and was told only the noodle bowl with Tofu was gluten free (no thank you).
As someone with a gluten allergy, I must ask:
1) Did you change your menu or items to include more gluten and make me never want to eat here again?
2) Was someone misinformed and did you previously serve me gluten?!?
3) Are you misinformed and making my current lunch experience unfavorable?

Regardless of the answer, until their menu is labeled with allergen info, I will not be eating here again, and neither will my company.
author: Brooke R.

description: Decent Vietnamese style sandwich. Pricey compared to most banh mi I've gotten elsewhere. As a good friend if mine once said, "even bad banh mi is pretty good."  It's a tasty sandwich, just not one of the best iterations.
author: Paul W.

description:
A hip, stylish looking Vietnamese restaurant with new-age ingredients in their sandwiches, but I'd prefer an old school place.

I didn't end up getting a sandwich but decided to share a bowl with my friend. They had ran out of vermicelli, so I got a rice bowl. Well...the chicken didn't taste bad, but the flavours didn't come together very well. I am usually a rice bucket and will finish up every last grain of rice in my bowl, but I left this one alone...for good reason.

Others seemed to enjoy their sandwiches/egg rolls. So maybe the bowl was a bad idea?

I also got the strawberry lychee drink. It was much stronger and sweeter than I expected. A bit too sweet for me -- I was waiting for the ice to melt so it'd be less strong. If you're not into sweet kool-aid drinks, this is not for you.
author: Alice C.

description:
Centrally located, great outdoor seating options. Pretty good menu. Came with my sister and we ordered 2 bahn mis. The staff wasn't too friendly. Seemed to forget about us (never came out to clear our table so my sister had to request for it after I had already put in a request when I ordered).

Overall the bahn mis were OK. A little overpriced for what you can get in the city however because of the location, I understand. Would come again to try other items on the menu. Some positives are available seating, bathroom, and on Fillmore.
author: Siv L.

description:
I am changing my review to 5 star. Why? I posted a review stating I had heard their rice bowl was not vegetarian. Not only did the owner reply to my post, they did so promptly and without attitude. They were nice and informed me of my error. 

Aside from the place being chaotic at times, I honestly loved my dish (and love it more now that I am 100% confident it was vegetarian).

I shall return, with bells on!
author: Jana C.

description:
This relaxed, stylish Vietnamese spot on Fillmore has DEFINITELY filled a void in SF's Vietnamese scene.

Before these guys showed up you were either

1). slumming it at the corner of crack and 'ho at Tu Lan
2). dodging road rage trying to hoof it up to Saigon Sandwich
3). wasting half your rent check at the Slanted Door. (Sorry, not a Phan. bwah ahahah).

Finally, we have achieved Vietnamese goldilocks! You walk in, order, take a number, and they bring you a hot steaming bowl of fresh and yum. Boom. Done. My bowl happened to have veggies (spicy cucumbers, jalapenos, cauliflower relish, pickled carrots and daikon, bok choy, cilantro), spicy mayo, brown rice, and pork belly. Weirdly, the pork belly was the least tasty part - it was very high quality, but not seared/caramelized enough to my liking. But its piggy grease offered a nice lube (ew, but I'm gonna continue with this description) to the freshtastic veggies. If I still lived in SF I'd be coming here at least twice a week to grab stuff to go after work. The rest of the menu looked delish. 

Friendly counter help.
author: BroSauce J.

description: I was visiting the city and shopping in the area. I stopped in this cute and small eatery some banh mi. The grilled five spice chicken sandwich was tasty. If you are in the area for a quick bite, I would recommend you to check this place out.
author: A L.

description:
Mee-diocre, for sure. 

Nothing special. 

Kinda plain. 

Their tofu is not prepared with culinary care. 
Their peanut sauce is boring. 

I had hope. But, no. 


If you are vanilla, maybe you'll love this place. It's just not for me. Sor-ee
author: Kaylan S.

description:
Fine I'll give them 2.5 stars, I was really not impressed. I had the 5 spice chicken Ban mee. The chicken was moist but it needed more spice in the chicken. Overall the sandwich tasted fresh and not as fatty as a authentic Ban mee but it's missing the salty pate. The pate should be in ALL the sandwiches. I was craving papaya salad so I got it and was majorly disappointed. They added vermicelli noodles in the salad which is so not supposed to be in there at all. There was a few slivers of papaya and all noodles and peanuts. I also didn't taste any shrimp paste in the sauce or saw any dry shrimp in it. This place is obviously catered to rich white folks. No way in hell should my meal be $10.

I was watching the Mexican chefs cooking all the Vietnamese food and noticed the sweet potato fries are frozen out of a plastic bag.
author: Karen T.

description: Shame on me for buying an $8 (!) lemongrass pork banh mi, when I live in the South Bay, which has a whole handful of places with great, fresh banh mi for $3.50-$5 tops. The pork was really gristly and gamey, and the bottom crust of the bread was too hard to eat.  (I love me a nice, crusty roll, but this one was out of hand.)  I also brought home a citrus salad with chicken (five-spice?), and the meat was really tired and dry, like leftovers that had been in the fridge too long.  If I'd paid a third of the price, I'd shrug but not go back.  At this price, I feel cheated. I'll stick to a real Vietnamese place next time.
author: Mary C.

description: Had to update my review because even though I had that crappy spring roll, I tried a bunch of other items that have been delicious!  Love the bowls and salads here - flavorful, fresh and generous portions.  The sandwiches are decent too but they are a bit stingy on the protein there.  In any case it's a good choice for a relatively inexpensive meal on Fillmore.
author: Olivia T.

description:
I stopped by for a snack, but my eyes were bigger than my stomach.  I wanted the egg rolls (cute, small, crispy and tasty!), fish and chips w/ sweet potato fries (crispy yummy, love the curry touch in the sauce for the fish and chips, looooove sweet potato fries, don't feel as guilty eating these than straight up potato fries!) and a Thai iced tea (refreshing!).  I was getting super full so I packed up the rest of my fish and chips and sweet potato fries (didn't get to eat these, bf ate 'em up, darn, will have to go back another time, haha).  

Service was friendly and quick.  I was able to snag a table, love the brightness and quaintness of the place, and the people watching is fun!
author: Maile N.

description:
Walked to Bun Mee from Montgomery Bart Station because I hate paying $2 for Muni & I have lots of time to walk around on Sun 8/14/11.

Went late in the day, didn't study the menu enough & just quickly picked Bun Mee Combo $6.50.  It's got roast pork, pate, mortadella, garlic aioli, onion, pickled carrot, daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro.

I had it To Go & ate it for dinner at home.  I thought the roast pork was ok, some pieces were really dry & tough.  Other stuff was fine.  Nice crunchy bread I liked & the pate was good.

I got the House-made Strawberry Lychee drink $2.50 - It's really sweet.  Just ok for me.

Total $9.77, Charged it.  Not happy about that.  Will stick to Saigon Sandwiches in the Tenderloin.
author: Ann L.

description: I love this place.  No this isn't Saigon Sandwich- it's better.  I love the selection and items you would never find at a typical Vietnamese sandwich shop.  I think they offer what no other place has which is the best cross section of traditional Vietnamese options and Americanized options.  I cannot wait to go back and try the sandwiches.  On my first visit I had their pork bun and it was awesome.  The pork was delicious, tender and the presentation was beautiful.  Bonus points for the service.  The people that work here are really nice.
author: Darin E.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since I'd heard good things about it, but I really thought it was just okay.

I saw that they had Pork Belly and I  maybe should have gone for that, but instead went for the healthier option and tried the 5-Spice Grilled Chicken, which was just okay - the bread was quality stuff, but the chicken filling was a bit skimpy...I tasted mostly the bread and the fresh veggies in the sandwich but very little from the chicken.  The side Mango Salad was very good and very fresh.

I'd try this place again ,but probably try one of the other options since I was a little disappointed with the chicken.
author: Ken G.

description: I'd say you're paying for the trendiness of this place over the quality of the food. By no means was the lemongrass pork sandwich bad--in fact it was pretty good--but the bread wasn't terribly fresh, and I felt like $9 for the sandwich was a bit steep in price.
author: Kristin S.

description:
So, we went there this Saturday. It was super-packed and they were running very late on every order.

We ordered a sandwich, fries, vietnamese coffee and lychee drink. We waited for a long time to get a table and once we found the table, they only got us sandwich.

After waiting for 15 min, I went and asked for coffee and fries. The servers said they would bring to the table but man, those damn servers don't want move !

My wife kept on waiting for her coffee but they did not bring it to the table.

Sandwich came right away and was pretty ok.
 
Finally I got so pissed off, I went to the counter and asked them a refund for fries and coffee. Not once did they say sorry or let us just give it you complimentary for waiting for so long.

Do not recommend going to this place on weekends. Their service below average.

Never going to this place again for ruining our saturday afternoon !
author: Anurag T.

description: If you are looking for generic, tasteless, "white washed" Vietnamese food this is the spot for you. I have been lucky enough to always had authentic BanhMi and while running errands on Fillmore my boyfriend and I decided to give this place a try, we got the pork belly and lemongrass pork and they were both bad, seasoned-less meat, no marinade on the pickled vegetables, no special sauce, far from what an authentic BanhMi should taste.
author: Ladywolf M.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? I went to Bun Mee with a friend when I learned their sloppy bun sandwich was on the 7x7 big eats (I read it in 2012).  To this day it's a staple when I go here (along with the sweet potato fries).  

I know I'll be here again and that I won't be disappointed.
author: Neema F.

description: We placed an online catering delivery order from Bun Mee for an important event. We pre-paid and confirmed the order via phone and email. Despite these confirmations, Bun Mee dropped the order. They simply did not show up. When we called to ask where they were, we were told "I have no record of your order." The following day, Bun Mee's general manager apologized profusely, refunded our order and offered us free food. While this apology was professional, the damage was already done. I was put in the embarrassing position of scrambling to pick-up pizza for our hungry, important guests. I strongly discourage you from using Bun Mee catering.
author: Amelia R.

description:
Cute and modern in appearance, Bun Mee serves up "scooter food" (banh mi, salads, rice bowls, homemade drinks, cookies). Keeping with the scooter theme, they have Vespa pics on the wall. They can seat 16 people tops and there isn't much room to stand while you're waiting for them to make your sandwich. The place seems to be very popular. The banh mi sandwiches aren't meant to be completely traditional; you'll find that they add their twist to them, with caramel aioli, cauliflower relish, etc.

* Bun mee combo ($6.50): I liked the bread to filling ratio (plenty of filling) and the pickled veggies (carrots, daikon) were crunchy and tangy. The soft, toasted baguette was okay but wrinkled looking and without the crispy lightness of rice flour. The pate had a strong, livery flavor. The mortadella was fine but the roast pork was quite salty and not flavorful. The garlic aioli sounded good but didn't make much difference.  The sandwich also had cucumber, cilantro and jalapenos. 
* Green papaya salad: decent, fresh, crunchy with thin vermicelli rice noodles, carrots, and peanuts

The Tenderloin/Little Saigon isn't that far away and that's where I'd prefer to get my banh mi. Sure the ambiance is nicer at Bun Mee but the sandwiches are better elsewhere.
author: Lolia S.

description:
After walking by on several occasions and poking my head into their rather small but usually crowded little spot- last night I decided to become 'a customer'.  I had a nice first experience with Bun Mee (via takeout).  It started a bit quirky- I tried their online order system through their webpage- which was quite slick actually.  They list delivery as an option, but the system rejected delivering to me as an option because I'm in a different zip despite being 10 blocks away.  Then I placed the order for pickup (asap option), and my wife and I drove off...and 15 minutes later when we arrived to their relatively empty restaurant 30 min before closing- they said they had just received the order 'seconds ago' and would start making it asap....

...but there was no problem- they slapped things together quickly, we went home, and I engulfed a very delicious chicken sandwich and order of garlic salt & pepper fries.  The sandwich was excellent- stuffed with chicken as well as numerous veggies, had a great baguette bun, a nice crisp from the carrots and veggies, and a great flavor throughout.  The fries were great as well- they were smothered with jalapeños, garlic, and fried onions, and had a great flavor as well.  The jalapeños were a bit of overkill actually, so I worked my way around them.  I bathed everything in spicy sriracha sauce and enjoyed my 15 minutes of heaven.

Bun Meei did a great job, I will return for sure, and consider them for both take-out and dining in their establishment when in the area. I look forward to branching out through their rather extensive menu of offerings.
author: Andy S.

description:
good branding and a chalkboard menu? i'm sold. 

no, but seriously...could the people here be any nicer?

besides the above, bun mee is less than a block away from my apartment - so, it automatically receives extra brownie points. they've got a great array of different traditional vietnamese sandwiches with a californian twist, some appetizers (their spring rolls are amaze), but the bowls are what sold me. i ordered the hawker w/ garlic rice because i'm a sucker for a good runny egg. the egg was perfectly cooked and the portion was generous. lots of fresh veggies and high quality meat. also, their fresh strawberry lychee juice is a must.

i'll definitely be back here for a quick, tasty and affordable meal close to home.
author: Mandy A.

description:
Overpriced Viet sandwiches. When you can buy them for $2 in San Jose, this place sells it for almost $6! I admit, the five spice sandwich was pretty good and tasty, but for what it is, I regret spending that amount. I also ordered the papaya salad which was too sour and overwhelming, which is unpleasant for the Asian taste buds. The strawberry lychee was yummy but way too sweet. Maybe its the fact that Vietnamese people aren't making the food here and that this place is much catered to the non-Asians. 

But really, I dislike overpriced fusion food. When you can get better and authentic food at a lower price, you are getting jipped. It's a best bet to go to Saigon Sandwich to get your moneys worth.
author: Denise W.

description:
On Tuesday (July 19) I had lunch with my Belgian friend Emmanuel Guisset at this small, hip, and casual Vietnamese sandwich eatery in Pacific Heights in San Francisco, which used to be an Argentinian ice cream cafe. I have been there at least half a dozen times since they opened their doors to business in Spring of this year. The sandwiches served are in traditional French Vietnamese style and full of flavor. This is one of my favorite spots for a quick impromptu lunch in this beautiful neighborhood. I usually like to go there with friends on a sunny week day, so that we can sit outside and watch the fashionable crowd pass by. 

My favorite item on the menu is juicy steak sandwich with sweet potato fries.  Almost without failure, I have the same dish each time because it is so tasty.  Juicy steak sandwich is a grilled steak with lime pepper aioli and includes lotus root relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro and crispy shallots served on a freshly baked baguette. Their sweet potato fries are served with curry aioli and if I wasn't a gym rat, I would eat two portions of them, they are that delicious. My buddy Manu had his sandwich with a side salad that consisted of mixed greens, baby tomatoes, orange and grapefruit segments, tea egg and Vietnamese-style Caesar dressing which he enjoyed enormously. 

Life is good!

http://www.bunmee.co
author: Tamer I.

description:
I've only tried whatever was free, courtesy of Scoutmob (thanks for feeding me!). The menu contains overpriced and fancy banh mi sandwiches catered to the neighborhood folk there. I've tried their egg rolls (flavorful, packed with ground meat, glass noodles, mushrooms, carrots, and onions - 4/5) and the mango sesame salad (small simple dish doused in too much lime - 2/5). From what I heard from friends who have dined there, it's not worth it for the price you pay (~$30 for 2 sandwiches & drinks). And by looking at the sandwiches served whenever I pass by, it doesn't draw me in. Unless, it's free of course. 

Overall: 3. Get your banh mi fix somewhere other than pac heights.
author: Loriel L.

description: I ordered the bowl noodle and I did not like it at all.  I love Vietnamese food, but I was very disappointed with the noodle.
author: Ttmi T.

description:
Yum mee! 

The pork belly sandwich was pretty DEE-LISH! And for only $6.50, it's a cheap meal in my opinion. Yes, banh mis usually cost like $2.50, but this is Fillmore and they use high quality meat, people! What really made this sandwich stand out was the sliced hard boiled egg because it adds tons of flavor + texture. 

My sammie was accompanied w/ the strawberry lychee agua fresca, which was surprisingly refreshing! It even came with a whole lychee inside of it.

Luckily, we were able to get there at 1130 on a Sunday right before it got packed. I would suggest doing the same to avoid long waits for those bad boys! 

I will say the service isn't the best. The girl at the cash register didn't quite know what she was doing and when I asked for her recommendation between the combo sandwich or the pork belly, she replied, "I haven't tried either." How have you not tried two of the most popular sandwiches that your restaurant serves?! That shocked me quite a bit.

Kudos to who's in charge of their music. They were playing 93 Til Infinity when I was in there--a bit unexpected, but a nice little surprise!
author: Allison C.

description: They make a great sloppy bun, the noodle bowl is good. But best of all, the sweet potato fries and sauce. Really good stuff.
author: Philip K.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and used to really LOVE this place, but the menu changed recently, and unfortunately, a lot of my favorites changed for the worse. 

They removed the caramel-citrus rice bowl from the menu, which was my absolute fave. My second go-to was the peanut rice bowl, but their peanut sauce recipe also changed. It's a lot more viscous now and tastes a lot like soft peanut butter.
