Also, the way it's literally "squirted" onto the rice bowl makes it look far from appetizing, almost like tanish-brown soft serve. 

They also removed some ingredients from their spring rolls. They used to be AWESOME, but now there's no mango in them and also less meat. On top of that, you get to dip it into the peanut sauce that I described above. 

The salt and pepper fries are still good, as are the fish and chips, but I guess there's not much changing that can really occur with fried foods.

They deliver, so that's a plus, but I definitely ordered from them and ate there a lot more before all of menu changes occurred.
author: Brian B.

description: Tried the catfish recently; it was meh.  They were real cheap on the amount if fish.  Actually, they're kind of cheap on the meats for all their sandwiches.  I go here cause its close to school; My go-to is the Combo bahnmi.  jalapeno's are a must or youre weak!! just dont go here if youre after authenticity--i suggest Saigon Sandwich in the tenderloin.
author: Amanda J.

description: Belly Bun was a complete disaster. The soy sauce in it made the sandwich saltier than it already was. The egg rolls we had were just meh. On the other hand, at least the sweet potato fries were good.
author: Regina S.

description:
YUM.

I am so glad I came with other people and we each ordered different bahn mi's so I got to try all of them x)

I ordered the grilled pork, while my boyfriend got the sloppy bun and my best friend got the pork belly bun. Each of them were tasty and totally hit the spot. I had been craving a good bahn mi for weeks (I was visiting from NY). It's hard to say which one was my favorite of the three. I think that the Sloppy Bun was definitely interestingly different and I wanted more than the bite my boyfriend let me have! But I equally enjoyed both my grilled pork and the pork belly buns as well!

Now, it is a bit pricier than your normal hole in the wall vietnamese sandwich shop and so you're paying for the ambiance also but I honestly could care less. at $6.50 a pop, it was a cheap and delicious dinner in my opinion! 

We also ordered a basket of sweet potato fries that came with a red curry mayo sauce. I want to make my own! 

Next time I am in SF, I am going to make Bun Mee a regular stop so I can try everything on their tasty menu!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Bun Mee basically upsells your standard $3.00 Vietnamese sandwich. Be prepared to pay about $10 for your sandwich (more if you want to add egg and other fixings to it). 

I ordered the grilled five-spice chicken sandwich, which sounded like it could do no wrong from looking at the menu. Good, light bread, albeit a bit too crunchy creating more of a flaky mess than I would've liked. The veggie ingredients were fresh and crunchy, which was refreshing. The chicken was just okay -- my taste buds didn't really sense the five-spice part of that deal. 

I'm not sure $10 is quite worth it for a Vietnamese sandwich (the entire time I was sitting there I kept thinking about how this was only worth $3), but when you compare it to standard sandwich rates in SF, it's fair game.

Overall, I generally liked Bun Mee...I'm just really torn on the value aspect.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Bun Mee is a great example of prime location. When you've got a business in a great location, it can mean everything. 

Excuse me for being biased, (born in San Jose/Vietnamese) but I pretty much know a good Banh Mi at first bite. This spot always looks so crowded during brunch time on Sundays. I always heard good things, but I should have known not to trust hipsters when it comes down to authentic Vietnamese food. The environment and vibe of this place is hip and "cool", definitely not a mom & pop kinda deal. I had the 5-spiced chicken sandwich and bun bowl. Service was really friendly but the food was beyond bland! Were there five spices in my sandwich? I think I tasted one/two. The daikon add-ins were also really plain too. Not to mention the bun bowl wasn't really made out of the vermicelli you'd normally get in a bun bowl. No trace of fishy fish sauce either... And don't even get me started on the prawns! 

Unfortunately, this place was such a huge disappointment. There's really nothing special about the food. I give props to whoever worked on the branding/signage cause that's what drew me in. BUT, I won't be coming back.
author: Linda T.

description: I think about these pork sandwiches when I'm alone. One of the highlights of living in lower pac heights.
author: Tara H.

description:
I was in the hood and decided to give this place another shot. 

Pork Belly Banh mi, extra spicy with an egg ($8.68) - Added more saracha (of course), the pork belly was greasy and fat in a good way. The bread was perfectly toasted and left the roof & the  corners of my mouth intact. The pickled veggie were perfectly pickled. It still wasn't spicy enough for me (even extra spicy) but nothing that saracha didn't fix. 

Same issue with the cilantro though - I wish that it was just the top 1/2 because with each bite cilantro ends up hanging out of the corners of my mouth. 

I think a great improvement and I ordered the right menu item. I'll def be back when in the area.
author: Jade W.

description:
What I ate: Hanoi-style crispy catfish banh mi, shredded Napa salad, strawberry lychee agua fresca
Visit date: January 6, 2012
First time? Yes.

Yay Scoutmob for introducing me to Bun Mee. I normally would not be ok with paying anymore than $2.50 for a banh mi, but Bun Mee has your typical sandwiches, and then some. I had the and then some. The crispy catfish banh mi was uber good. The catfish stood up to it's name (crispy!) and was well-seasoned, the toasted baguette did not hurt the roof of my mouth (success!) and, though extremely stuffed at the end of my meal, I still wanted a little more catfish. The pickled carrot and daikon was just ok (I like it with a little more pickle punch). The Napa salad was pretty tasty -- think Thai papaya salad but with cabbage instead of papaya. I love lots of dressing on my salads, but because they sometimes serve it on the same plate as your sandwich, this salad was way overdressed -- it made my friend's sandwich go mushy...eh. Ask for it on a separate plate just to be on the safe side. The strawberry lychee beverage was too sweet for my taste, but once I watered it down it was delicious.

There's a nice vibe in the restaurant. My favorite piece of decor: a banner that says "Word of warning / All sandwiches are made with slices of hot jalapeño pepper / unless you're a sissy"

More on food:
Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish: Crispy fried turmeric catfish, red curry aioli, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapeños, cilantro.
Shredded Napa Salad: Napa cabbage slaw in a ginger lime dressing topped with roasted peanuts
author: Erin G.

description:
I am a vegetarian. Got a tofu sandwich. It was okay, I have had better. 
The biggest negative thing that turned me off from this place was watching the line cooks touch raw vegetables and make sandwiches with the same gloves as they touched the raw meat. Pretty gross. 
They should either stick to their stations or be sure to switch gloves. It was bad enough that they grill the tofu on the same grill as the meat. 
Cross-contamination is disgusting and dangerous for consumption.
author: Melanie S.

description: VEGETARIANS BEWARE: The food is normally delicious, and this has been a reliable vegan staple, but tonight there was meat in our our tofu spring rolls, quickly followed by violent vomiting.
author: Jeff M.

description: It seems either the ownership of this place changed or something else changed. Bun Mee seems to have lost that special taste that brought us back. I would have to agree, the flavor has generally Americanized (perhaps less use of fish sauce?). If you just forget it's supposed to be Vietnamese sandwich, it's still decent... but I would have to say, it no longer warrants an hour drive into SF.
author: Sam K.

description:
I really wish this place existed in San Diego or at least Los Angeles because it's so delicious! Fast service! Friendly workers and awesome food!

I got the Grilled Five Spice Chicken sandwich and split it with my friend since we weren't especially hungry. We also tried the sweet potato fries and they were yummy as well. Everything was SO SO good. 

I highly recommend making a stop here if you're needing something quick and tasty!
author: Elizabeth Y.

description:
Sloppy Bun, where have you been all my life? I was able to go on a Friday afternoon before the crowds arrived, so I didn't have to wait long. The decor is pleasing and the staff was very friendly. Ms. Tran is a class act herself. Welcome to the neighborhood, Bun Mee. 

Tip: Maybe call your order in ahead of time if you're getting it to go.
author: Dan B.

description: We got a garlic rice bowl with pork & jalopenos (cannot remember the name), and while it was tasty, the pork was quite fatty.  We also got a mango salad and the lychee drink.  Good, but not great.
author: Friend of D.

description: I live pretty close to Bun Mee and finally gave it a chance after 2 years of constantly walking by it. I tried the Hanoi Catfish and Bun Belly Sandwich and was not impressed with either. The meat was season-less and the food is not authentic by any means. The only item I enjoyed were the sweet potato fries and house aioli - definitely recommend getting this! Although the interiors are nice, the location is pretty small and has about six tables + some bar seating in the back. Overall, Bun Mee just didn't do it for me and definitely did not satisfy my banh mi craving.
author: Nikitha R.

description:
Good sandwich addition to the Fillmore area. Unlike typical Banh mi sandwich places, this place is brand spanking new and nice and clean! But the time between you place your order to the time that you pick up your order is a little too long for my taste. 

The sandwich was yummy. The veggies were nicely marinated and I love that you get the options of adding an egg and how you want the egg on the sandwich. That's a bonus since I LOVE eggs! Even tho they claim that their peppers are spicy, they really aren't...

The papaya salad had good flavor too. 

I'd come back here and try the other sandwiches.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
What can I say about this place? Ordered the catfish banh mi, which was satisfying. high quality ingredients, with good overall mouth feel and taste. The fish was very fresh, I enjoyed the crunch with each bite, solid baguette that offered good support of the ingredients, and the pickled vegetables was not too overwhelming and overall complemented well. 

The place is kind of small, with not many seats despite there been a lot of standing room and high ceilings. Maybe a good grab and go place. I'll definitely come back again

EDIT: I came back the other day, and I ordered the pork (meatball grinder) banh mi, and the ground beef (sloppy bun) banh mi, in order to expand my experience of this place and I have to say that the catfish was probably a lucky first order, and I would not come back again. 

I think the problem with the latter two banh mi was the overall experience. The banh mi that I enjoy is when meat is was well-seasoned (and was delicious enough to eat on its own), was consistent throughout each bite, and didn't have pickled vegetables or cilantro or spices that overwhelmed my taste buds. 

For Bun Mee, the meat quality was good enough, but the flavors/seasoning felt out of place. The ground beef (sloppy bun) was a little too salty and didn't go well with the jalapenos. Furthermore,  it wasn't well balanced, and with each bite I wasn't sure if I was going to get a big bite of jalapeno or a big bite of onion.  
For the pork, also way too much jalapeno, and again nothing memorable.

If each sandwich were the typical price of a banh mi (aka not fillmore prices), I still probably would not come here again. Maybe if I'm craving some catfish..
author: Lars B.

description:
A fan of the sandwiches - have tried the 5 spice chicken and the belly bun and both were good. The buns are a little tough and sometimes I feel like I'm sacrificing a layer of skin on the roof of my mouth every time I go there, but the flavors are really good. Adding avocado is tasty, but they don't give you much. As for adding a fried egg, it's really hit or miss. Sometimes they'll place it in the sandwich and it'll be a great addition. But other times they'll just haphazardly throw it half-on your sandwich, flopping out onto the tray, and you're left thinking "how do they expect me to eat this??" and end up with a tray full of runny egg.  

But, their rice bowls are lacking. Their old menu had a really nice variety of things in each of the bowls (I once got one with chicken, avocado, grapefruit, oranges, plus assorted veggies), but now it's just rice with some meat and assorted veggies. I haven't gotten a rice bowl since their menu changed, since they seem very bland and carb-heavy. However, the portion size is huge, which almost justifies the price ($10+).
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Bun Mee is a nice addition to the neighborhood.  The decor and menu options fit in well with the vibe of the area.  

I ordered the Bun Mee Combo and substituted an egg for the garlic aioli.   The person taking my order recommended this and she was spot on!  I also ordered a side of the green papaya salad.  

The sandwich was good, if a bit on the bland side.  The bread was fresh and had a nice soft crust.  I could taste each of the ingredients in the combo and there was an abundance of vegetables.  The green papaya salad was fresh, crisp and tart.  I could taste the anise and the chili's in the dressing.  However, I was hoping that for $3 (as a sandwich side), there would have been more of it.  Maybe the regular side salad portion is larger? 

Yes, the sandwiches here are pricey when compared to traditional banh mi, but pretty reasonable when compared to other types of sandwiches when considering the portion size and quality and freshness of the ingredients.

I thought the staff was pretty friendly and the service was pretty efficient.  There are small tables up front and a bar in the back for those desiring to watch the staff prepare orders.  The space is bright and modern but cozy.
author: Melissa L.

description:
If I had not been starving out of exhaustion, I probably wouldn't have stepped foot into the door. 

On first look, the place seems entirely Americanized - from the unorthodox spelling of 'banh mi' to the logo stylings reminiscent of our favorite apple brand. 

However, I was hungry and the place was bustling so I figured I couldn't wrong.

I ordered a Combo sandwich along with a Strawberry Lychee drink. And I was pleasantly surprised. They were both extremely delicious and well made. 

Don't come here with the expectation of eating an authentic Vietnamese sandwich because you aren't going to get one. Instead, come here with open mind to the food. The entire menu is composed of fusion dishes and I'm very glad I gave this place a try. 

Space is cramped so probably not the best for groups. The Cafe Du Monde utensil holders gave the tables a nice touch.
author: Hien N.

description:
Pretty blah. In a town full of great Bahn Mi at half the price this place isn't really worth a second look. 

Not awful, just meh.
author: Sam J.

description:
Yummy.  We serendipitously stumbled upon this place while taking a stroll down Fillmore St.  So happy we found it.

I absolutely loved the "belly bowl".  What an awesome creation bursting with a multitude of flavors!  Imagine tender, juicy pork belly; fried rice with huge garlic flavor; pickled veggies with the right amount of acidity, all topped off with a fried egg that oozes goodness when you break into it.  Yes- it is a mouth watering affair.

If you're craving Asian comfort food, I definitely recommend the rice bowls.  My patnah got the grilled pork rice bowl and was just as satisfied as I was.  

Very casual atmosphere.  Order at the counter and take your seat.  Food is brought to you and your only job is to devour that epic meal.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Abby D.

description:
weak. The sandwiches are more expensive and contain less meat than in most other Vietnamese sandwich shops I've gone to. Went yesterday to give them one last try. I just wanted to quick snack and ordered the Mama Trang spring rolls. They were tiny, looked like they were bought in bulk, and tasted like they were right out of the freezer.

Do yourself a favor and avoid this place. if you want a really good Vietnamese sandwich, head over to Cafe Buhn Mi on Clement. They're cheaper, better tasting and more filling..
author: Neal P.

description:
Like most eateries and shops on that stretch of Fillmore, Bun Mee is small but very cute.  There are only a few tables for diners to eat in, but it seems like most of their orders are pick-ups and to-gos anyway.

I got the crispy catfish sandwich and a coconut water.  Sandwich was $6.75, which I thought was a fair price.  The flavors are good. The fish itself was a bit mushy, which is a bit disappointing.

Woolly Pig is still my favorite sandwich shop for banh mis, but I would definitely come back to Bun Mee if I happen to be in the neighborhood again.
author: Candice B.

description: Paying more than four dollars for a Vietnamese sandwich is illegal in my oppinion. Only the Fillmore/Lower Pac height yuppies with formidable trust funds relative to the Marina crowd would be willing to pay that for a poor man's sandwich, which is basically what the sandwich is in Vietnam. Most other non-sandwich items on the menu is pretty un-authentic. This is a typical "asian fushion" place catering to the caucasion  palette (which is bland, less sodium, no MSG, no fish sauce crowd). You might as well get a hot dog then.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description: Honestly, this is not bad for Financial District food (which IMHO is just overpriced sandwiches). It is overpriced but at least it's on the authentic side. I get the belly bun every time (with jalapeno, no mayo) because that's the best item on the menu and I believe that there's no point in trying to eat healthy if you're already eating out. Are there better bahn mi places in SF? For sure! Little Saigon in the Tenderloin is not only better but also more affordable. Am I willing to trek through the crazies of the Tenderloin for some Vietnamese buns? No. You're welcome to do that if you're not a pussy like me.
author: Angela G.

description:
First RATS and now a 79 health dept score?!? GROSS.  You've finally lost me for good, Bun Mee.  

Your food is tasty and staff are nice (except the owner) but you seriously need to get it together! This is just disgusting.
author: t m.

description:
High prices, but it's in a prime spot on Fillmore.  Obviously their target market is the pac heights trophy wives, who see the pictures their husbands send back from their business (ladyboy) trips to southeast asia and think "ooh I wanna try that, I'm going to drag my $1500 stroller in there and try it out!".

At least the meat did taste ok, so I was gonna give this place 3 stars.

*Then* I looked into my water glass and saw a huge brown hairy floaty in it!  I went to the counter and told them about it, then got a drink that came in a sealed container.  The lady at the counter showed it to some woman, who I guess was the manager (I didn't have time to raise hell).  After sitting back down, I watched what they did about it.  The manager opened the top of the big water jug, peered into it, then closed it and did nothing!  I saw other people walking away from it with brown hairy floaties in their water too!  To top it off, I looked at the health inspection score thingy (ironically, right next to the pond-water dispenser) and they got a 79.  That's the lowest I've ever seen in the city.

As a safety precaution, I promptly went to a bar and drank large quantities of vodka to kill any bacteria I might have ingested.
author: Mike R.

description:
Tasty but terrible service.

I come here a lot simply because the food tastes good. But have had a number of disappointing experiences. Yesterday I went by to grab lunch. I ordered my chicken salad to go. I had to wait 25 minutes on the crowded side of the restaurant waiting while they filled all the phone orders first. As I was standing there, I saw one of the servers reach into a bowl that was about to be served (twice!) grab cilantro out with her unwashed hands, and toss it in the trash. She then picked up the bowl and carried it to a table. No wonder they have a health score of 79! 

Then my food was called 25 minutes later and they got the order wrong. They handed me a sandwich not a salad so had to continue to wait.

Today my husband insisted we order Bun Mee again. This time we were smart enough to call ahead. Again I ordered the chicken salad. When we got it home. It was missed 2 ingredients, both the jalapenos and carrots. These add a lot of flavor and crunch to the salad so it was very disappointing without it.
author: Katie S.

description:
I had a very enjoyable lunch at Bun Mee today, and I'll definitely be returning in the future to check out other sandwiches!

I had the pork belly sandwich with a fried egg, and it was absolutely delicious. The baguette is freshly prepared, and the juices seep into it to make the inside soft, but it still has that nice, curncy baguette texture on the outside. The pork was great, and the fried egg added great flavor.

As a side dish, I got the Napa salad. It was okay, if not a bit bland, but the main course made up for it. Someone else had the mango salad, and he commented that it wasn't amazing either. So they should perhaps re-think their side dish strategy, but the main sandwich was delicious. I think they should also have some kind of lunch combo special. I got the sandwich with fried egg along with a napa salad, and it ran me just over $11. Not super expensive, but it's a bit more than I'd like to spend on a quick lunch, and that didn't even come with a drink.

I will definitely return, though. The staff is extremely friendly, and the sandwich was awesome!
author: Kevin H.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place each time I visit the area to listen to music at the Fillmore Jazz street fair.  This time, there were no lines and we even scored a table for 2 in the tiny place.  I tried the Belly Bun, $7.25, double the price of a Banh Mi you'd get at Saigon Sandwiches but this is a higher end product.  The Kurobuta pork belly was pretty good, just too salty.  The slices of jalapeno gave it lots of heat.  I didn't add an egg but that's an extra dollar.  The bread is nice and crunchy but I thought the pickled carrots and daikon didn't have enough of a pickle flavor but at least it didn't taste as sweet as the ones Saigon Sandwiches make. 
Hubby had a big bowl of Saigon peanut bowl, $10.50 with garlic rice.  I had one bite and couldn't tell it had garlic in it but it came with a lot of peanut sauce, pork (or chicken, tofu.  Steak/shrimp are extra $2), papaya, carrots, kaikon, spouts, and peanuts, He couldn't finish it and had to pack 1/3 of it to take home.  Would consider making a return visit to try their other dishes.
author: Ry T.

description:
Overpriced "skimpy" food. Tried a sandwich and rice bowl, and they are very VERY skimpy with their protein, and the vegetables. You're stuck with mostly the carbs. The bread isn't that great. It lacks the scatteringly crisp crust and pillow soft interior of a good bahn mi. 
I think that people must be fooled by their prices - but in my opinion, paying more does not mean the product is better.
author: Joyti J.

description:
I came here a couple weeks ago with two co-workers for my work birthday lunch.  It's super duper small with room for only about 16 people to eat in.  We got there before noon on a Monday and only one table was filled.  We grabbed the table right by the register, which, by the way, is a HORRIBLE place to sit.  Everyone lines up right behind you so you get bumped a lot.  And then they brush by the other side of your table when they want to get water, which is located on the counter next to the register.

They have their menu on a board on the wall.  One co-worker and I both decided to get the Juicy Steak sandwich.  The other co-worker went with the Bunn Mee Noodles.  I liked my sandwich, but there could've been a better ratio of filling to bread.  Still good though.  We also split an order of the sweet potato fries.  Sweet potatoes aren't my most favorite food, but the fries were tasty.

Prices are kind of steep for sandwiches and noodles.  I prefer Cafe Bunn Mi in the Richmond for similar food at slightly lower prices.
author: Kris L.

description: Sandwiches were good and fresh. You're paying more than Lee's but getting some better quality ingredients. Vietnamese Iced coffee tasted very authentic. Nice but not amazing and not sure I'd go back.
author: Marilynn L.

description:
Third time's a charm. 

April 10 - I had the combo and it was bland and tasteless. 1 star 

April 17 - I had the juicy steak sandwich with a side of fries. yes, a side of fries at a banh mi joint... hipster banh mi joint, hence the insanely expensive sandwiches. I told myself this is the last time I'm ever coming here, but the fries were pretty darn GOOD, so I have to come back. 3 stars 

April 20: I had the Belly Bun (Pork belly sandwich) and thought it was SO yummy. I was so full from the sandwich, I couldn't even eat the fries which is the main reason I decided to give this place a 3rd try. 

to sum it up, this place is good (if you give it enough chances). I'd definitely come here again, but i wouldn't go out of my way..
author: Angelica C.

description:
Came to Bun Mee after walking up and down the street trying to decide what to eat. My gf said she wanted to try Bun Mee just cause it had a funny name. Came here and right off the bat I knew I wanted to try the belly bun and the crispy hanoi catfish.

The belly bun is a pork belly sandwich, it wasn't super fatty which was nice but when it came, it was a little on the cold side. I still enjoyed it though. The crispy catfish was good too, although I think it would've faired better if it had a tad bit more of the red curry aioli. 

Overall the place is a little bit on the pricey side, especially for a banh mi. But I will come again the next time I'm in the Fillmore because they don't serve just the traditional banh mi sandwiches. Even my gf, who is vietnamese and from GG, enjoyed this place. Whenever I get a banh mi that is over $2.75, she tells me I get ripped off but she said she will make an exception for this place and come again. Finally, She said that the iced vietnamese coffee was just like how her mom makes it. This is the first time she EVER complimented a restaurants vietnamese coffee!!!!
author: Sean W.

description: The Bun Bowl is my favorite and HUGE easily can get two meals out of it. Saigon peanut bowl is also a fav. The sauces on both are so good! Take out has always been super fast for us!
author: Kristin D.

description: I got the pork belly bun mee with the hard boiled egg as recommended on the menu. It was delicious. Also had some of the sweet potato fries and I highly recommend getting them!
author: Conway W.

description: The sandwiches are good but I just tried a rice bowl with pork and it was awful - it just tasted weird, had way too much rice, and the pork was over-seasoned and gristly.  I couldn't finish it and so spent $13.00 on a lunch #1.  Also they have an 86 food safety score which seems pretty bad.
author: Candace M.

description:
12.01.12 || bookmarked 05.03.11

After an afternoon of strolling on Fillmore and its neighboring streets for shopping, drinking, and raffling prizes (all for charity), my stomach was angry at me.  Bun Mee to the rescue.

I had the Bun Mee combo sandwich (grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, paté de campagne, mortadella, garlic aioli, shaved onions, pickled carrots, daikon, cucumbers, jalapenos, and cilantro).  $6.75.  It hit the spot.

Nice alternative if you don't happen to be in the TL while you're hankering for a Vietnamese sandwich.  Just be prepared to pay that premium.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This place is fine for what it is. I'm surprised there's so many haters. I've been in several times- it's yummy, clean Vietnamese Bun Mee.  I've had a couple of the bowls: the Grilled Five Spice (YUMM!), and the Saigon Peanut Rice bowl ( my fave). All the sandwiches are solid! 

Still not sure why everyone's all up in arms. It's fine, maybe not "authentic", and maybe its just "too white" (or whatever), but it's really pretty tasty. People just need to calm down and realize it for what it is. A cute, cleaned up Vietnamese Cafe in a gentrified hood. They use fresh ingredients and you really are not gonna get much better at this price point, sorry!
author: nancy s.

description: I had the grilled lemongrass pork sandwich to go, which was good but not worth the $6.75. The bread and size of the sandwich were much smaller than what I expected. The flavors were good but nothing too exciting. For that price, I think I will stick with Saigon sandwich.
author: Allison S.

description:
The first time I came here I ordered a Belly Bun with hard boiled egg and a side of sweet potato fries.  It was so good, I was sure this would be a 5-star review.  That being said, I've been there a few times now and had a few different sandwiches.  None could compare to the first belly bun I had, even subsequent ones didn't have the same overflowing quantity of meat.

Even if they can't reproduce that first miraculous experience, I'll still keep coming back, the sandwiches are tasty and interesting and I love the sweet potato fries.
author: Marty F.

description: The portions are small for the price. The food is good in flavor but the music is awful.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I'm a fan of places with cute names and also really enjoy Vietnamese food so when I saw Bun Mee I knew I had to try it.

Note: I came with a friend who was Vegetarian and there were only 2 options for her to choose from as most of the items have fish sauce in it. 

Food: I myself ordered the pork bun mee and the Vietnamese iced coffee. The pork sandwich was perfectly toasted but I found the sandwich a tad dry. The iced coffee was really sweet (just the way i like it) but it didn't particularly taste like a Vietnamese ice coffee (known for its coffee strength and sweetness)

Price: The price of a sandwich is 2x more than my favorite bahn mi place in the city (Saigon Sandwich) but I didn't think it was overpriced considering the Fillmore area and also that Bun Mee is a sit down whereas Saigon Sandwich is in the Tenderloin and is a take out place stand only.

I definitely wouldn't mind trying this place out again and will probably order the sweet potato fries next time!
author: Betty C.

description: Always consistent, delicious, and fast! My husband and I always get the vegan tofu sandwich, bun bowl with tofu, and fries. It's gotten to the point that we rarely order delivery food from anywhere else. So much flavor, texture, and quality AND vegan friendly!!!
author: Shelly P.

description:
This place is great, do come.

I came here with my girlfriend and we had a combo, sloppy bun with egg, egg rolls and two coconut cookies, yum. The sloppy is sloppy and good, you will enjoy it but ask for an extra napkin or two. The combo was tasty and I'll have it again and the cookies great. The egg rolls were really good and I'll come back for those and not to mention the cookies, try the cookies.

The staff here is really friendly and says something about the management; they hire good people.

The prices here are great for the quality and service; this is not the TL. If you want TL prices and service go to the TL.
author: Justin S.

description:
Yum!! I always hate looking for parking in San Francisco, but I always love when that means you stumble upon something great. My brother and I were trying to find parking for Sift Cupcakes and we see Bun Mee Eatery. We were just gonna go on our pastry adventures again, but man the food the people were eating outside looked amazing. So we checked out the menu and decided to go inside. 

Everything on the menu looked so good. I decided to get a Vietnamese sandwich with tofu. SOOOO GOOD!! The bread is nice and toasty so it has that nice crunch, yum! The filling was so good to, I love tofu! My brother got the pork belly sandwich and that was soo good too! I wanted to get the bigger bowls of food but my wallet and stomach fought over it and my wallet won, lol. 

Its a bit pricey if you're a little kid or have the strings tight on your purse, but definitely worth it. Its such a cute little place. And the people who work there are so nice.
author: Denice D.

description:
So good! It was my first time here today thanks to other good reviews. Service was nice. Very modern looking place, not the average Vietnamese place you expect. Very Filmore. Good, clean, fresh food. I haven't had a ban mi sandwich in a while. But bun mee has figured it out. I had grilled lemongrass pork, hold the jalepeños. I don't eat a lot of spice. But it was great. To start with I had the pork & shrimp summer roll. Very fresh. Crisp veggies and mint with pineapple. I thought the pineapple was a great touch to balance out the spicy peanut dipping sauce provided. ( I love peanut sauce BTW). As for the sandwich: crunchy baguette, soft in the middle. Beautifully seasoned pork not too salty. Crisp pickled veggies. I usually don't like cucumbers without ranch but I ate every bit of it. 
Side note there was some excess oil on the outside of the bread. I just dabbed it with a napkin and was able to look past it. Other than that the meat itself did not taste overly greasy. Great experience!
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Not delicious at all. Sandwich was also very dry. If you have ever had a delicious Vietnamese sandwich, this isn't the place to go.
We wished we hadn't eaten it because we still wanted something tasty to eat but didn't have room. Next time we go somewhere that we don't like the food, we will leave and get something delicious elsewhere.
author: Patricia B.

description: I knew I should be skeptical of a place that turns authentic food more Americanized. I praise them for having a variety of ingredients in their banh mi but in this case, I think its not a good idea to mess around too much with the original. I'll go to my hole-in-the-wall place in civic center and put up with the parking situation down there just to get a taste of the banh mi I ate since I was a little girl.  This place just didn't do it for me.
author: Cathy N.

description:
Food is great, a 4! I love the chicken salad.

But service can be horrible. specifically, the blond woman at the counter is awful. She should probably consider a role outside the service industry...
author: Christine B.

description:
Part of my 7x7 2013 big eats to try before you die list, finally checked off eating their sloppy bun with an egg. I've have really been hesitant to try this place growing up with Banh mi in San Jose with the legit stuff but I came in here mentally prepared and accepting that this is not a traditional Vietnamese deli. Once we scarfed down our sandwich, we both smiled and agreed it was quite good. The pricing is standard for a sandwich but certainly not for a Vietnamese sandwich which can be $3-4 but hey, it is what it is and it's not bad. I'm actually looking forward to try their other ones, anything but the traditional combo, which I know won't hit the spot.

Will I come back: yes, to try other things
Quick tip: service is fast and ambiance cool and casual, try the sloppy bun with an egg
author: Johanna P.

description: Simply delicious! @bunmeesf Sloppy bun & garlic fries: yum! Belly bowl / pork belly, rice, fried egg & veggies is sublime! #cheapANDyum
author: heather s.

description:
I really enjoyed the sloppy joe banh mi.  It's definitely filling and a unique spin on traditional vietnamese sandwiches (in other words, it is in no way traditional). 

I'd definitely come back to try the other sammies.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Not bad at all!  This place is underrated I think.
Been here twice, got the grilled pork sandwich (or bun mee, I guess?).  It's very juicy and fatty - yumm!!
Both times the service was excellent, everyone's friendly and attentive.
author: Dasha B.

description:
This was my first banh mi, I ordered the five spice chicken minus the jalapenos. As a late afternoon snack it was great. Nice contrasting flavors of the pickled carrots and daikon was new to me.

Someone else ordered the Bun Mee combo and the pate was quite good as well.

As for a drink the Strawberry Lychee Agua Fresca delicious.

If I come back for a meal, I'm gonna order a papaya salad next time.
author: Brandon W.

description:
If you've ever had a classic Vietnamese pork sandwich and you truly appreciate all the "yummy in you tummy" qualities these sandos have to offer, I suggest giving them a try at Bun Mee. The price may be a bit more steep than the average vendor (about 7 bucks) buy hey, they're located in Fillmore.. Expect every price tag to be on steroids! 

The spice is perfect, the meat is juicy, and the veggies are crisp. 

The atmosphere is lax.. Small and containable. I liked it.. Thanks bun mee!
author: Gianna J.

description: Yummy five spice chicken sandwich and sweet potato fries, bomb homemade strawberry lychee beverage,  good friends, good service, boo yah. Ill be back soon!
author: Nadia I.

description:
I just got back from a business trip in Canada, and was craving Asian food, and sandwiches. Enter Bun Mee - a great way to satisfy both! I ordered the pork sando; BF ordered 5 star chicken. 

The chicken was delish! Has great flavor, with a bit of a kick. The pork sando came about 10 min after, due to some confusion with our order number. 

I'm pretty certain my meal today gave me food poisoning. My stomach has not been right all day. This is the last time I'm eating here...what a shame.
author: Zaneta C.

description:
I've ordered from Bun Mee for lunch catering at the company I work at and the lunch catering has been soooo very delicious! The packaging of the food has been wonderful, the food itself is super good - clean flavors and very flavorful. Everything is crazy fresh and good. I had an order today and looking forward to another lunch catering order this Friday! Lucky me and my group that gets to eat the food! Items that I've ordered:
- assortment of individual rice bowls
- assortment of individual rice noodle bowls
- sandwiches
- rolls

I highly recommend Bun Mee. I want to go to the restaurant next....
It might be slightly higher priced, but it is super fresh and yummy and that accounts for a lot in my book.'
author: Jules B.

description:
It's the "whitey" version of Lee's Sandwiches which, ironically, is the "whitey" version of an actual Viet Sandwich shop.  

Two times removed and it's not that bad.  

I despise pretty much all forms of organized religion (I can, however, get behind them Buddhists, I like their style) but if there was a "church of bread," I would be their biggest supporter.  

More art/religion than science/baking, bread is a special form of food transport that gives us reason to eat straight up butter, whatever sauce you're too embarrassed to lick off the plate, and an infinite number of and combination of processed deli meats.  

The bread here is what gives the sandwich at Bun Mee a sub-par review from me.  A bit too hard and chewy for my liking.  

Don't get me wrong, I would eat this sandwich every day, but to be inducted into the hall of fame of Viet sandwiches would require some serious re-tooling.  

Scooter.
author: Archie R.

description: Walked by while shopping, decided to try a couple of their sandwiches. Had the 5 spice chicken and their pork sandwich. It's good, but not better than those hole in the wall Vietnamese shops in Chinatown (for less than half the price!).
author: Mei W.

description:
I love this place. Who thought a crispy tofu sandwich could be so amazing.
Expect a little wait in line usually.
author: Tenzin N.

description:
Decent Bahn Mi, but definitely pricey. I ordered the steak bahn mu which was tasty, but lacking in the meat. For and $8 bahn mi I expect that thing to be generously filled! I am use to pay about $3-4 at other places back home.

In summary, the food is good but not worth the price. I would eat here again because it is conveniently located near my apartment. However it not something I would eat regularly - not for at the price.
author: Richard P.

description:
Could be one of my top lunch places in SF. I really like the Bun Mee here and could not believe the flavors of the side dishes. 

My biggest complaint is that it is on Filmore. I wish it was in Noe Valley in my HOOD!  Hint Hint......
author: Ryan B.

description: This is a nice little bun mee eatery. We tried the 5 spice chicken and the steak sandwich. Both were good but lacking of great flavour. The salad it nice especially the dressing. There are are plenty of options in San Francisco for Bun Mee and this one doesn't stand out. Prices are decent as the food.
author: Gonzalo C.

description:
Decent sandwiches, but I left feeling underwhelmed. I had the Sloppy Bun (with egg). Too much of the flavor was overpowered by the bread. I did sample the catfish sandwich, which tasted significantly better.

Not bad for a $10 lunch on Fillmore, but I'm in no hurry to return. Note that I wouldn't object to returning; I just won't seek it out.
author: Randy N.

description:
I tried their grilled pork vietnamese sandwich and it was delicious beyond words. Each sandwich comes neatly wrapped with a cute moped sticker.

I love the aesthetic of this place, it's inspiring to any artist or designer :)
author: Anastasia T.

description: Eggplant sandwich with the cauliflower relish - delish. The Vietnamese iced coffee and salt and pepper fries are also favorites!
author: Sarah V.

description:
I'm on the fence between 3 and 4 stars...probably more towards the 3 side. 

Few highlights - 
*Great prices, large portions
*GrubHub delivers (that's an extra bonus for me)
*Friendly employees
*Clean restaurant (kind of small though)

Favorite dishes (so far) - 
*Noodle bowl (only $10) - Vermicelli noodle, lettuce, pickled carrots, cucumbers, mint, cilantro, roasted peanuts, and crispy shallots served with a nuoc cham dipping sauce. You pick your meat - I get the grilled pork, but you can get chicken, tofu, shrimp or steak. Make sure to add a crispy egg roll for an extra 1.50
*Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl (only $10)  - choice of Grilled Pork, Chicken or Organic Tofu. Shredded cabbage salad, daikon sprouts, pickled shallots, topped with roasted peanuts and peanut sauce over garlic or brown rice. Can also add an egg roll and/or fried egg for an extra $1.50

Overall...reasonable prices, friendly staff and pretty tasty. I recommend you give them a try next time you're in the neighborhood.
author: Dru M.

description: The rice bowls are phenomenal! You can't beat the price and portion size. Hawker bowl. Get it!
author: Laura M.

description:
I had the pork bun noodle bowl and shrimp spring rolls. 

It was ok, but I've definitely had better. I also thought this was overpriced for what I had. The pork was definitely delicious, but really nothing special. The spring rolls were disappointing, and I think they cost me about $6 for two small pieces (divided into halves), they were also loosely wrapped and lacked flavor. 

I wouldn't deter people from going, some really love it and continue to go back and I can see why. But I personally wouldn't recommend it as a "must go to" place. There are much much better, but this definitely isn't a terrible option. I'm just not as big of a fan of this place (though I really do love this cuisine) then others I have been too. Also with so many types of food of Fillmore, I would recommend checking out other restaurants first!
author: Sherry F.

description:
I had the Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl with tofu. It was nicely garnished with cabbage, daikon sprouts, and pickled shallots. The sauce was fragrant and well-composed; the peanut and lime elements harmonized. I also appreciated being able to select brown rice. The tofu topping was not phoned in: it was seared and flavorful.

I really enjoyed my dish but am deducting a point for one flaw: the toppings-to-rice ratio was off. I know rice is the cheapest element, but for $10, dagnabbit, give me more veggies and tofu. Especially tofu! Three pieces doesn't do it.

The service was friendly. The space was smal. Luckily, I beat the lunch rush and was able to get a table.

Will definitely be back to try the sandwiches and salads.
author: Elinor A.

description:
I've been here about 10 times over the last 6 months. I really loved this place the first 7 times but I have to say that the quality is really gone down dramatically and substantially over the past 2 months. The chef just doesn't seem to be able to take any special instructions - how hard is it to remove onions and not add mayo to a sandwich?
They have got to work harder on attention to detail.
author: Raj T.

description: The food might be good, but the service has made it clear they do not want to honor delivery orders.  I have now had 3 orders which have mysteriously disappeared when placed on various online ordering sites.  Unless you go get your food in person, I wouldn't order from here.   Their salads are great, the rolls are great - the sandwiches are good (on the greasy and heavy side, but well worth the splurge) - but the bread really makes it.  Its just sad that you can't get it unless you go in.
author: Allison G.

description:
Interesting concept, nice design, but the food can be way better. 
Bland meat, so-so service, and generally is slow. 
With some improvement this place has a ton of potential.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Bun Mee fits perfectly in its Pac Heights neighborhood.  Focus is on fresh products, cleanliness ... and charging a premium for it.

No complaints about the Belly Bun (braised Kurobuta pork belly, salted radish relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro with a hardboiled egg add-on).  Really quite good.  Granted the Kurobuta pork belly was really tender but I'd be perfectly content with a similar banh mi from Saigon Sandwiches at half the price.

What was disappointing was the Sloppy Bun (red curry gound beef, house garlic mayo, shaved onion, thai basil, jalapenos with a fried egg add-on). First of all, the meat to bun ratio was embarrassingly small.  The fried egg helped but to me it was a messy sandwich that dripped everywhere, little meat and then you're left with toasted bread.  Uh, yum.

The sweet potato fries were fine.
author: F. P.

description: Ordered the Hawker Bowl with brown rice and pork. In both appearance and flavor, it was utterly unappealing. The rice was gluey, and the pork, which should be seared quickly at a high temperature to give it a grilled sear and rich caramelized surface and taste, was pallid in color and bland, served in oversized stringy pieces.
author: R. P.

description:
I've always been impressed with the food and service at Bun Mee. The Vietnamese pork sandwich is freaking incredible, and holds just the right amount of spice. If I go with a friend we generally will split the prawn spring rolls with peanut sauce, also to die for!

My favorite part about the setup of this place is the two tables near the front of the restaurant, it's perfect for people watching.
author: Jason M.

description:
I just beat the lunchtime rush right after 12:00PM, the service was fast and friendly and I got back to work in the Presidio in plenty of time. 

I had the Belly Bun, pork belly in an awesome oily sauce, parsley, carrots and  jalapenos. The bread was fresh, the textures were awesome and the flavor was savory, slightly smokey and definitely delicious. I did have to pull out a couple of jalapenos to suit my taste (there were a lot of seeds to go around and pith so it was very spicy). 

The sweet potato fries are the best I have ever had but I could easily pass on the remoulade they came with, they tasted great without it.

Though pork belly is very fatty (and I was expecting this) the two blobs of fat at the end of the sandwich (where there should have been meat for the $) were disappointing. 

Also, they call it a "Bun" but it's a sandwich so I was caught off guard by that. For reference Momofuku is my baseline for pork buns.
author: Brooke W.

description:
Today - I went overboard to make sure that I did not get the spicy peanut sauce with the my roll orders.  I said it at least 3 times.  I like the food but my tongue is burning from the peanut sauce.  If that's the sauce that's not spicy, thank goodness that I didn't order the spicy peanut sauce.  How hard can it be?  Seriously, food is good, service is super bad!!  I recommend that you check and taste before you leave with your feed.

Hint yelp people:  DRAGON EATS on Gough and Grove is better and cheaper.  3 rolls for $6.00 and they don't make stupid mistakes.
author: Richard Z.

description:
My coworkers made a trip out here and ordered me TAKE OUT - fatty pork belly Vietnamese sandwich and it was BOMB! 

He added an egg on it, which made the yolk cream out of the sandwich when I took the first initial bite.  It was around $10 including a shared sweet potato fries. There was also a special thick BACON mayo spicy sauce for the fries?! That was good! 

I've been raving about it to friends, will make a stop in and check out their full menu!
author: Chanel L.

description: The delivery people here are terrible. I tried to surprise my sick boyfriend by ordering him pho and having it delivered to his house. I live in philly so I paid on the phone so everything was taken care of. When I told the delivery guy I lived in philly he not only hung up on me while I was talking but he didn't fulfill my delivery bc of this. Despite this apparently being a third party company that does the deliveries it's absolutely no excuse for being so rude! I was so excited to be able to give my boyfriend this surprise from across the country and this inconsiderate delivery guy ruined it.
author: Colleen D.

description:
I'm torn. Do I give 2 stars? Or do I give 3 stars? 

I've never physically been to Bun Mee. The one and only experience I had with them was when I ordered with delivery. So... the person who delivered the food was unprofessional... and had the nerve to say that a huge chunk of his income is from TIPS. I've worked in the food industry before... and you shouldn't ever ask for TIPS or for more. I felt so disgusted after he said that. 

As for the food-- I rather go to a small mom and pop Vietnamese place where they're sticking authenticity. The food was very... hm... how do I say it? Geared towards Americans.... it was too Americanized for me. Probably also given the fact of the location of the restaurant. Oh and the food is on the pricer side.
author: Eugenia G.

description: The Hawker Bowl with chicken is one of my favorite lunches.  Authenticity arguments aside, the Banh Mi sandwich is good too.  I also like a mango side salad if I am feeling crazy.
author: Neal M.

description:
Upper Fillmore is the best area to chill on a beautiful, sunny day in San Francisco.  When I am here I get my fill of Sift and Bun Mee.  I can be a sucker for Viet sandwiches and this doesn't disappoint.  While the wait can be a bit long, esp. on a Friday night when there are loads of people waiting for their order, the flavors are unique and different from the sandwiches I've tried like the Irving Deli (on Irving St.) and Bahnwich on Taraval.  

While I do agree, with some Yelpers, that the meat is semi-dry , I enjoy the added radishes, carrots, and peppery flavors of the spices in the sauce.  I'm not a big fan of cilantro and jalapenos so yes I'm missing out on flavors in that sense, but the sandwiches are still enjoyable even without.  Oh yes, the egg.  For $1 more the added egg is definitely worth a try.

Overall?  I wouldn't say it's a MUST GO every single time, but it's definitely worth trying if 1st time, and worth coming back every so often.
author: Jessica S.

description: It's a tiny little place but worth it. Great spring rolls w/ peanut sauce. The Vietnamese sandwiches are a little pricey compared to most hole in the wall places, which was expected. I've had the chicken and tofu, both very good. My husband loves the tofu bowl too.
author: Leah B.

description: This is a fun, dependable, yummy quick place to grab lunch or a snack. The sandwiches and bowls are excellent. The springs rolls are pretty good. Been here twice. Combo sandwich is good and so is the Sloppy Bun. We have each had a sandwich, shared a roll, had a beer or some coffee and the bill is like $30. The food arrives fast.
author: Michael S.

description: The shrimp mango avocado salad was sooo good.  A bit small inside but the menu is great.  Sandwiches, salad and rice bowls.  If you just want a simple cheap Delicious Bahn, I still think Little Vietnam off of clement st is the spot.  But this place was a great change of pace.
author: Chelsey G.

description: SO GOOD! I'd never had a Vietnamese sandwich before Bun Mee, but now I have one any time I'm in the area. The staff is super friendly, the food is absolutely delicious, and you can be in and out in 10 minutes. The restaurant isn't huge but they have searing inside and out, or you can grab to go and walk up to the park. So tasty!
author: SF M.

description: I live around the corner - this is the restaurant I most frequently visit. It is cheap, quick, and delicious.
author: Sean Z.

description: Vegan mayo? Employees understanding that fish does not = vegetarian? Change is good. Thanks Denise for sticking to your promise and educating your employees re: the food they serve and what's in it!
author: Gev M.

description:
I too am bummed about the menu change. The caramel citrus bowl (with grapefruit and avocado) used to be my favorite. It was delicious and healthy. Now they just have a peanut rice bowl, which is not exactly healthy, features rubbery tofu and a gloppy sauce. Are they trying to save money by paring down the menu? Not sure, it seems that way though. 

The vietnamese coffee and limeade were still good. The decor and graphic design are super cute, but you can't eat them. 

The banh mi was never good (BiRite has one that is much better), the spring rolls are bland, the papaya and mango salads are terrible. 

The service is slow, marginally friendly and often they get your order wrong (I always order brown rice and an egg for my rice bowl. Once they gave me just that, nothing else that was supposed to be in it. Sometimes they forget the brown rice. I always get a quizzical look about the egg...). Sigh. I guess I won't be back until they bring back my caramel cirtrus bowl (hint, hint, fix your menu people!!)
author: Nicole M.

description:
Really cool location on Fillmore with lots of city life surrounding this small walk in and order place.  Tight surroundings include tables and counter seating for around 8 people.  It's always fun to sit at the counter if there are only two or less to watch the action and learn what to order next time.

Come here often so you can try more items.
author: Randall F.

description: I came here with the intention of only trying the sloppy bun. It was about 2/3 the size of a regular Vietnamese sandwich, which was good because I was not terribly hungry. I was really surprised when I opened it up. I have never seen a banh mi so organized. The cucumber ribbons were all perfectly lined up and the jalapenos were equidistant from one another, pretty ridiculous. I paid extra for an egg, but there were two! I read that the bread is from San Jose, but seemed actually a little better (crustier and chewier) than what I am used to. The meat was seasoned just right from the curry spices. It was a pretty freaking good sandwich.
author: Huey N.

description:
This is a solid place for Vietnamese sandwiches. Yes, they cost more than the shops in the T-loin, for obvious reasons. However, if you live in the neighborhood or aren't the type to venture over to the T-loin regularly, then this place is worth a shot.  

My husband and I were pleasantly surprised by their grilled pork sandwich. The pork was perfectly seasoned and juicy. The vegetables and herbs were fresh and crunchy. The bread was soft and delicious. Seriously mouthwatering and worthy of several repeats.  

I don't suggest coming here for anything besides sandwiches, however. We're huge fans of bun (rice noodle and salad dish), and opted to try it here. The fish sauce was lacking and my shrimp tasted like gasoline.  

With that said, I will definitely return for the grilled pork sandwich, especially since they are right up the street.
author: Jade F.

description: Meh, I don't think this place delivers.  I had the Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl with chicken and brown rice at a cost of $10 and the menu states that it comes with avocado, papaya, orange and grapefruit.  There was exactly one slice of each of the ingredients mentioned above and the bowl primarily consisted of brown rice.  The chicken was good but its so scarce that it was like looking for water in the desert. Overall, everything was very bland and not worth the price.
author: Monica G.

description:
Cute restaurant in an awesome neighborhood.. they have a separate vegetarian/vegan menu that tells you about all the substitutions that can be made to make stuff vegetarian!
I usually get the smokey eggplant sandwich with sweet potato fries.. pretty good.. love the sweet potato fries, but I think I have loved sweet potato fries pretty much everywhere, so won't really come specifically here to get those fries again.
They need to get more seating space, or make to-go orders get processed much much faster. Try and sit beside the windows if those spots are empty.. Fillmore is an awesome street to people watch in!
author: Aditya M.

description:
I stopped by with my mom yesterday to give this place a shot. walking in, I love the decor and the folks working there were friendly and attentive. The menu is cool and I believe that the unique twists on some of the fare are based on New Orleans being the homebase of the original store (homebase...such a nostalgic word). 

Anyway, I ordered the crispy tofu sandwich, a mango sesame salad, and garlic fries. As we were getting ready to leave, my mom decided she wanted to try the catfish, so she ordered it. I really like the feel of this place. 

The tofu sandwich was good. Nice crunchy bread, with fresh carrots, cilantro, onions, and shallots. The jalapenos were crunchy and gave it that ever so slight bit of heat. The tofu was solid (takes whatever flavor is around it) and the mayo was okay...I'm used to a thinner and slightly tangier mayo on my bahn mi sandwiches, but that's me. I messed up and left the salad out on my stove overnight, so I didn't get to try it. Boooo me!

I tried my mom's catfish sandwich and it was really good. The fish is cooked nicely and goes really well with the accompaniments. The fries were bland and I didn't taste any garlic. There were a few jalapenos in the container, but the fries weren't spicy at all to me.

All in all, I like this place and plan on trying some of the other dishes on the menu. Plus, they are walking distance from my mom's place so even better.
author: Karim V.

description: Just love the chicken salad, 5 spice chicken sandwich and the sloppy bun. We do take out from bun Mee pretty regularly and love how quick they are.
author: Kyoko T.

description:
This place is pretty good.

Their catfish sandwich is insane--great flavors, nice crunch and man those pickled veggies really hit the spot. Add a little hot sauce and you're good to go.

Their tofu sandwich is a major major letdown though. The tofu is tough and the flavors really feel like a huge carb bomb. Also, keep in mind that it's not soy mayo but mayo made with soy so if you're vegan you're going to need to tell them to hold the mayo.

I also have issue with the speed of their takeout. About half the time my food comes on time, and the other half it just seems to take forever. The shop is small and there's not a ton of places to hang out so you feel like a real creeper just standing there.
author: Paul C.

description:
Nothing too special, but serviceable as a quick/tasty lunch spot.  

The banh mi's are certainly the focal point here, and even though they do have sides, I would recommend just sticking with the sandwiches themselves.  In my 3-4 trips here so far, the ingredients have ranged from semi-fresh to fresh, which is a plus, but the sandwiches haven't been doing it for me.  My main gripe, especially when compared to other banh mis in the city, these lack a lot of filling, especially when it comes to the meat serving size.  You are often left with just a heel of bread and a string or two of carrot. 

As stated, the sides haven't done anything for me, including the fries.  

Service has been fine each time.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Beyond excited when Bun Mee came to the neighborhood....top it off, they deliver!!!
I love the salt & pepper fries and all the Bun Mee sandwiches are great (add an egg, it changes everything!!).The service is fast, very limited seating, don't come with a large party without calling. 
Music has been a bit loud every time I've been here....Suggestion- order delivery if you have a headache.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Yawn. Bun Mee is very mediocre, and I wouldn't have stopped here to eat if it wasn't for my aching tummy. 

To summarize:

-Skimpy portions, meat was very bland
-Bread was stale and took away from the sandwich
-Overpriced for such a bare sandwich
-Presentation was very meh; if you're going to charge 7$ for a tiny ass sandwich, at least serve it with a mini salad or something!

Going to a banh mi joint down south like SJ would give you way more bang for your buck.
author: Hanui C.

description:
We happened upon this spot during a summer walk in the city.  We've recently started eating Bánh mì sandwiches and find them quite delish.  Their version was tasty, but not as much meat as we're used to from traditional Vietnamese spots.  I believe we had ours with sweet potato fries (which is the only fry we eat).  The fries were actually better than the sammich.  Since we shared the entire order (sammich and fries) it wasn't too expensive.  And, it's actually a lot of food for one person.  

Will we return?  Maybe...  Of course, it's hipster-ish and I don't particularly go for that scene, but sometimes I break my own rules!

Oh, good music playing in the background.  I was getting my hip/hop groove on.
author: Felicia P.

description:
Yummy! Got the catfish sandwich which was super tasty and fresh. 

The iced coffee...not so good, and should have had the sweet lychee drink.

Great for quick, casual bite.
author: Sharon M.

description: the food is great but their supervisor, Manuella is the rudest person Ive ever encountered. I live 2 blocks away from this location but now refuse to go back because she was so unpleasant.
author: M L.

description:
On our walk down this block, we noticed that there's a cluster of restaurants which appear to be trying to take hole-in-the wall Asian street food upscale and hip.  We passed by the expensive steamed bun shop, turned the corner at the expensive street taco shop, and finally arrived at Bun Mee ... the expensive Vietnamese Sandwich shop.

Well - they actually offer some hot food as well ... but stay with me here.

Yeah.  It's cute.  And no doubt the rent on this stretch of Fillmore is high.  And it looks like they spent too much money on the kitchen, which takes up half the restaurant.  Apparently, I can pay up to $7.95 for a banh mi, though most flavors are a little over $6.

The flavors are not exactly normal - you can get pork belly, or smoked eggplant.  And this is where you have to start asking yourself the question - do exotic ingredients make a sandwich *better*?  Or just more expensive?  I mean, to me, a properly made, traditional banh mi is pretty much one of the best things ever, and changing it really isn't worth *more* to me.

So we came armed with a Blackboard Eats deal - $10 for $15 of food!  Or something like that.  Actually, you could get a sandwich ( except the steak sandwich ), a side salad, and a drink.  The minimum possible value for your $10: $11.  The maximum: $13.75.  This was not the deal we were looking for, or expecting.  In fact, the only way to get even close to the deal advertised would have been to get the steak sandwich, which was specifically excluded.  That was kind of rubbing it in, I think.

In any case, we got the combo and the eggplant sandwiches, shredded napa and mango salads, and strawberry/lychee agua fresca and a beer.  Beer Lao in bottles was all they had, so that's what we got.

The sandwiches were good, though we had a hard time finding any pate or mortadella in the combo sandwich.  Salads were fresh, the mango salad having plenty of mangoes.  The agua fresca was similarly good.  I have no problem with the taste or quality of the sandwich.  I just happen to like the real thing from the local hole in the wall ( or Lee's ) better.

They were not crowded at all on a Thursday evening around 7pm.  We found seats right away, and did not have to wait in line for longer than it took to figure out what we wanted to order.  Food arrived relatively quickly.

We did decide to try out their famous coconut creme cookie after dinner.  $1.68 after tax.  And after they for some reason decided that they needed my *name* to enter the cookie order.  I have never had a more complex cookie purchase experience.  The cookie is thin, and as my companion said, it's "kind of like a coconut oreo, but more expensive."

In the end, it's a perfectly fine place if you're willing to pay that much for a ... different ... banh mi sandwich.
author: Albert H.

description:
Cute name, great aesthetic, overall disappointing. Full disclosure, we didn't try their sandwiches, just an afternoon snack. 

I'm a stickler for good cafe su da (Vietnamese coffee) and was struck that when I ordered mine, it came to my table immediately, which made me suspect that it wasn't dripped to order, the authentic way. Already knowing the answer to my question, I inquired about the process by which they make their coffee, and was told what I already suspected, that they typically make a batch of it every one or two days. At $3.50 a glass, it's overpriced and weak compared to what the "real" Vietnamese places are doing. 

The fried egg rolls were decent, but again, the $5.50 sticker price seemed way too high for two small egg rolls. I'm usually not fazed by overpriced food, because to me, if it's good, it's worth it. But in Bun Mee's case, it was both expensive and underwhelming. 

On a positive note, the overall feel of the place was great and the use of Cafe du Monde coffee cans as chopstick/napkin holders was cute. Too bad they weren't actually brewing the coffee in those cans to make my Vietnamese coffee.
author: Lee H.

description:
Update:  I have been here many times, and with varying experiences. 
Food is generally great- REALLY amazing when they first opened, and it has fallen off a little, but still very, very good!

I would give them a solid three stars but tonight, we had such terrible service from one staffer, that I am giving them two. She brought the entire experience down because she out and out ignored me. 

My friend and I arrived for a pick up order but there was parking right in front so we decided to stay. I stood in a long line with two servers at the counter. As SOON as I got to the counter, the blonde woman turned her back on me, (no acknowledgement whatsoever) and proceeded to flip through papers, back and forth and back and forth. Her co-worker, the only guy in the front of the house, was working his tail off and was great. But, I had to wait for him to finish with his customers because this woman was not going to do a finger to assist a customer. Oh, until he couldn't find my order and then she assisted HIM, not me. 

When we finished our meals and I needed a take out box, I went to the counter again and stood there and stood there and stood there while she ignored me AGAIN! her co-worker, the guy, who was doing all the heavy lifting, was busy serving meals to tables, something I noticed she didn't do... and finally, I just went up to her and asked her for a take out box. She was terrible. IF I owned a business and had an employee who were ignoring customers, I would write them up and have a LONG discussion. IF it didn't change, I would fire them.   I may not sign her paycheck, but I sure as hell am paying her salary by patronizing the business. Too bad that is lost on her. Hopefully, the owner reads reviews or will see her work performance and correct the situation. I sure don't intend to go back soon so that i can be ignored again. Too bad her poor co-worker has to do all the work she won't do. He was great, but she really was like acid and soured everything.
author: susan a.

description: Maybe I ordered the wrong thing but I don't understand what all the hype is.  the lines are long, the food is bland at best.  I got the smoked eggplant sandwich with a fried egg - it was not hot or spicy; and it was very dry.   I thought they said the sandwich came with hot jalapenos.  i didn't taste it.  it was fun to try but not sure I would be back - i spend half of the lunch hour in line for a sandwich!  There were no spots to sit in the restaurant.  i recommend coming here at 11:30 or so if you want to sit and eat.  Otherwise, just grab the sandwich and go back to your desk.  I tried this with my vietnamese friend and she said it wasn't really authentic.  The decor was nice, and I liked the feel of the space - just wish there were enough seats for the patrons.  Also another plus is that the sandwiches are under or around $8, which is very good for downtown.
author: Bebe W.

description: A meal for two consisting of Vietnamese iced coffee, some sort of fried spring roll appetizer, and two sandwiches was over $40. Friendly service, tasty foods, but you can definitely get better in the Sunset District , for about $25.00. Overall review, not worth the money. The only reason to go is if you happen to be craving this kind of food as you walk by.
author: Pablo K.

description:
HAIR IN YOUR SANDWICHES!!!

Let's cut to the chase, there was a piece of hair in one of the sandwiches and they didn't do anything!! The cashier was trying to apologize and was lost for words. 

I noticed that the restaurant received an 84 for cleanliness and that number was the number AFTER they had already fixed all their problems. I asked the cashier if that was one of the many reasons they received an 84 because they serve their food with hair. 

None of the chefs wear hats when cooking.  

To add more insult to injury, my friend and I ate the damn things because we were hungry. He insisted he wanted to try the cookies despite the hair in the food because 7x7 named the cookies at Bun Mee as one of the best....The cashier did not even think of giving them to us free, I just laughed.

So overall........Bun Mee gets three strikes....

1.  Restaurant did not try to rectify the situation.
2.  Restaurant couldn't apologize and just kept on nodding and couldn't believe there 
     was a hair in the sandwich.
3.  Bought some cookies after we advised them about the hair and still got charged. 


If you want hair on your sandwiches and have the Bun Mee team not do anything nor apologize...this is the place for you.....

Oh.......just to show proof if the manager or owner reads this review..I have receipt 408 and 413!!!
author: T M.

description:
The price is acceptable for the portion size, and the food is so good. 

I absolutely love, love, love the Bun Noodle Bowl with chicken. Yummm.

The catfish sandwich is super tasty too.
author: Lydia S.

description:
Very delish casual dining or take out.  I've had their salt and pepper garlic fries (ok), mango salad (very good), the juicy steak sandwich (which both bf and I loved), and their hawker bowl.

I'd say things are fresh, tasty, good quality and worth the bucks.  Highly recommended.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
Not somewhere i'd crave out of the blue, but considering I work in Pac Heights, Bun Mee is a fun place to come to on my lunch breaks (especially since their music is usually ON POINT). A little expensive for Bahn Mi's IMO, but considering the location, it's at a pretty good price point.

Definitely a place to try, at least once or twice.
author: C D.

description:
I'm a white kid from Pleasanton.  These sandwiches are crisp and fresh, but I'd like even more char on my pork if you don't mind.  Pork needs to always be crispy on the outside.  Otherwise, I'd be happy to eat 10 of these.  I'd say the average chubby joe like me needs two for lunch.

Good stuff.
author: NoCal S.

description: Great spot for easy in easy out. Quick and cheerful service, quality is a plus for the price point here. Can't go wrong- enjoy.
author: Christine T.

description:
Eh, not impressed. It's not bad, but not great either. I understand that the Banh Mi is  pricier most likely due to rent on Fillmore or something- but still, I would go back only if I'm truly desperate. Also, I ordered a pork sandwich, not a carrot sandwich, as mine was stuffed 3/5 with carrot. wth.

If you are craving a banh mi, and would still like a bougie-ish/whitify decor and feel, go to Cafe Bunn Mi in the inner Richmond.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I had never had a vietnamese sandwich before this.

I ordered the grilled pork sandwich and an iced coffee.

The sandwich was delicious and I had never had anything like it before.  The sandwich came with the request meat, pickled carrots, cilantro, and onion.  I also, by request, had the most delicious dipping sauce (made of fish sauce and something else).  

The iced coffee was also incredible and is available in to-go cups.
author: Jared O.

description:
5 spice chicken bahn mi - the bread is a bit too thick for my taste.  I'd prefer Lee's sandwiches over Bun Mee.

Their sweet potato fries were lukewarm, some were cold and hard.  Had a feeling the mixed an old batch with an OLDER batch.  

Probably won't come by again...
author: Janet L.

description: I really miss the eggplant sandwich. It was smokey and full of all kinds of mouthwatering bits of carrot, daikon, jalapeño, seasoned mayo, cilantro omg I'm jonesing and there's no where to go
author: Sarah R.

description:
A friend of a friend made the decision of stopping here for some grub, I'm happy the kid did because this spot is fab. 

I kid you not the minute I walked in I was dancing, they have a great music selection for you to enjoy while you enjoy your well done, well prepared sandwich, along with the cool scooter/vespa art on the wall. 

I walked in like they knew I was coming, they lady at the register greeted me with a smile despite the line in front of her, and the music was on point as I weighed out my options on my first delicious taste of a Vietnamese sandwich. 

The sandwich was a rainbow of veggies well stacked up on each other. I ordered the stake sandwich, the thing looked too pretty to eat, but of course hunger won and the sandwich disappeared, but during this whole time a smile was on my face. Impossible you say! I kid you not, it stayed on my face, I was in good company, we talked about the awesome flavors and the bread.

I will be coming back for more of this awesome food. Good work people!
author: Edith G.

description:
Went back for some take out for a park outing and got the meatball, which I hope they keep on the menu, and a catfish. Both were outstanding. The quality of food here is just amazing. All they need is to add Chao, Xoi, and Pho to the menu so I can eat there for breakfast too. 

[Also, the owner is super professional, responding appropriately to a less than perfect visit. Much appreciated.]
author: James S.

description:
I went here on a whim and except for the fries, the food is nothing noteworthy and and quite pricey for vietnamese sandwiches. The worst items I tried were the two salads. (mango and something else). It's not terrible but pretty unoriginal and meager.

The sweet potato fries, though, make for a great snack, as they are uniquely seasoned with (what I believe) is ramen packet seasoning after they are deep fried. Even though I paid them a visit after some crazy cardio, I didn't at all regret dipping those sticks in the vinegar sauce and plunging them into my mouth. 
Yummy! 
Parking here Is pretty much impossible so be sure to bring someone along to pick up the goods. 

I commend them on the modernized version of a Vietnamese sandwich shop, however, as always, food quality, taste and value come first.

No return trip from this yelper.
author: Sue T.

description:
Great vegetarian selection of food, only downside is the crispy tofu roll doesn't come with coriander. 

Worth a visit if you enjoy fresh and tasty Vietnamese food with a modern twist.
author: Bianca M.

description:
Been here once. Had the Pork Belly BAHN MI, and it was extremely greasy. I didn't finish it. Very tight and not much seating inside. We took our sandwiches to-go and ate at the nearby park.

House made lemonade is pretty good.

The sauce for the sweet potato fries was so-so. Kind of tasted like curry. Not sure how I feel about that as a fries sauce.

OVERALL: Would not come here to spend $7-8 on a so-so bahn mi sandwich. I'd rather go to Little Saigon and get a delicious Vietnamese sandwich for $3.
author: Gina R.

description:
Our work received a catered lunch from Bun Mee today from this much acclaimed place.

We had fresh salad rolls (with sliced kurubuta pork, prawns, etc) and tofu rolls, the mango sesame salad, a plethora of sandwiches and coconut cookie sandwiches for dessert. 

1. The fresh rolls (both the prawn and tofu versions) had the SOFTEST rice paper skins I've ever eaten. EVER. And I've had a lot of fresh rolls. 

2. Mango sesame salad... the dressing was SOOO flavorful. I expected it to be okay... but I did a total double-take and got seconds.

3. Only had room for one sandwich: the grilled pork. It was great. No complaints. Great flavor, the pork was tender, the bread crisp but not too hard.

4. and... then... oh the cookies. All my coworkers were raving about this and even though I was full, I couldn't NOT try it. The coconut cookie sandwiches have an oreo like cookie part and it's filled with this creamy coconut filling that's super light and fluffy. Not too sweet. Some of the coconut flakes are just crisp enough. Everyone had at least 2 cookies. 

This place will need to be repeated. Definitely.
author: Nicha K.

description:
Meh... I thought I would whirlin to get something healthier than the Mac &Cheese across the street at The Grove. Enter Bun Mee...

I generally love Vietnamese food... But I would have been better served going around the corner to Out the Door. I chose the noodle bowl, which seemed watery and flavorless. The egg roll was soggy, and the fish sauce do nothing to improve it. Not impressed...
author: Erin C.

description:
Not the greatest, and not the cheapest, but it does the job when you're craving some Vietnamese sandwiches.
