Part of me feels ridiculous paying over 6 or 7 dollars for a Vietnamese sandwich, especially since one barely fills you up, but if that's the cost of having a shop on Fillmore street near my apartment then so be it.  

My main gripe is the inconsistency of the sandwiches.  For starters, sometimes the bread tastes fresh with the perfect balance of moisture and crispiness, other times it's too soft and dull.  Odd, I know, but you really can pick up on the subtlety.  Plus, there's more:

Sometimes the catfish is crispy, other times it's a little too soggy .  
Sometimes the steak is juicy and easy to eat, other times it's tough and dry.  
Sometimes the pork belly has great tender meat, other times it's 75% lard.

Get my drift?
author: Bobby L.

description: Use them for catering and their sandwiches are SO DELICIOUS!! The mango sesame salad is so scrumptious as well. This is my favorite Vietnamese sandwich
author: Chelz A.

description:
Yummy!! Gourmet Vietnamese Banh Mi's without the sketchy neighborhood and questionable mom and pop kitchen hygiene.

Coworker recommended this place so we dropped by to pick up some deliciousness!

Pork Belly - braised kurobuta pork belly, onion, daikon, relish, jalapeños,cilatro.
Add a fried egg for a dollar and you are in heaven!

The bun noodle bowls (Bun Thit Noung translated literally noodle meat grilled) seem to be the next popular dish. 

Worth checking out - not your usual Vietnamese deli.

Banh Mi varieties also include chicken, pork, steak, sloppy joe style ground beef, and even catfish.

Bun noodles - chicken, shrimp, vietnamese caesar - with/without vermicelli noodle option available for low carbers.

Small sides including Vietnamese classic salads and spring rolls but they offer sweet potato fries! Score!!
author: Mia N.

description: Nom Nom Nom! So delicious!! I went here tonight for dinner and had a rice bowl with shrimp and my tongue just wanted to keep eating even though my stomach was full.  I don't know what else to say except that I hope to get to return while on my trip here because it was just so delicious.
author: Nicole B.

description:
I normally love Bun Mee - the price is right for the quality, the flavors are normally pretty spot on, and the ingredients taste fresh. HOWEVER, I just ordered lunch from Bun Mee (Summer Rolls and a Five Spiced Chicken Salad), and it was almost inedible. 

Rolls: They added pineapple to the summer rolls,and in general they were sloppy, fell apart, and definitely a distinct step down from the previous incarnation. The sauce also had obviously been sitting for a while as it had oil on the top, and was much thicker than normal. 

Five Spice Chicken Salad: The chicken was gray, and so fatty that I couldn't eat it. It also had bits of bone. Disgusting. They have added some crispy wontons that look/feel like they're not fresh. Only the tomatoes were really ok.
author: Lauren L.

description: I had the peanut bowl and 3 hours later, I'm still thinking about how boring my lunch was. Where's the flavor? No amount of Sriracha could make up for the blandness of this dish. Big fat yawn.
author: Sandy L.

description:
The sandwich phenomenon happening in sf the past few years has done horrible things to my pant size. Bunmees fresh take on asian inspired sammies did not disappoint. 

I got the combo sandwich which was quite tasty but nothing super duper extraordinary. Good play on flavors with the pickled carrots, a bit of spice,meat and some sort of tapenaude? I will definitely get it again. Plus they are huuge! The jalepeno garlic fries were also interesting with the shaved jalepeno onion topping. 

What gave this place 4 stars instead of 3 was the crazy good, crazy small gingerbread cookie sandwich. If I could buy a box of them I would. I am even considering ordering a sandwich right now so I can get that cookie. Seriously, order it you wont regret it.
author: nina a.

description: Hard not to notice Bun Mee's smoky spice filled chimney while strolling down fillmore. This french vietnamese sandwich place is a keeper for its shocking price tag : 6.75 bunmee combo kurobuta (japanese for black pig) sandwich ... yes in pac heights! That is a satisfying dosage of spice salt and hot sauce. Vietnamese coffee? Check. Coconut creme cookie? Guanrateed satisfaction, literally one is enough. Fast? Super fast. In this economy i am digging Royal ground coffee (close by) for classical sandwiches and Bun Mee for the alternative.
author: Dilys S.

description:
McDonald's 20-piece chicken nuggets cost $4.99.  Everyone knows this, because it's everyone's secret guilty pleasure.

But, would anyone in their right mind pay more than $4.99 for the nuggets?  Hopefully not.

No one in their right mind should pay more than $5 for a banh mi.  If there is one that costs more than that, it better be freaking amazing.  Unfortunately, the almost $7 that I forked over for a Belly Bun (pork belly, pickled vegetables) was totally not worth it.

In fact, no one could pay me to order that again, as the sauce they put on was so, so salty that my coworker and I choked after one bite.  I couldn't even eat half of the sandwich.  While the pork belly and the vegetables were good, the sauce completely ruined the entire sandwich.

Thanks to Scoutmob, I scored a free order of their spring rolls, which I gave to my coworker (he said it was delicious, and it did look good).  I'm willing to give them another shot, but I'm definitely not ordering the Belly Bun again.
author: Tori S.

description: The only reason I am writing this review is because the yelp asked my too... (the little window popped up after my last review. I don't have much to say about this place mainly because I didn't have much on my plate. There was plenty of Bun and NO MEAT. If I would have returned to the counter had I noticed the mishap sooner, they probably would have thought I ate the chicken and just wanted more. It was a sad sandwich, and what little I had was just ok. I'm not sure what the rave is here, but it must be from people who have a thing for marinated bread. Can't say I'll be back, but who knows.
author: Miguel V.

description:
Bun Mee has a number of good options for a vegetarian. This was my first visit to Bun Mee. I was famished after a run, and found myself on Fillmore. 

I bought the tofu wrap and add the papaya side salad. Because of the rice noodles, the 2-piece wrap was quite filling for lunch - I ended up taking one whole wrap home. Good value, good food, quick service.
author: Joanna L.

description:
I've grownup eating as many "Banh Mi" as someone growing up here eating peanut butter sandwiches. The post important aspect of a Banh Mi is the bread. I have to say that I was really dissappointed in their bread. It was toasted, however the outside started to crackle so the tops of the bread were just falling off and it was DRY!!, the sandwich was so DRY. there wasn't even enough mayonnaise or even a bit of soy sauce for it to be moist. I had the juicy steak but it wasn't juicy. I ended up throwing out the bread and just eating the carrots, daikon, cilantro, and the meat separately.

I will not be going back, whether I paid $5 or $10, money is no objective when it comes to good eats. This was NOT a good eats for me.
author: J. C.

description:
I really wanted to hate this place. Even though I can't stand people who scream about places like this being inauthentic, whatever that means, I can see their point. Saigon Sandwich and Cam Huong and their ilk make banh mis so damn good, why mess with success? 

Well here's why: For only $3 more (which also happens to be TWICE the price of a Saigon banh mi but still a bargain), I can specify exactly how I want my banh mi and I'll get delicious all white meat chicken. No sorry, I am not listening to your story about how dark chicken with fatty skin is so authentic and delicious. I'm an overly westernized white tool so I find it disgusting which is why I usually go with the grilled pork at Saigon. And as an added bonus, that extra $3 assures me that I do not have to fight off indignant bums and crack hos and dodge piles of human feces on Larkin. Yum. 

I'm just deducting a star for now because when I tore in to my sandwich an hour or so later at the SF Ballet in Stern Grove*, the bread was kind of crumbly, but maybe they're just meant to be eaten fresher than that. 


*PS. See? I told you. I'm a white tool. Don't be trying to feed me fatty skin dark meat chicken or pig hooves or whatever.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Edit: They've improved their service and rice hasn't been an issue for the last few weeks.  Thank you very much!

I live two blocks away from Bun Mee and have stopped here for dinner about ten times over the past two months.  Without fail, they are always out of something substantial - like rice, noodles, or all of the meats except steak.  I recently discovered that they accept orders online but forty-five minutes after placing my order, they called to tell me that they couldn't fulfill the order because they were out of... rice.  If one of your signature dishes is a rice bowl, you can't consistently run out of rice by 6 pm and expect customers to return.
author: Elaine W.

description: Fast ordering, great food, and giant portions all at a reasonable price. Can you ask for more in SF?
author: Camilo A.

description:
I think I've tried half of their banh mi menu at this point and I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet!  This place is a little on the small side so I tend to just take my orders to go.  That being said, this place is at the top of the list for me if I'm in the mood to wander out past Divis for lunch at work.  The best part is you can order your sandwich and pay online then just pick it up, ready to go, at the restaurant.  No human interaction necessary!

Loves:
Grilled Five Spice Chicken
Belly Bun
Combo (you'll want to take a nap after this one ... it is heeeavy)

Eh, it's alright:
Sloppy bun
Catfish

Everyone says it's a little pricey for banh mi (considering you can get one in the TL for $3).  But people, remember where we are now.  For $7, the prices here are way reasonable for what you get than other places in this neighborhood.

Next time I come here I'll remember to sign up for their frequent diner card because that's what you'll turn into after eating at this place!
author: Jean A.

description:
If you're expecting authentic Vietnamese food go elsewhere. 

The customer service was great, friendly and attentive, 5 stars for that. However the food was just... Not. Good. 

I ordered both spring rolls and what I got was not what I expected. First of all the price was a bit steep, $5.75 for only two rolls? Ouch. A spring roll normally as a lot of flavor from the pickled radish and carrots, but it was bland. No flavor at all. The peanut sauce was probably literally peanut butter and salt. It was thick and sweet. Weird. Also, there was pineapple in the spring an pork roll... Lol what?

On to the banh mi, I had the combination and the pork belly about 6.50 each. First of all the bread was hard and had a lot of butter in it. Again, no flavor in the pickled vegetables. If you don't look at it like a banh mi, it's a good sandwich. But as a banh mi it was horrible. It tasted very bland, and the meat was flavored very "American." Also, there was NO TRACE OF FISH SAUCE ANYWHERE!!! WHY?! -sobs- It didn't hit my banh mi craving at all.
author: Lianna L.

description: I love me some banh mi sandwiches and Bun Mee does a pretty good job with their renditions.  I think it could have been a bit spicier but I was pleased with grilled five spice chicken.  Good prices too.
author: Blake B.

description:
Small space, moderate prices, good healthy tasty food done right.

Fresh strawberry lychee juice
5-Spice Chicken or Grilled Pork Sandwich with Jalepenos and Mint
(Exclamation).

Grilled corn (seasonal only )

This location is in the works of having the city approve a liquor license. I am crossing my fingers on that. I could always use a cold one with all that wonderful  Sriracha.

I'm not hyped about viet sammies normally, but I like Bun Mee. 
They rock.
author: Hannah A.

description:
P.S., I had to re-write because the original review was flagged and removed.


I see the place used be a gelato place I love became Bun Mee

and i'm like,Fxxx you!

Oo, Boo, Meh

I guess the change in my pocketWasn't enough i'm like, Fxxx you!

And fxxx The Sandwich too!

I said, if i was richer, i'd still be with on LarkinHa, now ain't that some sxit? 

(ain't that some sxit?)

And although there's pain in my chestI still wish the gelato the best with a...Fxxx you!Oo, Boo, Meh

Yeah i'm sorry, i can't afford a sandwich,
But that don't mean i can't get you there.

I guess he's on upper Fillmore and i'm more Larkin St,
But the way you play your game ain't fair.
I picture the fool that falls in love with you
(oh shit they are gold digger)

Well
(just thought you should know Japo)
Oo, Boo, Meh

I've got some news for youYeah go run and tell your friends Boo Meh!

7 bucks for a vietnamese sandwich?
No Thank you!
And I had better on Larkin.

The place reminds me, Zao used on Fillmore and California, and uses same chopsticks.
The Zao was totally BS failure.
Maybe same owner, I don't know.
If so, I can see the end.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Really loved the food here - am so happy I finally got to try it after hearing so many great reviews from my friends.  YUM!

The items to get:
- Belly Bun sandwich: It's ammmaazing!  So delicious and tasty.
- Salt n Pepper garlic fries.  We liked it so much we ordered second.
- Limeade for a drink - not too sweet, too!
- Vietnamese coffee too - these things are delicious

I particularly liked how everything was just so fresh.  I hear all of the vegetables are cut, marinated and pickled in-house, which is awesome!  Really friendly service.  Great neighborhood to check out/walk around in before/after, too.

We will definitely be back!
author: Arry Y.

description:
Hey, this is good stuff. It may be a little Americanized but it's still Vietnamese. I eat Vietnamese at least 3 times a week. 
 I do think consistency is something they need to work on. Which is why I pulled one star. 

I'd love to see Bun Xoa on  the menu please. =D
author: Anthony M.

description:
When trying to elevate typical cheap ethic eats to gourmet level you run a high risk of coming up short in a cost-quality analysis. Your gourmet fair has to far exceed the cheap eats to make up to compensate for markup-- an uphill battle in it of itself -- but when your product doesn't even match the quality of a cheaper buy you're heading for trouble fast. 

For this reason I'd warn friends off of Bun Mee sandwiches when Little Saigon probably better than it is cheaper. The steam buns are pretty good and arguably worth the extra cost but those sandwiches left me feeling cheated. The salads were pretty good. Especially the free mango one I redeemed in through the Scoutmob offer. All things considered, I'd go back with the aforementioned caveat in mind.
author: Quentin J.

description:
I got a crispy tofu sandwich for a quick bite to eat today and loved it.  The bread was super fresh, crusty, and crunchy, and the filling of tofu, carrots, jalapenos, dressing, etc. offered the perfect mix of spicy, sour, and refreshing.  I was glad I turned down the spicy sauce, didn't feel like I needed it on top of the jalapeno slices and seeds. 
I'll definitely go back when I'm on Fillmore Street for another sandwich or to try something new.
author: Jean L.

description: Great spot to pick up a delicious and unique lunch. The Five Spice Chicken sando with an iced coffee is where it is at.
author: D S.

description:
I love this place! Like really, really love. I've been here a couple times and every time the food was so amazing. I've had the "sloppy joe", pork belly, smoked eggplant, grilled chicken and grilled pork sandwiches, all of which were delicious. I always order a fried egg to go on the sandwiches, because I love eggs and they make everything so much tastier. I know that the prices might seem slightly on the pricey side, but keep in mind that these aren't JUST Vietnamese sandwiches. These are gourmet, fusion sandwiches, and that is exactly what you are paying for. If you want a cheap, authentic Vietnamese sandwich, hit up the Tenderloin for that. But seriously, if you want to get your money's worth, don't order the more "traditional" style sandwiches. Go for something different, because that's why you're at Bun Mee, right??

Anyways, I did order the glass noodle salad for like an extra $2 or something, but was definitely not impressed with it. It was too tart and the noodles were just kind of a weird texture. And it was swimming in too much dressing. So I would definitely recommend sticking to the sandwiches. Fries are okay too because.. well you can never go wrong with fries!
author: Amanda C.

description:
For all the haters on Yelp, this place sure is popular! 

Bun Mee is a great Vietnamese option when you're strolling along Fillmore. I wouldn't describe it as a "destination" restaurant, but I live in the area and find myself here almost every weekend for some good, solid food. 

Is this more expensive then any of the other Vietnamese restaurants cited by other Yelpers in the Tenderloin? Of course, look where it's located. It may cost you a couple bucks more, but certainly that's in part due to being in a high rent area.

Onto the food... Everything has been pretty good. I'm a fan of their shrimp salad and rice bowls (you have got to try their lime rice!). I'm not much of a sandwich person, but have taken a bite or two and found it to be great. So why not 5 stars? Bun Mee needs to reevaluate using such fatty pieces of meat. While I do like their food, I do not like the chunks of fat hanging onto their beef and pork. 

As for service, it's always been stellar. Good luck finding a place to sit, though. They are often packed!
author: Laura K.

description: This is based solely on the catering they've done for our office, and, as such, I can't make any comments on their pricing. Having tried a variety of their available bahn mis, I will say this: they're not spectacular, but they're not bad either. But, and this a big but, their hot sauce is absolutely amazing - from what I can make of it, it's primarily Sriracha based, mixed with whatever other secret spices they've decided to throw in. A shame they don't package and sell this stuff by the bottle!
author: Johnny W.

description: I recently ate here for the first time and thought it was quite good.  We ordered the chicken sandwich, steak sandwich, rice and chicken for our son and a couple beers.  I believe it was less than $40 with a tip, which I found very reasonable.  The rice was moist and deliciously seasoned as well as the chicken and chicken sandwich.  The beef could have been better in my opinion and reminded me too much of beef jerky.  Overall good experience and I would definitely recommend popping in for a quick tasty meal.
author: Josh A.

description:
Not really a fan. I think the sandwiches at Dinosaurs (Castro) and Saigon Sandwich (TL) are wayyyyy better.

The bread is way too dry and crumbles into pieces when you bite into it, the ratio of (under-seasoned) pork to (bland) pickled carrots and daikon weighs too heavily on the bland meat, no cilantro that I could see...

And all this for the price of two sandwiches elsewhere...

Not going back.
author: I Love S.

description:
Bun Mee, I really tried giving you a chance, and I REALLY tried liking you, but I just can't.

My first experience here there was hair in my food, and when I told the girl behind the counter she just shrugged. Whateves, right? Ugh. If you're that apathetic about your job, then I guess I just won't care for your food.

The Vietnamese coffee and lychee lemonade are too sweet, like straight sugar. It's pretty gross. 

Now, I won't bother going here. I'm just apathetic, like their employees.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I tried this spot out for the first time the other day! I love Bahn mi sandwiches so I'm always on the lookout for new spots. I ordered the crispy catfish sandwich...the bread was a little tough but the fish was good. I do wish it had more sauce. Next time I'll ask for extra sauce. I ordered the bun bowl with tofu. I really liked it and the flavors were good. Next time, I'll order the pork sandwich. I'd go back. I want to try more of their stuff.  The staff was friendly. Cool spot.
author: Mel P.

description:
This place is trendy and new. There are only 6 small tables inside and a short bar. Basically they serve the vietnamese sandwiches. I ordered the 5-spice chicken and my friend ordered the eggplant sandwiches. They are OK and did not wow us. Nothing really specail or authentic about the food. You can get the same or even better ones at half prices in normal Vietnamese resturants. The prices are too high. I gues it is because of the location. It is pretty for Caucasian-ized for sure. 

No. I wont go back again.
author: mc a.

description: great lunch spot, super fast, fresh and flavorful! they have a good mix of bowls, sandwiches, and sides, even for vegetarians.. they have a tofu bun mee that is amazine. the drinks are yummy as well and everything is priced well. the seating space is small but you should be able to typically find a spot. definitely will return to try out more of the menu.
author: Ms B.

description:
Bun Mee is nowhere as good as Saigon Sandwich.

Their buns are generic.  The fillings are seasoned with too much vinegar and garlic (destroys your breath for the rest of the day; tastes overwhelming, not good).  

Salads have the same flavor as the sandwiches, and often a gummy mouth feel that sticky rice alone can't explain.  

I hope they pick up their game.  The restaurant is cheerful, and most of the staff are friendly.  They're not worth a visit right now.
author: Bonzo C.

description:
I was coming back home from a trip to Texas and after allllllllllllllllllllll of the Mexican food I ate (4 times in 5 days!) all I wanted was some good Asian food. The whole flight I couldn't stop thinking about how glorious my BunMee was going to be. I went straight from the airport to pick up dinner there and once again, it did not disappoint. My boyfriend and I split the Sloppy Bun an 5 Spice Chicken Bun...DAMN IT WAS GOOD! We also each got a side of fries--the sweet potato fries with spicy aioli and the regular fries that were spicy and sprinkled with black pepper and jalepenos. Both sides were excellent, as expected.

 I know I just moved to San Francisco and I really need to try a ton of different places, but Bun Mee makes it SO hard by being so damn good!
author: Holly G.

description:
The Belly Bun is good, but it costs the equivalent 102900.00dong.  That's a lot, considering I can get one at Lee's for nearly half the cost, and it tastes almost identical. Actually, it tastes better.  And its twice the size.

I also found a chunk of egg shells in my french fries. The mass was held together by dried egg whites.  When I told the girl working the counter, she didn't give a shit.  When she told the owner standing behind her, she didn't give a shit. I don't expect any explanation or even a new order of fries -- I just want you to give a shit.

Foodborne pathogens y'all.  Get with it.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Overpriced, but a hip locale and clean. That doesn't make up for the semi empty sandwich. It also doesn't make up for the nice big chunk of fat. It was tasty meats, but definitely not worth it. So, that's pretty meh. It's 2x the price and just doesn't deliver. If it was packed full of the tasty meats and no big chunks of fat, that would muster out an extra star. 

Salt and pepper fries were good. I would come back for that. They reminded me of going to a Chinese restaurant and ordering salt and pepper wings.. only this is fries and not wings.. They weren't amazing, but they were good.
author: Donna H.

description:
I dig the idea of traditional Vietnamese sandwiches with an American twist (insert clever metaphor for America being a melting pot here)..

However, Bun Mee is overhyped. Their sandwiches lack spice, and they seriously skimp on ingredients-- which makes this place seriously overpriced, especially when you're a hop, skip and a jump from Little Saigon in the Tenderloin.

Extra star for the pleasant surprise of serving mango in the fresh spring rolls - which themselves were filling and delicious.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Way too expensive. Sandwich was nothing spectacular.

There are too many places in the City where you can get better a much Banh Mi for half the price.
author: Brooks D.

description: The sandwiches are pretty ordinary; nothing about them stands out except their small size. It's completely overpriced, $6 for the cheapest sandwich? You could buy two sandwiches for that price on Irving. Yes, it's in pac heights and everything there is expensive, but the food needs some improvement before I can justify that price.
author: KC W.

description:
This is not Saigon Sandwich or Sing Sing Sandwich Shop. For better or for worse.

Bun Mee is modern and trendy. Its menu is enticing and innovative. But it can't beat a classic banh mi in Little Saigon or San Jose--you know, smothered with fancy pork and pate, served by nice Vietnamese ladies, and sold for $3.50 each. 

Dave H. and I had to catch a movie, so we came here for a quick bite. We shared the grilled five spice chicken and the belly bun as well as green papaya salad and sweet potato fries. 

The sandwich bread was had excellent texture (neither too soft nor too crunchy) and the pickled veggies, flavorful and plentiful. The fillings didn't wow me, though. The fries were my FAVORITE. I really enjoyed the red curry aioli. As for the papaya salad, it didn't have much papaya and tasted just like the pickled veggies.

I won't be running back here, but I may return on a stroll through Fillmore.
author: Liz T.

description:
One of my big yelp pet peeves are when people judge a restaurant on what it isn't trying to be.  Most people would be quick to judge bunmee's sandwiches as not authentic Vietnamese sandwiches.  Well duh, it's not trying to be authentic Vietnamese. They're trying to be creative and create sandwiches that are inspired by favorite Vietnamese dishes.  If they wanted to be an authentic restaurant, they would've named their restaurant "banh mi", right? i digress.

Juicy steak sandwich and braised pork belly sandwich is what I ordered, along with a bucket of sweet potato fries and momma tran's egg rolls.

The steak sandwich lives up to its name. juicy and steak-y. the steak was cooked medium rare, and for a sandwich of its kind, it's the perfect temperature, since if the meat is overcooked, it'll pull out of the sandwich when you bite into it (and I hate that!).  The flavors are bold, clean and pronounced.

The braised pork belly sandwich (add the boiled egg!) is my kind of sandwich.  Complex in flavors and textures, it definitely defines what forward-thinking Vietnamese sandwiches can inspire to be.  the aioli adds the creaminess complexity to this sandwich that balances out the richness of the pork, and the pickled vegetables provide the acidity that cuts through the richness. 

Since I'm used to having some shrimp chips to munch on when I eat Vietnamese sandwiches, the sweet potato fries are a nice substitution.  It actually fits the menu perfectly since if you're familiar with Vietnamese cuisine, the Vietnamese use a lot of sweet potatoes to make the traditional northern banh tom.  

It's a great spot for the pac heights area, and if you're lucky enough to score one of the tables at the window, it provides a perfect opportunity to eat and people-watch all the glamorous and upscale patrons who stroll along the fillmore (and who can definitely afford these sandwiches - so quit complaining!!!).
author: Lucy W.

description: Casual eatery for a quick no-nonsense lunch or dinner.  I had the crispy tofu banh-mi sandwich.  Tasty, but needs more kick (and I was warned that it would be spicy).  Don't expect the greatest Vietnamese sandwich in the world, but it will do to satisfy a craving or fill you up.
author: Marcin M.

description:
I had the five spice chicken sandwich. My first  bahn mee. 
I didn't care for the flavor of the chicken, but I loved the aioli sauce and veggies. 
I would eat here again to try a different sandwich.
author: Harper C.

description:
Bun Mee, it's just OK, I mean I feel like San Francisco is not a good place to get Vietnamese Sandwiches in general. This food was nothing memorable, and was lacking vegetarian and vegan options and was very overpriced for what it is. 

Skip this place and maybe go to Saigon Sandwiches or Dinosaurs in the Castro (16th St @ Market St) you will save yourself some money and get something that will most likely taste better.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I echo other yelpers, $7 to $8 for a Vietnamese sandwiches! Really!

At $7 plus a sandwich you would expect a darn good sandwich or they give their employees full healthcare benefits.  Nope! The sandwich was very average and VERY mild.   

This place must be catering to a demographic that is, lets say, not very adventurous who have a lot of extra spending money.  It is very clean and very unremarkable.  Not my cup of tea. For an amazing Vietnamese sandwich go to Little Vietnam on 6th street.
author: Aus B.

description:
Honestly I went in with the notion that this will be a pricey, glorified Viet sandwich place. Don't get me wrong, it still is lol. I just wouldn't go in ordering something unoriginal that you can get elsewhere in the city for far less. 

But really, it wasn't awful. At least they didn't butcher up the flavors or made it taste any less satisfying. What you're likely paying for is a clean, nice place to sit enjoy your meal and socialize. It's in a great location for people watching!

They curry sloppy joe sandwich was very interesting and tasty, I will give them props for that. You def cannot order that at Saigon or Lee's and I really think that's the direction they should go in. It's awesome that you can add egg (in a few difft styles) to your sammie as well, my preference, the runny egg :)

The steak caesar salad was big portion, so that was nice to share. The steak was actually grilled beef, so that was nice, but nothing special. We also got the pork rice bowl with the garlic rice, giving that dish a nice touch. Tho, I felt the rice was a little soggy.

Limeade was definitely refreshing, the strawberry lychee drink started out really good, but got too sweet towards the middle. I liked that there were bits of lychee shredded into it. 

Would I come back? Prolly not unless someone else wanted to check it out but I'm not against it. But still, good to try everything at least once.
author: Ly T.

description:
I read about this place in The Fillmore, so when I was thinking of a place to eat after working out, I thought of Bun Mee. I mean, I was absolutely STARVING. I was willing to eat two sandwiches just for myself, but I didn't want to be too much of a heffer, so we each got a sandwich and a salad to split. I ordered the roasted pork sandwich and my boyfriend ordered the 5 alarm chicken sandwich. For the salad, we got the Vietnamese ceasar salad with steak (or was it pork? It was so unmemorable I don't even remember, and I ate here 2 days ago. CHRIST). 

The good thing about the sandwiches is that the bread is nicely toasted, and not too hard. I absolutely despise toasted bread that is so rock hard that I might lose a tooth biting into it. Anyways, the bread was good...and...that was pretty much it. I mean it's a decent sandwich. The meat is cooked well, but for nearly $7 for a sandwich that isn't even that big?! No thanks. The 5 alarm chicken sandwich was seasoned better, but don't call it a 5 alarm spicy chicken sandwich when it's not even remotely spicy. Lame.

The salad was pretty good, but nothing amazing. I think it was about $11, and definitely not worth the price. Overall, it's just mediocre food--and kinda pricey if you ask me. 2 sandwiches and a salad cost $26. NEXT.
author: Victoria B.

description:
I'm not in this part of town much and was having a hard time deciding where to go for lunch.  Was it going to be Pizzeria Delfina, Bun Mee, or something else?  I've had Delfina so I decided on Bun Mee.  Despite reading reviews that Bun Mee has average bahn mi, I went here anyway.  What brought me here was their version of Garlic Fries.  It's a small place with a few tables, and some counter seats.  Also pricey at about $7 per sandwich.

You order at the register, get a number and have a seat.  I saw most people were ordering salads, but I wanted to try the bahn mi.  I am a big fan or Saigon Sandwich.  I was not expecting this place to be that good, despite having a place to sit.  I had the steak sandwich, and it was just OK.  I would have wanted more veggies and cilantro on it.  It was just OK.  I was reaching for the Sriracha as the jalapeno didn't provide enough heat to me.

The Salt and Pepper Garlic Fries were very good though.  Sauteed onion, sliced jalapeno, salt, pepper and a wee bit of garlic.  For something with garlic in the title, I wanted more.  I do have to say they were some tasty fries, due to the jalapeno and onion.  I've never seen it, but will duplicate it at home, complete with the mandatory garlic, my way.  One full head per batch.

While just A-OK is pushing it, 3 stars is good enough.  I don't think I'll be back until I'm in this neighborhood again.
author: Michael M.

description:
Our friend the Real Estate agent makes me want to heave when she says this phrase, over and over... 

"It's all about location, location, location." 

YEP, that is why this place is in business and these 4 + star reviews are hilarious.  

A bunch of us met up and had sandwiches here, and the consensus: 2 Stars from ALL six people who had lunch. Seriously. You can't really do worse. 

the reviewer who gave the B L A N D review says it best. 
Five spice chicken? Which five? salt, pepper, salt, pepper, and more salt? 

This is in a perfect location for those in the neighborhood  who do not wish to venture into the (gasp, shudder) Tenderloin/Little Saigon to Saigon Sandwich or Lee's for a REAL banh mi sandwich. Not sure what some reviewers are saying but Saigon and Lee's has always served up service with a smile and no old lady is ever yelling at me there, thanks. (He must be thinking of that place on Market near safeway or something.) 
The FTR that says 'skip the chains'... um... Lee's is effing awesome, why would I skip it? and that this place has the 'authenticity of Saigon Sandwiches' MUST be HIGH. seriously. Cuz Saigon sandwiches knocked my socks off when I tried it for the first time many years ago. 
 
btw, Even those sandwiches are not the absolute best, but in SF, they will suffice. 

Their prices are insanely outrageous (you can get a sandwich TWICE as big for half the price in Little Saigon) but again, Location. 

No one was impressed and the total  we spent added up to quite a hefty sum. 

Dry, flavorless, dull sandwiches. 

A great example of how twitter/FB can make something so very BLAH appear to be so very awesome.
author: Sf Momm Y.

description: Not a Vegan restaurant, but as someone who eats Vegan I really appreciated all the dishes I ate: Eggplant Sandwich; Crispy Tofu Sandwich; Mango Sesame Salad, Fries. Perfect portions, flavor combos, the right kind of bread for this kind of sandwich, good service.
author: Victor D.

description:
Expensive vietnamese food. 

A trend in the restaurant world.  Feels authentic because you have to hover for your seats if the place is packed. Your order with the cashier, get a number and then hope a table opens up.  Victoria C. and I practiced the hovering technique while looking at the menus. We also were the only Asians in the restaurant... 

A lot of selections. Must try the banh mi's if you are coming here... pretty delicious. The only thing that could be better is crispier bread.  The spring rolls were fantastic too. Highly recommended. The Vietnamese coffee was a little too syrupy for me - but their strawberry lychee drink was divine.

Parking can get complicated - street parking only.  The tab is 10x more than you would spend at a hole in the wall Vietnamese place - but I think it is worth it for a culinary treat.
author: Lisa L.

description: Can't say I tried the food. We planned on stopping here before a movie and arrived with plenty of time to spare. The door was open. Despite the website saying this business opens at 10:30, we were then turned away at 11:10 because "oh we haven't updated the website." I know google says 11 and yelp says 11:30, but I would think the business's website would be trustworthy. Oh well, out into the cold we went.
author: Brian R.

description:
Hah, take a look at the rating distribution and it's obvious this place isn't living up to the hype.

This is a trendy banh mi spot with cute decor and a great location in lower Pac Heights, but I left totally unsatisfied. The sloppy  bun was tasty but there was a teeeeeeeeny bit of meat on my sandwich that was otherwise all bread and a spot of vegetables. Same thing for Jane S.'s roast pork sandwich. I really don't understand how people are calling this the best banh mi in the city. I basically left feeling like I ate a hunk of baguette dipped in sriracha.
author: Lisa W.

description:
When I learned via email blasts, Twitter & Facebook that Bun Mee was going to be setting up shop on Fillmore, I was super excited. I'm originally from Philadelphia, where the Vietnamese sandwiches are to die for. My mouth is even watering for those sandwiches as I write this review.

I was greatly disappointed when I went to Bun Mee on Sunday. First of all, the space is super small. The kitchen/food preparation area takes up over half of the restaurant, which leaves very little room for the seating area and even less room for the standing-and-waiting for your food area. 

I ordered my sandwich which was $7 and held the little sign in my hand up high so they person who was supposed to bring it to me didn't miss me. I stood against the wall, sipping on my drink and watched as others came in and ordered food. I really had no idea where they were going to sit.

There was one person making the sandwiches, one person making the sweet potato fries and one person putting it all together for the server to deliver to the tables. It looked efficient except for the number of guests to be served, it was not. 

I waited for more than 10 minutes for my one sandwich. I watched as the owner spent that whole time chatting with friends. I really wanted to say something to her about helping out her staff so she could expedite the food-making process.

There was no seating so I took my sandwich and met my friend across the street at the Grove. I was hopeful the sandwich would be better than the service that I received. It was not. And I won't be telling my mom I ate there. She'll be disappointed to know that I cheated on her cooking/food with bad food.

Sad face.
author: Siv L.

description:
To say I'm a bahn mi newbie is an understatement; having tried only a handful, I'm sure I haven't tasted the best the Bay has to offer, but Bun Mee has left an impression on me. 

The BFF & I paid the week-old eatery a visit yesterday & ate lunch at the counter. 

We ordered:
* [momma tran's crispy egg rolls, 2 for $5.25]: the wrapping was crunchy, but I like a real toothy, bubbly crunch. The 'nuoc cham' dipping sauce was SO spicy--I was double dippin' all over the place b/c I could not get enough. 
* [grilled five spice chicken sandwich, $5.95+$1.50 for sunny side up egg]: love in a bun! Bread was well toasted but still soft enough that it didn't assult the roof of my mouth. 'Five spice' was not overwhelming & chicken was mostly lean. Lots of crunchy veggies, but jalapeños were not hot enough. I would definitely order again. 
* [caramel citrus rice bowl w/ brown rice & grilled steak, $11.95 & strawberry lychee drink. $2.50 for my BFF]: my amazing BFF wanted me to point out that he doesn't even like citrus & he loved the burst of orange flavor in his bowl. Also, the bright, delicious flavors were so strong, he could taste everything despite bring a little stuffy from allergies. If that isn't a compliment to the cooks, I don't know what is! 

Five stars for well made food that I'm craving again today! My only suggestion (I'm sure they'll work this out on their own in time) is to make sure the cashiers are well trained before throwing them to the lions (aka hungry lunch crowd.) The Asian girl taking my order was kind of clueless, frazzled & unfamiliar with the menu.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I will preface this with the fact that I've eaten Banh Mi's for 30 years. Growing up in San Jose, I always called them "dollar sandwiches" because that's what they used to cost, forever. Sometimes I'd get 3 in one day from 3 different places.

I've only been to Bun Mee once. I've only had one sandwich. This is after I had a curry rice plate, sushi, gyozas, and another sandwich, 10 minutes prior to stumbling upon Bun Mee. I was no hungry, but I will try any new banh mi shop anytime.

I ordered something familiar on the menu... Roast Pork. Everything seemed "usual" except the garlic aioli and the price. This is the first time i've ever paid more than $5 for a banh mi. At $6.25, my expecations were pretty much, as high as could be.

So I will break this down objectively:

Bread - Very good. Light.  Fresh. Crispy crust. Soft insides. 4 Stars.
Pork - The most tender roast pork I've ever had in a banh mi. Nice flavor. Seasoned just right. 4 Stars.
Produce - "carrot salad" and cilantro were stuffed inside and overflowing. A couple of jalapeno peppers added nice balance. 4 Stars.
Garlic Aioli - Different enough when compared to mayonnaise. I like it. 4 Stars.
Value - 1 Star. $6.25 seems a bit much when I break it down. If the sandwiches were just 25% larger, I'd be giving 4 star value. 50% larger, and it would be 5 stars. For sure.

I will definitely go back and try something different. Who knows, I might add a star... or take two away.
author: Ray C.

description:
After seeing all of the hype this place has received, I took the chance to visit Bun Mee during the Fillmore Jazz Festival. It was surprisingly uncrowded and I was able to get a seat without waiting. Unfortunately, they were running a limited menu that day with only three or four sandwiches available. 

I got something not, apparently, on the usual menu - I think it was a lemon seasoned pork. The seasonings were a nice twist and quite flavorful. Disappointingly, the sandwiches that day had been premade and were sitting in the back; I received mine about 30 seconds after I ordered it. Sadly, this had a dramatic effect on the bun.

A further disappointment came when I asked the woman at the register for a glass of water. She denied my request, and offered to sell me a bottle. Looking around the restaurant, I noted several other patrons with pint glasses filled with tap water. 

One day I may return to explore the full menu that is not pre-prepared, but I will not go out of my way for it.
author: Gregory S.

description:
I knew what I was getting myself into. My friends had been there and reported back with "mediocre food, overpriced, not worth it." I trust their judgment. We agree on almost every SF restaurant (except Tataki, Pacific Catch) and have similar expectations. Yes we like nice restaurants with high-priced delicious food, but we also appreciate as much as anyone the value in a cheap lunch that gives you enough energy to power through the afternoon. I believed them, but still I had to see for myself.

So, I took a lunch break around 2 and walked the four blocks from the library of to Bun Mee. I was hungry and knew the sandwich wouldn't satisfy so I went with a grilled chicken salad. My friend has a sloppy joe sandwich. My salad wouldn't have been bad except the chicken was undercooked and unappealing. Her sandwich looked lonely on that small plate and didn't last more than a minute or two. I'm happy I didn't order one, way too small for a guy's appetite.

So, I guess I can't be all that disappointed cause I'm not surprised. I learned my lesson and will stick to the rest of Fillmore from here on out.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
B = 5 star
L = -1 star
A = -1 star
N = -1 star
D = -1 star
-------
Equal 1 star!


I got excited when I heard that a Banh Mi place was opening up in San Francisco. I love Vietnamese sandwich! I came from Orange County and they have good Vietnamese food there and when I moved to San Francisco, there's just no good Vietnamese place around here. I would have to drive down to San Jose for a good banh mi or follow around Little Green Cyclo truck (but i just want to "dine in" for tonight, if you know what I mean!)

So when I heard about Bun Mee, I thought I found my IT place... only to be DISAPPOINTED. The place is cute and their homemade cookie was good but everything else was so bland! Their pork and catfish Banh Mi lack taste! When I had a bite of my friend's pork, i yanked out a good chunk of FAT. When she saw that, she just had to stop eating her sandwich. 

We also had their shrimp salad. Their shrimp looks so pale on the stick .. it could definitely use more grilling... it did say "grilled shrimp".

Our fries came out COLD. Like it has been sitting there and they decided to serve it to us. 

We also had House-Made Strawberry Lychee drink, and it was too sweet for my taste (and this is coming from someone who loves sweets!) We came in around 8pm so maybe the drink came from the bottom of the container where all the sugar rest? I dunno, it was just overwhelming sweet!

To top it all off ... for 2 orders of sandwich, 2 drinks, salad and fries!  $35.80! Ouch! 

Not taking my friends here for sure!
author: RED C.

description:
Delicious rice bowl and A++ tofu rolls (love the mango chunks). The grilled eggplant sandwich was very good but not quite as fantas-terrific as the rice bowl. 

Service was prompt but wish the waiter - making frequent deliveries to sidewalk patrons - would have closed the door behind him: the cold night air intruded on the otherwise warm, cozy atmosphere.
author: Michael H.

description:
One word: TERRIBLE.

To start off, I would like to say that it galled me to pay $6.50 for a Vietnamese sandwich when costs usually range from $2.50-$3.50. Then again, it was made by non-Asians so I guess I can see why they would be charging 2x the amount when they skimp on the meat more so than the Asians do. 

So why was it so bad? The list can go on but let's just focus on a few main flaws for now. I ordered a combo + we all know what usually goes in a traditional combo [i.e. pate, ham, fancy pork]. What came in THIS combo was pasty "pate", 2 thick slices of pork meat that was simply boiled in unsalted hot water,  mortadella [so thin you can't taste it but can see it], and the typical veggies [pickled carrots/daikon, cilantro, jalapeno peppers] as well as onions. For me, the killer was the onion. It was  raw + taste was strong enough that it overwhelmed all the other flavors that were suppose to be there but were NOT. I can understand that you're trying to do the fusion thing but the sandwich was so bad that I couldn't get pass 1/3 before I gave up. The only saving grace was the bread. Plain baguette that it was, it was fresh + remains the only palatable component of the product.

*sigh* 

This just gives BANH MI sandwiches a bad name.
author: Julie L.

description:
1- Banh Mi Pork
1- Banh Mi Catfish
1- Sweet Potato Fries
1- Mango Shrimp Salad
1- coconut cookie
2- Lychee Lemonade drinks

$40 for extremely bland Banh Mi's and soggy Sweet Potato fries. The only items my mate and I did enjoy was the drink and coconut cookie. 

The Mango Shrimp Salad was refreshing but the 6 shrimps on skewers probably would've tasted better if they had grilled it longer so it would have the char/grill taste.

1) The bread needs to be more toasted. The bread makes or breaks the Banh Mi. PERIOD.

2) My Banh Mi Pork had way too much Pate which not only made the Banh Mi messy but also greasy. My biggest issue about my Banh Mi Pork has everything to do with the pork: 1) the pork was more FAT than pork and 2) the pork was absolutely BLAND & tasteless. The pate did a good job of concealing this fact until I ate the pork by itself.

3) The Banh Mi Catfish had the same issue as the Banh Mi Pork. The curry sauce in it completely concealed any flavor the fish lacked. The fish doesn't remotely look or taste like the traditional Hanoi Catfish that I am familiar with but instead, reminds me of McDonald's Fish Filet that has that breaded batter look. It's just extremely bland same way the pork in my Banh Mi was. 

IMHO? I'm totally paying for the location & ambiance here because I'm certainly not getting what I paid for, which should be delicious Banh Mi's. I'll stick to Lee's Sandwich, despite them being considered the "McDonald's" for Banh Mi in the Vietnamese community.
author: Soozie H.

description:
Yes, I agree with everyone else. It's clearly overpriced but where else in this neighborhood can you get a bahn mi. I think the best way to describe this concept is to buy a bunch of bahn mi sandwiches, plain and simple, and get inebriated, and then figure out how to tweak and add things to each plain bahn mi. I always like the idea of putting a fried egg in sandwiches, burgers and almost anything else. That is, until it gets extremely sloppy and impossible to keep your fingers from getting messy. 

Grilled Five Spiced Chicken with caramel aioli, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro - pretty ordinary, reminds me of the ones you can get elsewhere

Belly Bun - Braised Kurobuta pork belly, salted radish relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro - uniquely highlighting juicy pork belly in the sandwich. Enjoyed.

Momma Tran's Crispy Egg Rolls - Ground pork, woodear mushrooms, glass noodles, shredded carrots, and onions served with nuoc cham dipping sauce. 2 egg rolls per order - If this was cheaper, I would recommend it as a good way to make any sandwich into a lunch combo. The fixings on the side are a bit much and I could do without.

As a viet sandwich shop alone, there are a few in the City I like better. As a dining establishment on Fillmore that diversifies the landscape, I think it fits well.
author: Dennis L.

description:
This is definitely one of my new favorite go to lunch spots on Fillmore! I have to say I'm a little shocked at the bad reviews, but then again Yelp is so unpredictable based on people's opinion's and what they chose to devote their stars to.

First of all for those complaining about the price, I think $6 is totally reasonable for a great fresh sandwich on Fillmore. If you prefer the dingy places on Larkin that have been closed by the health department then go for it!

The sandwiches and their ingredients are very fresh, and the bread is out of this world! They could be a bit spicier, but with that said I tend to like more spice than the average person.

I LOVE their logo and the design of this place. Great addition to Fillmore street!
author: Wendy W.

description:
sorry to be a hater but i really wanted to give this place a higher rating. my girlfriends and i stopped by on saturday for lunch after the local bakesale for japan held at SPQR. 

we got there early (before noon) so there wasn't a line yet. but once we put in our order and sat down, the line was out the door. 

anyways, on to the food. both my friends had the bun mee combo sandwich. neither of them seemed to rave about the sandwich . in fact one of them commented that the bread kept flaking and breaking apart and that it probably wasn't the best choice of bread.

i ordered a salad. yes, i'm one of those who goes to a banh mi place and orders a salad ;) i had the shrimp over greens with a few slices of mangoes tossed in. the dressing was good but the shrimp was very "fishy" and tasted more like it was boiled rather than grilled. nothing exciting. 

while the food was not impressive, i did really like the decor. the signage outside, the menu on the wall, the various framed wall art and photos, the cute benches and chairs and even the cafe du monde can napkin and chopstick holder on the tables.

i'll probably stick to the tenderloin for authentic vietnamese grub. saigon sandwiches is on my to-go list.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I want to give Bun Mee a 3.5 - but of course on Yelp there aren't any half stars for reviews. 

The sandwiches I've tried here have been tasty - the Belly Bun and the Steak Sandwich. They have been good, but every time I've been there - they've screwed up my order. Once they didn't add the egg, and that's perfectly fine - but we were expecting the egg. Another time they didn't include my crispy egg rolls. Both times were take out and it took a pretty long time to receive the food. One of the times we were the first ones to order at 11am - but some lady had ordered 20 sandwiches to go. Waiting 20+ minutes for two sandwiches is a little disappointing.
author: Beth W.

description:
I had an eggplant banh mi at a five star location with a four star decor :)

Sadly the sandwich itself was a disappointment. 

One  star for a stale, rock hard baguette made soggy in the middle by a spoonful of cold eggplant mush :(

Average it out, 1.5  stars.  Bun Mee? Bun Meh.
author: Jenaynay W.

description:
This is the first banh mi shop I've seen in a long time that really focuses on the design details.  Super cute and not one plastic condiment jar topped off with chili pepper in sight.  Everything from the Cafe du Monde can napkin holders, the scooter logo and Andy Warhol-esque soup cans and well-curated framed photographs along the wall remind you that you're in Pac Heights and not some hole in the wall on Larkin.  I was thinking: maybe it'll be like Saigon Sandwiches lost 30 pounds, had a facelift, a personal style and wardrobe consultant and started shopping at Barneys.

It's unfortunate then that they sort of missed the details of the sandwich itself.  I ordered the Bun Mee Combo sans mortadella for $6.50.  The hand carved roast pork was tender but lacking savory spices.  The overall disappointing components--bread and aioli--were also both missing unique flavor.  Under-toasted, the roll was still a flaky mess; it should be soft with a crunchy outer shell but not be brittle.  The roll nearly disintegrated in my hands as crumbs rained all over my plate and lap.  I was expecting something sort of tangy, but instead the "garlic aioli" reminded me more of plain creamy mayo and was excessively smeared, overpowering even the texture of the pate de campagne which is a shame given the generous portion of pate.  

Nevertheless, I was greeted with lots of friendly smiles so I'd love to make this cheerful spot a regular check-in when in the 'hood.  Just hope they continue to develop their recipes.
author: Irene S.

description: I ate here while on vacation. I got a sandwich, but like another reviewer stated I too am used to getting it at a lot lower price and a larger sandwich.  It was pretty tasty though.  I also got one of their chocolate coconut sandwich cookies, which was really yummy!! The place is quaint, but uses their small space well.  There are a couple tables outside, which is where I sat since it was a nice day.
author: Allison B.

description:
3.5

small and cramped can get a bit noisy.  had the bm combo with pork and pate aka mystery meat.  loved the house made strawberry lychee drink.  total was $6.75 + $2.50 + tip

bun mee is meant to be inspired fusion and not to be an authentic hole in the wall with $2 sammiches.  this is pac heights after all.  the baguette is solid so whatever floats your boat, they have fried egg to sloppy joe banh mis.  if you can't take any heat, ask for mild peppers.  my belly is still on fire from the jalapeños.  i had to chomp on ice cubes like a preggo to calm it down.
author: Anh V.

description: Not worth the rave reviews I have seen in a few SF magazines. Totally overpriced, small portions, and no option to special order things like summer rolls. I couldn't believe what a disappointment this place was after all the hype surrounding the grand opening a few months back. Maybe the banh mi sandwiches are better than the salads but honestly I'm not feeling optimistic enough to try this place again.
author: Erin W.

description:
As the saying goes, "Never judge a book by its cover."  Well, this statement can easily be applicable to restaurants - as I, myself, fell for Bun Mee's cool, modish exterior/interior design.

To start, whoever is responsible for their marketing did a fab job at designing the logo.  You can't help but be intrigued by the bold "BUN MEE" sign outside their door.  Being a huge "Banh Mi" lover myself (the actual spelling of the Vietnamese term for bread), I had to stop by for bite (even though I was feeling full from my Yoppi froyyo). 

BUN MEE's chalkboard menu somehow makes a simple Vietnamese dish feel extremely trendy.  There are about 9 different sandwiches to choose from, which you can pair with a side of sweet potato fries or salad.  I'm not sure how sweet potato fries are relevant in this picture, so I refrained from ordering some.

Since I love paté, I ordered the Bun Mee Combo (with roast pork, paté, mortadella, garlic aioli, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber).  

Before even taking a bite out of it, I knew I would like it.  But boy, was I WRONG!

Reasons why my Bun Mee was a fail:
- Although there were multiple ingredients piled into my banh mi, all I could taste was bread and bland pork
- While the pork was relatively tender, it had no substantial flavor.  I couldn't taste the paté or garlic aioli whatsoever
- For $6.50, it was a tiny sandwich.  At Lee's Sandwiches, you could get one almost twice as big, half the price, and with more authentic ingredients. 

Yelpers, if BUN MEE was the first time you ever had a Vietnamese sandwich, I recommend that you try Latte Express 5, Lee's Sandwiches, or Spice Kit (a decent "Americanized" version of the Banh Mi).
author: Judy C.

description:
I like this place, I really do, but it wasn't worth it today. 

I usually order the Grilled Pork sandwich ($6.50) which is great & is what I SHOULD have ordered again. Today, I opted for the Bun Noodle Bowl which is essentially a small tong-ful of vermicelli noodles, some herb sprigs, and too much dressing/sauce (granted, I poured all of it into the bowl simultaneously expecting more noodles). If it wasn't for the additional lemongrass pork, it would have been a VERY sad and disproportional $10 lunch. However, this restaurant is in a good location, limited seating (but good use of space considering the small size of the place), trendy atmosphere, & acceptable service.

If you want a super authentic Vietnamese sandwich, I'd suggest hitting up Saigon Sandwich in the TL ($3.50 sandwich? I think yes).
author: Briana F.

description:
$6.25 for a bland pork sandwich last week. And bland today. Sorry, no more visits!

Prior to visiting Bun Mee, my rule of thumb for Asian eateries was: If there are Asians eating there, it should be decent.  However, after visiting Bun Mee (where there were surprisingly a lot of Asians for Pac Whites), I have revised my rule of thumb to, "If there are *no* Asians eating there, it is probably not too good." 

That said, I had high hopes for this place.  Ignoring that this is overpriced Asian street food, I wanted to love the pork sandwich.  However, it was sadly quite flavorless both times I tried it.  Here are the highlights (lowlights?):

-Meat was flavorless
-The carrots/veggies/cilantro were not vinegary or flavorful at all. Just crunchy
-Only a few hot peppers.  No fiery kick at all.
-Too much aioli

Random Business Etiquette: If anyone's ever done business in Asia, the etiquette is to use both hands when presenting someone with your business card.  I was reminded of this when the (caucasian) woman who handed me the paper bag with my sandwich handed it to me very precisely with both hands.  Anyone else notice this?
author: Caroline I.

description:
Bun Mee's take on the Vietnamese sandwich is one that intrigues me greatly, and am glad that their product met my expectations, and thus worthy of 3.5 - 4 stars!

Lately, the store fronts of Pacific Heights (predominately up and down Fillmore) have been turning over and changing.  As mentioned, was intrigued by the fusion nature of Bun Mee's sandwiches especially because I've often said that banh mi's may be my favorite type of sandwich outside a panini.  Plus, their "scooter" street food menu is well balanced and not overwhelming.  

If you've read my reviews before, you know Asian fusion is one of my favorite cuisines, and I think Bun Mee does a fine job of mixing traditional Asian/Vietnamese ingredients with American ones.  Here's what my dining companion and I ordered and shared:

- Sloppy bun was surprisingly good!  I didn't grow up eating sloppy joes, but I'm a fan of flavored ground beef in pockets and pastries, so why not a toasted baguette?!  The curry flavor was on point and shone with just the right amount of other ingredients: onions basil and jalapenos.  Good call not adding the traditional bahn mi ingredients such as the pickled carrots and daikon.  It's suggested to add an egg, but we passed.

- Belly bun was equally, if not more delicious!  Braised pork belly was tender and seasoned well.  And in this sandwich it was a great idea to bring in the pickled carrots and daikon, cucumbers, jalapenos and cilantro as it added freshness and texture to the otherwise pretty heavy and flavorful pork belly.  With a boiled egg it's one helluva sandwich.

- Side of green papaya salad was just okay.  While the ingredients were fresh tasting it lacked flavor and heat.  However, the sweet potato fries served with red curry aioli were crisped and season right!

Staff is friendly and offer great suggestions, and space is clean and fun.  I'll likely go again with another bahn mi aficionado and try the Bun Mee combo since it's most like the traditional and one of the rice bowls or salads.
author: Marie B.

description:
Finally, the spot that puts great Vietnamese sandwiches in a hip locale.  The location is prime and the interior has been gorgeously renovated.  I'm pretty sure I bought  gelato for a pretty girl in this same space on a second date a few years back.

Unlike the other great banh mi spots, this isn't dingy and divey, and unlike the hipper viet sando spots like Spice Kit, the food is great.  The staff were extremely friendly as they banged out excellent food.

I fear that this place will the suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune in the form of an unruly line and the impossibility of finding a seat, but I can't wait to go back.  

Also, the "Sloppy Bun" made me weak in the knees and the coconut cookies are exquisite. Once this place gets a liquor license, it will be unstoppable!
author: Quinn S.

description:
Bun Meh.

I went here for a quick bite to eat with a friend before a movie.  She got the five spice chicken and I got the sloppy bun.  We were completely underwhelmed.  I didn't come here looking for an authentic banh mi, but I was hoping that I would at least get something interesting and tasty.

However, the staff is very friendly and efficient.
author: Mena A.

description:
Bun Mee makes a great sandwich marred by its cheap bread. This is not a French baguette. This is the 75 cent a loaf Safeway equivalent. Instead of chewy it's hard and dry. Injures the roof of your mouth with every bite. 

Such top notch fillings deserve a better home than this. Switch out your bread, charge a dollar more a sandwich if necessary, and you've got a 5 star shop.
author: Mark F.

description:
Really overpriced folks, seriously.  It's not that it was bad, but I've definitely had better and for less than half the price.  

I got the pork combination one and the meat did not even compare to the grilled pork that Them Ky (restaurant in the TL) uses. Actually, one problem was that they skimped on the meat (only filled up 3/5 of the sandwich in the middle) AND I actually got 3 big mouthfuls of pure fat.  

The salt and pepper fries were alright, the kaffir lemonade just tasted like country time lemonade and my friend's beef sandwich was kind of underwhelming as well. 

I mean, I understand that there aren't any other Viet sandwich places in the area, but you really could do so much better.  Like I said, it's not bad per se, but for the price, you could get a two sandwiches and a drink in the TL which do taste a lot better. ::shrug::
author: ML N.

description:
Do you LOVE when a new restaurant opens up down the block, and it proves itself to be reasonable, quick, AND delicious? Ignore all the bad feedback on here, Bun Mee has got it going on.

What to order? A sandwich and a side. My friend had the roast pork with papaya salad, and I had the 5-spiced chicken with sweet potato fries. Both were great, fresh, and filled us up for under $12. 

yum. yum.
author: Misha F.

description:
Oh wow, what a treat! My hubby and I got to check this upscale Vietnamese sandwich shop out during their soft opening. So lucky us, we got to sample almost everything on the menu! Here are some of the standouts:

Sloppy Bun - This one's a real winner. Think of the comforty goodness of your mom's sloppy joe - but spiced up for an international vacation and then dressed with a soft boiled egg, sweet basil and hot peppers. Ooh, yummy!

Sweet Potato Fries - I'm a sucker for homestyle fries, and these were awesome. Thinly cut, so as to maximize the crispy factor, but still soft inside for a great texture contrast. They have that sweet but salty combo going for them, plus the portion is huge - plenty for two.

Napa Slaw - Do most people go to a sandwich shop for a salad? No - especially not when Bun Mee's bread is so exceptional... but if you find yourself in a salad mood, or just needing a little extra something, something... check out the Napa Slaw. No, it's nothing like Cole Slaw (other than that it's made with cabbage). It's more of a traditional vietnamese salad with peanut sauce, carrots and the good ol' standbys of basil and pepper. Light and lovely.

Finally if you appreciate the art of presentation, Bun Mee is for you. Yes, the food is fantastic, fresh and fast... but it's also served with an eye for style. This is the kind of place you where you can take your foodie friends. They'll be impressed by the cool hipster vibe and the yummy pieces of art Bun Mee serves up. Give it a try... you'll be back.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I am actually writing this review while I wait for my food. I figured I'd give myself a head start. I have the time because of the fact that I've been waiting for 20 minutes now for my simple Vietnamese sandwich. Aside from paying Wayyyyyy to much money(twice the price) for a banh mi it looks ok. The service is ok, the atmosphere is awesome, but again the wait and service is adequate. 

Finally my sandwich is coming into sight after 22 minutes of waiting. (at least I hope it's my food)

Well 23 minutes later I get my to go food. It's great food!!! Overly waited on, but great food. 

I have to unfortunately give then 2 stars because wait and service alone would bring me back. Not just food....
author: AJ J.

description:
Super hyped on a new bahn mi place in the hood, spill-over distance from Harrys and the Grove. 

Super disappointed. Love the style of the spot, but banh mi should be a scrumptious comfy little sandwich and this was a meager cold little samwich. Tried both of their 2 classic styles and not impressed.

Go to Saigon Sandwich for a $3 sandwich that is what banh mi is supposed to be.
author: Young Todd Marinovich M.

description: A-ok food.   The banh mi (sandwiches) are better than the rice bowls, but the banh mi aren't as good as some of the other cheap spots in the city like Saigon Sandwich.  Usually banh mi is $2-$3, so I wasn't impressed with the $6-$7 price tag.  The pork was pretty fatty and not as good as hoped.  The catfish sandwich was the only one that I was impressed with.  Good amount of seating inside with 2 tables outside, so feel free to bring your dog as long as you can snag one of the outdoor tables.  Family friendly also.
author: Naomi P.

description:
I kinda want to give this place a 2.5.  But giving it a 2 would be kinda mean.  I don't want to be mean.  But, the dark side is eating away at me.

After walking up and down the street with my wife who was in shopping bliss, we decided to give this place a try.  

We've been to many banh mi places (LA, SF, SJ) so we have our preferrences.  

I was sort of in sticker shock.  The point of eating banh mi is that you could get a nice quality meal for just a couple of bucks.  In many cases, we'd buy more sandwhiches for dinner if we love the sandwiches.  So, for 2 or 3 bucks, you wouldn't think twice about ordering more.

In this case, the "combo" was  about 6.50.  The equivalent of a "dac biet" or "special" banh mi.   I don't know, I've never paid 6.50 for a banh mi.  I saw the hipsters working the cashier and kitchen, so I thought about the overhead and the local economy.  My philanthropic side took over, so I ordered 2 sandwhiches for about 13 bucks (the other was a chicken banh mi).  As I handed over my cash, I felt slightly raped.  It was like paying 10 dollars for a beer at a game, 2 dollars for a banana at the airport, 8 bucks for top ramen, or paying  5 bucks for a cup of  joe at a specialty coffee shop (long story).

The sandwhiches were good.  They were not great.  They were not worth their weight.  The bread was not of the quality I expected for a banh mi- as I was hoping for more of a slightly chewier consistency.  It was light, and flaky, but it's all about the bread's glutanous quality that makes it taste substantial.  So, was the increase in 3 bucks there?  No.

The ingredients were there, though I was hoping for a bit more.  I don't know, maybe julienne the carrots differently?  I mean, they're marinated carrots and radishes for goodness sake.  How much more special can you make them?  Sure the cilantro was fresh, but it's cilantro.  The meat was good, but I feel that they drowned out the flavor of the meat with their sauces.  If I wanted Ike's, I'd go to Ike's.

Anyhoos, it was a good experience.  I'd probably come back here if I lived in the area and didn't want to hop in my car or bus to go to the TL for some awesome banh mi.  

For now, I'll just leave it at that and not be a meany.
author: John L.

description:
Finally! Something quick, different, and somewhat affordable in my hood!!

As I strolled down Fillmore St. on a sunny afternoon, I came across what I thought was a darling image of a store front with a scooter decal planted on the window. Apparently, these next few days are their soft opening with their grand opening on April 1st. I was immediately intrigued as I stroll in to look at the menu. Sandwiches and sides are what's offered now but soon they will have a full menu with salads and entrees. 

Banh mi brings back memories of my friends and I in Vietnam last summer of 2010. Our obsession for this French-Vietnamese sandwiches had us hunting down little street cars every day and night as we stroll through the streets of Saigon, Hanoi, and Nha Trang. They never make them the same way here but wait no more, Banh mi enthusiast!

Bun Mee lives up to par with cute decor, clean atmosphere, and appetizing menu. I devoured my 5-spice sandwich -- it was sweet, crunchy, and scrumptious. I also didn't hold back when my friend had some leftovers from her fried catfish sandwich with sweet potato fries with curry aoili and kaffir lemonade. The portions are a bit on the smaller side and the sandwiches are made spicy but I couldn't taste what was spicy at all (but that's just me). Vietnamese coffee is offered here, maybe with condensed milk? The only thing I could say could be better was their choice of store music -- I am just not a super big fan of Britney Spears :(

Overall, we were beyond satisfied and you really can't beat the prices for Pac Heights. As I am just around the corner, this will be my new go to place.
author: Enji L.

description:
Bun Mee to me is an innovative twist on some of the more popular traditional vietnamese dishes. Some things turn out good! Others (the papaya salad) not so great. 

Still a work in progress, I definitely see potential though.
author: Dave H.

description:
Ordered the 5-spice chicken. Delicious and fresh, the roll was amazingly crunchy, the chicken however was slightly chewy/fatty, maybe some people like that texture but I don't. The size of the sandwich was rather disappointing. I don't think its worth the $6.50 I paid for it. 

I am no Bahn Mi expert, but Bum Mee has altered the sandwich to meet american taste buds, or so it seems. I personally like the Tofu bahn mi from Saigon Sandwich. Bigger sandwich for less money- $3.50
author: Ashley H.

description: While walking around Fillmore Street, the aroma and noise made me want to see what was happening. I ended up getting the crispy tofu Vietnamese sandwich. And with my luck, it was a Friday so I free fri(day)es that included jalapeno peppers and onions~
author: Irene S.

description:
If you arrive 30 minutes before closing, then they will be out of a few items. 

What we ordered: 
1) Salad Roll - they were out of it. 
2) Vegetarian Salad Rolls - was available, then was out after we ordered.
3) Sweet Potato Fries - good. These are thin regular fries, not fatty wedges. Always a good item for the kiddos. Especially because they were all out of the rolls.
4) Momma Tran's Crispy Egg Rolls - This was the only suspect food item ordered. It has pork meat in it. So if the pork is pink, then it is not cooked. This was apparent when compared to other rolls in the order. We send it back and they refunded the money no problem. 
5) Bun Mee Combo - it was an average sandwich. Bread was fresh and crispy. 
6) Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish - also average because it is just a fried fish sandwich.
7) Bun Noodle Bowl - my brother ate it. 

Overall, we'll be back because the food was edible.
author: Van T.

description:
After reading the reviews, I was quite wary during my first visit.  I think because of this, I found the sandwiches tasted better than I expected.  Of course when comparing to traditional Vietnamese sandwiches in content and price, you will be disappointed.  But if you just take it for what it is, it is a pretty good sandwich.

We had the five spice chicken and pork bun, and both were tasty.  We liked the bread and the meats were seasoned well.  However, the mango salad was disappointing.  It was really good, BUT only had a few small pieces of mango in a bed of cabbage.  The chocolate coconut cookie was amazing!  A must try!

The place is small and clean.  It wasn't packed so our sandwiches came out fast.  I'd give this place between 3.5-4 stars.
author: K V.

description:
This place makes good sandwiches, they're bahn-mi inspired and admittedly so. People, stop bashing them for being inauthentic, seriously. It's a modern twist on a good thing. There's a reason I live in Pac Heights, I DO NOT want to go to the tenderloin for a damn vietnamese (inspired) sandwich and will gladly pay a lil extra for that convenience. I'm glad I don't have to go to some shitty shit-hole for a $3 sandwich, sorry but my time is more important than saving a couple bucks.

The place is cute, well-decorated, and the owner is super nice. Staff is flaky, they're nice when she's around, not so much when she's nowhere to be seen. 

The sandwiches I've had there have all been tasty: 5-spice chicken, pork, and sloppy. Can't go wrong with sweet potato fries and an agua freca, NOM! Go there if you can get off your high horse and want a tasty meal.
author: Jen P.

description:
True, the sandwich quality isnt quite the little saigon level and the price is almost double...BUT....

They do make tasty sandwiches, satisfying and good quality. And honestly, I personally am FED UP with walking though blocks and blocks filled with drug addicts and freaks and EDPs to get good banh mi. That garbage just ruins the experience for me. 

If nothing else, do at least try this place once if you like vietnamese sandwiches or never had an asian sandwich before.
author: Ash S.

description: This place is ridiculously busy, yet personally I prefer the cheap Vietnamese sandwiches you can get elsewhere. I got the pork belly sandwich, which was I really looking forward to due to my love of pork belly and momofuku pork buns.  Sadly there is so many spices here that you can't taste much of the pork belly.  Also got the mango salad.  Although I appreciate that they use fresh ingredients, it was a bit too sour for me.  As for the strawberry lychee drink...the exact opposite....it was super sweet.  (Or perhaps eating the salad followed by the drink was confusing my taste buds).
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Too much bread+sauce, not enough veggies :( 
Had this place a couple times with different types of vietnamese sandwiches and each time it's the same.... I need to find another place that will do the banh mi justice!
author: Victoria K.

description:
DROOL DROOL DROOL... 

Sloppy Bun - curry ground pork, shaved onion, thai basil

Combo - roast pork, paté de champagne, and the works

Lime Pepper Aioli Steak - w/ the works, lotus root relish, crispy shallots, and shaved onion

Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl - vietnamese slaw w/ roasted peanuts & special peanut sauce over rice

Vietnamese Caesar - grilled steak/grape tomatoes/orange and grapefruit/tea egg salad

Mamma Tran's Crispy Egg Rolls - ground pork, crab meat, wood ear mushrooms, & glass noodles

what a great addition to fillmore!!  :)
author: Kristen C.

description:
I can't believe I ate the whole thing.  I had five spice chicken earlier in the week.   The flavors popped.  Tis is the BEST SALAD I have ever had!
This is my second time this week....BECAUSE it tastes good.. .
BUT THIS place...clean, friendly, helpful
FRESH FRESH FRESH
OH by the way, the reason I first entered this is the restaurant across "Glaze" forgot to acknowledge my presence after 20 minutes...........one of the cooks told me that I would be  waited////but...I still never even saw a menu....good that I discovered  Bun Mee...I'm pretty sure they don't use MSG
author: Minnie M.

description: Yum yum yum. Best Vietnamese sandwich I've had in a long time (5 spice chicken). Also got the sweet potato fries and they were great.
author: Jessica W.

description:
As good as it gets! I'm a banh-mee fan, and while I'm not Vietnamese enough to comment on the authenticity of the dishes, the bahn(bun)-mee sandwiches here are unpretentiously great. Tip: Don't forget to add a fried egg. 

But I write this review to rave about the 'Saigon Peanut rice bow' - oh oh oh so delicious and flavorful. Of course good location, good branding art-work, decent and prompt service, all make me come back whenever we're strolling Fillmore on a hungry stomach.
author: Pablo R.

description:
12.10.01    1st visit

Food:         3 1/2 - 4 stars    depending on what item



The chicken banh mi was weaker than true vietnamese shop.
      It did not have that taste of a product that have deep and strong 5 spice
       marinade. The grilling of the meat wasn't intense that u couldn't taste it.
