The combo was pretty good, it was the best of the two.

Both was toasted ... a plus
                  ingredients were seperatedly clumps, therefore u either 
                               get a strong taste of either:
                                      pickleed carrots
                                       protein item(s)
                        - I had to open it up and redistribute the items evenly to ensure 
                               a more complete marriage of flavors.

Pickled carrots:
     It a judgement call ... everyone have a different take on what taste good
            - Large old fashioned size are more crunch to it and more flavor.
               The skinny version is more chewier yet u could spread it more 
                evenly.

Summary
       -  pretty good re-invented banh mi
       -  The chicken need either more stronger or longer marinage and
                   deeper char ...   personal taste ... old school style
       -  carrots ... preferred the old style
       -  item was prepared on order I believe ... even the protein (I think)
author: S.K. Y.

description:
When you have to temporarily close your doors because the SF Health Department has closed down our upstairs neighbors for a rat infestation you may want to look elsewhere. 

Not like the sandwiches were all that tasty before the shutdown: stale bread, dry chicken, minimal ingredients all with no flavor. Yawn. 
Makes me totally miss Super Combo down on Polk and Pine.
author: D C.

description: I'm adding an update because I've now also had the "juicy steak" sandwich, which was excellent.  My friends enjoyed the tofu rice bowl, the strawberry lychee drink, and the eggplant sandwich.  As before, the corn and sweet potato fries were great.  This place is DELISH!
author: Molly P.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here last night.  He got the Sloppy Bun and I got the Smokey Eggplant (their only vegetarian bun option).  Maybe it's unfair to compare this place to the Chairman Bao Truck from Off The Grid, since I know they are different styles of buns, but Bao wins for sure.

I think my main issue was that one small, cold, soggy piece of smoked eggplant with some cilantro on a tiny ass and sub-par roll was about $7.  I suppose cold is the style, but it was really unappetizing.  It was good enough to finish, though.  Their homemade limeade was very tasty, as was their coconut cookies!  Their cookies actually upstaged the bun for me, which is not good if your place has the name BUN in the title.

The other comparison I will make to Bao is that the Bao bun is actually good on it's own.  Even without their tasty tasty filling, I would eat Bao's bun on its own, it's very yummy.  Bun Mee's bun was like a small stale Subway sandwich roll, it tasted Day Old if you know what I mean.  Maybe if they got some fancier buns, warmed up my sandwich, and brought the price down to $4, I would give them four or more stars.
author: Kyle T.

description:
I have read most of the recent reviews. If you live in the neighborhood, it is a one of the best restaurant additions to Fillmore Street. Yes, I have been to Saigon in the Tenderloin several times, but this is supposed to be Vietnamese fusion and you're not faced with two old granny sandwich nazi's behind the counter yelling at you. 

My girlfriend and I returned to eat at Bun Mee last Friday. 

They were busy! There was a line, but it magically vanished in about 3min. Impressive.

As a special that day they served a coconut chocolate cookie. It was simply AMAZING. Seriously, the Girl Scouts should be selling them by the box, they're so yummy.

The food was consistently good as per my first visit. The service was impeccable.

It's a solid lunch/dinner spot for us in lower pacific heights
author: Bruce A.

description:
Best banh mi-inspired sandwiches I have ever had.... I must admit that I was stuck on the sloppy joe and although I do not have a huge sweet tooth those cookies were delicious... ( I wish I had a menu so I could outline the proper names of everything) 

Great food from a great staff with great prices... Bun Mee has just made my destination list in SF. Cheers!
author: Brian R.

description: This place was ok. I liked the atmosphere of the place but as far as the bunh mi, I've had better. I tried the pork lemongrass and the pork belly. The pork lemongrass was ok but more on the dry side. It definitely needed more flavor. The pork belly on the other hand was sooooo salty. I was only able to eat half of it after drinking a few glasses of water. I definitely do not recommend that, and the flavor doesn't taste too well. I did like the bread though. Nice and toasty. Unfortunately I won't be going here again. Sorry.
author: Tram H.

description:
I love Vietnamese sandwiches. My favorites from this place have to be the belly bun with the hard boiled egg. And the catfish is a real winner, even on days of Lent where we can't eat meat. 

Belly bun rich in flavor, just enough saltiness, on a hit making bread.
Catfish has a unique curry ish taste that reminds me of mama's cooking.
Mama Tran's rolls are unique egg rolls. Lots of filling and a great crunch.

My bf and I came in on Saturday and ordered one of each with the sweet potato fries. He ordered the ice coffee (which he said tasted just right and woke him up real good) while I ordered the limeade (not too sweet and just tangy enough). 

Its the perfect lunch on a nice sunny day for the cherry blossom festival. We sat at the bar and got to watch the staff make everyone elses' lunch. They were all super nice and accommodated us well. The staff greets every guests with smiles! :) 

And who doesn't love a little hip hop music in your life while eating a bomb.com sandwich! Mmmm....
author: Nathalie N.

description: A solid four stars! This is mainly for their banh mi. I ventured to try one of their salads and was sadly disappointed. It was overpriced for the quality. Their banh mi on the other hand is quite the opposite. This is definitely a regular haunt.
author: Nader A.

description:
Pretty good! Really good service too! Glasses guy did his best to get me hoisin (which they do not offer, like whaa?) He gave me all the sauces he could! How nice of him :) 

The banh mi here is alright. I need to try it a second time to be sure.
author: Margaret S.

description:
My friend and I have walked past Bun Mee at least a dozen times now and noticed it's always busy. We decided to kick into our Sunday with a Vietnamese sandwhich. Today, like every other day was a buzz with patrons.

I tried the pork sandwich, sweet potato fries and kaffir lime-aid...so good! The pork flavor was really nice with the jalapenos, cilantro, pickled carrots and aoili on a french baguette. Wow, I'm not sure I've had a better sandwich.
author: Leanne S.

description: Food here was really good in my opinion. Make sure to get the fresh spring rolls. The peanut sauce is awesome. Loved my sandwich and will eat here again!
author: Jaron S.

description: Really really good sandwich for a really good price! I had the lemon grass pork sando which was some of the best bahn mi I've ever had. The drink (although I don't know exactly what it was) was also very good.
author: Caleb W.

description:
Vietnamese flavors and new flavors infused in each of their sandwiches makes it a hot new sandwich spot on my list. Don't miss the add-on list!

Hard to park around here but it is a nice stroll on Fillmore St.
author: Oanh N.

description: So close to five stars. The side salads need some work, the combo sandwich was amazing, didn't love the pork, enjoyed the chicken salad, very much. A little pricier than I expect from small Vietnamese sandwiches, I always get two, but here they're worth the few extra bucks.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Bread quality is a pretty big part of any sandwich.

In my opinion, there are two distinct types of banh mi breads in use throughout SF.

Type A is the light, flaky crusted, straw colored, football shaped variety that generally leaves a pile of crust shards on your plate the second you bite into it.  

Type B is more like a slice of a baguette.  The sort of baguette you might find at a bakery, with a hard, amber crust  and big sourdough style air holes filling up the insides.

I'm partial to type B, but it tends to be the more uncommon of the two.  

Bun Mee uses something closer to type A, but of a slightly higher quality than that which I am generally accustomed to finding.  It squishes flat when you hold it in your hand, but the flaky crust doesn't just disintegrate.  It tastes fresher than it appears to be.  

Likewise, the quality of the meats and veggies is pretty key.

At Bun Mee they have a working grill right there in the store for all to see.  They grill up the chicken and pork in big batches in front of you before chopping it into sandwich sized morsels for the assembly trays.  

Offhand, I'd say that it appears that most banh mi stores grill up the meats a day in advance and microwave them up for each individual order.  

For all of this attention to detail at Bun Mee you pay a steep premium, of course.  A sandwich that would cost $4 at most places will set you back $6.50 here.

It probably doesn't hurt that there don't really appear to be any serious competitors within 10 blocks of this spot either.  

I'd rate Bun Mee as the sort of place that's clean enough, and makes a nice enough sandwich that you wouldn't be ashamed to bring a date or a coworker here.  

It might not ever displace that greasy and dingy sentimental favorite of yours though.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Every time I see a new place open on Fillmore, I get excited. In fact, when I walked past Bun Mee, I squeaked with delight and then took a photo as a reminder to try it. First of all, there isn't that many "ethnic" restaurants on Fillmore so it's nice to diversify the area. 

Our first attempt failed because Bun Mee underestimated how much business they would attract and therefore ran out of sandwiches and had to close early. Bummer! 

Second time is the charm. Wow, business was booming and  there was a line out the door. Do not be deterred by the long line because it moves fast!  Thanks to two cashiers and four sandwich makers in the back. 

The insider recommendation was pork belly bun and 5 spice chicken sandwich. I ordered the Bun Mee Combo and imperial rolls while JN ordered the 5 spice chicken sandwich and papaya salad. We typically share our food to enrich our tasty ventures.

Overall, both Bun Mee Combo and imperial rolls were disappointing and was on the bland side. While the 5 spice chicken was tasty, I did not care for the vermicelli that was mixed in with the papaya salad. I am definitely trying the pork belly bun next time. Sigh, Bun Mee feels like a puppy crush, fleeting and not satisfying.
author: Sophie C.

description:
after having been to Num Pang in NY and enjoying their creatively delicous coconut shrimp banh mi, i couldn't help but wonder why in the world SF didn't already have a different kind of vietnamese sandwich shop. once word was out that Bun Mee was going to open, i remained excited until the day i finally got to try it. 

i was anticipating sinking my teeth in to a creative delicious banh mi only to be left thinking "i actually would rather have a regular banh mi from Saigon Sandwich." i tried the pork belly one and the juicy steak one. the pork belly one was good but if you let it sit for more than 10 minutes the fat/oil in from the pork starts to soften the bun too much, making the bun mushy, thus turning the bun in to a texture much like fat. then it feels like you're just eating a fat sandwich rather than a pork belly sandwich. the flavors were good but not fantastic. the juicy steak sandwich had a lot of flavor but almost too many flavors. steak, peppers, jalapenos, fried onions, raw onions....it was just too much. it took away from the simplicity of banh mi. 

though the idea is fun, i think the execution didn't quite meet my expectations. i think i'll stick to the traditional until i go back to NY to get a Num Pang sandwich.
author: Regina C.

description: My belly bun sammie at Bun Mee was good (not great or spectacular) with an okay blend of pickled veggies and oozing fatty pork belly. The veggies lacked the sour punch I'm used to in a banh mi. I asked for some extra jalapenos and cilantro. It's not exactly authentic bahn mi sandwiches, but I knew this walking in. The prices are about double what you would get from other Viet sandwich places. Feels like a 3-star.
author: Derek N.

description:
I may not be one of those white people (!) who can exactly tell the difference between a "good" and a "bad" Asian food.  However, I can at least tell when something is totally off.  Bun Mee was one of the worst Asian food joints I ever tried.  Wish I could rate them a minus ten stars or something.

And what's worse than their amazingly bad food, it is unbelievably and disgustingly over priced.  I had a peanut rice bowl w/ chicken and small side salad that costed me $17.  The rice bowl was served with just a small piece of dried tough to chew chicken without any flavor (amazingly no flavor at all) and over cooked brown rice in an artificial wooden plastic bowl.  Yes, a plastic bowl.  If it was like I was having a $5.99 rice bowl at an Asian fast food place, I wouldn't totally mind but the dish I had was $12.  Bad food plus high price added trashy food performance.  It was truly a nightmare.

There are so many Asian joints like Bun Mee in this city that use pop and cute decorations for their places and serve unbelievably bad food with high price.  And what's so funny about those places is that somehow there are always people who even line up for them - e.g. bad Thai restaurants with cute interior designs in Tender Nob etc.  There were two Marina looking like girls right next to me who were constantly saying "It's soooooo good! I love Vietnamese food!!!"  Oh gosh if I was a Vietnamese, I am sure I would have had a heart attack.  Girls, this is not a Vietnamese food.  This is called a trashy mixed up Asian food that exists to steal money from people like you.
author: Fuschia Jane B.

description:
Belly Bun with egg, please.  Mmm mmm mmm... 

Bun Mee reminds me of Kitchenette's yummy sandwiches, plus more! I'm determined to try everything on their menu.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Amazing Vietnamese sandwiches, lots of flavor and good size. I get delivery from here frequently and it's always on time or early. Delicious I highly recommend.
author: Brooke K.

description: Great lunch spot -- the office got food from here today. I'm always happy with the chicken banh mi and limeade, though the coworkers seemed less pleased with their salad and catfish banh mi.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Good sandwich which they kindly made w tofu and got my my Mom a salad w shrimp and mango.
Mom said the shrimp was so-so but she is super hard to please...

Also shared some fsweet potato fries, tasty, but I think I only needed to try them once.

The choc wafer cookie w cocnut creamy filling is to die for...
author: Monkey T.

description:
I think Bun Mee is a nice addition to this area.  Its fast, affordable and clean.  The ingredients they use seem to be high quality the only problem is that there isn't alot of them.  I took my Vietnamese friend (she's from Irvine so she's legit) and sampled a few sandwiches.  Here's our review:
Bread: Fluffy,  crunchy, solid.  Standard in a town where Acme, Semifreddis and Tartine bread are the norm. 

Meat: Quality, didn't seem like Ranch 99 but there wasn't enough of it.  My guess is that they opted for free range, humane slaughter which means not alot of meat but you feel less guilty about devouring it.  You get what you pay for: more meat = lesser quality or less meat = better quality.   Here its LM, BQ. 

Veggies: I think I'd want more flavor so I asked for extra pepper and wished I asked for extra cilantro, too.  I know what I'll do next time. 

Here's an interesting idea.  I wish they'd have a build your own sandwich option like Subway but w. Vietnamese options so that I could tell them how much stuff I'd like to put in my sandwich.  I'd gladly pay more to make my sandwich a double.
author: Sarah C.

description:
At first I must admit I was a bit skeptical about this place with it's catchy name and it's upper crusty location.  I'm a longtime fan of Saigon Sandwiches and I still think it's the best bang for the buck but after reading some of the reviews I decided to give it a try.  

Color me impressed!  I tried the 5 spice chicken sandwich - the bread was fresh and toasty and the veggies were nice and crisp.  The nice part is you can actually see the cooks at the grill cooking the fresh chicken (the meat at Saigon Sandwiches is questionable).  Overall it was a very tasty sandwich, the sweet potato fries were cooked to perfection and delicious and there are actually a few tables and a bar where you can enjoy your meal instead of waiting in a super long line just to grab your sando and bring it home to eat.  It was well worth the extra couple of bucks and I would definitely go back to try some of the other items on the menu.
author: Julie P.

description: Super yummy , pretty cafe, upscale Vietnamese sandwich with budget prices. Love it. I got my pork belly and iced coffee.
author: Sean H.

description:
Wow, have to say I was looking forward to eating here. Cute restaurant, nice logo. 

Service, well, lacking. Placed my carry out order. Gal behind the register seemed sweet. Left a tip in the jar. And stepped aside to wait. And wait. And wait. The three guys who placed an order after me got their meal. While I was waiting, I noticed a waiter looking for the table with number 20. He went back to the kitchen and came out. Then returned to the kitchen and out to the dining area. After awhile they realized it was my takeout order and packaged it for me. I did get a luke warm apology. 

Took my food home.  Of course it was cold. Plus, they switched out the five spice chicken sandwich I ordered, for the belly bun with an egg on top. Passable, although very greasy. Mildest jalapeños ever. The mango salad was mostly napa cabbage,  very little mango and sesame seeds. Not worth three dollars. 

Would it be bad to go back and reclaim my tip from the tip jar?
author: Catherine P.

description: Mango sesame salad - Very simple & light. Overly simplistic. Pretty much nothing beyond mango, greens, sesame seed, and dressing. But free on Scoutmob = a good deal any day!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
So I guess I just don't understand why everyone keeps mentioning this place is "pricey". I'm far from rich and I work not live in Pac Heights but I guess as a jaded San Franciscan I don't think 10 bucks for an awesome meal is a crime. 

I'm slightly addicted to the Belly Bun (add boiled egg!) with a side of sweet potato fries. Just like any hip restaurant, don't go there every day, wait til your cravin it!

I'm minusing some respek for the nasty soap in the bathroom. Its that pink stuff you see in gas stations, ew. Thats not what I want to smell everytime i take a bite.
author: Kim A.

description: Fresh ingredients and friendly service, but you're paying Fillmore prices for a medicore banh mi. They're just not as tasty as the kind you can get on Larkin. Lee Sandwiches is cheaper and better.
author: Jordan C.

description:
I walked by last week, and noticed a sign for the official Grand Opening on April 1.   Call me a fool, but I made my lunch plans a week in advance.

But fortune smiled, and they decided to do a "preview week", and I was able to get my first (of many) Fillmore St. Banh Mi today.  I had the only vegetarian option that I could see - the Spicy Eggplant.

It was very well made, with a flavor that lit up my mouth for minutes after I'd left the restaurant.  A very pleasant feeling.  My only criticisms of the sandwich:  the bun wasn't hot, or quite crispy enough for my taste.  Also, I detected a fishy taste - do you use fish sauce?  You may want to alert your vegetarian customers.

I would hope you add a tofu option or other vegetarian offerings.  This is SF, after all.  But since I'm not a vegetarian, I'm looking forward to trying your many other choices.

I'll be back tomorrow!

Just to note, there are two French restaurant/bakeries in the vicinity.  And now two Vietnamese restaurants.   Now this is a competition that I will like!  Of course, you do have French baguettes and french fries on your menu....who knows, maybe a collaboration with La Boulange?!
author: Ravi C.

description:
Eh, I'm a banh mi fanatic yes...and I was absolutely blown away by the quality of grilled meats. I got the "juicy steak" banh mi.
Amazing how such a simple sandwich can get so many variations but hey, that's fun! So, pickles are great and thick with nice texture, bread is just right (with a nice crunch and soft bite) and the overall quality of ingredients sets it way above the bar in the city.
Too bad for the price point...but hey, that's the rent on Fillmore St.

Besides: THE COOOKIES!
OMG, the chocolate/coconut cookies!
COOKIE, COOKIE, COOKIE!
so good...
author: Dario B.

description: Love the sandwiches! Have not tried Vietnamese sandwiches before, but I became a fan because of Bun Mee. Crisp & fresh. My favorite is the 5-spice chicken WITH the jalapeños, but the others I tried were good, too. Also recommend the mango salad. Expect to have greasy fingers as you will want to dig in.
author: Lajos M.

description:
Sweet place!  I admit I was pretty skeptical when I saw a Banh mi place on Fillmore of all places.  Was this going to be a shop serving bland, uninspiring Banh mi for double the Tenderloin prices?

I'm glad to say the answer is no.  It's not Tenderloin prices, but it's not lower Pac Heights prices either...and the food is pretty good.

I picked up the pork belly sandwich and was very happy with the choice.  The bun was perfectly crisp on the outside while still soft on the inside.  The pork belly just melts in your mouth.  So, so good.  I like the fact that the taste of the pork belly wasn't overwhelmed by the other flavors in the sandwich.

Being the first weekend they were open, I could see that they were having some operational difficulties (i.e. the sandwich assembly line wasn't very efficient).  I know the owners realize this and I think things will improve for Bun Mee over the next few weeks.

Overall, a great new addition to the area.
author: Y K.

description:
Holy crap this place is amazing.  I love the fast food style ambiance mixed with the chalk board menu.  Its a great space and just what fillmore needs.

I wanted to order everything on the menu, but settled for the Fish Bahn Mi sandwich and one of their delicious dessert cookie sandwiches.  I got everything to-go with a friend and ate it about an hour later.  Still amazing and travels well.  I wish I lived next door to this place, I think I would turn Vietnamese.
author: jessica b.

description:
It's a new place, so I've only visited one time.  With that caveat, you can continue reading my review or not.

I was confused by the name and asked the woman working the cash register when I stopped in during the pre-opening to look around.  Didn't order anything that time and didn't really get an answer.  Play on Bánh mì?  But, Bun means rice noodle, right?  No noodles here.  Design was nice, so it looked promising.

Asked a few Vietnamese folks for their thoughts on the place.  Most were put off by the price.  But, hey, it's Fillmore street, so not really out of line.  And, I'd already enjoyed expensive Vietnamese sandwiches at Out the Door in the Ferry Building.

Came by myself for lunch and found a seat at the bar where I could watch the cooks.  Noticed that the majority of the staff was not Vietnamese, there were folks who looked like owners who were; no problem.  It was hot in front of the cook tops and also loud throughout the restaurant (they had a big crush around opening).  

Ordered at the cashier.  Went with a standard roast pork and a side salad (out of Mango Sesame Salad), so I got the cabbage slaw.  While waiting in the kitchen, I noticed that they were cooking up most of the meat ingredients in house.  Chatted with my neighbor at the bar about this new place.

First, I have to say that the slaw was very good.  The sandwich was fine, but not great.  Not as good as Out the Door (the most direct competition).  Different enough from Lee's or your typical inexpensive Vietnamese sandwich place that it's not really a direct comparison.  The roast pork didn't have the pink color and distinct Chinatown flavor of the typical Banh mi joint.  In fact, the pork was a bit bland and very thickly cut.  The bread was interesting, but a bit on the fluffy side for my taste (would have liked a bit more crunch).  

I should confess that I'm not an expert.  I do enjoy the aforementioned ferry building place on occasion and normally hit up Lee's in SF.  I've enjoyed better Banh Mi down in San Jose (off Tully Road), but don't really know where to point one in SF.

I hope to go back after they've been open a few months and try again.  Seems fine, but not a destination for me.
author: Jice E.

description:
This place saved me. Have you ever gone to the doctor's office up the hill and then was famished and walked up and down the staid and stuffy chain-like stores and restaurants that is now lined side by side on Fillmore? Nothing appealed to me until I hit this place.

A banh mi, some rolls and a coffee later, I'm happy. It's not the best Banh mi but it's a welcome respite from the wealth of Pac Heights.

p.s. they assume you want your coffee iced, so if you want it hot, you have to ask for it hot.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
The food here is very simple and feels authentic without any fear of mystery meat. 

I have had both the lemongrass pork sandwich as well as the peanut rice bowl with chicken and both were delightful. The sandwich was plenty of food for me, but may be on the small side if you are a growing boy. The rice bowl is enormous, which was great because I am all about leftovers. 


The space is adorable but tiny. I particularly like this spot for a quiet solo lunch and will happily add it to my rotation.
author: Molly S.

description:
I stopped by for lunch after seeing this in 7x7 magazine. 

ORDERED: 
Sloppy Joe Bun mee with egg - Maybe I had too many expectations. Although the filling was good, I didn't see what the hype was. I personally thought the egg was unnecessary and the bread needed to be toasted more if it was toasted at all. The sloppy joe meat and the egg yoke soaks into the bread making the whole thing really messing and soggy.  

I'll probably go back one more time for the catfish Bunmee since that sounded pretty good.
author: Jess H.

description:
A few friends and I were walking down Fillmore this Saturday, enjoying the sunny January weather and planning on grabbing a coffee at The Grove before splitting off for dinner. As we sat outside enjoying our caffeine fix, Bun Mee beckoned us towards its glorious hipster storefront. We were at the mercy of its aesthetic appeal, and after we had drained our mugs we somehow found ourselves bustling into the tiny restaurant, bumping shoulders with each other and everyone else. 

Since we already had dinner reservations, we just ordered one sandwich to taste among the 4 of us. It wasn't the most polite thing to do, perhaps, but we just had to see what the sandwich was like! The cashier didn't seem too pleased with us, but who could blame him? 

We ordered the lemongrass grilled pork banh mi and sat ourselves at the bar, away from the crowds. The sandwich came out after a few minutes, and we split it into four delectable pieces -- the perfect appetizer! The french bread was excellent, as were all of the yummy pickled vegetables. My friends all loved the fattiness of the pork, and I really liked the lemongrass seasonings, though the fat was a bit of a deterrent for me personally. 

Though I wish the prices were more on par with other places selling the same fare, and it would be nice if the place was just a bit more spacious and had more seating, I think that the ambience and the tasty food make up for the drawbacks. I would definitely come back. Very fun!
author: Sam L.

description:
So, it was tasty, it was good, but my friend and I agree, it is Charles Pham's version of Bánh mì. You take a S.E. Asian staple and twinkie the fuck out of it. So yes my round eye friends, enjoy, after all it was made especially for you.
*** Whispers to asian friends***     Meet me around back, we'll hit up that authentic place for some too-fiddy lovely and iced coffee and meet back up with the happy crackers. What they do not know will not hurt them.
author: Mark B.

description:
Depending on the time parking is easy or impossible.

Just opened up....found it in the SF Weekly.

Bun Mee is a Vietnamese restaurant and I ordered their Five Spice Chicken Sandwich and their Sliced Pork Sandwich.

okay i've updated this because i had only eaten the five spice chicken sandwich and wrote the review.  I ate the sliced pork sandwich and i'm moving it to the front of this review.

the sliced pork sandwich was Bland.  I hated it.  I didn't like the style of pork, no seasoning, it tasted like a piece of meat would taste, something that might turn you into a vegan or vegatarian.

Now, the five spice chicken is Exactly as i thought it would be...it was good.  Warm, soft bread(as opposed to the usual HARD french original vietnamese sandwiches are on).  Delicious sandwich which I can only compare to the sandwich at Asian Kitchen in Cache Creek Resort and Casino.

for 5.95 it seems a bit high but honestly its about the same price anywhere except for the place i go to downtown.  but we won't mention their name here because it wouldn't be fair.  I wrote about asian kitchen because its so far away.
author: Bing D.

description: DO NOT GO HERE! I ordered a steak bunh mi and all i could taste in the sandwich were carrots and cucumbers! where the hell did the steak go? i didn't order a carrot sandwich okay?! terrible! i was so pissed! their lemonade drink was just as terrible! i will never eat here again! spend your money somewhere else!
author: Morgan D.

description: The food is mediocre and the cashiers are incredibly rude.  The cashier on Saturday kept insisting that he had offered me a bag when he hadn't.  Please learn decent customer service.
author: Matt M.

description: Quick? Check. Friendly? Check. Good? Hmm. The menu seems interesting enough, but the food doesn't quite deliver. It isn't bad, but for the price it should be pretty fantastic. I can get a basic bahn mi in Little Saigon that is full of flavor for 1/4 what this place charges. Instead, I got a fancy sounding yet bland dish that I didn't care to finish.
author: Brett B.

description: First of all, I am Vietnamese. Not saying I am an expert in Vietnamese cuisine, but it helps that I grew up on the food. Banh Mi and Pac Heights? Words that don't necessarily go hand in hand. However, I was pleasantly surprised their Banh Mi sandwhich was tasty and after the first bite, it brought back warm childhood memories.
author: E ..

description:
We had the grilled pork sandwich and it was pretty good.
The meat was tasty and the bread was light and crunchy as you'd expect with Vietnamese sandwiches.  The sandwich cost $6.50 which is more than what I've paid at other Vietnamese restaurants, but the location and decor was nice and I guess it was worth the visit.  Seating is sort of limited and there was a short (~5 minute) wait when we went there for a weekend lunch.
author: Durif M.

description:
The bread sandwich I had here was pretty delicious. I think they called it a grilled pork sandwich? I did notice some delicious faint traces of grilled pork I think. Maybe that's why they named it that? A little expensive for a bread sandwich though IMO.

The coconut cream cookies should get their own spin-off shop. They are the real star here.
author: Gabe M.

description:
I understand why you would keep in line with the rest of the 8 dollar sandwich options on Fillmore, but come on.... there's hardly any meat in these banh mi's!  

If you're gonna go here... you need to also get the sweet potato fries and dipping sauce so you feel like you ate something... oh and they're really good

Sorry new neighbor... I really want to love you.... but here we are.
author: Brian J.

description:
As a fan of Bahn Mi, I cant give the one I had here more stars than 3.  Here is why:

-too much mayo
-not enough pate
-carrots, onions and peppers were very very bland, no vinegary flavor, no spice

I paid $10 for a sandwich and soda (which I did not drink because although I asked for a diet soda, I was given a regular with 160 calories of sugar and after a sip I realized there was a mistake so I just left it). I was expecting a much more flavorful sandwich.  I wish the veggies had more flavor but no. Maybe some hot sauce would help. 

I might come back after they have had a chance to work out some kinks and I hope they do because I hate having to trek out to the nasty tenderloin to get my Bahn Mi fix at Saigon Sandwiches...which are still the best (and the cheapest) ones I have ever eaten, anywhere.
author: Nilu r.

description: Overpriced, much better bun mee in the city. For what you pay it should taste better, but it is a solid choice if you don't mind being ripped off.
author: Misha Z.

description: Sandwiches are delicious. I love them. One Star downgrade because the limeade was a cup of diabetes. I had to add tons of water to it.
author: Angela W.

description: Been eating pretty regularly at the new Bun Mee on Market.  Quick, consistent, cheap.  Love it.  I've had almost every one of the sandwiches, my favorites are the sloppy bun and the tofu.  Delicious and quick for a busy workday.
author: T. H.

description:
I wish there were half stars. I'd give this a solid 3.5. 

I went in an ordered the Bun Mee combo and the girl behind the counter informed me that they were out of two of the ingredients that were needed for that. Why they didn't have a sign on their big menu board saying they were out of it is beyond me. But she was super nice and friendly about it. 

I ended up getting the Sloppy Bun and Green Papaya Salad. The Sloppy Bun was really good. Very much like a fusion sloppy joe, and I would argue, better, since I don't like sloppy joes all that much but I would eat this thing again. 

The Green Papaya Salad was disappointing. You can tell the salad is pre-made and has been sitting around. It tastes like I would expect the leftovers to taste after a day in my fridge. (Not that I will find out as my leftovers are already in the compost bin.) Too bad. My friends had a similar experience with the Napa Cabbage Salad. So word of caution: stay away from the pre-made salads. 

I also had the Vietnamese Iced Coffee which was good but just a touch sweeter than I felt it should have been based on my other Vietnamese iced coffee experiences. 

The venue itself is nice and a great place to sit for a bit on Fillmore. 
All in all, I will be back, but just for the sandwiches. 

Bun Mee - start making fresh salads!!!
author: Kate W.

description:
I only tried the pork belly bun mee.  The pork is very tender, juicy and flavorful.  It is one of my favorite bun mees!  But it was too small.  I was hungry after 2 hours.  The wait was excruciatingly long.  The girl told me 15 minutes but I actually waited 30 minutes just for one sandwich!  I hope the owners review the comments and beef up their sandwiches.

I, also had their mango and papaya salad.  Both are too bland and not that great...sorry to say.  Don't waste $3 extra for them.
author: Ammala B.

description:
Absolutely delicious. Indulgent. Sinful. 

I had the sloppy bun and was sweating as I devoured it and a bunch of sweet potato fries within minutes. Love the jalapeno spice factor - they do not skimp! 

My bf got the chicken sandwich and it was equally delicious. 

Go hungry.

4 stars because the Vietnamese coffee was sub-par.
author: Sabrina S.

description:
Went here with my mom when she was in town. I had the five-spice chicken, and she had the sloppy sandwich with an egg. Mmmmm!!! 

'm deducting a star based on some concerns that my motherly mother had about their cleanliness. We sat at the bar and watched them make the sandwiches. They use gloves, but they touch the outsides of them with contaminated hands... But I will keep eating here until I get struck down with cross-contamination.
author: C B.

description:
I've been here a handful of times in the last three months.  The first time I was pretty impressed, but every single time I went back the service and food got worse and worse.  Tonight was the worst and probably my last time visiting.  We walked in around 7:00pm and ordered right away for a togo order.  As soon as we sat down I noticed that no one in the place had any food in front of them so I figured we were in for a wait.  After 30 minutes of waiting everybody was starting to get frustrated.  A few call in orders went out the door but that was it.  

A few people actually went up to the cashiers to ask/complain about the wait and were faced with giggles and no real answers.   No apologies  no nothing.  Eventually they just went to the back of the place to avoid customers.  

After 45 minutes of waiting I started getting frustrated and asked what was going on because I saw two people who ordered after me get their orders.  No apology or offer to discount the meal.  We walked out after an hour of waiting with our food.  

Once we got home (no more than 5 minutes) we found out that we waited for nothing.  I ordered the Crispy Catfish and it was poorly breaded and soggy.  Noodles for the noodle bowl were way overcooked and the bowl was filled with what looked like a pre-made salad mix.  

Very frustrating night out.
author: Rich T.

description: Definitely recommend if you're looking for a quick decently priced meal. Healthy sized portion with tons of flavor for a small price, which isn't that easy to find in this city.
author: Mark W.

description: If by authentic, you mean cheap ingredients, dirty storefront, and lack of culinary innovation, the critics are spot on. But, if you are a foodie, Vietnamese or not, you'll love the food. To be fair to authenticity, Saigon Sandwich is the best authentic shop and Bun Mee has great food at a good price. Yummy!
author: Ivan R.

description: I've come back a couple of times since my original review and the place has been consistently solid, so I'm rounding up to a 4.
author: Baron C.

description:
This place just nails it. I had their juicy steak sandwich that came hot, spicy, tangy, on a scrumtrulescently sturdy baguette. A great blend of eastern and western flavors. The meat is sliced thin and the textures just balance one another perfectly. 

The sandwich with a natural cane soda was about $13, I think. Next time I have to try some of those sweet potato fries! They looked amazing.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I read the other reviews, and decided to give this place a shot, even though the other reviews weren't quite stellar. I really don't see what this place lacks.

First, on the bread, maybe they've changed it? Yes, it's not a classic baguette, but it might actually be better. It widens out in the middle, allowing it to hold much more, which is really ideal.

Next, we had four sandwiches, and all four had a good amount of veggies, the lack of which seemed to be a common complaint.

Then, the pork belly was amazing. We had to get another.

Salads were good too - I'd like to go back and get a bun.

Service was also excellent. People were cheerful and helpful and efficient. 

And $6.50 seems very appropriate for a sandwich in this part of town, especially one with good quality ingredients, and seating.

No question - great lunch spot.
author: Michael A.

description: Two bites, all I could tolerate. Not at all a veggie crispy tofu sandwich. For ~$14 you would expect more for a crispy tofu sandwhich & coffee, and/or a disclaimer that the repulisive "sandwich" that you get is non-veggie.  Do yourself a favor & avoid this disgusting hipster-art establishment. #worstvietnamesefoodinsf
author: Matthew N.

description: Tried the banh mi combo and the five spice chicken one and found both to be very tasty and fresh.  It is a bit out of the way unless you're already in the Fillmore but would like to go back to try some of their other choices.
author: Joyce Z.

description: One of my FAVORITE restaurants on Polk and great for weeknight dinner when you just can't bring yourself to cook.  I am addicted to the Saigon Peanut Bowl with chicken.  Hubby loves the sloppy bun (its yummy).  We also often get the fresh rolls, which are good too.  The bun noodle bowl is my least favorite on the menu - its fine, but not as good as other things.
author: Jill G.

description:
Being Vietnamese and growing up on authentic "banh mi" sandwiches probably makes me a little biased.

Food: The 5 spice chicken sandwich had nice flavor and was cooked well and the bread had a nice toast. Had the papaya salad, thought it was a little too acidic.

Ambiance: Nice modern yet retro design. Just enough tables to fit a little under 20 people.

Service: Sandwich came out in a timely manner.

Price: $6 for the sandwich and $3 for the salad. 

Overall: If you're on Fillmore and have to have a Vietnamese sandwich, then cool, stop on by. But if you're in the hunt for the real thing, take a trip down to the Tenderloin and save a couple extra dollars too.
author: Binh D.

description: This is an awesome sandwich place! They make the sandwiches with a nice spicy kick to them, and there's a whole menu of different ones to choose from. It reminds me a lot of Pittsburgh-style sandwiches, but with a unique twist.
author: Alex R.

description: Oh Bun Mee, why did you take away your best menu item??  The Citrus Rice Bowl was so fresh and delish!!  Please bring it back, it was the only thing that kept me going back.
author: Keri W.

description:
I enjoyed the food here primerily because the frying is very good (if you are going to eat fried food, it better be worth the calories and bad health points).. the fries were very crispy so were the rolls, crunchy and fresh.
The sandwiches are also very good, but I did notice a slight difference from the first few months that they opened to a sudden change in the last month (hence deducting one point), not sure what it is about, hoping it is a hiccup.
Would love some more veggie choices.
author: Mirto H.

description: Not the most authentic bun mee I've had, and alittle over priced. That's what you should expect ordering an asian sandwich in the Marina/Pac Heights I guess, you pay the yuppy price for the yuppy food. Overall, it's good and filling.
author: Chi L.

description: Dying to come here because I've always loved the branding which I had seen years ago, and the taste lived up to the nice design.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Overall good experience. I think what this place has going for it is that it's the only place of its kind in pacific heights, and a safer option for those that don't want to venture into the tenderloin for a cheaper, and in my opinion more flavorful (and authentic even?), version of the same thing. Bun Mee's sandwiches are more fresh though, and probably made with meat from grass fed cows and all that jazz. 
I got the juicy steak sandwich and added pate. We also got the sweet potato fries which were really good. It was a good sandwich but I would have liked a marinade and a tiny bit more flavor. I would go back but wouldn't go out of my way for it necessarily.
author: Shirin M.

description:
Stir it up.

Don't forget. Especially when you order the Vietnamese coffee. I was clueless and was sipping dark java until one of the staff casually mentioned I might want to stir.

Thanks for that. And thanks for the sweet and potent afternoon pick me up.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is refreshing addition to filmore street as in the sandwhiches are surprisingly fresh, healthy, and tastey. They may sound fancy, but they are pretty simple. The shrimp salad/ rice bowl has a great sweet tangy sauce. I've had both the pork with garlic aoli and the bun mee combination sandwhich. The combination sandwhich has pate on it which I found fabulous. The sauses aren't all that heavy and the bread is super fresh and tastey. I also am a huge jalapeno fan and they come on every sandwhich. Adds a great spice to the otherwise simple sandwhich.

As the restaurant is new the wait is currently about 15-20 minutes even togo, but you can call ahead. 

And make sure to get an ordre of the sweet potato fries, they are exceptional and come with a tangy spicy dipping sauce that complements them prefectly.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Preface: I am not a hard-core Bánh mì person. 

I had the rice noodle bowl with the fish sauce - my protein was tofu and I added an egg on top. It was great! Others at my table at the peanut rice bowl (one with beef, the other prawns), a pork belly sandwich, cabbage salad and fries. All in all it was great! Everyone loved their dishes. The tofu in my noodle bowl was amazing - seriously one of the best tofus I have ever had.  They don't have their liquid license yet, so I ordered an iced coffee - amazing. Blows a "thai" ice tea out of the water. Really looking forward to going back! I will probably just do take-out, since it's super small inside, and not very good for large groups.
author: Gina M.

description:
I'm only reviewing the 5 spiced Chicken Bahn Mi.  Basically the sandwich was unbalanced in flavor and texture.  

The bread wasn't toasted enough and frankly all I could really taste in the sandie was the bread & pickled daikon.  The chicken had no flavor and the texture was so similar to the bread, I couldn't tell if I was eating chicken or not.  The chk was almost soggy or something...not tender...but soggy.

I think the sandie would fare better if they add a sauce to the chicken to punch up the flavor.  Distribute the daikon & cilantro evenly.  And get a better bread roll.

The price was $6-7 bucks too which for a Bahn mi is overpriced.  I'd be willing to pay it if it was a good sandie, but not for something weak like this.

The layout of the place isn't too bad tho.  Small, but earthy and clean looking.
author: C A.

description:
if you're docking stars because it's not "authentic" vietnamese food then i don't have any time for you. 

i don't care WHAT kind of food it is, so long as it's delicious and i get a bang for my buck - which bun mee satisfies. 

first time? get the combo bahn mi and mango salad.
author: Dexter F.

description: Best tastiest sandwiches especially the eggplant one! Employees are friendly - great service food and atmosphere!
author: Cat K.

description:
I have eaten lunch many times at Bun Mee.. Its a treat for sure! The selection is good, but I always stick with the lemon Grass Pork, with extra meat, and jalapenos! Ask for the Curry Mayo for sure ..The service is friendly, and you really cant go wrong with this eatery. Its most definitely worth the time to stop by and try it.. I'm not a big fan of the bowls so I stick to the Pork or Steak sandwiches, make sure to ask for the jalapeno fries !!
Enjoy!!!
author: M. B.

description: Coming from rural area hoping to get some amazing Vietnamese in SF, was slightly disappointed at the much Americanized BUN MEE that it offered. Much too heavy on the mayo and salt.
author: Ivy R.

description:
This place was decent. It's very Americanized (which should be a given in that location). I guess I've had much better vietnamese sandwiches since I'm asian. However, their bread is pretty good. It is also very clean here compared to the rest of the 'banh mi' in SF. But sometimes the dirtier the place, the better the food tastes. If you've never had vietnamese food, I guess this is a good place to start. Their menu gives a pretty good description of what you're eating. 

Try Saigon sandwiches in the TL.. that's my favorite spot for banh mi.
author: Cara N.

description:
Outstanding Vietnamese food, great prices.

Try the salt and pepper fries, and have a fried egg on whichever sandwich you choose ...  Delicious.
author: Kevin M.

description:
That thing this place was named after? I've never had the real thing. I don't know what that says about me, but there it is.

If we dropped the name and just told you it's "similar" to bahn mi (in the same way curry up now can have a tikka masala burrito still be a burrito), then what do we think? Seems more fair because I don't get the impression Bun Mee is trying to be the real thing.

Well I think it's great. The sloppy with a fried egg was juicy and perfectly seasoned. Half of one was enough for me considering the other dishes we were ordering. The citrus rice bowl was a little bit on the plain side and some of the chicken was a little grizzly, but the avocado and oranges were very fresh. Definitely get it with brown rice, though I guess that depends on your preference. Also, they only have one kind of cookie - aka they put some serious thought into what that one cookie should be and they've perfected it. It's basically an oreo with coconut cream in the middle. It's lighter than you would think, but satisfies the sweet tooth.

Of all the restaurants on that stretch of Fillmore, this one is the most interesting I've tried yet.
author: Joanne S.

description:
ok....its not authentic.  whatever.  anyone who knows me, knows that i have never been one to scoff at this.  all that matters is that it: a) taste good and, b) be a good value for what you are getting.

i had the "sloppy bun" which is basically a sloppy joes in a banh mi.  The ground beef was flavored with red curry.  super tasty.  i opted for the fried egg on top.  fried eggs make everything better.  the veggies were in the right proportion and the bread was fresh and tasty.  i havent had a banh mi in a long time, but this one seemed substantially bigger and more filling....like twice the size.....which delightfully offsets the fact that it costs twice as much as normal banh mi.  my only complaint is that the beef was WAY too hot.  the point where i needed to limit my intake for fear of burning my mouth....even near the end of the sandwich.  i am working on a job right around the corner from here and i cannot wait to try a different sandwich.
author: Christian C.

description:
Oh, wait, I'm reviewing Bun Mee and not Dinosaurs in the Castro.

At times my ratings are skewed because half-stars aren't yet allowed on Yelp, but Bun Mee gets a solid 3-star "A-OK" from me.

I get it; let's take the popular concept of the traditional Vietnamese sandwich and fancy it up with some "Oh, I didn't think of putting that in my sandwich" fillings, and you've got yourself a business! And add the bougie Fillmore neighborhood to the mix? WINNER.

I commend Bun Mee on a strategic and great business model/concept, but in terms of ambiance and food quality, it was simply A-OK. Pricing was a bit high for a Vietnamese sandwich ($5-8), but understandable given the Fillmore.

My friends and I tried three different sandwiches: pork, catfish, and chicken. The pork sandwich was nothing special, the catfish sandwich was actually pretty good, minus the over seasoning, and the chicken sandwich was boring.

In summary, as far as Vietnamese sandwiches ratings go:

1. ANY San Jose Vietnamese Sandwich Shop
2. Saigon Sandwiches
3. Bun Mee
4. Dinosaurs
5. Lee's Sandwiches

I'll return if I'm walking down Fillmore with an angry, hungry stomach for sure... but ONLY if I'm walking down Fillmore with an angry, hungry stomach.
author: Mike N.

description: I had the grilled chicken salad which was well dressed and tried my friends combination banh mi which was decent. Its nice to see the open kitchen, but the place is pretty tiny. Not sure I'd go back because of all the other great options in the area, but it wasn't a bad experience.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon before I had to fly back to the OC.  Place is okay, I've had better viet food.  Go to the asian spots in san fran and you'll get better and cheaper viet food.  My group were the only asians in there, so that tells you lots haha.  But if you're walking around the cute shops on Fillmore then it's convenient to go here.  Salt and pepper fries were yummie, sandwich was eh, and my friend got a strawberry lychee drink.  I would come back for the strawberry lychee drink for sure!
author: Lizzie C.

description:
I like big bun mees and I cannot lie ...

I'd have to go with the Yelpers on this one.  This place gets a solid 3.5 stars.

The interior is nice and clean, with a cool decor and casual feel.  There are a handful of tables up front and a row of bar seating in the back where you can watch the food preparers hone their craft.

I had the 5 spice chicken sandwich and an order of tofu salad rolls.  The ingredients were fresh.  The sandwich tasted great, but like most bun places, the meat was a little scarce.  The tofu salad roll was better than expected.  I tried to order the regular salad roll (which has meat in it) but they were all out.  The peanut dipping sauce that came with the rolls was excellent.  It had a nice kick to it.  I was tempted to scoop out the remaining sauce and eat it straight.  It was that good.

Overall, a cool place to eat and moderately priced for what it is.  I recommend this place to anyone looking for a tasty sandwich at a reasonable price.
author: Grant W.

description:
I'm going to give this 3 stars for the neighborhood.  Fillmore needs a place like Bun Mee.  It's cute, modern, and stylish while maintaining it's super casual feel.

For two people, we ordered a 5 spice chicken sandwich, a roast pork sandwich, and a side of imperial rolls (total with tax: $19.11.  yikes!).  The roast pork was fine, but too delicately seasoned for banh mi.  The pickled carrots and hot peppers take over (didn't notice too much daikon in the veggie mix).  The 5 spice chicken had more flavor, but I thought it was more hot spicy than flavorful 5 spice-spicy (at a loss for words today).  Bread on both sandwiches was too soft for my liking.  The imperial rolls (2 per order) were fine, though small.  I would have liked a more traditional dipping sauce--theirs is very heavy on the lime, which didn't quite complement the meat filling.

I would eat here if I was really craving banh mi and didn't want to go into the Tenderloin for my favorite sandwich place (no, not Saigon).  However, I think it's too expensive for what it is for me to eat here regularly and feel good about it, and the sandwiches have too much bread and not enough meat.  I ended up pulling off pieces of bread and not eating it.  I guess this is good for meal portioning--I definitely don't feel too stuffed like I usually do with a whole sandwich!

Note: this is not a quick service place (though service is good!).  Make sure you drop a few quarters in your parking meter before you head in.
author: Diana C.

description:
Bun Mee has likely the widest variety of vietnamese inspired sandwiches you'll find in town.

Are they authentic? No. Are they more expensive? Yes.

Should you eat them on opposite day? Goodness no!

The restaurant rounds out the menu with salads and rice bowls that are also fresh and tasty. All of the food is prepared out in the open, so there's no mystery as to who or what is going into your meal. The seating back there is really the only spot free, as the place is often packed and seating is limited.

Both the lichee and iced coffee drinks are calorific and awesome.

To quote Kirk, "Bun mee up, Scotty."
author: Nik D.

description:
The delicious salad rolls come with a kick ass spicy peanut sauce. 

My b/f loves the pork belly sandwich and also said they do a great job with the grilled lemongrass pork sandwich.

Sweet potatoes fries are good if you eat them there, but they get super soggy if you get them to go

They deliver and I order from them once a week. I'd physically go to Bun Mee more, but I hate wading through all the hipsters on Fillmore just to get a salad roll.
author: Taylor C.

description: This review is just for their DRINK. The limeade and the lychee strawberry concoction mixed together is AMAZING! it has a great sweetness and sourness together. Best part is you get a giant lychee in your cup. Can definitely tell it's fresh because there were strawberry seeds swimming around. For $2.50 I'll be buying more in the future when I'm around. Didn't try the sandwiches yet, I'm a bit ambivalent since it costs more than what viet sandwiches should cost.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Eclectic, creative selection of Vietnamese sandwiches, with no dumbing down.  Fresh sliced peppers.  House mayo.  Yeah.  Tried the sloppy joe with fried egg -- sloppy joe meat made with a red curry.  Also tried the pork belly -- so fatty, like straight up creamy.  Yum.  Also tried the napa cabbage side salad -- this had good flavor, maybe would have been better Mandolin-sliced.  Yes, I am totally picky when it comes to anything Vietnamese.

We sat at the counter after a tired-looking mom claimed stake on the window seat.  I wasn't about to argue.  It was nice to watch the cooks assemble the sandwiches and salads anyhow.  You order at the counter and sit down with a number.

Great lunch for two under $20.
author: Linda N.

description: Sadly. I think they gone downhill since they first opened. I think they sandwiches were bigger and less expensive. I could be wrong but that is what it seems like. I was a big fan but not so much anymore. :(
author: Samantha Y.

description:
Bun Mee makes my currently favorite cookie - the chocolate with coconut creme (and I discovered it before 7x7 so I'm not biased).  5+ stars for the cookie.  

The rest, meh.  High quality ingredients, but less flavorful than, say, Saigon Sandwiches.  I also wish they had a tofu sandwich like Saigon... 
But not a bad alternative to real Vietnamese sandwiches, especially for Pac Heights.
author: seema s.

description: Great little Vietnamese place on Fillmore- wonderful to mix into the area. I really like their pork  sandwiches, especially the Bun Mee Combo. I've also had their Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl, very good and similar in quantity as the rice bowls at Pac Catch. Definitely get their fries! :)
author: Meredith M.

description:
My wife and I have now enjoyed both a lunch and dinner at this welcome addition to Fillmore Street.  I do very much like the location and then there's the rest of my review.

The food is quite good and I find their ingredients to be fresh, flavours to be plentiful and portions just about right.

The service is a bit erratic and that's quite possibly down to many customers served by too few wait staff.  Alternatively, the wait staff and cashier (don't forget the cashier, the person who takes your order, Jay D!), might simply be forgetful, not paying attention or too caught up in the whole scene to focus on their primary work objective:  make the customer happy. 

Having knocked elbows and scored a scarce table (ain't supply and demand a bitch?) we were presented with a takeaway package containing our dinner.  Instead of rectifying the mistake by taking the food away and properly plating it, our waiter apologized for the mistake and brought us plates and utensils to spruce up the inside picnic dinner we were about to eat.

At any rate, I do like the food served here and could only recommend that the front-of-house team do justice to those dedicated professionals working in the kitchen.

Until then, you might want to bring post-it notes and pen with which you can write reminders like, "We're taking our meal here; not in the park", "Might you go light on the cilantro, please?", etc., etc.
author: Jay D.

description: My office got catering from this place today. We got a variety of the bahn mee sandwiches and 4 different salads. I tried the five spice chicken salad and also the belly bahn mee and cobo bahn mee. plenty of flavor and decent portion of meat for each sandwich too. i like the salad that came with the five psice chicken salad too. I had this place bookmarked to try and now will def have to make a trip into the store too...
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
I had the Noodle Bowl with the 5 spice chicken takeout tonight. Although the individual ingredients were good and fresh, all together it just lacked... taste. I kept thinking "What's missing? I usually LOVE vermicelli bowls? What's going on?" and it finally hit me: although the chicken was tender (but borderline undercooked??) and good on it's own, it lacked the punch of taste required to bring it's brethren of less spiced brothers (vermicelli rice noodles and veggies) to the next level.

The crunchy spring roll that I ordered on the side was very tasty, but it was tiny.

I really want to like this place... I really do... and I think the last time I was here, it was good but I cannot honestly remember what I had... And for Vietnamese food it really is on the expensive side...

Maybe next time I'll try a sandwich.

p.s. Online ordering was very easy and convenient.
author: Shizu T.

description: i am totally obsessed with the crispy tofu bahn mi.  it is just super fresh and spicy and crispy and perfect.  also amazing sweet potato fries.  i miss working up the street.
author: kate s.

description:
3 stars because it's a terrific location and easy to pop in and out while you stroll Fillmore.

3 stars because the food is good, but not great.  I find myself thinking of other options when I am in the neighborhood.

I would return if I was passing by it and hungry and didn't want to think too hard about where to go.  I don't think I'd go out of my way to return.
author: Miranda O.

description: Strolled past and did a u-turn after spotting diners' awesome looking sweet potato fries and loaded sandwiches. Why on earth did I go for the Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl and consequently feel rather disappointed, you may wonder? Good question. I decided to be healthy, but healthy I should not have been. The rice bowl wasn't half as visually appetizing as the fries and sandwiches, and I didn't really dig the pickled veggies. The garlic rice was tasty- I'll be replicating it at home, that's for sure. My advice: stick to the fries and sandwiches..
author: Hannah C.

description: Decent sandwiches, definitely good enough to go back. Traditional bun mee with a tasty flair.
author: Dan L.

description: Super psyched there is tasty Vietnamese in the neighborhood. I have only eaten here once so far but plan on many return visits. The only thing I wasn't crazy about was that the corn on the cob tasted greasy, they coated it with something weird.
author: patrick b.

description: Below average sandwich & spring roll!   Way over priced.
author: David P.

description: Almost everything is delicious. I'm crazy for their fish and chips. The fish has a curry batter that goes well with the "chips" which are sweet potato fries.
author: patricia F.

description: Amazing sandwich spot on Fillmore. I love the sloppy bun with fried egg - seriously messy, but so delicious. The chicken sandwich is also pretty good - a little dry, so ask for the red curry mayo on the side to add a little more to it. And Bun Mee has the BEST sweet potato fries - so crispy!
author: Kimberly S.

description: We stopped by this place in a whim on our way to the airport and I was sorely disappointed by their sandwiches. I'm not sure if SF has great banh mis, but these paled in comparison to the ones I've tried on the east coast! The girl who took our order wasn't the friendliest either - she seemed so blasé, and those things really bother me when I'm ordering food or at a restaurant (seriously, service is so, so important). Nonetheless, their food was forgettable - definitely won't be coming back for a banh mi fix!
author: Stella Y.

description:
My friend and I went there for lunch today around 1pm- it was crowded but we were still able to grab a table for 2 right away.

I got the 5 spice chicken and he got the grilled pork. Either Bun Mee had read all the bad reviews below or we just got lucky, but both of us commented on how much meat was in each of the sandwich!!! If you were to look at a cross section, it was 3/4 meat with 1/4 bread! I got the papaya noodle salad as a side and he got the mango. They were both very fresh and tasty!

I also ordered an order of spring rolls. The skin was super soft and the fillings were super fresh, I loved it (although they were expensive if you were to compare them with the ones in the regular vietnamese restaurants) 

Will definitely come back again and try some of the other dishes!
author: Jessica L.

description: This place is for the individual that doesn't want to venture out into Little Saigon or a Vietnamese restaurant for Banh Mi. I had the Juicy Steak sandwich with Garlic Fries and did enjoy the quality of the steak but was disappointed to see my little sandwich. I prefer to get my Banh Mi elsewhere as it's not hard to find a Vietnamese restaurant in the city. If I have to come back I'll have to try their bowls cuz those look tasty.
author: Catalina C.

description:
The scenario plays out like this: 

Why on Venus did I not just stop off in Little Saigon to pick up a banh mi before heading home? Or, why on Venus did I not just catch the 1 down to Little Saigon and grab a banh mi? These are the questions I asked myself when I was living in the neighborhood and I ended up here. This is the sort of place that I typically avoid because a great banh mi is $3, and here they're $7 because of the location and it's a new space -- not a Viet hole in the wall. But, fiendish and in need of a quick bite, I caved and, yes, it's okay, good at moments within the extra pate & the garlic fries tossed in jalapenos... And, the Vietnamese Iced Coffee is as traditional as it gets. I just can't get around that price for what should be $3.50. I am glad I moved  out of the nabe though because I could easily see myself feeling guilty for ending up here more often than I really should because I choose any style of banh mi over most things on our little planet.
author: Jon A.

description:
Read of 7x7 that they have a pretty good tasting cookie.

Got the "Coconut Chocolate" cookie $1.50. Interesting twist of chocolate and coconut.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Trying to be Vietnamese but just missing the boat entirely. I wish this restaurant focused more on authentic flavored instead of appearances... Food first then the rest will come naturally. Big miss, go to clement street for great Vietnamese food!
author: SF Y.

description:
I had lunch at Bun Mee today. What a great new addition to the Fillmore!
The place is great. Love the decor, the place is welcoming and cool looking. They have  this really fun lamps made of bike wheels and things like that.
The best part? the food!
I had a their pork belly sandwich and it was yuuuummmyy! The pork belly was really well made, loved the ingredients like the cucumber and the jalapeno peppers...and the toasty fresh bread!

Prices were also a pleasant surprise...really good value for what I paid for. Finally a place that is not asking for 10-12 bucks for a sandwich!

Ohhh and the sweet potato fries were great. They have this really good kid of lime/pepper sauce that comes with it, so good I wanted to finish it all.

This will be one of my favorite spots for sure! So glad Bun Mee opened so close to my place.
author: Gimena P.

description: I love the bun mee noodle bowl and almost always get it was the crispy spring roll on top. The space is small, and fillmore is esp crowded on weekends, but usually we're pretty lucky about getting a good table. I like sitting by the door and people watching.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Bun Mee is a nice addition to the neighborhood.  No, it's not as inexpensive as the bun mei (sp?) in the Tenderloin.  Hey, it's on Fillmore Street in Pac Heights and a good deal all things considered.   The decor is comfortable--I sat at the counter.  It's a small space with a counter and 3-4 tables for 2--not a place for a big group to eat--but kid friendly.  It's always busy, but noise hasn't been a problem.

Foodwise, it's limited.  What's offered is very fresh, appealingly presented, and good.  The bread is fresh and warm, the fillings hearty and tasty, nice fresh veggies, lots of sweet potato fries, and good keffir limeade.  A beer and wine license is in the works.  The $13.00 price was about average for the area and you can go cheaper.

I'll go back often.  You could have a really good, inexpensive lunch of the Imperial Rolls and and another side for $6.00.
author: Julia C.

description:
I went here once soon after it opened, and while I remember it being good at the time, I haven't returned since that first trip. 

Now that I just moved to Pac Heights, I'll have to give it another try to see if it's more memorable the second go-around.
author: Kathleen H.

description: I absolutely LOVE Bun Mee! I had never tried Vietnamese sandwiches before (I've been wanting to for a while since I had seen a couple of places around town with them) and once I tried the "Combo Sandwich" I was hooked! I've tired other sandwiches on the menu and they are just as good! My favorite thing is that they add freshly cut jalapenos! Yum! OH, but what really made me comeback was their sweet potato fries! They're delicious! They pair it with some sauce, I'm not sure what it 's called, but it makes it even better! They do offer salad bowls, which I've seen many other people eat but I have not had the chance to try one of those. Hopefully in my next visit. Other wise, it's a great place to have a happy, satisfying lunch.
author: Romy S.

description: The crispy tofu sandwich from Bun Mee is delicious, as is the chicken version.  The various bowls are also tasty, but I think the thing to get is one of the sandwiches.  Don't skip the sweet potato fries with dipping sauce.  The fruit drinks are also worth trying, and so is the chocolate cookie.  Bun Mee is delicious, economical, and one of my favorite spots.  Worth a visit.
author: Lucullus L.

description: Not really impressed. My sister and I wanted to love this place but it's just not very flavorful. In a city like SF that has dumplings and bao on every street corner, I was a bit surprised that it wasn't a bit more authentic. Food was decent, flavors all sounds good but it was just kinda average.
author: Marissa P.

description: I dine at Bun Mee about once a month because they are convenient to my home when a quick dinner is needed.  My usual order is the Chicken Sandwich and Sweet Potato Fries with Curry Dipping Sauce or the Mekong Salad.  The food is OK.  You just order at the counter, take a seat and they bring the food.  Or, you can take out.
author: Donna P.

description: I'll try it again because it is close to work but I have to say I was disappointed in the meal. I had the eggplant sandwich and it was too garlicky. The sweet potato fries were good. I guess I'm put off by the prices and the long wait. But I have to remember it is in Fillmore.
author: Lhm M.

description:
We've been here twice now and I think that I would rate this more of a 3.5 than 4 but I'm too happy to have a banh mi option in the neighborhood.  

The first time we ate here we had 2 roast pork bun mee sandwiches and the sweet potato fries.  Everything was delicious.  The consistency of the bun was so perfect and the fresh veggies were amazing.  The meat had great flavor as well.  My only complain is that it wasn't very spicy even though there was a decent amount of jalapenos in it.  The sweet potato fries were amazing and the aioli-like sauce served with them was the perfect pairing. 

The second time we went there I had the Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl and the bf had Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish.  They were out of prawns so that was the first let down.  The second was the dish in its entirety.  It had some good flavors but just fell flat.  The bf on the other hand was extremely pleased with the Crispy Catfish and said that he would definitely order it again. 

Long story short, the good definitely outweighs the bad and we will 100% be going back to Bun Mee!!
author: Danielle R.

description: We came to Pacific Heights to eat somewhere else and the wait was crazy so we followed the smell to Bun Mee and it was delicious.  I hardly ever eat Vietnamese sandwiches so I don't have much to compare to, but wow, my grilled pork one was yummy.  Husband ordered the pork belly sandwich and was freaking out it was so good he kept repeating that he was going to order another one.  Well by the time we got our food, the line went out the door so he didn't want to wait.  There are other items on the menu besides sandwiches and would definitely come back to try more when we are in town again.
author: Mei-I F.

description: Really enjoyed my smoky eggplant sandwich! Jalapeños added just the right amount of spice and the bread tasted nice and fresh. Great for a quick informal lunch.
author: Amy T.

description:
I came across this place for lunch with friends and wasn't too sure how it would be but was pleasantly surprised. I ordered the roasted pork sandwich and side of salt and pepper fries. At first look I was hesitant (I like simple and less is more works best for me) but it was DELICIOUS and the sandwich was big for me so I brought it home for my boyfriend to finish off and he instantly said he wanted to go to this place!

Small dining area but we ate at the counter and it was nice. I'd go back when I'm in the area. :)
author: Sara M.

description: Overpriced-- but to be expected- you're paying for Lower Pac Heights Fillmore prices. When this place opened last year, it was teaming with hipsters but it's much safer now. As for the food, the 5 spice chicken is good but that's about it. You can probably get the same sandwich in the tenderloin for $4 less but you'll have to play a game of "is it human or is it animal" on your way there.
author: Ernie C.

description: I wish I'd actually tried this place years ago; I live right up the street and I don't know why I never dropped in before. I'm in love with their shrimp salad and sweet potato fries. Sometimes the staff gets a little flustered when it's busy, but they're usually helpful and friendly. Overall I really like this spot and come here way too often, haha.
author: Matthew J M.

description: Great sandwich and fabulous sweet potato fries with an amazing aioli. I got the steak version of the bahn mi and I really liked it. I loved the sauces and flavor. Pretty reasonable prices too!
author: Madeline S.

description: I love this place. California style Vietnamese sandwiches, delicious mouth watering pickled veg, always so tasty, and you don't feel like you have to eat some kind of mystery meat. Just what I want & crave. Great quality. Staff is charming and hard working, they will take great care of you. Best to carry out and enjoy slowly.
author: Chelse B.

description: I want to love this place because I love Vietnamese food. But, I've gone twice and ordered two different dishes, and both were subpar. I ordered the fried catfish sandwich one time and the noodle bowl the other. The noodle bowl lacked flavor and the fried catfish sandwich was very hard (literally... difficult to bite through).  I hope people have better luck!
author: Amy L.

description: Definitely not authentic, but that doesn't mean it's not delicious! They didn't have many vegetarian options (one sandwich and one bowl, I believe). The fries with the jalapeno were tasty. Even though there are only so many things I can eat, I'm sure I will be back.
author: Katie L.

description:
First, you'll be hardpressed to find a $3 vietnamese sandwich ANYWHERE in SF, even in the tenderloin.  Those places that USED to sell $2-$3 sandwiches are now selling them for $5.  Just like Pho, I hear people say all the time that Pho should be $5.  Unless you're in Orange County where Pho is $5 for a bowl that is half msg and half water, $5 pho is a thing of the 90s.

That being said, paying $7 for a sandwich did not seem unfair to me.  The sandwich was "ok".  I could probably eat a few and still not be full.  I got the five spiced chicken.  The limeade was far too sweet for me that  I couldn't finish it..

It took awhile to fulfill my order (15 minutes for one sandwich), and there did not seem to be much of a backlog as there was no line and I walked straight up to the cashier.  However, the cookline was working as fast as they could so it wasn't an effort issue thats for sure.

The decor is nice, and the staff friendly.
author: Nam H.

description: Tried this place for the first time with a group of friends- great bun mee (tried the lemongrass pork, chicken, and the combo). We enjoyed everything abotu this place- the beer (Tiger was my favorite), bun me, and tofu spring rolls. I only wish is wasn't $7-$8 for a Vietnamese sandwich. Will defiantly be back when I want to spend $10 for a sandwich and drink.
author: Wendy J.

description: This is very good Vietnamese street food fare!  My kids love this place and always request to come back.  My daughter loves the tofu sandwich; my son orders the pork sandwich; and I get the catfish sandwich.  We then share the sweet potato fries!  Food is fresh and phenomenal!
author: Alan H.

description: LOVE the friend tofu bahn mi! This is my favorite spot for a quick, cheap lunch. Also a big fan of the sweet potato fries, strawberry lychee lemonade & the thai iced coffee (the latter is perfect for warding off food coma after consuming the said bahn mi :-)
author: Liya R.

description:
My hubby and I decided to grab an early dinner before seeing a play at a local theatre, and wanted to check out this place based on all the buzz it received.  In one word - overrated. I'll get to the food review in a sec (it was ok) but I have to rant first. The thing that HORRIFIED me was when I saw the cashier go and clean up a table after some patrons left - he wiped the table down with a rag while dusting all of the crumbs and food bits from the table onto the FLOOR.  Who does that??!  Would you do that at home?  If so, I don't care, but brushing stuff onto the floor at a restaurant is unsanitary and gross.  Note to management - please train your staff.  You're running a restaurant, not a barn.

Ok, for the food. Since I'm a vegetarian, my options were a bit limited. I decided on the Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl (with tofu over brown rice) and the hubby had Salad Rolls and the Belly Bun. I was a bit surprised at my bowl - it was almost all rice, with a tiny bit of the cabbage salad (which was really tasty), and about 12 daikon sprouts. The rice was slightly undercooked and dry.  The tofu was nicely grilled but a bit chewy.  

My suggestions to improve this dish - modify the ratio of ingredients that go in the bowl.  There must have been over 2 cups of rice in that bowl, and it could benefit from a bigger portion of salad, less rice.  If you prefer to cook your rice to a very dry state, that's fine, but it needs a bit more salad.  While the slabs of grilled tofu were good, either bring a knife to the table in order to cut the tofu (I ended up picking up the slabs with chopsticks and attempted to delicately nibble at it), or dice up the tofu before serving so it can be mixed in with the rest of the stuff in the bowl.
