Peanut sauce was ok - the overall flavors (creamy peanut sauce, tangy dressing from the salad, pickled shallots) combined well, but everything was dulled by the massive amount of hard, chewy rice.  

The hubby said his rolls were "ok" and compared them to the fresh rolls at Zadin - nowhere near as good as Zadin (no one does those better!).  His sandwich was also ok - he's willing to go back there and try another sandwich, but he'll have to go by himself because I don't think I need to go back.
author: Usha M.

description:
i really wanted pho, but i was my friend who is vegetarian, so bun mee was a good compromise.  i didn't bother ordering anything too asian for fear of being disappointed.  i ended up getting the mekong shrimp salad, which came w/ avocado, mango and blood orange vinaigrette.  it was actually quite delicious.  

prices here are definitely high for "vietnamese" food, but it's a lot fresher and cleaner than more authentic places.
author: Helen T.

description:
1 - combo
1 - tofu rolls (they were SO good)
1 - egg rolls (as if I didn't need any more meat)
1 of those cute lil' coconut cream cookies.


Delicious fillings - but really cheap bread. That's really the only way these sandwiches could improve. The rolls were great, lovely sauces. A bit expensive for the portion/cost ratio, but whatever, it's the Fillmore.

EDIT - stupid delivery boy, not their fault (they subcontract delivery). Great response time on my concerns, though - go Bun Mee!
author: Neko M.

description:
Bun Mee is a great neighborhood eatery.  I'm actually jealous that it is not in my neighborhood but thankfully Pac Heights isn't too far away.

Bun Mee takes an old standard, the Vietnamese sandwich, and does it well.  On my first visit I was able to try two of their sandwiches.  I ordered the sardine sandwich (after seriously considering the pork belly sandwich for a good five minutes) and my fiance ordered the roast pork sandwich.  Both were good but I would have to say that the roast pork was better than the sardine.  The sardine sandwich could have had more flavor, I actually added hot sauce to mine, and could have been served warmer.  By comparison, the roast pork was juicy and tender and full of flavor.  

Bun Mee's bread was beautifully toasted and very soft.  Unfortunately, it was a bit cold by the time my sandwich was served to me.  The pickled radish and fresh chili contained within both sandwiches was delectable.

We paired both sandwiches with a side of sweet potato fries served with Bun Mee's house made aioli.  The fries were perfectly fried and the aioli had great flavor.  

I washed all of this down with a glass of house made kaffir limeade which was excellent and achieved a perfect harmony between tart and sweet.   

I'm looking forward to my return visit to Bun Mee and their Pork Belly sandwich.  [I've returned to Bun Mee and had their Pork Belly sandwich and it was good - much better than the sardine sandwich.]
author: Oski B.

description:
Oh mee, oh my, Bun Mee makes a good sandwich! 

The blend of textures in the Bun Mee Combo is just delightful - pork, pate, and mortadella, all served on a toasty bun.  The sweet potato fries are perfectly spiced and perfectly crispy.  And the Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl was a big hit at the table.  I only wish they had more seating!
author: Kristin M.

description: I get the chicken salad and the veggie spring rolls and they are yummy, though I think $10 for the salad is a little much when the Bun Mee costs ~$6.50-$7 each.
author: Clara N.

description: Yeah I'm not so sure I will be coming back.  We got a blackboard eat code which is good for sandwich, side salad and beer.  They did not allow us to order the steak sandwich and could only order two of the salads.  We asked if we could get fries which when paired with a sandwich costs the same as a salad but no.  Anyway we ordered the cat fish sandwich and the belly bun sandwich.  More bun than ingredients in the sandwich is why I won't be back.  It's pricey which is understandable because it's on Fillmore but I felt like I was eating mostly bun.
author: Pierre L.

description:
I was very excited to see this cafe pop up in my neighborhood. But after giving it a few tries, I think overall it's not worth it. The sammies are tasty (esp the classic pork and the 5 spice) but they are double to triple the price of what you'd expect to pay for a viet sammie. And, the bread is not fresh or crisp enough.
     Based on someone else's review, I gave Mama's crispy rolls a try the last time. F-. Soggy oily skin, oily fat quality pork, minimal veggies inside. I was really surprised by how badly they managed a fried pork roll.
author: Beverly C.

description: Love these sandwiches! Especially the lemon grass pork. Perfect for to-go lunch and also for a two person casual meal at the counter or in the sun on the street.
author: Daniel D.

description: Not authentic at all. Sandwiches were not even warm or toasted. It tastes very Americanized. For half the price, I could have gotten an AUTHENTIC Vietnamese Sandwich on Irving street in the Inner Sunset that will actually taste good. What a waste of money and my lunch!
author: Liz C.

description:
OK so this is for the Belly Bun.

This thing is juicy met in your moth goodness.  I am a fan.  I am not a fan of the $7 price point.  Bun Mee sandwiches are all but $2 in San Jose and $3-$4 all Lee's and $3 on clement.    

However the price point does fit the bloated price points of the area.  Thank you Upper Fillmore yuppies!
author: Spanky M.

description:
First off, I rarely feel compelled to write a review, but I really had to say something because someone just mentioned this place to me recently. I am Vietnamese and grew up eating good banh mi sandwiches in San Jose, so I was a little hesitant to try this place, but I try to keep an open mind. Unfortunately, I definitely would NOT recommend this place. It's got a good location and is nice and cutesy with the name and all, but  that's about it. 

The service was terrible. I just stood there, a foot away at the counter, watching these two people at the register flirt with one another for who  knows how long, before anyone bothered to turn to me and ask if I could be helped. 

I got the 5-spice chicken sandwich, and it was such a disappointment. The food is just too flavorless and bland. You don't do chicken breast, you need to do chicken thighs and where's the nuoc mam? The pickled veggies need to taste like they have been actually pickled. It was a terrible and tiny sandwich for $7. 

Save your money, and head over to Saigon Sandwiches where the ladies don't have you stand around and wait, where you can get 2 sandwiches for the price of this overpriced one, and the sandwiches are as good as what you can get in San Jose (where really good Vietnamese food is).
author: Debbie A.

description: Loved the sandwiches first, then discovered the carmel citrus rice bowl and the salad and this has become my go to lunch spot for delicious food, comfortable atmosphere, quick service, and a price that can justify visits on a regular basis.
author: Jason S.

description: Tasty!   Pork sandwich was great with egg!!....my gal had the bowl with chicken, very tasty....prices are great for City!......
author: chris p.

description: Great "westernized" Vietnamese Noodle, Sandwich Shop.  Food is fresh, flavorfull & prices are right.  We went there a Friday night and all 4 of us ate for $50 with drinks, the food was great and staff friendly. The restaurant is rather small so I noticed a lot of guests do take out which I would too if we lived in that area.
author: Beth P.

description: I love Bun Mee. It's quick, fresh & delicious.
author: Samuel H.

description: Hyped up by those who haven't tasted better:  turn to Cafe Bunn Mi on Clement instead.
author: Koalie W.

description:
Bun Mee is quite new so there is some confusion up front when you order. They will get that fixed.  They also need to work on the sandwiches a bit.

I got the Bun Mee Combo described as roasted pork, pate, mortadella, garlic aioli, onions, pickled carrots, daikon, cucumber, jalapenos and cilantro. I'm pretty sure it was all there but I couldn't pick up on the roasted pork or mortadella.  The pate was tasty and so were the veggies.  The bread was good.  But in honesty, there wasn't enough between the bread for the price.  That and the fact that tastes were either not evidenced or not balanced in the sandwich account for my feeling that Bun Mee is just average (for now and for me).
author: David D.

description:
I would have given this place 5 stars, because the food is awesome! BUT...I gave 3 stars because the customer service was way below par. I was making a large order for a staff meeting, so I called the day before to place the order, so that the restaurant could prepare. I was told by the man who answered the phone that I would need to call back at 10am the next day to order. I asked if the delivery fee could be waived since it was a large order and our office is 2 blocks away, and he said no. 
So, I called at 10am the next day to place the order (which I was planning to pick up at 11am) and was told by the frustrated sounding woman that they are not open yet and I would need to call back at 10:30am when they are open. I told her I just wanted to place the order to make sure the food would be ready in time, and she again refused and told me to call back at 10:30. 
I called back at 10:30am and placed my order and it was ready at the time I went to pick it up, but it was quite a hassle just to pre-order!
author: Jillian A.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and really wanted to like this place. I'm so bummed the service and attitude of the staff is rude they could care less about your experience.. Given that its a neighborhood place I thought they would be friendlier and want to provide a good experience forbid you ask for any changes to your order or questions about the menu....you will get a big eye ball roll. Even the guy handing the take away is rude and moody!

 Oh well there is OUT THE DOOR around the corner and they are always friendly and food is consistent.
author: Wendi Y.

description: Exactly: meh i've experienced better! if you want real good vietnamese sandwiches, go to  Little Vietnam Cafe, I'll guarantee you'll find the best vietnamese sandwiches in town!
author: David L.

description: Tasty food, in a great area on Fillmore.  Sweet potatoe fries with aioli dip is great, although it's not really Vietnamese at all.  The price is a little more than I would expect for what you get, but the food is fresh, and generally is healthy.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Would have given 2 1/2 stars if it were an option. Saigon rice bowl with pork.  Pork was dried out and one had the sense it was precooked.  Not "precooked" before it came to the table but precooked a couple of days ago. Parsley garnished looked a little tired.  Flavors good, ample portion.

But do you REALLY want to eat at an establishment that scores a 79 [score displayed at Bun Mee on June 9, 2013] from the SF Health Department, whose website says of this score: "71-85: Needs improvement.  Multiple violations observed. Typically, several high-risk violations."

Won't return.
author: J F.

description:
Food here is excellent, but the service is poor.

Yesterday, I walked in and approached the male cashier.  "How are you?" I said cheerfully.  "I'll be right with you," was the response.  I was the only one in line and they weren't busy.  Strike one.

The salads have an option of chicken, beef, or pork.  I like the ingredients in the "grilled chicken salad," so I requested that salad but with pork.  Minutes later, the manager-looking type guy brought me a pork sandwich, which I refused because I didn't order that.  He looked at me like I didn't know what I wanted to eat.  Sorry, I haven't eaten bread in three years for dietary reasons, so there's no way I would have ordered a pork sandwich.

"But there is no pork salad!"  he said.  Strike two.  Then I told him why would there be an option for other meats on the salads if I couldn't get a grilled pork salad?  Is the lettuce pre-mixed with chicken only?  

I went back to the female cashier to pay for the price difference between salad and sandwich.  I apologized for any confusion, and she looked at me like I was a major pain in the ass.  Then I looked over at the manager and the chefs, who were glaring at me like I had killed each of their first borns!  Strike three!  

Although the salad was pretty good, you can get good Vietnamese salads and sandwiches at numerous restaurants in the city at a fraction of the price and with WAY better service.  I think this place caters to the snooty FIllmore crowd that wants Vietnamese food from time to time, as it is the only Vietnamese place in that neighborhood.  

In my humble opinion, bad service always trumps good food.  I will not be returning to Bun Mee.
author: M G.

description: Worst bánh mì I've ever eaten. Not much pork, and what was there was mostly fat and gristle. I have a pretty high tolerance for low grade meat (and even enjoy a fair amount of fat) but each bite contained something I refused to eat. General sandwich composition was imbalanced, with half of my pork bahn mi containing almost no meat whatsoever. I've had far better sandwiches from south bay strip malls.
author: Kris H.

description: Looking for somewhere reasonable and delish after purchasing 2 movie tickets for $30 on Friday night. Bun Mee looked worth a shot, but it was exactly as I suspected. Flat and not cheap enough for what you get. It's one of those places that is very average, which always leaves me feeling that I should have spent double the money for something *really* tasty. It's just not cheap enough to have a feel good meal, and the kitchen does nothing out of the ordinary for your taste buds. But alas, on fillmore street the restaurants pretty much have you by the balls. I've yet to be satisfied on the cheap there. Save your money and eat up at Out the Door, SPQR or the like.
author: Maria R.

description: It's gotten better from when they opened to now but still not that good. Kinda mediocre. The sandwiches are better than the salads. The fries are bad. Sauces are mostly indistinguishable. Staff has gotten a bit friendlier but still not very nice.
author: A J.

description: Fresh, healthy, quick. I'm not a connoisseur of Asian food so I can't speak to its authenticity, but I would definitely go back. Loved the sweet potato fries with the aioli!
author: Heather K.

description: This was my first time at Bun Mee and I loved it! I ate all of my sandwich and was full, but not too full. I ordered the sloppy bun and was worried that it might not be enough food and I should have ordered a side as well. But, it was the perfect amount of food and the sandwich was delicious. I also didn't feel terribly gross and greasy after eating, which is a compliment for a 'sloppy' sandwich. If I am in the neighborhood again, I will definitely visit bun mee.
author: Alycia N.

description:
One of my favorite sandwich places in SF!  All the sandwiches are delicious, perfectly cooked meat and well balanced toppings.  The entrees are always very tasty too.

Don't try to eat in on a busy weekend though, it's super small and gets very busy!
author: Erica E.

description:
This place seems to be trying to bring Vietnamese sandwiches into the hipster/food truck age. I went with a fairly standard BBQ Pork sandwich (they call it Grilled Pork). I'm not sure if I just got a bad sandwich, but it was a pretty horrible experience. The pork was like chewing rubber. I could not tear it, even when I went savage style and yanked on it with my hands while holding the other end with my teeth. Eventually I had to hock it into the trash can like a fat loogie. My girlfriend was horrified.

Her sandwich was a bit better (Sloppy Bun). It basically tasted like a sloppy joe. Kind of freaky, but overall, not bad.

I've been eating Vietnamese sandwiches since I was a kid. I guess you can say I've been spoiled by paying $1.50-$3.00 (and more recently, ~$4) for a tasty sandwich (that I am able to chew on). This place was about $6 each. $6 for a sandwich where I couldn't eat the meat = a bad deal, imo.
author: Rick L.

description: I enjoy Bun Mee. If you're looking for a healthy meal that's fast & convenient, I'd recommend this restaurant. It's also great for take-out. The staff is friendly and helpful.
author: Lindsay M.

description: The lemongrass pork sandwich was excellent.  The sloppy joe was OK.  Ordered delivery and would order again.  The grilled chicken salad was fresh and tasty?
author: Greg B.

description:
I would give bun mee a "no star" rating if I could. They are polluting the air and environment with their nasty clouds of smoke that billow from the roof and onto the public below. I live on the block and I can't even keep my window open because that smoke will stain my walls and it physically makes me sick. 
  Bun mee I hope you will do something about this like get a FILTER PLEASE!!!!
author: Trump D.

description: Sometimes a hit, sometimes a miss. Ate here many many times however not so much lately. Sandwiches can be tasty however almost meatless at times & and always way too much cilantro . Rice bowls are quite tasty but too many jalapeños and lately most of the dishes have been inconsistently prepared. Overall typical of so many boutique cafes and restaurants, not enough quality control by the owners after initial start up. Staff is very friendly and service is fast. Always looking for alternatives now since we live in the neighborhood and have tired with inconsistency.
author: Kent L.

description:
After Bun Mee posted a sign a few weeks ago saying they were closed due to a RAT PROBLEM in the attic, I'll never go there again.  Although I commend their honesty, I won't be able to get past the rat issue-ever.  Why would anyone admit that?! The sandwiches and salads only ever were mediocre and not very flavorful at that.

In addition, I witnessed upon a few occasions the staff nibbling from the prep station and running their fingers through their hair, (another review mentioned hair in their sandwiches, here's the reason!), without washing their hands immediately.  

For that instant Vietnamese craving, I'll walk up and around the corner to Out the Door instead-they never disappoint and it's clean.
author: J.Q. M.

description: I have to admit that Bun Mee makes pretty good sandwiches because they use better quality ingredients, which is the difference between some Vietnamese restaurants. I would not recommend the spring rolls, which was a bit pricy. I also ordered the coconut creme cookies, which was good.
author: Rosanna T.

description:
I made a promise to try every sandwich on the menu. I haven't done that yet but I did come here once a week for a month so I have eaten most of them. The sandwiches are great, not the best in the city but worth return trips and nothing had been bad.

If you come here expecting a sandwich that you can find in the Tenderloin or at mom and pop Vietnamese shops you will be disappointed. This place is not aiming for that. Being situated in Upper Fillmore they must cater to the neighborhood and have prices to cover the cost of rent. Yes, you will pay more for a sandwich but the space is very clean and the food tastes fresh.
author: Brandon P.

description:
snadwiches yes
noodle dishes and salads no
cookies YES!
it takes them a while to get the hang of "no cilantro"
author: Lily K.

description:
Oh goodness, where should I even start? 
First of all, I go to Bun Mee expecting nothing less of perfection. I mean, it was in the San Francisco examiner! And plus, that photoshoot on the facebook? Made everything look way tasty, so of course, I come walking in with HIGH HIGH expectations.

I walk in and the place is small and it kind of smells, mixed with the delicious smell of the grill and possibly body odor? Anyways, I'm glancing at the nice menu and I see flies. FLIES!? Really? I thought this was suppose to be the Fillmore, it's suppose to be clean. And apparently this place is suppose to be classy? That's gross.

The people behind the counter looked bored out of their mind. I felt like I was bothering them if anything. The very tall man did not smile once I was ordering, so I felt uncomfortable even being around him. I wanted to get out of there, so I grabbed my number and just escaped. But alas, I look around and there are no available tables. I literally had to wait 5 minutes for someone to realize that there wasn't any room for me to sit. So, I found a spot on the counter. I squeezed between two couples that didn't leave any room to breathe, great!

I discovered that I was behind all the action of the making of my sandwich that sort of got me excited again. So as I waited, I watched. To my surprise, they weren't being as urgent as it's said to be. I thought this was suppose to be a fast pace restaurant? I guess not. 

The guy on the grill took his sweet time taking out whatever meat it was to the grill and kept on talking to the people in the back. The girl on the line seemed to be in a bad mood. And another tall man was looking at everyone at the counter with nasty looks. I didn't feel pleasant at all and regretted sitting at the counter immediately. Suddenly, another man came from the back and started yelling out names and orders... this didn't go well with the loud music that didn't fit the persona of "Bun Mee".

I got my grilled pork. And what do I find? It's cold. Really? I waited 20 minutes for a cold sandwich. The worst part, everyone in the place was talking so i Don't dare to intrude in their conversation. So what do I do? Ask for a bag and leave. 

Not once did I see anyone wash their hands. Not once did I see someone smile. Not once did I feel welcomed.

Who wants that? Don't ever come back. This place will not suffice your hunger or what you thought it would be. This place brings false hope.

Where was the owner? Aren't they suppose to be taking care of all of this sh*t so it won't happen?

I felt bad for the flies, if anything they were trapped in the hell hole.

Don't try it, I'm sure you'll find way better ones in the Tenderloin, yeah I went that low.

THUMBS DOWN ALL THE WAY.
author: Tina N.

description:
Ben Mee is a sandwich and salad place. And it does that with a lot of fresh flavors.
My favorite is the grilled chicken salad, which is some of the best grilled chicken salad I have had in the city. The flavors of some of the other dishes remind me of Vietnam.
author: Susan C.

description: Had to try this place because of their mention in the Yelp article about pork belly. So I got the crispy duck and the pork belly sandwiches. Nothing out of the ordinary compared to other Vietnamese sandwiches I've had. A little bit of a wait too, but the decor and location is nice and nostalgic.
author: Alvin P.

description:
If you are expecting a traditional Vietnamese sandwich ( like one from the famous lee's sandwich, east san jose or little Saigon in oc) you will be very disappointed like I was w bun mee. 
It's probably good enough for the trendiness of Fillmore but leave expectations for a $4 tasty sandwich at the door. 

Had the combination sandwich and a side of mango salad. Bread was on the dry side, minimal pate, radish and carrot poorly seasoned. Salad was a bit of cabbage w a few sparse mangoes and a light citrus vinagrette. 
Had a sip of the Vietnamese iced coffee-- a bit too sweet for my taste. 
All in all, if you've had your share of authentic banh mi, skip bun mee.
author: Alexa L.

description: Bun Mee creates a nice twists on the traditional Vietnamese Ban Mi sandwiches made with Toasted French bread, carrots, cucumbers, Daikon raddish, cilantro and a choice of meat.  The variety of sandwich choices at Bun Mee all looked good and toughest part of my first visit was making a choice.   I decided to go with the fried catfish with egg and took my seat at the bar.  The sandwich was good and left me wanting more.  Will have to visit again and try other menu items to make me a fan.
author: Carlos V.

description:
Its pretty obvious from the location of Bun Mee in lower pac heights ... in the midst of bougie central that it is NOT going to be your 100% traditional vietnamese cuisine. I'm pretty sure that was the point. 

That being said, it is a solid establishment with several pros and cons. 
I liked the sandwhich I got which was the combo. I also tried the pork belly sandwhich was very good as well. The bread they use for the bahn mi is very large and crusty --- just how i like my bread to be. I give it props for not digging into my palate like most breads do. I was a little bit underwhelmed by the spread on the sandwhich. I'm used to them putting that thick buttery creamy stuff on it. There seemed to be a little bit of dead space in the sandwhich, which I guess is pretty common for a banh mi, but maybe it was just because the bread they use is so large that they don't have enough to fill it with. 
I also tried their imperial rolls which were very good! Packed full of meat and served with lettuce, mint, pickled carrots and dipping sauce. The dipping sauce didn't taste like the normal fish sauce... a little off, but still good. I thought the imperal rolls were better than ones you'd find at your nomal vietnamese pho restuarants. 

Let's be real here, this place is a pretty big hit with the non-asian folk. I found myself in a sea of non-asians for the first time in .... i dont even know when. I love the idea of this place --- trying to modernize a seemingly vietnamese dish. But I'm torn... as an Asian, I still feel like I can get a better and cheaper sandwhich at many spots in the city (although you may compromise the cleanliness, but that's a different story...) . I give it 3 stars because the taste was pretty good, but more can be done to improve the sandwhiches.
author: Tim B.

description: Bread. Bread. Bread. A crisp crunchy first bite gives way to a chewy interior that houses thoughtful flavor combinations. My favorite is the D-licious catfish sandwich! Smoky eggplant sandwich is also yum. Sweet potato fries are a must. My hubs always gets the coconut creme cookie, too. Last time we were there, they had lychee strawberry juice! Cute interior design touches, too.
author: Daphne J.

description:
I rarely review things, but felt the need to defend this place.

Yes, it's expensive compared to banh mi places in the TL. But that Bun Mee isn't in the TL is precisely why it's more expensive, and that's ok. Rent can't be cheap on Fillmore, and it's convenient when you're on Fillmore and want Vietnamese. It'd be completely inconvenient to hop on Muni and go to the Loin just to keep it real.  

I've had the grilled pork banh mi a few times and thought it was great every time.. the ingredients are quality. My wife gets the noodle bowls and loves them, and the iced coffees are fantastic.

Definitely worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood and want something new.
author: Brad R.

description: Crowded, popular, and they know it.  They try to get you in and out as fast as they can, but it does help.  Had the veggie sandwich, iced coffee, which were exactly what I expected - fresh, well-done.  Really can't complain.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Let me start by saying I really wanted to like this place.  I went in fully understanding that there is no way this sandwich could be good enough to justify the price vs. Saigon (which is my go-to for bahn mi).  But even still, I left feeling underwhelmed.

I had the sloppy bun w/ fried egg and a side of sweet potato fries.   Flavor was pretty good, but portion was really small.  The roll was barely half full of meat so I had quite a few "bread-only" bites and the side of fries was pathetic.  I counted no more than TEN fries on my plate - for $3 you have to be kidding me!

Total tab came to around $12 and I left kinda pissed off knowing I could've fed myself and 3 friends for that price @ Saigon.

Luckily for Bun Mee, there are enough clueless people in SF to keep them in business.  But those in the know will try this place once and then quickly retreat back to their more traditional favorites like Saigon.
author: R S.

description: I dont give 4 Stars lighly. im still craving my crunchy yummy sandwich here. i ate here 2 nights out of my 3 nights here. Yum o.
author: Beth K.

description:
Is basic customer service so hard to expect when you're paying $10 for the same sandwich you can get in Little Saigon for $6?

My wife and I went to Bun Mee for the first time on Sunday July 24th
This was my experience with one male staffer:

Staff to me: Here are your sandwiches, can I bring you anything else?
Me to staff: Yes, a glass of water.
Staff to me: I'm cleaning up right now. I can't bring it to you.
Me to staff: Well, you asked....
Staff to me: You can get free refills at the counter.
Me to staff: I don't have a glass.
Staff to me: Did you say you wanted a glass of ice?
Me to staff: No, I said I'd like a glass of ice water please.

Staff brings it, and ignores me for the rest of the time we're there.
No checking in with us, and no "Thank you" when we leave.
author: Michael S.

description: After a few months, I decided to give this place  another try. This time, BunMee hit the mark. My pork belly with fried egg was delicious. The filling was plentiful and  bread had the right amount of crunch. Ownership  was probably going through  growing pains when they first opened. As I continue to love Saigon sandwiches, Bun Mee ranks right up there.
author: Isabella L.

description: Unbelievably tasty sandwiches and specials, drinks are fresh and all original recipes - so good!
author: Christian S.

description: If your craving some meat and some really great food then this is the spot for you! Always a great experience when I come here! Steak is the best!
author: Eric S.

description:
Despite what others are saying about this place, I think otherwise.

1st of all, i know this is only the 3rd day after its grand opening, but some of the mistakes they make i think are pretty bad. I wanted a roasted pork sandwich, but they're out by 4:30 that afternoon, fine, i'll just get another one and come back and try the roast pork next time, no problem. So i ordered the 5 spice chicken instead. It not only took us a long time to get the food, one of my friends' order was lost and he wasnt getting his catfish sandwich for a while until he noticed someone behind us has already gotten his order. My friend basically had to go up to the counter and asked for his sandwich for them to realize he even ordered a catfish sandwich, sad for the business's disorganization. 

2nd of all, my chicken was UNDERCOOKED! the first bite of my chicken sandwich was pretty delicious, but the 2nd bite was disgusting because i chewed on a piece of undercooked  chicken and literally spit it out because i was so grossed out by it. and when i actually opened up the sandwich, i saw another couple chunks of undercooked pinkish chicken, i was pretty annoyed of course, so i had to talk to the girl behind the counter and she made the kitchen make me another sandwich and gave me a plate of papaya salad for free as a compensation in addition to her apology. I'll give her props for trying to resolve this issue the nice way to ensure customer's satisfaction. However, my chicken sandwich never came because apparently no one remembered to make my chicken sandwich, and i was just sitting there with my friends waiting and watching the cook grill meats (they have these counter seats where you can see the whole assembly line of each sandwich they make). after talking to the counter girl again, she then realized no one made the sandwich for me and she had to make it herself. after i finally got my sandwich, the bread was not toasted so it's soft all around, that to me was very disappointing because one essential part of a good banh mi is the crusty french roll. first my chicken came undercooked, and now my bread was undertoated, it really ruined my 1st impression with this place

3rd, there's probably a reason why i always hear people say "you dont wana know what goes on in the kitchen in a restaurant" because just by sitting at the counter where i could see the cooking process, i was already grossed out and started to question the quality of the cook. for example, the guy who's grilling the chicken, he first touched the raw chicken and steaks with his gloved hands, and later on he grabbed some fries into a togo box with the gloved hands that touched the raw meat instead of the tongues he's supposed to be using, uhhh, talking about being good with sanitation. that is NOT how you serve food, uncooked meat should NOT come in contact with cooked food in any way! 

overall, their sandwich is not bad, but i definitely have a lot better ones in the city. and being a 6-7 dollar viet sandwich, i would actually expect more than just the long wait, undercooked meat, and improper food handling, dont you think?

PS. i will give it a month to get over the learning curve and see if they've  worked out the kinks and i'll update after that. hopefully the next time i return my experience will be better
author: Joyce C.

description:
i would go back if i'm in the area and happen to be craving for a banh mi sandwich.  but also, depends on the time/day.  i walked in around 11:15am on wed and there were few people in front of me.  so the wait was not too bad, but the girl at a cashier seemed new to the "food" biz and pretty slow in taking orders.  also they pretty much kept how the previous place (don't exactly remember, but it was either the ice cream place or a dessert place?) used to be and i can definitely see some chaos in the front of the place where people walk in to order, especially on the weekend.  i used to be in the hospitality biz, so i tend to notice these things...

as for the sandwich, it's not a place where i'd go from the other side of the town.  there are so many authentic (or as close) places for almost 1/2 of what this place charges (and bigger).  of course, it is the "low pac", filmore address added to its cost.  the bread wasn't all that, seasoning was a bit on the sweet side, papaya salad tasted more like japanese version rather than vietnamese one..., totally lacking cilantro....  

it'll be a while for me before stepping into this place again.
author: Peaceful S.

description: Got the pork belly. Still thinking about it a few days later.
author: Grace C.

description: So this place is super cool inside, and out, but the food is only so so, the only veggie Bahn Mí they have squidgy eggplant. (no tofu!) The rice bowl was alright, but the veggie/tofu to rice ratio isn't great and the prices are way too much for for what you get. If you want a good vietnames sandwich  head to the TL or go to one of the many delicious sammich places near the embarcadero like Le Croissant. If you want other vietnames food you're better off at sunflower.
author: Jared Z.

description: They make the best roast pork bahn mi in the city hands down! Rice bowls and spring rolls are really good too.
author: Chris D.

description: My chicken bun mee was disappointing because overall it was mushy, the bread was not fresh or memorable, and there was no spice found in this bland sandwich. I found myself wishing I had just stopped by my regular Vietnamese hole-in-the wall for a superior bahn mi at half the price.
author: Sarah Z.

description: yep! loved it! I had the eggplant sandwich and it sure was tasty! I'll be back next time I'm in the hood.
author: Lucy M.

description:
While I was waiting for my dad to be discharged from CPMC a couple of blocks away, I decided to come here again for the grand opening day. (nothing against hospital food, but it tastes like something I would cook, and I'm not a great cook, so why should I pay for it?) Anways, I gotta say, these guys are off to a great start. The staff is extremely nice, friendly and are down to make recommendations for new-comers. I decided to try the Crispy Catfish, and it was definitely impressive. Previously I had nitpicked that the 5 Spice Chicken could have had a little bit more meat in the sandwich, but this time there was a good amount of filling in the Catfish sandwich. I also have to recommend the housemade Kaffir Limeade. I'd like to say it's the best Kaffir Limeade, but honestly I've never had one before. You should still try it though, as you won't regret it. There's a good amount of people piling in during lunchtime, but the wait isn't long.  

side-note: I "think" they're also selling T-shirts, since they have a bunch of orange cans behind the counter that say "TEE-SHIRT". Perhaps the shirts are IN the cans? It's a neat idea if it were true. Didn't see any price tags and it's not anywhere on the menu. If you guys have anything in black and size-medium, I will gladly drop some bills over to you.
author: Efrain T.

description: Food is tasty, but as a neighborhood joint that I visit with some sort of frequency, consistency is lacking. They often run out of noodles, which seems crazy, and half the time the chicken is burnt from over grilling. If you go here for dinner, expect them to be out of something and for the rice to be over cooked and mushy.  Cross your fingers that they get it right because when they do, it's pretty darn good.
author: Patty H.

description:
Tried the catfish, sloppy joe, smokey eggplant sandwiches and salt and pepper fries!

Everything was delicious!!!!!

The salt & pepper fries were particularly fantastic!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 

Good food, service, location, and value!
author: Josie T.

description: Got the free salad from scout mob, saw they had Beer Lao, had to get one of those. Ahhh, free salad and remembering being in Luang Prabang. Stayed for a sandwich too, the sloppy bun: red curry sloppy joe with garlic aioli thai basil and a fried egg...delicious, I recommend this spot if you're in the area.
author: Michael V.

description: I would give zero stars if it were possible. Overpriced, tasteless, dry, very little meat tons of carrots, no seasoning, forgot the jalapenos, forgot I asked for no onions, got to go to share w/a friend, asked to be cut in half- they forgot and I had to go back, doesn't smell like food is cooking, cold wait staff and employees!!!! Maybe this spot ( location) is cursed since nothing last long here. The gelato shop there prior was much better! The bread was good but that's all!!! I hope they either go under or pull it together! Don't be fooled by the stars on the overall rating. I overheard others leaving w/ similar complaints. I wanted to like it but can't . If you want Bun Mee go to the Tenderloin!
author: emily b.

description: I'm just gonna comment on what I ate. Cool idea but overall food was just edible. I would still prefer the $2 bun mi sandwiches elsewhere. I had the five spice chicken, it was actually more like the one spice chicken. Completely lacking in flavor. The tofu spring rolls were fine but the sauce killed it. It was not peanut sauce ! Some weird off flavors. Their saving grace was their strawberry lychee fresca! Probably not coming back
author: Michael T.

description: I absolutely love Bun Mee. I always get the sandwhiches. The chicken/grilled pork is mouth watering. I tried the salt & pepper fries tonight, super good. They come with a side of mayo. They know just how I like it. Especially with the Sriracha bottle on every table. Yum yum
author: Price M.

description: Tried the shredded pork sandwich with a Vietnamese iced coffee - not bad, and the service was fairly fast! I've had better Vietnamese food elsewhere, but this neighborhood needs a place like this that's fast, easy and reliable.
author: Keira R.

description:
Okay so I read some review on yelp, which sometimes can mess you up, because everyone is so different about things they like and how they grew up. I am from the east and never had a Vietnamese sandwich before moving to San Francisco. A friend of mine took me over to lil Saigon on larkin and that's where I've always gone, to be honest I never quite knew what was in the sandwich except what kind of meat I was having. Now that I have had bun mee I actually know all the produce that is in the sandwich and the sauce on it, never knew I was eating diakon?  Well I took an order to go a few days ago and I have now had it 3 nights in a row, it's sooo addicting, I am a sandwich gal, I could live on sandwiches and they are so affordable, really there's not too many sandwiches that are 6-7 dollars. I tried the chicken and the pork and I loved em both. I actually got the sweet potato fries with the sauce, I would actually love you to package that sauce I ate the leftover with plain chips and it was delish. You could package that and sell it to go.  Americans love that creamy slight spicy sauce on everything. I also had the egg rolls and they were sooo good.  You could eat the order by yourself.  I used take out all 3 days and my order was done fast and everyone was nice, maybe I'll dine in sometime, I like the atmosphere. Common and tribe called quest was in the background playing. 
Very cool place you guys will do well, your logo is cute and fun and prices are good!!,
We need one of these in the marina/cow hollow, they need some cool vietnamese spots!!!
author: Jennifer M.

description: The more times I eat here, the more I like it.  One of the better banh mi I've had.  The meat is higher quality (not as fatty and fresh tasting) and seasoned nicely.  But, it's about twice as expensive as a typical sandwich but I guess it's worth it since you don't have to worry about getting mugged in the Tenderloin.  That's worth an extra $3!  If you live in neighborhood and are craving one, this is the perfect place.  I've tried the chicken, pork and steak sandwich.  All were very tasty but my favorite was the steak.  Also tried the citrus rice bowl, boy did that hit the spot.  So delicious.  The chocolate coconut cookies are very tasty too.  After gobbling down a cookie, my husband regretted not buying the 4 cookies for $5 deal.
author: Shelly W.

description: I don't know why there are so many haters out there! I was craving Vietnamese sandwiches and came for lunch. I loved everything about the sandwich. The bread was tasty. Not too dry at all! The pork this time was well cooked and not chewy. I loved the carrots and daikon. I also like how you can see them making it instead of possible sketchy kitchen practices at other cheaper places.  This isn't your normal Vietnamese shop - think gourmet Vietnamese sandwiches. Like what Slanted Door is to Vietnamese food as is Bun Mee is to their sandwiches!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Bun Mee is great.  Since it's opening, I've come back to Bun Mee about once a month, mostly Saturday mornings when I'm in need of a hearty Vietnamese sandwich or late nights after coming home from work.  My favorite sandwich is the Sloppy Joe with the fried egg--great flavor and perfectly comforting.  Although Bun Mee is definitely not the typical Vietnamese sandwich, I really appreciate the twist on the Vietnamese sandwiches.  I can go elsewhere for great traditional Vietnamese sandwiches, but those places don't have the sloppy joe with a side of crispy sweet potato fries.  :)  I'm deducting a star because while the sloppy joe is my favorite, I think their other items range from good to average and it's a bit pricey.

As a side comment regarding the other reviews about this place:
It's true, you can get a great sandwich at Saigon for half the price, but I see it as two different restaurants completely, specializing in two different things.  There is really no comparison between the two.  I visit the two establishments when I'm craving a particular sandwich, but I'd say my love for the two establishments are pretty even.
author: Trinh N.

description: France and Vietnam knocked boots and they ended up with Bun Mee. Simply unbelievable and for San Francisco (and anywhere in the US for that matter) the price is hard to beat.
author: Jahan T.

description: I don't know a whole lot about Vietnamese food, but after eating at Bun Mee I'm a fan. This place serves mainly Vietnamese sandwiches and salads, and is great for a quick bite. I ordered the crispy spring rolls and the split the sloppy bun with a friend (was just the right amount of food). The sloppy bun is their most popular sandwich-- a Vietnamese take on the American classic sloppy joe. It was definitely sloppy, and definitely delicious.
author: Ashley D.

description: Tried the belly sandwich today which was a little too salty for our palate. Still a cute and quick concept for tasty food.
author: K Q.

description: Pretty good quality food.   They have great service and it's located in a cute neighborhood.  The only con is that it's a little pricey and the portions are small compared to other Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Rupa P.

description: I come in about 4 days a week and eat the Mekong Shrimp Salad with chicken and it is MMM-MMM GOOD! And most importantly, the staff is AMAZING ;)
author: Danielle G.

description: Food was ok, I'd never had bunh mi. Branding and design of place was great and a refreshing addition to the conservative Filmore dining scene. However the counter staff needs serious help. Young woman in your 20's learn to at least fake a smile when dealing with paying customers, or maybe get a job in the back of house where you can be disgruntled all shift and no one cares. Otherwise this place is worth checking out in  non-peak hours.
author: casey c.

description:
The two-star description says it all:  "Meh.  I've experienced better."  The high bar for bahn mi is the Irving Deli, where, for a very modest price, you get an exquisitely balanced combination of flavors and textures. 

My first, and likely last, visit to Bun Mee was on a Saturday at 12:50 p.m.  I gave my order for two pork sandwiches, declining the half-dozen attempts to up-sell side orders, drinks, fried eggs, and desserts.  After I paid my almost 14 bucks, I waited.  And waited:  22 minutes to make two sandwiches?  And the verdict?  Doughy bread, with only about a centimeter of crisp on the crust.  The pork was undercooked, something you really don't want, and its flavor was all but masked by the too-strong hot peppers and overly vinegared vegetables.  Two stars?  Maybe it should be one.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: I had that cookie that's suppose to be soo good.  It tasted meh, not bad, not great.  I looked at the menu when I waited with a friend since that cookie was our "dessert".  Vietnamese food shouldn't cost that much.  I might be back to actually try their food but there are soo many food options on Fillmore that I can't see myself coming back anytime soon.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Cute atmosphere, unique quick vietnamese food on a trendy street. Stopped in to check out the menu the place smelled really yummy and hubbs quickly grabbed one of their delicious coconut cookies for the road. tasted like more! So after a day on fillmore street we decided to pick up dinner to go and I know we'll be back. I had the caramel citrus rice bowl which was fresh with a light flavor. I would have preferred it with ground chicken rather than grilled but it was good. I saw someone eating the sloppy sandwich and it looked awesome. Next time we'll try that. Good addition to the neighborhood.
author: Audrey V.

description: Grilled pork sandwich with sweet potato fries and a red curry mayo dip. The fries were perfect, crispy and hot. The best part of the sandwich was the combo of chewy bread and the pickled daikon/carrot mix. The pork was not memorable. Friendly staff in a cozy cafe made for an awesome lunch. Sriracha bottle on each table (yes!) Beer, pellegrino options, soda, and self serve water available. A wee but pricey but what isn't in the city? I took a menu and plan to head back another time.
author: Jen Y.

description:
yum mee!

the chicken in the chicken sandwich was so tender and soft. and i love all the fresh veggies they put in. the carrots were cooked well and still had a slight crunchiness to them. and whatever they were marinated in made them burst with flavor. the peppers they put in made a few bites REALLY spicy. the bread was very crumbly, and i almost choked on bread crust pieces a few times. i hate when that happens.

the strawberry lychee drink was so good!! i loved getting a few strawberry chunks to chew with each sip. the lychee flavor was very subtle, but they put in a whole one that tasted great after it had been soaking in all the strawberries.
author: Ji L.

description:
sandwiches are solid. obvi not authentic.

Yes they are more expensive then a place in the loin, but come on people its on filmore and the ingredients are way better.

I have been here a few times and everything ive had was tasty
author: Cristopher K.

description: I have been going here to get my Banh mi fix ever since they opened.  The service is friendly and sometimes it may take a little bit longer than I would like for take out but the sandwiches are consistently good. I prefer the bun mee combo.  Their coconut sandwich cookies are really delicious. Today I tried their garlic salt and pepper fries and they are spicy but so good.  I don't know why I haven't ordered them before today, but I'm glad I did!
author: Lorraine Y.

description: Belly Bun sandwich.  salt and pepper fries on the side.  i liked them so much we got a second order for our group.  bun bowl with grilled pork.  viet ice coffee.  the place is brand new.  the lemonade was very good.  a bit on the too sweet side for my personal taste buds, but nonetheless, very good.  the bathroom is clean and has all the necessary components for a great establishment.  i wish they took amex, but it's okay.  i know how high the amex merchant services fees can be.  and the restaurant is in a great neighborhood.
author: Dae Y.

description:
I have lived in the Tenderlion my whole life and I have tried the best Vietnamese sandwiches my neighborhood has to offer, that being said, Bun Mee has brought a different look and taste that I myself have come to enjoy.  I have tried their veggie eggplant and felt that the sandwich has a great creamy-buttery tart sauce that compliments the veggie pretty well. If there is one thing I want for a last meal is sweet potato fries. OMG I love sweet potato fries, even better if you put it in your sandwich along with the sauces, dude that's a great pig out meal for me. They might or should consider making fried sweet potato Bun Mee sandwich. 
Bun Mee is a pretty hip spot to grad your sandwich and go. That might be ONE of the reason their logo is a moped bike. But that's just me who feels that way. Most Viet sandwich spots are small and cramp with no space to hang out. They want you to get your food to go.  I don't think they want my hood-self hanging around anyways. I mean I was there in a busy Bun Mee day and got my order hella faster than most places with a long line. 
Bun Mee's sandwiches are great and they have the sloppy bun, if you love sloppy joe they have that as a Viet sandwich, it's like that whole east and west cuisine smash and had a baby.
author: Franny A.

description:
I am confused by all the low reviews??? Working at a small surgery center down the street, we order in food everyday and today we decided to try Bun Mee. 

We ordered two combos, three steak and three pork belly and they were all very good!  We ordered a side of sweet potato fries with a great dipping sauce. Great favor, fast service, all with a friendly smile! The coconut cookies are wonderful.  The drinks, Strawberry Lycee and the iced coffee were a tad too sweet, but we lived with them. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lacey M.

description: I have never been a big fan of their food. It's just been blah. Any random Vietnamese place makes better bahn mi and noodles. Previously, I did say I enjoyed their customer service. Tonight was not the case. We ordered one sandwich and one bun bowl. It took 45 minutes, while three people who ordered behind us got their food before us. Customer service was crap. No apologies or explanations were offered. They just looked around nervously without even addressing the issue or offering an apology. It was appallingly bad customer service. Oh, and a line cook wearing nothing but a sports bra is pretty unappealing. Their sweat can easily fall into your food. To top it off,our food was cold, soggy, and pretty disappointing. Never coming back.
author: Christine C.

description: My boyfriend and I had the pork and five spice chicken banh mi. While they were fine as sandwiches in general go, they were probably the most underwhelming Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had. Admittedly, I may not be an expert, but, the main problem was that these sandwiches lacked the fresh flavors I associate with banh mi. It tasted very... American (I know this makes me sound like a snob, but I don't know how else to describe it) and the bread was not as good as I would have liked, either.
author: Erin C.

description: It was alright. The sweet potato fries with the sauce were amazing, highlight of the meal. I got the pork sandwich. I wished it would've had more meat in it and maybe a dipping sauce to go with it or just more sauce on the sandwich. The decor is nice and cozy. We sat in one of the cute little window seats which was fun.
author: Kate M.

description:
how excited was i when i saw the sign for a vietnamese sammich shop to open up on fillmore? very excite!

i work nearby, sometimes, and i try to bring my lunch, because as we all know, the neighborhood is not so cheap! forgetting to pack food from home, i walked over to bun mee on my lunch break and ordered the roast pork sandwich. i was already annoyed with the hefty price, but thought "maybe the TASTE is amazing + worth it."

nope.

15+ minutes later, i took the goods back to work and couldn't wait to sink my teefs into the sandwich. 

what a disappointment. 

the meat was bland. more fat than meat. the sauce didn't help at all. and after eating it, i was still hongray. and my banh mi craving had not been satiated.

for the rest of the work day, all i could fantasize about was getting a delicious sammich from lee's (saigon sanwiches would be closed by the time i left work) to make up for the bun mee disappointment. as soon as i punched out, i drove straight to lee's. mmmmmm. tummy happy.

i might try another sandwich from bun mi, just because it's in the neighborhood. perhaps the chicken, so i don't have to pull chunks of fat from my mouth, mid-chew. and it'll kill me to pay that much for a sandwich that might leave me hungry! :/

i do have to say, the home-made cookies were delish. as was the strawberry-lychee agua fresca (i tried some from my co worker). maybe the other dishes are tasty as well.

we'll see.
author: Ashleigh R.

description: For years I couldn't understand the Vietnamese sandwich craze until i had a grilled prawn sandwich from Bun Mee. From the amazeballs grilled prawn, to fried egg, to tofu, to eggplant sammys - i am IN LOVE. The only downfall is, unless you're George Costanza and like your kung pao spicy, I recommend you watch out. Nose running and eyes watering, a coworker asked me if everything was OK. Nope, just bite into whole slices of jalapeno hidden in the middle of my sammy. Even with lips on fire i now luv luv luv me some viet sammys. Lee's sandwiches ain't got NUTHIN on this place. KUNG PAO!
author: Rebecca S.

description: Had the Lemmon grass pork, it was very good. The crispy egg rolls were delicious as well. Service was quick. Good spot for quick bite.
author: Chris K.

description: hands down the best bun mee place i have ever been to. too bad they dont have one here in san diego, i would go there all the time. when we were in san francisco we were so happy to discover the place.
author: Paumela B.

description: I would either make the price a little lower, or the sandwich a little fatter. Aside from that... OMFG I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! So good, so fresh! So close to my work! Ahhh! I would eat lunch here every day if i could afford it!
author: A. H.

description: One of my favorite lunch places in the area.  A bit pricey for banh mi but these are more creative versions than you would find in your typical sandwich hole in the wall.  Rice bowls are good too.
author: Andrew C.

description: Great sandwiches at a good price. Friendly staff.
author: Kathryn M.

description: It's a small spot, but have never had to wait.  They are friendly, quick and affordable.  Most things are good, but Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl is the best!!  The sweet potato fries are delightful, as well.  Simple fresh food.
author: Lindy C.

description: The ambiance here is cute. The banh mi is decent, not any better than your average banh mi. But then again, I'm not the biggest banh mi fan in the first place. I got the cookie which was coconut cream sandwiched between two thin wafery chocolate cookies. A bit pricey at $1.50  but 7x7 had named it one of the best cookies in SF, so I decided to give it a go. It was good, but I definitely don't think it was the worth the title or the cost. I'd rather spend $2 more and get a box of Girl Scout cookies.
author: Steffi L.

description: Good not great. The banh-mi at Lee's Sandwiches in the TL are tastier and cheaper. I'd return though.
author: Kiristen R.

description: Poor customer service and sandwiches are dry as death valley. This place dnt feel real welcoming and it seems everybody hates what they do which can explain the poor service!!!  I don't recommend anybody to eat here!!!!
author: Eric R.

description: Please get yourself a grilled pork sandwich. oh and just as a heads up there are jalapeños on the sandwiches.
author: Abhi M.

description: Let the haters hate, but I say YUM.  I love Bun Mee.  True, I wish there was more seating, I wish the service was faster, but regardless, I've eaten there almost once a week since it opened.  Lemongrass chicken bahn mi is great, but pork belly (with boiled egg!) is even better.  Eggplant is a great veggie option.  Love the papaya salad as a side.  Definitely worth checking out.
author: Julie H.

description: Fun place with good food. My GF and mine favorite new to go place for a quick meal!
author: Shahar B.

description: I've been here a few times and its a great place to stop for lunch while shopping on Fillmore. Both times the food arrives quickly, its well seasoned and the sweet potato fries are perfectly crispy. I think their pickled carrots could be better... its random I know, but well-done pickled carrots are amazing.
author: ALISHA W.

description: Mmmmmm, tried the sloppy bun and loved it!  Take-out is definitely the way to go on a busy weekday. They're very busy at lunchtime and staff are still clearly working out some minor issues (one person waited a long time because they forgot her fries), but they are so darned gracious and nice who really cares about a few glitches?  I'm not usually much of a fan of the pork  but I am going to have to see if the pork belly at Bun Mee will make me oink for joy!
author: Eve C.

description: The food was great (we ordered the sloppy bun, salt 'n pepper garlic fries and the saigon peanut rice bowl).  However, the person taking our order (not the owner) was very rude when explaining the sides that came with our meal.   Since this was our first time there, we did not know a side dish came with our meal.  She (the order-taker) seemed was impatient and rude when explaining which sides come with our order.  I would go back for the food, but I would not want to have to interact with this staff member again.
author: crystal p.

description: Delicious! Sloppy bun with fried egg is a winner. Quick, cheap.
author: Wendy K.

description: Bun Mee anytime!  Their sandwiches are scrumptious! Well... at least the five-spice chicken and the pork.  When we first walked in, I thought to myself, "Where in the world are the wifey, my kid & I gonna sit and eat?!"  The place was packed! Was it because of the Scout Mob Deal? Or was it the food? I soon realized that it was because of the food. My wife had the Grilled Pork, my kid had the Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl (Chicken) and I had to get the 5-Spice Chicken sandwich.  All three were delicious and I would definitely come back just for all three but I would seriously be missin' out on everything else Bun Mee has to offer on their delicious menu.  My wife is all for trying different places at least once but this is one place we'll have to visit more than twice!  The girls up front were great.  All I had to do was tell 'em we've never been here and one of them explained the ordering process.  Sitting at the bar was fun.  Something about watchin' the action in kitchen makes it feel like you're in a real-life FoodTV show featuring whatever you might be enjoying right then & there.  And watching the chef prepare what your next experience might be like is watching a preview at the movies!  We will definitely check this place out again.  And again... And again.
author: Delbert A.

description: Had the five spice chicken and the sandwich was small for $6. It was good but nothing special.
author: Sophia K.

description: Should one opt for authentic bahn mi sandwiches for half the price in the Tenderloin or yuppified Bun Mee sandwiches on Fillmore?  Both are good, and the latter is no less authentic.  The Bun Mee combo is immensely satisfying, as are the side dishes.  The service is friendly, and the space, though tight, is well designed.  Bun Mee is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Michael P.

description: Excellent lunch spot!  I had the "sloppy" bun, which is like a sloppy joe with red curry ground beef, jalepenos, and I ordered it with an egg.  The bites are flavorful, savory, and have egg yolk oozing everywhere.  go go go!
author: Terry K.

description: Bun Mee was a Bum Mer for me.  Went durning opening weekend. Congrats to them for the big crowds. Place was nice, decent selection of items.  The main issue for me was was pure lack of flavor.  I had the roasted pork sandwich and it was just bland, very disappointing.  I'll stick with the banh mi sandwich shops on Clement street.
author: Dilly M.

description: I found this place by chance while taking a stroll in the city. I was thinking an ice cold beer and a small sandwich would be a perfect afternoon snack. Much to my chagrin no beer or wine here so I settled for a pork sandwich and a glass of water. The pork was not as hot as it should have been and just lacked "something". Maybe it needed more aioli and a squirt of suracha. The staff was friendly and the vibe was good.
author: Raymond L V.

description: They opened 3 weeks ago and I've found a way to get here twice already. The sloppy bun is a must order. The veitnamesse ice tea is sweet and perfect on a warm day. The decor is a combination of vespa, minimal ad/graphic design and informal school room with thier chalk slat menu board. The staff is friendly and eager to make your meal better. It gets a bit crowded as it feels the space is award. I like to sit at the chef's bar and watch them create the sandwiches. The green papaya salad is pretty good as well. Sweet potato fries for $3 is a rip off with the amount the serve. They have a great location as a modern ethic restaurant on Filmore. I'd be okay if more popped up too.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Let me start by saying that Bun Mee is a welcome addition to Fillmore St.  There are other French and other Vietnamese restaurants nearby however none of them specializes in the unique sandwiches offered by Bun Mee.  

I visited today (Opening Day +1) for lunch at about 1pm with my girlfriend.

As far as decor, the restaurant has a clean open feel to it and a very legible simple menu.

Perhaps it was growing pains but the 30 minute wait for a sandwich seemed a bit excessive.  "Made to order" sounds good in principle but given the simplicity of the menu, it seems a little absurd.  If they were to prep at least some of the ingredients in advance, they could shorten this time.  I observed many patrons departed without ordering as soon as they heard about the long wait time -- not good for the income of the restaurant!

Now to the food.  I ordered the "juicy steak" sandwich and my girlfriend ordered the citrus rice bowl with chicken.  My sandwich was good, but not great.  The vegetables and meat were fresh and cooked well however the flavors were not as interesting or as complex as those you might find at Out the Door, Slanted Door or Heaven's Dog.  That said, I would order it again.  My girlfriend's dish was incorrectly prepared which was a little disappointing after the long wait.  To be fair:  the staff was extremely polite and understanding.

One area of improvement would be at the front register.  The attendant was not very familiar with the food's ingredients, did not know they were completely out of certain items (the reason my girlfriends dish was wrong) and forgot the drink portion of the order.  It seems like the owners and operators have placed all of their best people in the back cooking and running orders while the front isn't well nailed down.

Pricing is very fair although you might have to add 30-60 minutes of parking ticket charges to the bill -- an $8 sandwich is a value, at $11 it is not.

Normally the long wait for a botched order would be a reason not to return however the extremely attentive response from the staff combined with some sympathy for their early days would lead me to give it another shot.

I really do hope this place succeeds....
author: D G.

description: I know I'm not getting the full on authentic experience but that's just fine. If I come to bun mee it's cause I want to know it's super clean, fresh and reliable "westernized" Bahn mi. Which is totally fine. And I think they have a couple of stand outs - the red curry sandwich (with the egg sounds great) and the spicy chicken. If you take kids, ask for it "open" which means deconstructed. The kids can then build their own with all the bits they like. Leaving out the herbs and veg usually!
author: Rachel H.

description:
i was a little hesitant about bun mee when it first opened. if i wanted vietnamese, id go down to larkin. after a few years and several good reviews from friends, i decided to give it a try. 

i appreciate their online ordering system. it was pretty easy and painless. unfortunately, the food was meh. i ordered the bun noodle bowl with imperial rolls. the noodles were soggy, the rolls were greasy and the dressing was flavorless. 

super disappointing, i was hoping for a good vietnamese joint down the street from my house. i guess ill just have to keep going to larkin. its cheaper and tastier. id suggest you do the same.
author: CaliGirl X.

description: Average Vietnamese sandwiches and mediocre papaya salad.  Don't get the sweet potato fries to-go unless you want them soggy.
author: Jessica P.

description: I've totally been wanting bahn mi in the neighborhood for a LONG time, and it's alright, but nothing special. Got the chicken bahn mi. Wanted to try their lychee drink but they ran out. Not sure that it's worth the price as well. I guess it's alright if I'm craving a bahn mi and feeling too lazy to travel any  real distance.
author: Verna L.

description: Great food, atmosphere and service!  You can't go wrong, so delicious!
author: SKY S.

description: The sandwich I got was alright, but I really could just get a better sandwich from the east bay. The service was meh, and could really use better training. They literally acted like I knew what I was getting. And mind me for usually ordering a char siu sandwich usually... But don't expect customers to know what to order especially when you are in SF. There's too many people and cultures in one area to be acting like that.
author: Mary R.

description:
I work down in the tenderloin, and have tried many of the Vietnamese sandwich shops down there, that being said, I really liked what Bun Mee had to offer. I like their twist on traditional banh mi, and thought many of the flavors were very good. We didn't eat any meat, so I can't attest to the flavors of their pork as some of the other reviews have, but the eggplant sandwich was really good! A bit salty, but really interesting flavors! The Green Papaya Salad was very good as well, I only wish there was more of it when we ordered it as a side dish! The sweet potato fries were delicious, but the real star was the aioli that came with them, AMAZING!

Also, do yourself a favor and get a lime-aid. Very sweet, just like on the streets of Vietnam! The service is still a bit slow, but I will chalk that up to them being a new establishment, and hope that they get their act together soon. The prices don't bother me so much, as it is still very affordable for Fillmore st. No, it may not be the most authentic Vietnamese sandwich in SF, but it is a welcome addition to the Fillmore restaurant scene, and I will certainly be going back.
author: Jessica V.

description: No one should EVER pay more than $5 for a bunh mi!  If you don't know much about Vietnamese sandwiches, then I'm sure you'll enjoy this trendy place.  But for those that know what a traditional Vietnamese sandwich should taste like and cost, just stick with Saigon sandwiches on Larkin street...best bunh mi in the city!  And the best part...all under $5!
author: Tina L.

description: Came here expecting to down a bomb sandwich, but this place doesn't offer your typical Vietnamese Sandwich. The types of Vietnamese sandwiches they offer are unique in a way I suppose, they add I guess an American fusion to it. The menu was quite surprising, seeing that they offer Sweet potato fries definitely wasn't expecting that at all. Overall, the food was alright, not to die for. Probably wouldn't come back unless I was around the area.
author: Alex T.

description: Pretty good for the price and size of the sandwich...I had the roast pork bahn mi on this visit. Although the sandwich was tasty overall, there is a place around Larkin and Eddy streets that's more flavorful and cheaper.
author: Orlando J.

description: The food here is actually pretty good. Many would say overpriced, especially if compared to anything from the Tenderloin shops but I mean, c'mon that's obvious. The surroundings are nicer of course and if you happen to go during less busy times you can sit and eat. The upside is that it's clean and just feels like they use better ingredients (whether or not that's true I don't know.)  Since I don't eat meat anymore I didn't try those options, but the Hanoi Style Crispy Catfish is pretty tasty.  The sides are yummy, but you have to go into it not thinking about what it would cost to make it yourself.  That's kind of the story I find repeating itself quite a bit in the city anyhow...
author: Cando V.

description: Awesome addition to the neighborhood! Split the catfish bun mee and the eggplant bun mee. Both were delicious, fresh and satisfying. Will be coming here a lot more to try the rice bowls and pork belly bun mee.  And the five spice chicken bun mee.  And everything else...
author: Louis M.

description: Love love love Bun Mee.  They have delicious sandwiches and yummy salads and great iced Vietnamese Coffee.  My favorite place on that Fillmore strip.
author: Dagny C.

description:
was excited to try a new restaurant on fillmore with banh mi no less!  expectations were further fueled by the great location, adorable store front & simple/modern decor.

food was totally meh.  completely underwhelming and overpriced for what it is.  would rather go to an authentic hole-in-the-wall to get a better tasting sandwich for a fraction of the cost.
author: Karen F.

description: Had lunch here today. The spicy grilled pork sandwich was fantastic!  The five spice chicken sandwich was quite good. Everything tasted really fresh. Sadly, the egg rolls were just ok. Even so, I'd definitely go back when in the neighborhood.
author: Kay L.

description: This place is pretty good.  Ordered the fish and chips and a sloppy beef sandwich.  You can definitely taste the quality and it is worth more than your locoal vietnamese sandwich place. I'll be back to try their 5 spice sandwich.  Oh yes, and I also got their kiwi/lychee drink.  Pretty sweet, but can't stop drinking it... Definitely a good place!
author: Joseph C.

description: I'm pretty sure there are other items from Bun Mee that are good, but this review is just for their "Bun Mi". I pretty much grew up eating Bun Mi since I was like 5 years old so the expectations were pretty high. It was OK, the portion was pretty small for it being $6-7. I'm use to getting Bun Mi's that are only $3 that are double the size. Flavor was also OK. I guess I'll go back if I HAVE to.
author: Nate T.

description: Just had lunch here. The banh mi sandwiches are so good. The baguette is perfectly toasted and we just tried the new salt and pepper fries with soy mayo dipping sauce-Yum!!! Leo knows how to get to work in the kitchen! Thanks=)
author: Mai Q.

description: Denise the owner contacted me via email and was very apologetic about what happened.  She provided me with a refund AND a gift certificate.  That was very nice of her.  Every place has its off day.  I may just return to give it another try.
author: CHRISTINE L.

description: Hey Bun Mee! Thank you for making my hubby happy.  He loves your sandwiches :)  I liked what I have too but I can't remember what it was, something funky but yummy, yes.  We will be back in to try more soon :)
author: Roya T.

description: Not only do I love all of their sandwiches, their house-made coconut cookie sandwiches are addicting!! I would venture to say they are one of the best I have ever had. You must try them!
author: Kelly K.

description:
Great modern twist on classics! All you haters out there are obviously not understanding that this is supposed to be non-traditional, why else would they choose a prime location on Fillmore? Don't come here expecting your typical Vietnamese food for cheap prices (but the prices are actually reasonable). 

I had the sloppy bun with fried egg- full of flavor and spices with fresh veggies. A little bit less cilantro as well as less cooking on the egg would have been ideal, but I was still a happy camper. I also got the mango and sesame salad that had a great kick to it and was refreshing. The décor here is also original and fun--I will def go back to try other menu items.
author: Rena Z.

description: I LOVE vietnamese food, especially Vietnamese style banh mi.  The first time I stepped into Bun Mi, I was in awe.  I thought to myself, finally! a Vietnamese restaurant that is clean and modern, and their vespa logo is super cute.  I had the grilled pork sandwich.  It was good, but $7 is a bit high (because I can get the same quality sandwich for $3 at another place).  Anyhow I decided to go back and give it another try.  I ordered the pork belly sandwich and egg rolls.  The pork belly sandwich was so SALTY I couldn't eat it and the juice made the baguette all soggy.  The egg rolls were a disappointment as well, all wrap and not much filling.  I don't think I would be returning.
author: Alyx L.

description: Bun Mee makes some delicious sandwiches at a reasonable price.  I am training for a triathalon, so I only eat food that I know is healthy.  I tried both the 5 spice chicken and sloppy bun sandwiches, which included fresh vegetables and tender perfectly cooked meat.  Both I highly recommend!  Also, if you like sweet potato fries, this is hands down the place to go.  The fries have the perfect balance of spices and crispiness.  In terms of the atmosphere, the place is classy, clean, and well decorated.  I'm not a big food critic and this is my first time writing a review on Yelp, but in my opinion Bun Mee really took the sandwich to whole new level of favor.  I will definitely become a regular.
author: Stephen P.

description: This is a new restaurant in SF Pacific Heights area.  I've lived in Vietnam for over 3 years (2007-2010) and it brings a unique blend of the authentic Vietnamese sandwich with hip, organic and visually attractive, western-friendly sandwich to SF.  The decor is simple but stylish.  The feel is very casual (antique stools, wall paintings and decor) and comfortable.  But most of all, the food is great.  I definitely recommend trying out the steak sandwich or one of the rice bowls.  Don't forget the limeade which is made daily by hand.
author: Paul S.

description: I was underwhelmed. We had the pork combo, 5 spice chicken and tofu ban mi's. The pork and chicken needed more marinating- lacking in flavor. The tofu was ok. They should consider marinating the tofu with something other than soy sauce or cooking with lemongrass - and mine was missing cilantro - maybe a fluke, but it's a key ingredient and I missed it. I would probably give 2.5 stars if I could. The bread and pickled carrots was good at least.
author: MyHanh H.

description: Ate here yesterday evening after a great write-up in a local magazine - unfortunately, this place doesn't live up to the hype in my opinion.  First, I had the 5spice chicken sandwich - it was good, but didn't have the tangy juice associated with this type of sandwich, and had TONS of hot peppers on it - plus it was $6.25 - now I know, if I want a good Banh Mi, go back to Civic Center area and get it for 50% less!  Second, we also ordered the sloppy Joe Banh Mi - it was the worst - a little smear of meat, no red curry taste whatsoever, and again TONS of red peppers.  Service was only ok - wished we would have passed this one by - will not return.
author: R F.

description: The most authentic Vietnamese restaurant I've come across.  Generous portions and reasonable price.  Everything on the menu is fantastic!  The Pork Belly bowl is to die for.  My favorite city lunch restaurant so far by a wide margin.
author: Garret I.

description: Great crispy tofu sandwich and sweet potato fries. Love the red curry mayo. Yummy - will definitely go back.
author: T C.

description: Love the salads!  Great combination of greens and flavors that remind me of Vietnam!
author: David F.

description: Americanized viet sandwiches. Definitely doesn't compare but it's still a good sandwich. I'm rating this based on the comparison between a real viet sandwich and how they make it here.
author: Lucy T.

description:
Never been to this place but have heard great feedback from my fellow concierges that have dined here.

I just can't help but to comment on Jess H.'s comment on 6/2/2011.  You ordered a SLOPPY Joe Bun...of course it was sloppy! Hence the name! You make me want to say "DUH" but I won't. ;-)
author: Elizabeth C.

description: This new kid on the block eatery and take-out place was buzzing when I popped in for lunch the other day.  I tried the catfish sandwich - it was delicious - with julienned veggies and a side of green papaya salad.  Next time I want to try the noodles with tofu and peanut sauce.  Definitely worth a try if your taste buds are looking for something new and fresh.
author: Karen L.

description: Although you could find a Vietnamese sandwich for way cheaper in Little Saigon (TL), this place is what we'll go ahead and call fancy.  Try the Bun Mee combo!  Delicious...
author: Mila M.

description: Very good Vietnamse Sandawiches, but pricy, $10.35 for a sandwich and an ice coffee
author: Mark W.
