description: Try to forget how much you would pay for a banh mi in the Tenderloin - because here all you have to worry about is finding parking, not sidestepping the brawling homeless people on every corner.  If you can forget the prices, you'll be pretty pleased with the banh mi and the delicious sweet potato fries.  I also had the strawberry lychee drink - a tad too sweet and overpowering.
author: B. Y.

description: Glad its open and welcome to the neighborhood!  Had the roast pork sandwich, very good: bread was excellent, warm and crunchy.  Good Vietnamese flavorings.  Limeaid was very good as well.  Small place but attentively decorated.  I thought it was great!
author: Glenn S.

description: Yummmmm!!! Bun Mee, a place that offers all types of Banh Mis, you surely won't be disappointed. It's located on the Fillmore in a small nice space. They have all sorts of sandwiches, salads, beer, and wine. Their sandwich/banh mi selection is amazing - there's something for everyone, ranging from chicken to tofu to pork to fish to beef. My friend and I split two banh mis, one pork and one catfish. Both were soooo good, but I preferred the pork one while my friend liked the catfish. They give all the Vietnamese fixins with it: carrots, the pickle stuff, etc. It totally tastes Vietnamese, but it is by no means authentic. It definitely has a Western/Americanized flavor to it, so be prepared to expect that. The bread the sandwich is served on is very good, and every sandwich is about $7-9. I think this place is a must to go to! If I lived closer, I'd come here at least once a week for lunch or dinner.
author: Priya G.

description: i really like bun mee- i get excited when i see their logo of a cute orange scooter hanging outside the restaurant. that means i am just steps away from stuffing my face with yummy vietnamese sandwiches. i always look forward to the end of the week when i usually treat myself to their sandwiches and the salt and pepper garlic fries. (their garlic fries are amazing- i would totally just order 3 and eat their fries as a meal). however, the only thing keeping me from giving this place 4 stars is the service. since i work so close by, i regularly get take out here but for some reason, always end up the most unhappy waitresses. what's up with that?! pooey!
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: I hate going to a restaurant with high expectations, but that's what happened here.  I visited Bun Mee in the first few weeks it opened and wasn't too impressed.  The sandwich toppings are very creative but seemed a bit bland, surprising for all the spices I know are present.  I had the sloppy bun with a fried egg and felt I needed more heat in my sandwich.  I did try my friend's Grilled Five Spice Chicken which seemed to have a better flavor profile.  I will say that the Vietnamese iced coffee was some of the best I've ever had.  The milk and sugar didn't overpower the drink, making the coffee the star of the show.  So good.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Yummy!!! And reasonable!!! My favorites in order: 1. Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl with Chicken (huge portion and the caramel citrus sauce is awesome!) 2. Ceasar "Steak" Salad (the steak is really tender and the grapefruit makes it unique and flavorful) 3. The Juicy Steak sandwich (the steak is a little tougher but still a good sando). I want to go back and try the spicy chicken sandwich. The food also doesn't have any MSG!!! It actually seemed on the healthier side and it's a good atmosphere for a casual restaurant where you order at the front.
author: Jenna Q.

description: Cool, hip place with great food at reasonable prices. Especially like the sweet potato fries and dipping sauce. Will be back.
author: Richard L.

description: I stand by my review for the Fillmore location but I was underwhelmed by the new Market street outpost.  Line was very long, and the sandwich was dry (they forgot condiments, mayo, etc.). Not worth it, given other dining options downtown..
author: Christine H.

description: This "gourmet" style of Vietnamese sandwich shops is adequate if you are in Pacific Heights. However, the king of the Vietnamese Sandwich hill still remains "Saigon" in the Tenderloin.
author: Norman V.

description:
I had heard a lot of hype about Bahn Mi so this place has been on my list for a while. I finally went and had mixed thoughts. I ordered the Sloppy Bun (curry ground beef) which was about $6. That's pretty solid for a sandwich on Fillmore, but their drinks are all $2.50+, even for a soda so you'll end up spending $10 or more. The ingredients were definitely fresh, and flavors were good. My biggest complaint had to do with quantity. I felt like my sandwich had no meat in it, it was almost all shaved onion and aioli. I sat by the bar, where you can see the ingredient cheat sheets they have for their employees for all of their sandwiches. The sloppy bun said "3oz sloppy joe meat". That would be why my sandwich seemed light. If I go back, I'll try another one of the sandwiches. The 5 spice chicken looked like more care went into seasoning the meat, and perhaps the quantity is a bit higher. One other gripe those of you that like spice... I ordered the 'spicy' version of my sandwich, and it definitely wasn't. It was covered in jalapenos, but those little guys tasted as hot as a yellow bell pepper. Not sure why. My coworker said the same thing. He can't handle spicy food, accidentally got his covered with jalapenos, and he even thought it was mild. 
I also ordered the vietnamese iced coffee. This was tasty and larger than the ones you would get at my father's kitchen. But they aren't made fresh, it was poured from a large pitcher. It's also 3.50 vs 2.50 at my father's kitchen.
author: Adam F.

description: Very cute little place.  The sandwiches were darn tasty and lichee strawberry lemonade is to die for.  They are currently waiting on a liquor license.  Try the Sloppy Bun or the Belly Bun.  Both are tasty, tangy and ready quickly.  The space is small and cute and the service is friendly.
author: Jackie G.

description: This place kicks ass.  Both the chicken and the pork belly sandwiches rock and the sweet potato fries are excellent.  Highly recommend this joint.
author: T B.

description: i'm surprised this place has 3.5 stars - it's definitely a 4+ situation! their food is tasty, very well done, and reasonably priced. i've come back here several times and always been happy :) this is one space where i think yelp might be off. TRY IT!
author: Elise H.

description:
Great new addition to my neighborhood. I come here often but they are new so still trying to figure some things out.  I really like the simple sandwich's. I generally get the five spice chicken.  The only thing is the pricing is a little off for the sides.  The sandwich's are ok priced but the problem is with the sides.  The fries are additional 3 dollars and come on the same plate that barely fits the sandwich.  For the fries it is about 15 of them.  They should just increase the price of the sandwich and add the fries or salad or give you a realistic amount for 3 bucks.
I came for dinner to grab a rice steak bowl which was good but the brown rice was undercooked.  I finally asked the waiter and he went back and checked.  It was hard and he apologized and tried to give me a coconut cookie.  I don't do coconut.  He then brought me a side of white rice.  I  was laid back about it but they could have done better.
author: Jason M.

description: The only bahn mi I'd touch since they use quality ingredients. It's one of the better places to eat on a lower budget along Fillmore, unless you like going to Burger King. Get the Belly Bun (Kurobuta pork belly) with a fried egg. Those coconut cookie sandwiches are so worth it.
author: Tami Y.

description: This is my new favorite lunch place. The five-spice chicken sandwich is outstanding. I really wasn't expecting to like a banh mi, but the flavors work really well together, and Bun Mee uses good ingredients. The Vietnamese iced coffee is also terrific. I'm totally addicted to it!
author: Jamon B.

description: Had the Bunn Me Combo, a pork combo, and that was pretty tasty. What really got me was the catfish and the sweet potato fries. Those were SO good! A no brainer ordering that again.
author: cyndi L.

description: Favorite new lunch spot in SF.  The Five Spice Chicken sandwich is exceptional - great flavors, french bread is perfect density, very spicy.  My go-to lunch sandwich.
author: Lloyd W.

description: Great for a quick bite.  Try the spicy chicken.
author: Gregory G.

description: Go for the sloppy bun with fried egg and jalapenos, get the sweet potato fries...let's be real. Great curry aioli and meat, imbibed with fresh veggies...great choice.
author: Drew W.

description:
Always friendly and quick service, the food is almost always very good. Super convenient and fast, perfect for lunch!
Update: I came back after my travels just to discover that the place had been closed due to sanitary concerns and now reopened. 
I thought if I liked it with those insects in the kitchen...lol.. I would like it even better without them. Oh well.. Their "Pork belly" was just brown rice floating in pork FAT, 95% fat and just 5% meat. Go for it if you like it!  I am not coming back.
author: Vicky K.

description: I had the Caramel Citrus Rice bowl with tofu. The flavors were good, but 70% of the dish was overcooked, gloppy rice. I couldn't eat it, so the meal amounted to $12 for two pieces of tofu, a tablespoon of papaya salad, two itty bitty pieces of grapefruit, and whatever dressing didn't get sopped up by the nasty mass of rice. Not worth it.
author: J C.

description: Really good sandwiches and excellent sides, housemade limeade and vietnamese iced coffee.  Jeez this stuff is so good.  I had never had viet sandwiches but I was really psyched.  I had the pork belly and she had the chicken sando.  She didn't really love hers, but we loved just about everything else.  The place itself is super cool and cute and we ate outside along Fillmore Street.  I'll definitely go back.
author: Matt S.

description: I love Russian Hill, and Bun Mee is just another reason why I KNOW I could live in this neighborhood and never want to leave.  My friend and I hopped in for a "snack" as we toured the neighborhood's watering holes and eateries.  I first heard about Bun Mee on "Unique Eats" (Cooking Channel), and it lived up to the hype.  We were thinking traditional, and opted for the pork belly, a.k.a. the Belly Bun.  Can I get an 'Amen' for the pork belly?  I experienced a rebirth after biting into this sandwich.  There are certain meals that host killer flavor thanks to quality ingredients, but we are talking several degrees above killer status.  For a newby, you will find the intense richness of the pork so satisfying that you will feel like you just cheated on your favorite eatery.  It is sinfully delicious.  There is the crunch of the pickled carrot and daikon, the salty goodness of the radish relish, cool cucumber, and my favorite herb on the entire planet, cilantro! I am never one to think "sandwich" when I'm really hungry, but a Belly Bun--and probabaly any of the other sandwiches on the menu--would make me a convert.
author: Stephanie L.

description: yum! fave inexpensive, easy, not horrible for you place in the area.  tons of good options.
author: Alyssa M.

description: Finally....an excellent Vietnamese sandwich shop that not only has great food, but also has a great feel. My first visit was tonight , around 8:00. There was a line and the staff was clearly suffering from the "trial by fire" scenario of opening a new place, fortunately the owner, Denise, was holding it all together! I had the Bun Mi with grilled chicken. It was spectacular, the bread was perfect, crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. The architecture of the sandwich was almost art and the taste was 5 stars! I also got the Napa salad, it was really good with a light peanut dressing. The menu is extensive for a sandwich shop. Overall I was impressed and I will certainly go back again and again....
author: glenn w.

description: It's a nice addition to the neighborhood, but is just meh. I had the Pork Bahn Mi. The Mi was just not for me.
author: Yum N.

description: It's been awhile since I've stroll down this part of town. Since it  is aways been a pricey part of the city, the food and eatery reflect this. I figure I'll will try the grilled pork sandwich and a tofu spring roll here. Place is very chic and of course, the price you pay is double for the same in the TL or the Aves. The tofu rolls were ok with the spicy dipping sauce and so was the ban mee.
author: Wolfy W.

description: maybe we just ordered the wrong dishes (two saigon rice bowls, one with chicken and one veggie), but they just weren't good. the flavors were mediocre and left us both wishing we had gone somewhere else. it's a shame because it's a cute place and we really *wanted* to like it. i will say we also shared the sweet potato fries and those were delicious. and ps skip the pinot noir - we didn't think it was drinkable.
author: Kate M.

description: PIcked up at the one on Market.  Fried tofu sandwich.  Excellent, and one of the few presentations of fried tofu that wasn't a disappointing mess.  Great flavors, textures.  (I don't care about "authenticity"...I'm not going to a place called Bun Mee for authenticity.  I want an interesting, well-made sandwich at a reasonable price...will return.)
author: Keith J.

description: Definitely tasty! A little skimpy on the meat but overall I was satisfied. Everything was well balanced!
author: Jonathon C.

description: I love their salads but I really get annoyed anytime I order a meal to go and then always find out when I get home that there is something missing that's on the menu, e.g. avocado, mango. Pretty annoying. Please make sure your staff checks that the salads are complete before giving them out. Thanks!
author: Ive Z.

description: This place makes decent banh mi.  But comparing it against similar places that sell for less, it is just average.  Fresh bread/vegetables.  Interesting combos.  I would eat here if in the area, but not a destination place for banh mi
author: p w.

description: You can never go wrong with some sort of tasty meat inside some toasted bun. I love the fusion of Asian tastes in a classic western dish. Their selection of salads is also a great addition to the other salad places on Fillmore. Definitely grab one of their famous cookies if you want a snack!
author: Ivy C.

description: It was fine.  Good ingredients.  Good staff.  Good place to sit and people watch.  Had a late dinner - I got the rice bowl, hubby one of the sandwiches.  As I said it was fine.
author: Ash A.

description: Are you looking for a new hot spot to visit or tasty cuisine to try? Well, Bun Mee is on my list of must-do, again and again. Recently, Bun Mee catered a fashion mixer I organized. During and after the event I heard many accolades about how delish the sandwiches were. I have to agree. The fare is quite savory and a visit to their quaint, but chic restaurant was just as pleasing. The space is very hip, the ambiance relaxed, and the food a tasty treat.
author: Mignon A.

description:
Fairly good Banh mi, wish it had more meat or even loaf meat, and impressed with the bread. The bread is the best part. 

Momma Tran's fried spring rolls lacked flavor. How about some more ground pork? Especially since the dipping sauce was just a sweet rice wine vinegar with NO FISH SAUCE! Not good. Put the fish sauce back in. However the rolls were packed well for take out and didnt get soft even after a long car trip.

 "Salad" roll were good, but the sauce was messed up.Take the jalapeno or chili peppers out of your peanut sauce. No one expects heat from the rolls. What the point of iving us Sriracha if the sauce is already spiked? My dinig partner did not appreciate this.

Love being able to order online. Love that there is a comment section to note "NO HOT PEPPERS!"  Now if you could just fix your sauces we would come back.
author: Nan L.

description: Too much "bun"; not enough "mee". "Mee" as in MEAT. Have you ever eaten something and found one tiny bit of the whole meat so delicious that you wish there were more but there isn't? You'll find the same thing here. More meat, less bun. This place would be amazing. It is a great little place. Kind of a hole in the wall with outdoor seating and visible kitchen. I recommend it. And maybe ask for more meat.
author: Tiffany S.

description: I went to their "opening night" party and enjoyed the food very much.  The Sandwiches were freshly made and delicious although the buns were a touch on the thick side which I guess is just a matter of personal preference.  I really liked the sweet potato fries as well, lightly salted, perfectly sweet and piping hot!  This place is in my neighborhood so I'll likely come back once they're a little more established and hopefully upgrade this to 5 stars :)
author: gabriel s.

description: dissapointed about eggplant being removed from menu!!!  everyone at work looks forward for this sandwich.  PLEASE BRING IT BACK on the menu.  PLEASE BRING BACK the EGGPLANT.  we average 10 sandwiches per order.
author: Jomel C.

description: Average sandwiches that I wouldn't go out of my way to eat. Pretty good iced coffee. I sat at a table outside on a gorgeous sunny day and people watching after Bay to Breakers as the participants walked home was probably the best part of the experience.
author: k h.

description: Pretty yummy and fairly inexpensive for Vietnamese sammies! Atmosphere is modern and customer service rocks!
author: Jess A.

description:
Another delicious option on Fillmore.  

Steak banh mi was tasty and loaded with good stuff; sweet potato fries were a little less than crispy, but the red curry aioli is awesome; kaffir limeade is awesome; and the coconut cookie is a great way to cap it all off.  Quick service, and everyone was good about accommodating a bunch of take-out orders in the small space available.

There's at least 6 more things here I want to try, so this is going on the heavy rotation list.
author: Josh D.

description: I ate at bun mee and found it to be good ,but a bit on the expensive side but when i returned I saw that they had a sign on their window  from the health dept that the had a rat infestation ( vermin)and that was about two month after they opened .YUK!
author: nicolas v.

description: Yummers, but eat it there. Its better that way, Ive found so far. Kinda pricey too for the size. I had the eggplant. The little cauliflower on there is delish! I honestly could eat two, but we wont talk about that.
author: Tara M.

description: Very expensive for what it is!  But for a trendy place on Fillmore, that's a given.  Overall, I am grateful for a tasty & fairly healthy option in the hood.  & I like noshing to good hiphop on a decent system too.
author: Miss K.

description: We went there on 2 separate visits. We really like their roast pork belly buns with egg. Sweet potato fries were okay. Wouldn't order that the next time.
author: Melody S.

description: Grab a sunny little table outside or in the window and enjoy one of these delectable little sandwiches with their fresh juice!
author: Christina R.

description: A tad pricey but definitely better than Lee's Sandwiches.  Their rolls are toasted to perfection and their meats are so tasty and flavorful.  Some of the negatives:  the rolls and the papaya salad came after the sandwiches.  If I didn't mention anything I'n not sure I would have received them.    That being said,I'm sure it's just a case of still being new and that they'll work out the kinks.  I met Denise (the owner) and I can definitely see the love and passion she puts into her business.  I'm looking forward to Bun Mee being a long time fixture in the Fillmore dining scene
author: d h.

description: I had the chicken bahn mi and it was very juicy and tasted great. Not a fan of the jalapenos so I took them out. But overall, it was awesome! This place is NOT an authentic bahn mi eatery, as many people have complained about on this page, nor is it trying to be. It is influenced by bahn mi sandwich places. If you want the real thing, go to the TL or to San Jose and get one on the cheap for less than $4. This particular bahn mi place is rather pricey but fits in well with the rest of the restos on the block. I am looking forward to trying the salads next. It's also not authentic because they are also offering sandwiches such as catfish or eggplant that are not usual items in most bahn mi places. The combination also looks rather good and I'll try that next.
author: Gina R.

description: I walked into Bun Mee for a snack and to check out the menu.  I got the salad rolls and a pot of tea.  The total came to a little over $10.  Kinda pricey.  Very tasty, though and fresh.  I can get salad rolls at other places for $4, so I don't know if I'll go back for those.  The sandwich menu looks great and the prices start at $6 - not bad for the neighborhood.  The people that work there are friendly and the space is nice.  Try the sandwiches and let me know how they are!
author: Tapedeck B.

description: I really wanted to like this place. I live in Laurel Heights and I have been know to crave a Bahn Mi on a weekly basis and this one disappointed. It was missing something.. It just didn't taste like a Bahn Mi, more like a basic sandwich with asian meat filling. The sweet potato fries and coconut cookie were by far my favorite part of the meal! the cookie was delectable.
author: Adriana A.

description: Eaten banh mi for as long as I can remember. Its a lil' bit pricier here due to location but I had the Bun Me combo with egg and it was very good. I was impressed about the flavor they got with the grilled pork, warm, good char level, and a bit unctuous. The organic fried egg was cooked perfectly which enabled it to ooze a bit and congeal on contact with the perfectly toasted bread. Pate used was very fragrant and very savory. Enjoyed the egg rolls here. They were done perfectly and almost brimming with pork. Very good place with a cozy interior and very good flavor. I'd come again when in the area but the flavor can be gotten at any good banh mi joint in Ctown or Little Saigon.
author: Peter H.

description: i ordered the tofu spring roll to go- a vegetarian dish. i  get it home and  bite into a chicken/shrimp roll...yech!  it's a simple thing to get the order right and it's especially important to get it right  if someone has a dietary restriction. i don't know which moronic employee screwed up, but i'll never go back to this pigsty again.. just disgusting.
author: jack s.

description: Awesome sandwiches, in a rather kooky place. Love it.
author: Gonzalo M.

description: The best thing I had was a mango and cabbage (sesame) side salad. The sandwich (pork) was fine but I found everything to be a little expensive for what it was. I'd rather go to Saigon Sandwich and save a few dollars and the taste is pretty close. The 79 health score that I saw on the wall also gave me pause.. Not bad, not great... 3 stars is right for it.
author: Ben L.

description:
Had read a great SF Gate review and thought I would give it a try.  The place is trendy and bustling.  My daughter had a chicken sandwich and I had the roasted pork.  The chicken sandwich was tasty and the vegetables were fresh and crunchy but the pork sandwich was a bit gristly.  The table next to us sent their uncooked whitish looking fries back to the kitchen while our sweet potatoes fries were crispy and cooked well.

With all the great restaurants along Fillmore, this would not be my first choice of where to eat, but the feel of the place is fun and fresh and a nice stop for a quick sandwich.
author: J H.

description: I came to Bun Mee after watching a movie at the Kabuki and while I liked it, I didn't love it. I got the Bun Mee Combo and it was pretty good and not at all expensive ($6.50). We got there just before closing, so they had run out of sweet potato fries which I had heard were really great. My girlfriend got the Smokey Eggplant and liked it, but I would like to see more veggie options on the menu. The place is small, but has a fun design to it. Overall, the staff was very friendly and I wouldn't be opposed to giving it another shot in a few weeks.
author: Jeremy J.

description: I happened onto this place just walking on Fillmore one Saturday afternoon looking to grab something after a work-out that was quick and easy. I visited Vietnam about 7 years ago so Bun Mee caught my attention. I ordered the grilled five spice chicken sandwich for lunch and got the bun noodle bowl with chicken for dinner. They both had very good flavors, were tasty and the prices were reasonable. The staff was rather robotic and not very personable at first but after chatting them up a little bit they did loosen up. I'll go back if I find myself in the area.
author: G B.

description: I had the citrus caramel rice bowl with tofu. The texture of the rice was great, but the lack of toppings left something to be desired. It could use less rice and more vegetables, and take the salt down a couple notches on the tofu. These stars go to the staff. The staff was extremely helpful, someone took my to go order and so when I went to check on the wait, they apologized and offered me a free drink. Handled the mix up quite well.
author: Katie R.

description: I don't understand the hype. This place is just not good... and way way too expensive for what it is. The flavors were off, and for some reason, my papaya salad tasted like dish soap. Those who really enjoy it probably also think that Panda Express is high quality Chinese food. But eh, the service was better than you'd find at any authentic Vietnamese place... I guess that's worth something, right?
author: L N.

description: It was my first time here after hearing such rave reviews from friends, but I was actually pretty disappointed. I grew up eating Vietnamese sandwiches from random hole-in-the-wall places, and this place does not compare. I ordered the 5 spice chicken sandwich, which was ok. It wasn't very tasty, but it wasn't bad either. I also ordered the pork and shrimp rolls, but there was no shrimp. I don't know why they wouldn't just say they were out of shrimp. The peanut sauce is exactly as was previously described - viscous and like soft peanut butter. One more note, I ordered the strawberry lychee drink but after the cashier muttered something about limeade instead, I got the Kaffir limeade drink and it was too sweet and tart all at once. Needless to say, I'm sticking to authentic Vietnamese restaurants from now on.
author: Cathy L.

description: I love Vietnamese food and I LOVE Bun Mee!   We always make an excuse to visit when in the city.  The Banh Mi sandwiches are so good so I haven't gotten around to trying the other things on the menu yet although the rice bowls look incredible.  Make sure to try the sweet potato fries if you go.  They are also the best in class. The only negatives on Bun Mee is that it would not be good for a large group since seating is limited and it is a bit noisy.
author: Ralph W.

description: Stumbled into this place when walking down Fillmore. It is nice inside and the menu has a good variety. I got the 5-Spice Chicken Sandwich, which was delicious. I enjoyed the kick of the jalapeños and thought the baguette was perfect for the sandwich. I will definitely be returning to try their other menu options.
author: Zach P.

description: I love this place. Clean fresh food. More expensive than a family Vietnamese place but well worth it.  Only negative is lack of seating- you may have to get it to go
author: Samantha H.

description:
After giving them some time to ramp up, Bun Mee has me addicted!   

Love their food.
author: Nat S.

description: It was definitely a popular spot for lunch. I got the Bun Mee Combo and it was good - not great, but not bad. The jalapenos were a little too much for me, but the pork and pate were good. The veggies were a bit messy to eat and a little too tart for my taste. I did enjoy the coconut chocolate sandwich cookie - that was deelish! I would go back and try some other items if I was in the area but  wouldn't make a special trip.
author: Keromi K.

description: Last week I went in for lunch on Wednesday with a business partner. I have been in one other time for dinner. I ordered the sloppy bun with fried egg by suggestion of the friendly girls behind the counter. My partner ordered the crispy imperial rolls and a grilled pork bahn mi. The sloppy bun was to die for. I had a taste of the imperial rolls as well, while good, they were somewhat cold. The atmosphere of the restaurant is clean and stylish, and I like the fun music they play. Service is really important to me everywhere I eat, and I have to say the girl behind the counter and blonde waitress were impressive and knowledgeable of the menu. The waitress was fast and accommodating. And we were able to get back to our meeting on time. Overall, I can see what the hype is about. I will most definitely come back once again.
author: Barbra L.

description: reminds me of spice kit.  lot of hype.  charge 3x a typical banh mi for "gourmet" and add such items as pork belly.  problem was too wet and mushy.  but taste wise no blatant errors.  the bread was decently soft, thinned out, and nicely crispy without flaking into bits.  this is made for the masses, but not my style.
author: Rob C.

description: I was visiting SF this weekend and had been wanting to try Bun Mee since its opening as I love banh mi sandwiches and was excited about the idea of a gourmet twist. After months of drooling over photos on its website and FB page, I finally could give this chic eatery a try. We got there around 2:30 p.m. on a Saturday expecting a lull after the "lunch rush" but the place was bustling! In sum, I left still drooling over the belly bun and other goodies. The pork in the belly bun was perfect with the seasoned veggies, hard boiled egg and the garlic aioli (which I might have stolen from my husband's sandwich) made it divine. The bread was perfectly toasted. My husband ordered the Bun Mee combo and loved the varied meats. He devoured it as I did my sandwich. My 2-year old couldn't get enough of Mama Tran's crispy egg rolls and the sweet potato fries. The fries were tasty and perfectly salted. Loved the décor, music and overall ambiance. Oh, and the coconut cookies. Amazing. Can't wait to go back for more the next time we visit!!
author: Angelie K.

description: Love Bun Mee. A welcome addition to the neighborhood. All the sandwiches and side salads are awesome. The salad roll is a personal fave. But don't order the steak--it's tough to chew. Stick with chicken and pork and veggie. And definitely spring for the coconut cookie sandwich for dessert.
author: Melissa B.

description: for me, the bread really makes a good sandwich great. that's why banh mi is so great -- slightly crusty, aromatic french bread bursting with breadiness. Bun Mee adds creative, tasty combinations onto this toasted platform for a great price ($6-$6.50). I had the Hanoi catfish sandwich which has a similar spice to a Hanoi specialty, but is breaded instead, for a pretty successful sandwich. Good variety of seating means you can sit one-on-one for a date, at the counter with a buddy, or in a booth with 3 friends.
author: Frank T.

description: When I found out that they were opening a Banh Mi joint on Fillmore St, I was super excited and I couldn't wait to try it.  Boy, was I disappointed.  I ordered the Grilled Pork Banh Mi.  So, when I think grilled, I think of a nice dark brown color with a bit of char.  Nope...not here.  The meat was grayish in color and chewy.  Plus, it was bland.  I asked for them to add a fried egg thinking it would be nice and runny.  Nope...wrong again.  Instead of cooking the egg quickly in a hot pan so that the yolk stays soft, they put it in the oven so that the yolk cooked all the way through.  Not a hint of yummy runny yolks in sight.  My friend ordered the papaya salad and it was such a sad plate of wet, soft shredded papayas with what i think were vermicelli noodles.  WTH?  Vermicelli noodles?  Seriously?  The decor was nice, but really that's the only good thing about it.  A very disappointing attempt at fancy Banh Mi...you're better off heading West to Little Vietnam Cafe on 6th Ave or East to Saigon Sandwich on Larkin.
author: Tina P.

description: Ok, I'll give them the bread, but that's about it. First off $6.25 for a bahn mi is a little excessive. I know it's Fillmore and all, but at least make it a good bahn mi. The roast pork was terrible, my whole sandwich was big chunks of pork fat. I can get a better sandwich for $3.25 at Saigon Sandwich. This was my first and last visit to what I hoped would be a regular lunch spot for me. And you only got 2 stars for the bread
author: Kyle N.

description: nothing beats Saigon Sandwich. this is overpriced for its 'OK' taste.
author: Shawna C.

description: This place is horrible.  The food is completely bland; I actually threw it away when only half done; never mind the prices; its just not good and/or tastey food.  I had the papaya salad which is simply thickly shredded with vinegar on it; the Rice Shrimp Bowl was completely bland, not one redeeming quality.  Lastly, the sweet potato fries were edible but only because of the aioli.  I won't return and recommend anyone pass and go elsewhere for Vietnamese.
author: Kathy C.

description: Well the wife and I were just walking by doing the usual. Walking the Fillmore, (the good parts) and pass by this place. Craving a Bon Mi sandwich we decide to pop on in. The decor was nice, nice art and we liked the aesthetics and surroundings with the decor on all the walls. But hey, we're here to eat right? We order the Chicken Bon Mi sandwich no sides and a Vietnamese Iced Coffee for me. The sandwich was ok, it had good flavor, the pickled carrots and daikon were just right and the chicken had good flavor and the price was ok but a little high. If I were to order some fries and a regular drink, we'd probably would get out of here for over $20 bucks for both of us combined. We gotta remember, if Vietnamese food is even relatively expensive it has to bring something else besides the regular flavors. It has to be a step above regular Vietnamese food and this wasn't bad but it wasn't anything special like "ahh Bun Mee, gotta have it..." This place is like a Vietnamese Chipotle just streamlined and catering to folks in the need but haven't explored around the city to get a cheaper and equally flavorful sandwich. The iced coffee wasn't bad but it was a little too sweet and like I stated before, nothing too spectacular. Give it a shot and it may be for you but I know of other Vietnamese sandwiches that just hit the spot and is very good on price. I'll splurge on food when squatters on the street stop asking me for hand out saying "you know what the best nation in the world is? When you've heard what the answer is then you know what I'm talking about, any how I digress.
author: graham c.

description: Sandwich was good on my first visit.  I had hopes for this place, even proud of it.  This time, I tried the noodle bowl.  When I dug in, I tasted very cold noodles, they were hard to enjoy.  Slightly stiff, the were just too cold. I brought it back for a warm up.  Heck, paid 10 bucks for it, wanna enjoy it!  But they looked at me like I don't know what I'm eating and told me it's served cold.  I'm freaken Vietnamese!  This is the coldest I've ever had it.  They are usually room temp or warmer.  After telling me they had no microwave and my insistence, it got warmed up in a pot.  The subtle unwilling attitude was disappointing.  Wasted my money..still hungry afterwards.    Good luck.
author: Diane N.

description: i just had bun mee at a catered event, and it was delicious. the mango sesame salad was tangy and delicious, and the bun mee combo sandwich was really good! also love the spring rolls and noodle salad. everything was super fresh!
author: Victoria S.

description: I've only had a few things here: the crispy egg rolls, the 5-spice chicken sandwich, the mekong shrimp salad and the salad rolls. Of these, only the salad rolls were bland. I really like the flavors of everything else I've tried, however FWIW it is true that I have little exposure to authentic Vietnamese food. But I absolutely love the chicken sandwich! Contrary to what another review suggested, I am pretty sure they do use boneless chicken thighs, not breast meat. In any case, I think it's really really tasty! JMHO, of course. Also, for $6 it is an inexpensive and filling lunch. Having just moved into the neighborhood, I am finding myself there once or twice a week, usually getting my food to go. The scooter motif is cute.
author: Jane D.

description: I live in the neighborhood and it's nice to see new place to eat. Really nice people who run the place. I would really love to see this place succeed. Couple things it's a little slow to get your food when it's busy and i wish they would give you a little more meat. The 5 spice chicken sandwich is what i had, very fresh. Will go back as I'm sure they are working things out as they just opened.
author: Curtis A.

description: One of the best places to eat on Fillmore, especially good for take out. No place to sit if you are a large group and the staff can be a touch rude. If you are fine with this and want a good sandwich, you will not be disappointed.
author: Janet O.

description: Nothing great, certainly not authentic Vietnames flavors.  Decent spot to  pick up a quick bite if you are really hungry and need a quick grub fix.
author: Pablo M.

description: I love this new neighorhood spot, the space is very charming and the menu offers fun items that you would not find at traditional hole in the wall places. I ordered the five spice chicken sandwich and it was delicious. I've had eaten many vietnamese sandwiches and the bread at this place is by far the best. The chicken was well spiced and it was so tender. As a lite eater, I feel that the sandwich is a little on the petite size. The prices for a sandwich range from $6-8  a bit on the steep side but the ingredients were very fresh and it was super tasty. The coconut cookie was super yummy as well.
author: kathy l.

description: I really liked this place.  It is small, but it has a cute atmosphere.  It had great strawberry lychee agua fresca, and I enjoyed my sandwich.  The actually ran out of food when we were there and had to close early (around 9 pm on a Wed.)  I think they skimped a little on the meat on my steak maybe as result, but I really enjoyed this place and would go back.  $6.99 seemed like a reasonable price for an "upscale" sandwich.  I plan to call ahead and get this for pick up for a quick meal too.
author: Chris C.

description: If you get one thing here, try the salt and pepper garlic french fries.  The sandwiches were really good but I am just used to paying less for a for a similar type of sandwich.  The staff was friendly and the decor is really cool.  I will go back.
author: Anna K.

description: I've tried the rice bowls at Bun Mee.  I like the menu choices and will go back to try the salads.  A couple of weeks ago I had the chicken rice bowl which was pretty good, yesterday I had the steak rice bowl,  I just wish they would cook the steak a little more and keep the rice a little hotter (maybe because I got there close to closing they unplugged the rice cooker?)other wise I would have given Bun Mee more stars.
author: Mark G.

description: Solid sandwich place.  Unsure if it's all that authentic, but I thought it was very tasty.  The catfish was really special, and I don't usually like catfish!
author: C B.

description: i was here for the first time around 530 on a Sunday, not too crowded so I took my time to take a long look at the menu and ordered a belly bun sandwich to go. i got home and ate it around 8pm..didn't heat it up or anything and i wasn't even that hungry since i had a huge late lunch....OMG.. i was literally in heaven when I took the first bite..it was probably the best sandwich EVER..!!!! i dont know how other sandwiches on the menu are like but i can't wait to go back and try more..!!
author: Karen H.

description: Crispy bread, tasty pork filling & thin sliced veggies & hot peppers.....perfect lunch! I had the eggplant sandwich which was equally as tasty. Didn't take long, served quickly, a great addition to the Fillmore area!
author: P G.

description: It is soo good I have been trying to explore more of the menu but their belly bun sandwiches and fries have been so hard to pass by. One of my new favorite lunch spots. =)
author: Lisa M.

description: They manage to run out of salad rolls everyday by 6pm.  How dumb can you be?  Make more.  Food is good though.
author: Ross F.

description:
the sweet potato fries were good. way too price for a sandwich.

the bread was not crispy. i love mayonnaise but their combo sandwich had way too much mayo.

i will go the place 5 stars for the interior and marketing.
author: J L.

description: Kind of on the high side for bahn mi but we often work in pac heights and its cheaper than everything else around there and I love bahn mi,
author: Precita M.

description: I've been coming here often for the past few months, but now I'm going to patronize another neighborhood establishment. I go to Bun Mee because I can get a quick lunch that's somewhat edible. However, consistency is not here! Portion size is all over the place and sometimes I'm missing ingredients from my order. There's something not right when I pay $12 for a modest salad that's missing two of the listed ingredients. What's also weird is that the owner/manager is moody. Sometimes he acknowledges people at the register and other times he just gives me a pissed off look. Moody much? And today, he was giving a hard time to the person in front of me in line who asked for the neighborhood business discount (I think it's just a piddly 10%) citing that "we check IDs because everyone's going to ask for one." Really? Accusing a customer of taking advantage of the discount is not good customer service. See ya, Bun Mee!
author: Dee L.

description: Great chicken sandwich and very good sweet potato fries (are those Vietnamese?).  The cookies are the bomb.
author: Marc A.

description: Had both the grilled pork sandwich and the catfish. Both were tasty but a little on the small size for the price. Tasted very healthy, the salad was great. All in all a nice place for lunch.
author: Irewan M.

description: Great food - but a little expensive for just the sandwich (its not very meaty - although the steak one - which was awesome - was much meatier than the chicken).  Add a dollar to the sandwich price and include a side... Otherwise food was delish!
author: KK R.

description: Thought the veggie banh mi, i.e. the sandwich with eggplant was delicious.  I don't mind paying the Fillmore St. premium, but the place reeked  like a fast food grease pit.  My clothes smelled like I had just eaten lunch at the Doggie Diner.  Might return, but only if I can do take out.
author: Bathsheba M.

description: Denise and her staff did a great job fulfilling a large take-out order for me on a rush schedule and the food received rave reviews from the 20+ teenagers I delivered lunch to at Alta Plaza Park for a birthday party.  I came in to Bun Mee a few days earlier to see if they could accommodate my need for 30 sandwiches and a variety of side salads by 11:30 am on Tuesday, especially since they open for business for the day at 11 am.  Denise was great to work with and delivered on all counts:  everyone was friendly, the food was ready to go (and packaged nicely) at the requested time, there were no mix-ups in the order, and the sandwiches (roasted pork, 5 spice chicken and juicy steak) and salads were delicious.  I'm also a fan of Saigon Sandwich but wasn't sure they would be open and able to accommodate my order in time, and I was happy to give a new business a try.  I look forward to going back to Bun Mee soon to try other items.  Thank you Denise, and good luck with your new venture.
author: Laurie B.

description: okay, let's give them time, only soft opening this week.  and I do agree with Cindy C. who notes the bread is perfect.  so what's the problem?  well I got the pork sandwich today and the meat had no flavor at all, it was a strange white color, in large pieces and was not easy to chew.  it was not clear how the meat had been coooked and how pork could be that white.  for the rest - it was okay - but seemed to lack fish sauce or whatever would give it some tang.  the staff was friendly and the limeaid was refreshing - the strawberry drink was so sweet it needed to be watered down.  I may go back and give another try when the buzz dies down.  update to my review  - I got a very nice note from  the proprietor, Denise, after posting my review - she offered to buy me a lunch and said she was sorry my experience had not been great. so, while I am still questioning the pork sanwich, I really appreciate the friendly follow up and generous offer of a free sandwich.
author: Eric S.

description:
bun mee is great and delicious in theory but it's always a huge disappointment. 
the taste is usually there but something is always off.  i've been to bun mee 5 times and it's never consistent.  i think it's tasty and i want to like it, but it's always SO spotty.   
i went there twice last week.  first i had the pork belly sandwich (belly bun).  the meat was really poor quality and was solid fat.  i get that pork belly is fatty but this was literally pure fat with no meat on it.  simply put, very poor quality.  it was seasoned well but i had to spit it out.   my friend was eating a grilled pork sandwich and she said that hers was much better.  i figured my sandwich was just a fluke.      
a few days later i came by and tried the grilled pork sandwich.  the meat was much better than the pork belly i had before but there was so little meat.  i opened up both sandwiches and there is literally a strip of meat the size of a bacon strip on the bread.     
really?  come on.  if you're going to make a sandwich, commit to it and put some meat on it.  stop being so stingy.  
bun mee could be so much better if they just tweaked the details.  like put grilled pork in your grilled pork sandwich.  
on the bright side, their sweet potato fries are pretty good.
author: susie k.

description: i order the caramel rice plate with brown rice and tofu. for $13 bucks. a complete waste of money. the tofu was so over salted and looked/tasted like a dried up puck. the flavor of the rice and sauce were single minded and rather sour.nothing about the dish was right, at all. greatly disappointed and won't be returning.  great concept. cute place. not great food.
author: vanessa w.

description: mediocre at best... i had the sloppy joe sandwich with the fried egg and it was exactly what it is a sloppy joe sandwich with a fried egg.. sorry there is nothing vietnamese about that, just because you add basil and "say" there is curry in the sloppy joe which you do not taste.. it is what it is. but with that said their imperial rolls are delicious. the first time i had them they were crisp and dainty like a vietnamese version of lumpias but then i went back and they were thicker.. hmmmmm didn't love them as much. i am sure they want to please the customer by making it bigger but maybe instead of making it bigger just make 2x the amount of the rolls with the original thinner size. it is all about texture.... !! the spiced chicken sandwich was good but more bread than meat = boring and i am not trying to pay for a bread sandwich... it says on the board specify if you want spicy or mild but yet when you don't specify  the cashier doesn't even ask which you'd prefer. it is very commendable that this establishment is "trying"  to do well in pacific height but for a business to evolve and to continue doing well it is the little things that need to be noticed so that the customer knows the owner/chef actually gives a damn... the seating arrangement in there is really not good either. people/student bringing their computers to do homework, drink water and maybe have something to eat and to use up a table longer than need be is a waste and the place loses money.. is this a library or a place of business??!!!! just because the gelato store before was a place that didn't care about people lingering which probably is the reason why they went out of business doesn't mean that this new business should allow the same unnecessary activities... reevaluation of strategy needs to be discussed amongst managers/owners in order for any profit of this establishment specially when it comes to portions, flavor and quality because it really isn't that difficult to fix something so minor. my best to this place because i can foresee it doing well if things can be changed.... good luck
author: Nina R.

description: i was quite disappointed in this vietnamese sandwich restaurant. there was not too much chicken in the 5 spice chicken banh and it was flavorless, had to ask for more aoli to put more flavor into the sandwich.  the pork was equally flavorless although the spring rolls were fine.  comparing this to other banh places, it ranks poorly.
author: dennis m.
